HEADLINE: Swallowing Pride, More Parents Seek Tuition Aid 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
They are venturing into the private schools' financial aid offices for the first time, somewhat embarrassed and sometimes hiding their troubles from their own children. They are parents who have always paid their private school tuition bills on time, and now they have seen their stocks tumble in value, their year-end bonuses evaporate and their clients disappear. Some lost their jobs; others lost their spouses in the World Trade Center attack.
 In recent months, hundreds of affluent and middle-class families in the New York City area have been asking for financial aid so their children can continue attending private school. 
 In response, private schools are devising varying strategies to meet the surging demands for assistance. Fieldston School in Riverdale, the Bronx, which has 18 families who have never received assistance applying for aid, has raised an emergency fund worth tens of thousands of dollars to get the students through the academic year, school officials say.
"How can we turn our back on families who have paid tuition for 9, 10, 11 years?" said James Thompson, the assistant head of admissions and financial aid at Fieldston. "For the next academic year, we will spread the money out to cover more families."
Since Fieldston does not plan to increase its total financial aid budget by an amount sufficient to cover all of the new awards, some families now receiving aid will get less help next year, the school said.
Horace Mann School in Riverdale, on the other hand, has decided to reduce total aid for incoming students to help current students through. As many as 15 entering students who would have received financial aid if they had applied in previous years will not receive assistance, said Lisa Moreira, the director of admissions and financial aid. The saved money would go to the 30 to 35 current students who have now requested help.
Calhoun School, on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, plans to dig deeper into its endowment to meet the surging demand for aid, hoping that its new capital campaign will yield enough money to cover the additional families applying for aid.
Of the 13 families who have newly applied for assistance for their children already attending Calhoun, four have been rejected because their financial situations are not deemed grave enough to warrant aid.
The requests for aid seem to be increasing at many, if not most, of the area's 100 or so private schools. "More families are requesting aid than ever before," said Victoria Goldman, co-author of the Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools and Selective Public Schools. "Families have called me, saying they have just maxed out on their credit cards. The parents have some very difficult choices to make, whether to forgo the summer vacation, the new S.U.V., or to pull their kids out of the private schools."
Jean-Jacques and Carole Ferron, of Larchmont, N.Y., are one couple who made such a decision about their two daughters, Lana, 10, and Mae, 7. Business at the family's SoHo store, which sells miniature Zen gardens and stone fountains, dropped by at least half after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, and the Ferrons had to dismiss a few employees. Natives of France, they have had trouble coming up with enough cash to pay for their daughters' private school, the French American School of New York in Larchmont.
"We will eat less, but we will make sure that the girls get a proper education," Mrs. Ferron said. "I want them to be truly bilingual."
Savings in everyday expenses, however, aren't enough to cover the girls' $23,000 annual tuition bill, so Mrs. Ferron is considering asking for financial aid from the school. But she has wondered whether her daughters would be eligible, since the family is neither about to lose its house nor having trouble putting food on the table. They will still take the summer vacation in France but will stay with friends at no charge.
"We will skip the extra party shoes and stop buying new clothing," Mrs. Ferron said. "But I think some families are much more in need than us."
So she has contacted Academic Management Services, of Swansea, Mass., which negotiates with schools for extensions on tuition bills on behalf of parents. It has turned the Ferrons' lump-sum tuition bills into monthly payments, which are still two months behind. (Since most families want to keep their financial difficulties private, the Ferrons are one of the few families who agreed to be interviewed.) 
The sour economy has also made it more difficult for families with children entering private schools for the first time to pay their tuition bills. As a result, some schools are seeing a higher percentage of newly admitted students requesting aid.
At Friends Seminary on East 16th Street in Manhattan, for instance, 36 percent of entering sixth graders have applied for financial aid. Last year, 25 percent did. 
In other cases, parents who had planned to send their children to private schools prepped them instead for the entrance exams of the city's prestigious public schools like Hunter College High School and Stuyvesant High School, said Cynthia Bing, a leader of the Parents League of New York, a nonprofit organization for parents whose children attend either public or private schools. It's less expensive, she said, to pay a tutor for a few months than to pay tuition for a few years.
Although private schools are undergoing greater strains on their financial resources, most schools are in better financial position to help needy families than they were in the last recession. During the last decade, almost all of the private schools in and around the city received large donations that bolstered their endowments. And private school application numbers in this region held up last fall despite the economic downturn. Demand for spots still far exceeds the supply.
So some schools are even willing to give proud but needy families a nudge to apply for aid. 
"It's awkward to them," Ginger Curwen, a spokeswoman for Fieldston, said of families who have paid full tuition for years and never sought aid. "They are not used to asking for help. They are not used to going through the paperwork."
So when Fieldston's financial aid office heard through another parent that a family, whose business had shriveled after Sept. 11, was having a hard time meeting tuition payments, it reached out to them.
"The family did not want to ask for aid from the school, especially the father, whose pride was so deep," said Mr. Thompson of Fieldston. "We encouraged them to call and told him there was really nothing to be embarrassed about."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 10, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Education Page last Wednesday about an increase in the number of students seeking financial aid at New York area private schools misstated fund-raising plans of the Calhoun School in Manhattan. It will raise money dedicated to financial aid in an annual fund-raising drive. It will not use money raised in its capital campaign, which is restricted to building expansion, nor from its endowment fund.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: WARLORDS; 
Courted by U.S. and Iran, an Afghan Governor Plays One Side Off the Other

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

DATELINE: HERAT, Afghanistan 

 BODY:
United States Army Special Operations soldiers based here say they have formed a close relationship in recent months with Ismail Khan, the powerful governor in western Afghanistan who American officials fear is being courted by Iranian hard-liners. 
 The soldiers meet with him once or twice a week, several of them said. He has even taken them horseback riding (with an audience of about 1,000 spectators, to the soldiers' chagrin). "He's a down-to-earth guy," one American soldier said. 
 That closer bond, along with international pressure, appears to have driven Iranian conservatives underground in their efforts to gain influence in western Afghanistan, international officials and Mr. Khan's commanders say. 
Mr. Khan now seems to be playing America and Iran off each other to the region's advantage. Iran is reconstructing the road from Herat to its border. America has promised to clean out the area's canals. 
But while foreigners vie for his favor, Afghans, including some of his own commanders, are expressing frustration with the self-proclaimed emir. He is refusing to confirm four appointees appointed by the central government in Kabul to posts in Herat. He has appointed mullahs and archconservatives to key positions. An office for the promotion of virtue and prevention of vice, a Taliban-era fixture, has reopened here. And ethnic Pashtuns say soldiers and commanders loyal to Mr. Khan, an ethnic Tajik, are beating, robbing and imprisoning them. 
Halfway through the interim government's tenure, Herat illustrates perhaps better than anywhere else the challenges in governing the border regions of Afghanistan, where neighboring countries vie for influence and warlords rule. Mr. Khan shows how warlords with foreign backing can be a force for stability. But that backing may entrench such men so deeply in their posts that it will be hard for the transitional government meant to take office later this year to dislodge them.
United Nations officials and Mr. Khan's commanders say his military strength has clearly been bolstered by Iran, even though its open efforts to gain influence have tapered off recently. Much of Iran's aid came after Mr. Khan's return to Herat -- which he had governed in the early 1990's -- in early November, and before the inauguration of Hamid Karzai, the country's interim leader, in late December. 
In that period, top Iranian military officials ensconced themselves in Herat. One Iranian military group that set up shop was the Helpers, who had aided in the fight against the Taliban, according to Zaher Jan Azimi, one of Mr. Khan's top commanders. He said the group was later asked to leave, because "it wasn't clear who they were working for." 
Several hundred soldiers from the Iranian Army of Muhammad -- a force trained in Iranian camps to help take on the Taliban -- also returned to Herat after the Taliban fell, Mr. Azimi said. Around 100 of them have been integrated into Mr. Khan's military corps, under the direction of the Party of Unity, a Shiite, mostly Hazara group which has historically had close ties to Iran.
Mr. Azimi said under an agreement between Iran and Burhanuddin Rabbani, who acted as president from the fall of the Taliban until the Bonn agreement took effect, Iran sent the Herat police around 500 MP-5 submachine guns in December.
In addition, a United Nations official said, he saw Iranian Kalashnikovs being unloaded from a truck at a security commissary; the official said weapons were also flown into the southern Shindand air base, which reopened in January. Afghan soldiers who defected to one of Mr. Khan's rivals say they were being trained by Iranians several months ago at a base overlooking Herat.
Mr. Azimi said he could not say for certain that the Party of Unity had stopped receiving Iranian aid. Its officials deny any such assistance. 
Whatever help was provided to Mr. Khan, his army is now a military machine -- 50,000 to 60,000 strong and omnipresent. Rows of tanks sit on a hill, their barrels trained on Herat. Soldiers are everywhere, even in hamlets. Even some of Mr. Khan's aides have suggested to him that perhaps he does not need such a large, visible army.
A sign in the headquarters of his Fourth Army Brigade reads, "To have a national army protects our freedom and our Islam." But United Nations officials say Mr. Khan has been slow to come into line with the idea of a national army because he does not want to give up his own. 
It is hard to see how the central government will persuade him to do so: it has no economic leverage over him. In addition to the customs duties and taxes that Herat secures from its borders with Iran and Turkmenistan, it has a lot of cash left behind by the Taliban, who departed in haste. Bank officials here say Mr. Khan's coffers are almost as full as those of the central government, which has about $6 million in its treasury.
He was offered a position as head of a national commission on disarmament, which some Heratis saw as a way to ease him out of the governorship. But United Nations officials say his communication with Kabul has been so poor that it is not clear whether the offer still stands. 
Mr. Khan's intelligence chief and close aide, Nasir Ahmad Alavi, dismissed all of those criticisms. "People want to show Ismail Khan -- a famous man from jihad -- is against the interim government," he said. "This is not the truth."
Mr. Alavi was equally dismissive of dozens of Pashtun accounts of robbery, beatings and imprisonment at the hands of Mr. Khan's soldiers or commanders. Such charges, he said, come from "Talib commanders now living in Kandahar who want to cause division and make trouble."
In fact, the accusations come from ordinary Pashtuns interviewed in Herat and surrounding districts; in two local refugee camps; in Kandahar, where many Pashtuns have gone to seek help from the governor; and at the Pakistani border, which many Pashtuns are seeking to cross. Some of the stories, too, are from Pashtuns who fled persecution in the north, in the territory controlled by Gen. Rashid Dostum, only to be harassed by Mr. Khan's soldiers. Many have described relatives being taken to jail, where soldiers demand money for their release.
Mr. Alavi did say that until recently, when more than 200 prisoners were set free at the behest of elders from Kandahar, there were more than 500 Taliban -- meaning Pashtun -- in Herat's central jail. He also said that Herat's highest-ranking Taliban prisoner, the former governor of Badghis, had been released. Those remaining, he conceded, are low-level, but they are to stay in jail until their innocence can be determined. 
"If we release them all now, it will create a kind of instability," he said.
Mr. Khan has been quite open about his antipathy to the country's exiled Pashtun king, Mohammed Zahir Shah, who is now scheduled to return in mid-April. And in this, too, he is in line with Iran, where he lived after escaping from a Taliban prison. Some say that this time around, Mr. Khan is showing other signs of Iran's ideological influence, too. 
He appointed as university head a conservative theologian who used his first speech to vow that he would never allow coeducation. If he could not find enough female teachers, he said, the women's section would be closed. The university was coeducational during Mr. Khan's previous tenure.
The reopened office to promote virtue and prevent vice is in a new location with no jail. But it has banned female vocalists, told shopkeepers to take down alluring pictures of female singers and jailed some who did not listen. 
Sayed Mahmad Houssein Hosseini, 29, who is temporarily overseeing the office, said it was needed because a society liberated from the Taliban had become too libertine. He said the office had no military officers, though a car containing a mullah and five soldiers pulled out of its parking lot a few minutes later.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: DEMONSTRATIONS; 
Anger in the Streets Is Exerting Pressure On Arab Moderates

BYLINE:  By NEIL MacFARQUHAR 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, April 2 

 BODY:
Thousands of Jordanians braved a frigid downpour to march on Parliament today, demanding that the kingdom sever ties with Israel, while protesters in Egypt packed the streets around Cairo University for a fifth straight day.
 Up to now the anger in the streets has not gone beyond the control of any of the autocratic governments in the region. But officials spend each day and much of the night monitoring television reports or checking their mobile phones for the urgent headlines flashed there by subscription services. 
 They dread the moment when a major death toll -- or worse, news of the demise or exile of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat -- will put moderate Arab governments squarely on a collision course with their explosive, aggrieved populations.
"It's a volatile situation open to all possibilities," said Adnan Abu-Odeh, formerly a royal political adviser here and an ambassador to the United Nations. "The only truth is that people are angry and frustrated. So far the demonstrations have not been destabilizing, but nobody knows what will happen in the next 24 hours." 
The circumstances of Mr. Arafat's encirclement in Ramallah, with Israeli soldiers stationed right outside his door, make senior officials especially edgy. 
Despite Israeli pledges not to harm him, there is widespread concern that he might suffer some fatal accident. "The first casualty is the peace process," said Marwan Muashar, Jordan's foreign minister, urging Washington to press for an unconditional Israeli withdrawal from the compound. "This is a regional problem. They are putting their Arab friends at risk in the region."
The governments of Egypt and Jordan are counted among the most vulnerable. They have repeatedly tried to explain their peace treaties and full diplomatic relations with Israel as a means of exerting positive pressure on the fate of the Palestinian cause. But skepticism over such arguments is running high.
"The Arab regimes look more impotent than they ever have," Mr. Abu-Odeh said. "Their legitimacy has been reduced enormously. There is an implied test: if you say relations are rewarded, show me how useful they are. People want proof that the government's good relations with America and Israel are meaningful in that they will help both end the siege on the Palestinian people and Arafat."
Up to now the Bush administration has shown scant sign of being ready to meet such demands. Indeed, the president has made clear that he regards the Israeli operation in the West Bank as broadly justified, and he has focused his demands on Mr. Arafat, insisting that he renounce terror, clearly and in Arabic.
Cabinet ministers here said dozens of protests flare up daily throughout the country, with 38 counted on Friday alone.
The Amman march today was the largest in the capital since Israel activated its intense assault on the West Bank on Friday. The protest included a huge contingent from the Muslim Brotherhood flaunting a picture of Osama bin Laden and chanting in favor of attacking Israel.
"The army of Muhammad will return," they intoned. "The army of Muhammad is at the border."
Senior officials and political analysts said governments in the area needed to take some measure to assuage the anger and frustration on Arab streets. Egypt and Jordan have conferred on whether to downgrade relations with Israel by expelling its ambassadors.
"The demonstrations are getting stronger by the day," Mr. Muashar said. "The street is literally boiling." He said the continuing Israeli assault, combined with Washington's approval, was forcing moderate Arab governments to distance themselves from the United States.
"We are being forced to take steps we don't want to take," he said, "because people are angry and public opinion in the Arab world cannot be ignored."
Mr. Muashar was particularly critical of Washington for suggesting in the midst of an Israeli assault, with tanks besieging his compound, that Mr. Arafat should somehow be reining in Palestinian extremists.
"The leader is under siege and cut off from the outside world, and there are demands that he do more to stop the violence," Mr. Muashar said. "It is ludicrous."
After five days of resisting public pressure for a legal demonstration, the Jordanian government finally acceded to the request by opposition parties to march. But they tried to take the sting out of it by dispatching a few ministers to take part. 
Marchers in the crowd of about 6,000 who walked through the city blocking traffic for three hours were scathing in their criticism of Jordan's links to Washington and its peace treaty with Israel.
"The Jordanian government should throw out the American ambassador even before the Israeli, because it is only America who can pressure Israel to stop this aggression," said Wadha Rajoub. Like many demonstrators, she said she had turned out in part because she had family in the West Bank. Her cousin Jibril Rajoub, the West Bank security chief for the Palestinian Authority, is also under siege.
She was horrified by television pictures of the Palestinian dead in Ramallah being buried in a mass grave on hospital grounds because the morgue there had run out of room and Israel had barred their transportation elsewhere. 
Protesters poured scorn on the official government line that it should not break ties with Israel because it could still influence the Sharon government to ease the measures against the Palestinians.
"Reality shows that you cannot trust the Israelis nor influence them," said Omar Hudhud, one of dozens of attorneys from the Lawyers Syndicate marching, many of them in their professional robes. 
Officials in Jordan and Egypt have emphasized that they will not break ties with Israel, despite the demands of their populations. But those outside the government here speculated how long they could stick to that pledge, especially as demonstrations increase in magnitude daily.
Hasan Abu-Nimah, a former Jordanian ambassador to the United Nations, suggested that Washington should realize that its long-term interests did not lie in letting the Sharon administration pulverize the Palestinian Authority.
"To encourage Sharon, or to provide cover for what he is doing, is bad for Israel," he said. "Destroying Palestinian society is only going to create more suicide bombers."
The Arab League announced a special meeting of its foreign ministers in Cairo on Wednesday to consider what action might be taken. Iraq announced that it would press its proposal to revive the 1973 Arab oil embargo -- a plan highly unlikely to be enacted, given the state of the economy among exporters.
Some members want countries bordering Israel to open their borders to allow volunteer fighters to cross. Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, made such a similar suggestion a day earlier, mocking the Arabs by saying their arms would be more useful sold as scrap and remade into cooking pots.
But with no countries in the area ready to go to war with Israel, it is virtually certain that the suggestion will be rejected.
Officials in Jordan noted that it had recently reinstated its checkpoints along the Jordan valley after a team sent by Hezbollah in Lebanon had tried to cross into Israel.
Thousands of demonstrators in Cairo trying to march from Cairo University to the nearby apartment building housing the Israeli Embassy were again turned back with water cannons and tear gas.
In a separate protest at the Egyptian Foreign Ministry, crowds of artists, intellectuals and union leaders -- who have long opposed relations with Israel -- urged the government to expel its ambassador and sever ties with the "Zionist enemy."
In Tunis, the Tunisian capital, police in riot gear, brandishing tear gas and truncheons, battled to keep several thousand students within the campus of the national engineering school, where they were chanting things like "Anger! Anger! No more summits, no more words!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thousands of Jordanians marched on Parliament in Amman yesterday, demanding that the government break off relations with Israel. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Rebuilding Downtown 

 BODY:
The temporary memorials to Sept. 11 are now in place, and the clearing of the World Trade Center site is almost completed. There should be a sense of progress in Lower Manhattan. Instead we have a queasy feeling of slippage and lack of focus.
 Our concerns involve planning and money. The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, formed last November by Gov. George Pataki to oversee the site's renewal, seems to be taking its time in devising a master plan. Nobody wants to rush into a short-range solution that becomes a long-range embarrassment. Yet the corporation appears to envision an orderly series of reports on various aspects of the redevelopment challenge, one by one, month by month. If this year passes without concrete public proposals, critics may begin to ask whether Governor Pataki, who powerfully influences the redevelopment process, was delaying hard choices until after the November election. The corporation justifies its methodical tempo by suggesting that what happens above ground depends on what happens underground. In truth, long-term and short-term, above ground and below ground, everything needs to be considered together. 
 One thing that is happening rather quickly is the distribution of money to businesses as a means of inducing them to remain in Lower Manhattan. Using part of the $2 billion in federal aid at its disposal, the corporation has been offering incentives to residents and small businesses that want to stay in the area or move there. At the same time, the city is inviting applications for federal funds from large corporations.
It is questionable whether direct handouts are the best way to attract or retain big businesses downtown. If New York fritters away the money it received from the federal government, the recent good will between the city and Washington could be poisoned. A better use of these funds, in most cases, would be to invest them in transportation and other infrastructure projects in order to make downtown a cleaner, more accessible and efficient place to work. Some company executives admit privately that while they would certainly consider cash offers, they would regard a clear economic development strategy for downtown as a stronger inducement to long-term commitment.
That development strategy, in the end, will be up to Mr. Pataki and New York City's mayor, Michael Bloomberg. Some are urging them to go slowly. Yet the longer they wait, the harder it will be to get corporations to throw in their lot with a Lower Manhattan where the future is still a vague package of published reports. 
The planners seem to have reached some easy points of consensus: Rebuilding the World Trade Center towers is off the table, and instead of another massive plaza people are focusing on the more attractive idea of reopening city streets to relieve traffic congestion and restore avenues of light. Almost everyone agrees that Lower Manhattan should become a lively, 24-hour community, with a mix of housing, offices and cultural facilities. The World Trade Center site could expand and anchor that mix, with the memorial as its centerpiece. 
John Whitehead, the corporation's chairman, has talked about an international competition for the memorial. That is a good idea. The victims came from nearly 80 countries, and most were employed in global trade and finance. There should be guidelines for the scope of the memorial soon, so competition can get started. The final choice should be, as with any enduring memorial, a creation more symbolic than literal. The 9/11 memorial should be a great work of art worthy of the site, the memory of the victims and the spirit of this creative city.

HEADLINE: Crude Oil Prices At a 6-Month High On Mideast Worries 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
The price of crude oil climbed to the highest level in six months yesterday, nearly $28 a barrel, stoked by fears that the worsening violence in the Middle East could lead to a disruption of oil supplies.
 But most industry analysts discounted the chances of an embargo by oil-producing countries or a terrorist attack against their oil operations. They pointed out that yesterday's rise in commodity prices was building on a gradual but substantial run-up in oil prices that started at the beginning of the year, mainly because of reductions in output that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries began in 2001. 
 The more expensive crude oil has pushed up retail gasoline prices by about 20 percent over the last month. The average price of a gallon of regular unleaded gasoline is now $1.37 nationwide, compared with $1.14 on March 4, based on data from the Energy Information Administration, the analysis arm of the Energy Department. Industry analysts warned that the greater demand for gasoline that usually arrives with warmer weather could raise prices further in coming months. 
On the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, the price of crude oil for May delivery settled at $27.71 a barrel, up 3.1 percent from $26.88 a barrel late Monday. Nervousness in the market increased as OPEC members issued conflicting messages about what nations in the Middle East might do in response to the Israeli-Palestinian violence. 
A statement in Baghdad yesterday from the Iraqi foreign ministry said Iraq was ready to "use oil as a weapon" against the United States for its support of Israel.
But the Saudi foreign minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, said Arab countries relied too heavily on oil revenue to forsake the money in a Mideast political struggle. Prince Saud was quoted in Le Monde as saying, "If they want to strengthen themselves against the Israeli aggression, they have no alternative but to continue exploiting oil and gas."
Intensifying violence in the Middle East has in the past led to higher prices, oil industry experts noted, but once oil traders recognize that the situation is more stable than news reports might indicate, prices usually drift down. By some views, relations between the United States and Arab countries are more resilient than they were in 1973, during the first Arab oil embargo, and there are more sources of oil beyond the Middle East now. 
"An oil embargo is unlikely," said Lord Browne, the chief executive of BP, in an interview in his New York office yesterday. "There is so much surplus capacity, the shortfall would come from somewhere else. There is no great cause for concern."
Still, some analysts said the oil markets would remain volatile when Middle East fighting worsened. "In the absence of any lasting solution to the conflict, there will be a knee-jerk reaction in the markets every time there is an escalation between the Israelis and the Palestinians," said Raad Alkadiri, manager of country risk analysis at the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington.
Crude oil prices have climbed about 40 percent since January as a result of OPEC's decision last year to cut production by about five million barrels a day. But OPEC members routinely produce more than their formal quotas, and non-OPEC countries that agreed to the cuts, most notably Russia, have also kept exports high.
The supply of crude oil on world markets was pared after Iraq's exports fell in the first quarter, to a range of 1.3 million to 1.7 million barrels a day, from 2 million to 2.2 million barrels last year, Mr. Alkadiri said.
In June, when a United States economic recovery is expected to be in full swing and oil demand is growing, prices are likely to rise and OPEC will face pressure to increase production. But if the Mideast turmoil worsens, OPEC could seize the opportunity at its June meeting in Vienna to demonstrate its anger over American Mideast policies.
"If the situation is still festering," Mr. Alkadiri said, "and the perception is that the international community has done nothing and let the Israelis run riot, there is an outside chance that OPEC could say the high price of oil is not a product of supply constraints and so there is no need to increase output formally. That would be a very, very tough signal to the U.S. in particular. But we're a long way from that."

HEADLINE: City's Pension Funds Reel After Taking a Dual Blow 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER and ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
One of the most damaging but least scrutinized causes of New York City's current fiscal crisis is the city's pension system, which is being forced to pay out more generous benefits to retired civil servants just as its investments have lost more than $9 billion in the stock market.
 That one-two punch -- having to pay more money to retired teachers, police officers and others when its investments have soured -- has made rising pension costs a giant unexpected drain on the city budget. Only two years ago, the city estimated that it would need to contribute $817 million to the pension funds in the fiscal year that begins July 1. Now that estimate has risen to more than $2 billion. 
 That expense, nearly $1.2 billion higher than expected and still rising in the coming years, forms a significant part of the $4.76 billion deficit that the city is struggling to close by shutting centers for the elderly, postponing new school construction, scaling back library service and borrowing money to pay its day-to-day expenses. 
The higher pension costs are nearly as large a problem as the steep decline in city tax revenue resulting from the national recession and the attack on the World Trade Center. The predicament is worsened by the city's decision to shift much of its pension funds into stock investments throughout the last decade, a strategy that resulted in steep losses as the markets fell in the last two years.
Pension costs and losses, along with the growing payments the city must make each year to repay its debts, are the two main reasons that the city plans to spend slightly more money next year than this year while providing fewer services.
"It comes down to two things: we gave a lot of benefits, and we had bad investments," said Robert North, the chief actuary for the city's five pension funds. "Our benefits went up, our investment income went down, and the place you have to make up for it is in contributions. It is a classic pension funding problem."
Almost every major public pension fund in the nation has lost money in the recent stock market downturn, but New York City's funds lost more than many other systems did. The city adopted an unusually aggressive stock-market-based investment strategy, which served it well during the boom times of the late 1990's but left it vulnerable to losses when the market slowed down.
The city's pension funds still have more than enough money to pay benefits to retirees for years to come. And because the pension funds make investments for the long term, city officials say they are not concerned by a bad year or two. But to ensure the system's health and offset the costs of the increased benefit payments and the stock market losses, the city must contribute more money to its pension funds just when it can ill afford it.
The situation is serious enough to cause the Bloomberg administration to ask Albany for permission to spread out the costs of the increased benefits over a decade. The administration is also considering other ways to save, including creating a new class of worker, with less generous pension benefits.
Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw said the rising pension costs were "a significant part" of the budget problem. He said the administration hoped to win the support of labor unions to help the city address the problem. 
The pension fund problem is only partly a result of the recession and the downturn in the stock market. Decisions made by state and local officials have also played a critical role.
One of the chief factors driving up the city's pension costs is the cost-of-living adjustment that state officials enacted two years ago, over the objections of city officials. It gives automatic pension increases, tied to the rate of inflation, to retired civil servants every year. 
The automatic increases go not only to retired state employees, but also to retired city workers.
The Giuliani administration objected that the state was forcing the city to pay hundred of millions of dollars more to the pension funds each year without offering to help. 
The pension change will eventually cost New York City $586 million a year, once fully phased in. That is more than a better-known recent state legislative initiative that also hit the city in the pocketbook, the repeal of the commuter tax, which cost the city about $500 million in lost revenue a year.
To put the figure in perspective, the benefit improvement alone costs more than twice what the city spends each year on its parks.
As the city was being hit with the change, officials in Albany were reaping the political benefits, casting themselves as champions of the elderly and labor unions.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, the trustee of the state's $112 billion Common Retirement Fund, was a forceful, early advocate of the law, and cites it often in his campaign for governor. Gov. George E. Pataki, who embraced the proposal after a task force he appointed approved of the idea, issued statements both when he signed the law and when the first larger checks were sent to state workers.
Now larger checks are going out to retired city workers as well. The increases, which are tied to the rate of inflation, are limited to no more than an additional $540 a year to pensioners. (A civilian who worked for the city for 25 to 30 years and retired in 1999 will receive an average retirement allowance of $29,272 a year.)
But with 246,000 retirees drawing pensions now and 339,000 future pensioners on the workforce, those annual supplements add up.
To help offset the bill, the Giuliani administration lobbied for, and won, the right to phase in the higher contributions that the city must make to its pension funds over the course of five years: from an extra $98 million in 2001 to $586 million by 2005. Now the Bloomberg administration wants permission from Albany to stretch out the time period to 10 years. Doing so would save the city $275 million next year.
Stretching out that period has costs of its own, though. Each dollar withheld from the pension funds today is a dollar that does not earn interest: $1 withheld today will cost the city $1.08 to replace next year. An analysis by Mr. McCall's office estimates that phasing the cost of the higher benefits in over 10 years, instead of 5, will cost the city an extra $115 million a year for 10 years starting in 2010.
"In effect, the city is borrowing from the pension funds," the comptroller's report said of the proposal.
But the extra cost-of-living benefits are only half the story.
Stock market losses alone shrunk the value of the city's five pension funds by more than $9 billion last year. Consequently, the city must contribute more money to the pension funds this year to offset the loss.
The problem is that even a single bad year in the market can force the city to pay much higher contributions to its pension funds to ensure that they will be able to meet their obligations. That is because the system assumes it will earn 8 percent on its investments each year, and any shortfall must be made up. 
This demand often comes at a difficult time. Whenever the stock market does badly, the city loses a big chunk of the tax revenue usually generated by Wall Street, and is least able to pay out more.
Last year, instead of earning the desired 8 percent, the city's pension funds lost 8.25 percent. That means the city must pay an extra $234 million in the next year and an estimated $2.8 billion over the coming five years if its funds fail to do better than the expected 8 percent return.
The effect on the bottom-line value of the city's pension funds is staggering. The major pension systems -- for teachers, police officers, firefighters and other employees -- had a total value of $105.6 billion on July 1, 2000.
Through the following year, city employees contributed $523 million through their paychecks, and city taxpayers added $1.3 billion. The accounts themselves earned $3.5 billion in interest income and dividends toward the fund. 
Those contributions were far outweighed by losses and other factors. Bad investments cost more than $9 billion, and $6.4 billion went to benefits payments. By June 30, 2001, the funds had dropped to $91.8 billion, a 13 percent decrease. Six months later, the funds had dropped by nearly an additional $10 billion. 
Pension fund managers across the nation debate how much they should invest in the stock market and how much they should invest in safer, but generally less profitable, alternatives like bonds or real estate.
Over the last 15 years the city has used an aggressive investment strategy. In 1986, only about 30 percent of the pension portfolio was invested in stocks. Now the figure is close to 70 percent.
That makes the city pension funds more aggressive, and stock-market driven, than the average large public pension fund, according to an annual survey by Pensions & Investments, a business publication that surveys large pension funds. Last year, the survey showed that the average large public pension fund had 56 percent invested in stocks. 
City officials dispute the judgment that its investments were more aggressive than other public pension funds, pointing to other comparisons that would include investments in real estate and private equity like venture capital funds. 
For most of the 1990's, the city's strategy paid off handsomely. From July 1995 to July 2000 the city's pension funds earned an average of 16.5 percent a year, more than many other pension funds that owned fewer stocks, and twice what the city had been counting on. 
But in 2000, the Giuliani administration essentially took advantage of that windfall by reaching an agreement with the unions that allowed the city to make deep cuts in its contributions to the pension systems in order to spend an extra $800 million over the next two fiscal years on city services. 
The city comptroller at the time objected to the plan, saying it "injects money into the city budget when it least needs it." 
In the last two years, though, the city's funds have done worse than average, according to two financial services companies that rate pension funds. And now with the surplus in the funds gone, the city's annual payments must increase significantly. 
"For many years they looked like heroes for having that high an exposure to stocks," said Nancy Webman, the editor of Pensions & Investments. "Right now they don't look so good. You compare them to other pension funds, they might look like bums. But I'm guessing that over the long term, they might look like heroes."
City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr., who is the investment adviser to the city's five pension funds, said the decision to keep 70 percent of the funds invested in stocks and 30 percent in fixed income investments had been reached after a great deal of research and was not unusual among long-term investors.
"All serious long-term investors must accept the risk of lower short-term returns to achieve high long-term results," he said in a statement. "The pension system's trustees feel the present 70-30 asset mix strikes the proper balance between risk and reward. If the reverse asset mix followed by the funds several decades ago had been in place during the past boom market, much of the gains of that market would have been missed." 
There are other factors driving up the city's pension costs. The same week that the State Legislature agreed to award the automatic cost-of-living increases to pensioners, it also voted to eliminate pension contributions from employees after they have worked more than 10 years. Until then, the workers contributed 3 percent of their salaries toward their pensions. 
New contracts awarding raises to city workers have also driven up benefits, which are usually calculated against some measure of the worker's final salary. Those raises alone, if teachers and police officers get comparable raises, will require more than $300 million in higher pension contributions in the coming year.
All of this seemed affordable at the time the city was enjoying record budget surpluses and the pension investments in Wall Street were earning far more than dreamed, but the bills are still coming in.
"When times are good, you get pressure to give away more," said Charles Brecher, research director at the Citizens Budget Commission. "But then, when times are bad, you still have to pay more."

HEADLINE: TV Takes Up Some Weighty Matters of Economics 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Has globalization gone too far? Probably not, according to Daniel Yergin and Joseph A. Stanislaw, the authors of "Commanding Heights: The Battle for the World Economy," an economic history of the 20th century that will be broadcast as a three-part documentary on the Public Broadcasting System starting tonight.
 Though the program offers some dissenting views, its main message is clear: unfettered free markets offer the best path to prosperity. In case after case, the program demonstrates how countries as different as Chile and China became richer by opening up their economies. 
 Mr. Yergin, in an interview, argued that poverty cannot be reduced without open trade. "The power of trade is really underappreciated," he said. He said he was disappointed that "it's a less open world today than it was a year ago." 
But other experts on the international economy now contend that the time may be right for a taste of moderation.
"We spent too much time pressing countries to open up to international flows of capital," said Robert D. Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, "without helping them to nurture the institutions that were required to utilize that capital efficiently."
"The market does not work in isolation," he added. "It requires a framework of laws, and institutions and regulations."
"Commanding Heights," based on an earlier book by the same authors, also acknowledges the failure of the so-called "shock treatment" approach to economic reform in countries with weak laws and institutions, like Russia in the 1990's.
Still, Mr. Yergin remains more concerned about how countries should work with each other to prevent crises like the one that gripped Southeast Asia in the late 1990's and spread to Brazil and Russia. "Sovereign states need to shape the rules that govern how this economy works," he said. "It's an uneasy period of rule-making."
Rule-making alone may be a too simplistic approach to handling globalization, said Mickey Kantor, the former secretary of commerce who is now a partner at Mayer, Brown, Rowe & Maw in Washington.
"The idea that you can have unfettered globalization, a rules-based trading system with everyone undertaking the same obligations at the same time, is somewhat naive," he said. "There might have been times when we pushed too hard, too fast, with trade agreements and market openings. It just means that now, in some cases, we have to take half a step back."
During the last two decades of rapid trade liberalization, he added, the trend's more negative effects were not well known or understood.
Mr. Yergin disputed that globalization had contributed to the world's problems. "Globalization did not cause global poverty," he said, "but it did make us all much more aware of it." In any case, Mr. Yergin argues, developing countries should concentrate on economic growth before worrying about how to share its fruits. "You have to have something to distribute," he said. "If you don't have growth, you risk a downward spiral."
But Mr. Hormats warned that neglecting concerns about equity could lead to problems that could end up impeding economic gains anyway. "Growth is critically important because it benefits large numbers of people," he said, "but you have to at least demonstrate that others have opportunity. If they see growth as inimical to their interests, as opposed to something they can aspire to, then you get disruption."
"Commanding Heights" offers several examples of disruption, from coal miners in Britain striking against the privatization efforts of Margaret Thatcher, the former prime minister, to Argentines banging pots and pans to protest the floating of their currency on world markets this winter. But in the last year, free market policies have undergone some setbacks through the same process that first instituted them.
Last month, for example, the British government moved to transform Railtrack, the publicly traded company that maintained the infrastructure of the country's railway system, into a sort of public trust run by private managers. Last November, Congress voted to take over much of the country's airline security system.
Mr. Kantor says that some retrenchment is appropriate. "Clearly there are functions that don't lend themselves perfectly to free market solutions," he said. 
"Everyone would giggle and think it's quite funny if anyone suggested that you privatize the United States Army."

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Strong in March as Recovery Continues 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 2 

 BODY:
Solid auto sales in March pointed to a continuing economic recovery, though domestic automakers have not been able to break the cycle of losing market share to foreign competitors. 
 General Motors, the healthiest of the Big Three automakers, was able to hold its share of the market steady in the first quarter, a victory compared with the struggles of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Group, a unit of DaimlerChrysler. Analysts are growing bullish on G.M. because its sales have also become more profitable. Retail sales have risen while rental car companies and corporate fleets have cut back sharply on less lucrative bulk purchases during the downturn. 
 Stronger sales than expected led G.M. to step up second-quarter production from what it had projected.
Overall industry sales in the United States fell 1.5 percent in March from a year earlier, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a result that was on the optimistic side of most analysts' expectations in a healing economy.
"It is becoming increasingly clear that a broad-based recovery is taking hold," said Jarlath Costello, Ford's senior domestic economist. "The recession in manufacturing is clearly over." 
David Healy, an analyst for Burnham Securities, said "sales are stronger than Detroit expected and dealers' inventories are probably too low, so we'll be looking at increases in production scheduled for the second quarter, which is good news for the economy."
At the same time, a punishing price war among the Big Three, including big rebate offers and interest-free financing deals, has not been enough to reverse consumers' preference for foreign brands, which has been years in the making. 
While the market share of domestic makers erodes, companies like Toyota, Honda, Nissan, Volkswagen and BMW continue to capture more of the market with fewer incentives. Domestic manufacturers have contended that much of the foreign automakers' advantage comes from favorable exchange rates that make it cheap to import vehicles. 
As if competition from Japan and Europe was not enough, Hyundai Motor confirmed today that it had selected Montgomery, Ala., as the site for its first American plant. 
Hyundai's sales increased almost 15 percent in March. The company has been upgrading its products and offering lengthy warranty deals to allay festering quality concerns. Sales at the company's Kia unit also rose 11 percent. 
"Their strong point so far has been small cars at ridiculously low prices with improving quality," Mr. Healy of Burnham Securities said.
"The Koreans have been eating Detroit's lunch in the small-car department, and that's going to continue with this plant."
George Pipas, Ford's manager of industry sales analysis, said small sport utility vehicles made by Hyundai (the Santa Fe) and Kia (the Sportage) had contributed to a 25 percent decline in sales of the Ford Escape. The redesign of the Honda CRV and a new small S.U.V. from the Saturn unit of G.M. have also crowded the market for that type of vehicle, he said. 
"I think it's something we'll have to evaluate on a month-by-month basis," Mr. Pipas said. "It is one of the more competitive segments."
Ford did recapture the mantle as the industry's single best-selling brand over Chevrolet.Ford's Jaguar and Land Rover brands showed strength last month.
Overall sales at Ford Motor fell 11.7 percent, compared with a 1.7 percent drop at G.M. and a 4 percent decline at Chrysler. Chrysler showed it might no longer be the laggard among the Big Three as it made progress in its revamping plan. The company's German management team announced a major turnaround plan early last year, while Ford laid out its own plan in January.
Sales at Toyota rose 4.1 percent, while sales at Honda, the fifth-largest seller in the United States market, rose 2.1 percent. Sales at Nissan rose 15.1 percent. Volkswagen sales rose 3 percent.

HEADLINE: Andersen's Retired Partners Fear Benefits May Slip Away 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
Billy M. Mann is worried about the future. At 80 years old, Mr. Mann, a retired Arthur Andersen partner, sees trouble ahead for his pension of $42,000 a year and other benefits owed to him from 36 years at Andersen.
 He says he is not one for poor-mouthing, and he admits that "we're not in danger of going hungry or anything like that." But if Arthur Andersen files for bankruptcy or takes other actions that would cut off those benefits, Mr. Mann said, he and his wife, Jean, will have to make some changes. 
 They may have to sell their luxury condominium in downtown Austin and move to a more economical home, he said, or cut back on their financial support of Mrs. Mann's 97-year-old mother, who lives in an expensive nursing home. "We don't know if we could continue to keep her there or not," he said. 
When Enron imploded, thousands of its employees saw their retirement benefits dwindle or disappear. The public anger over the plight of Enron employees who had loaded their 401(k) retirement accounts with the company's stock at the urging of top executives fueled much of the anger against Enron's leaders and, by extension, Enron's advisers at Andersen, which audited the company's books.
But the problems of Andersen retirees like Mr. Mann show that retirement worries are not unique to Enron. The Andersen workers have been generally well paid, and their plight has not struck the same nerve as the Enron employees' troubles.
Still, with Andersen's future shaky, its workers now fret that their pensions are at risk, and its retired partners have filed suit against the company, a limited liability partnership, to try to protect their benefits, a move whose outcome is anything but certain. "Just because the money is in a pension plan doesn't mean that the money is safe," said Steven O. Weise, a lawyer in Los Angeles who is an expert in the structure of limited liability partnerships.
Concerns will probably grow about unprotected pension plans, said Nevin Adams, executive editor of PlanSponsor.com, an online resource for pension and retirement issues. When companies without protected plans become bankrupt, he said, employees and retirees will find that their pension plans "are not worth the paper they're printed on and are as worthless as their stock options."
Because Andersen is a partnership, its partner-owners do not have a typical pension with the backstop of the Pension Benefits Guaranty Corporation, which makes payments when companies go bankrupt. Nor do they have a 401(k) plan, sponsored by employers. Instead, working partners are encouraged to invest for their own retirements, partly through Keogh accounts. But the firm also provides retired partners with a stipend, now $3,500 a month, as a safety net should their own investments go awry. 
The retirees' lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Chicago, demands that the courts not allow Andersen to do anything that would endanger those benefits. Referring to discussions within Andersen about possibly releasing its partners from agreements not to work for competitors if they leave, the suit says such a step "will effectively liquidate all the assets of the company and will eliminate the company's current revenue." That revenue, which the suit says is at risk, pays for the pensions and some other benefits. There are 675 retired Andersen partners in the United States.
The other 5,100 retirees of the firm who were not partners have a bit more financial backing for their retirement benefits, though a collapse of Andersen could send everyone to court to try to collect what they have been promised from every conceivable source. The pension plan for employees is separate from that of the partners; it is, in fact, backed by private insurance.
The retired partners are asking the courts to decide that their benefits are covered by the same laws as standard pension plans and to force the company to create an independent fund to pay their benefits. If a separate fund is not created and the company files for bankruptcy protection from creditors, the retirees will end up in line with other creditors for payment -- and behind the secured creditors.
"What we're saying is you have obligations to maintain the partnership agreement in the U.S.," said Duane R. Kullberg, the lead plaintiff in the class-action case; he was a chief executive of Andersen in the 1980's. "We're owed it." The retirees can ill afford to lose the money, Mr. Kullberg said. 
For Andersen partners who are still working, the monthly pension has grown in importance as well, though their top priority is the survival of the firm. Their livelihood is now in jeopardy, with clients fleeing and a criminal charge pending, and they may never get out of the firm the substantial amount of capital they have invested in it -- often with borrowed money.
The limited liability partnership is a business structure that has been around less than a decade. It was created to protect a partner's personal assets from being used to satisfy legal claims against the partnership.
Andersen's partners earn hundreds of thousands of dollars a year and place a part of those earnings as a required investment in the firm. When the partners leave the company, they get money several ways. They receive what they invested directly in the firm over the years -- a sum that varies with seniority and salary.
Mr. Kullberg, for example, said his capital repayment had been "probably a half-million bucks." The partners get back exactly what they put in, and they owe no additional taxes on the payout, generally taken as a lump sum.
They also receive their share of the difference between the year-to-year cash taken in by the firm and the money due to the firm on a longer-term accrual basis. The retirees generally stretch those payments out over several years because they do owe taxes on them. The company also contributes to the retirees' health insurance and life insurance coverage.
The partners earn a pension, but at $3,500 a month, it is fairly small among professional partnerships. Other consulting partnerships, like PricewaterhouseCoopers, pay bigger pensions tied to income level, but Andersen's partners opted for a one-size-fits-all pension so current partners would not grow resentful over having to pay big amounts for retirees, Mr. Kullberg said.
Instead, Andersen's management designed a pension that would prevent poverty, said Mr. Mann, calling the benefit a "patch-the-pants allowance."
New partners were advised to build their own investment plans and retirement accounts.
The message was, " 'You're being paid well -- provide for your own retirement,' " recalled Arthur Wyatt, an Andersen retiree who is an accounting professor at the University of Illinois.
The partners were encouraged to invest in Keogh plans, the retirement accounts for unincorporated businesses; such plans are outside the company's control. An independent trustee, Northern Trust, protects them from claims against Andersen. Partners could also roll those savings into individual retirement accounts.
Along with monthly pensions from the firm, the employees who are not partners can invest in a company-sponsored 401(k) retirement plan, also held by Northern Trust. All retirees of the firm, whether partners or not, qualify for Social Security benefits.
The retired partners may have viewed their monthly pension payment much like their Social Security benefits, as a sure thing. Why didn't Andersen set up a protected fund for its partners' pensions in the past? One person who has closely followed the lawsuit noted that the firm's consultants would probably have advised it to build a separate pension and benefits funds, but "the cobbler's children go barefoot." The company seemed stable, and the income was steady.
"What undoubtedly happened was everybody just assumed they had nothing to worry about," said Mr. Weise, the lawyer in Los Angeles. Before Andersen's problems became apparent, if someone had marched in and asked for special protections for the pension funds, he said, "people would have thought you were nuts."
Now Andersen's retirees are looking into a financially uncertain future -- but the potential loss of money is only part of what troubles them, Mr. Mann said. He recalled a recent conversation with another retired partner.
"I said, 'You know, you hate like the devil to see the financial impact that this might have on everybody,' " Mr. Mann recalled. " 'But what really hurts is to see a great company like Arthur Andersen being pilloried.' "

HEADLINE: At $500 an Hour, Lobbyist's Influence Rises With G.O.P. 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2 

 BODY:
In the last six months of 2001, the Coushatta Indians, a tribe with 800 members and a large casino in southwest Louisiana, paid $1.76 million to the law firm of Jack Abramoff, a Republican lobbyist here.
 Last month, the Bush administration handed the tribe a big victory by blocking construction of a casino by a rival tribe that would have drained off much of the Coushattas' business. 
 William Worfel, vice chairman of the Coushattas, views the administration's decision as a direct benefit of the eye-popping lobbying fees his tribe paid Mr. Abramoff, more money than many giant corporations like AOL Time Warner and American Airlines paid lobbyists in the same period. 
"I call Jack Abramoff, and I get results," Mr. Worfel said. "You get everything you pay for." 
In the seven years since Republicans gained control of the House of Representatives, Mr. Abramoff, 43, has used his close ties to Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, and other conservatives in the House to become one of the most influential -- and, at $500 an hour, best compensated -- lobbyists in Washington.
He is also an important Republican fund-raiser.
Mr. Abramoff's recent success and importance in Republican circles is a reminder that even as much of official Washington has been focused on the war in Afghanistan, efforts to beef up national security after Sept. 11 and the crisis in the Middle East, the business of lobbying has been humming along quite nicely, more out of the spotlight than usual but more profitable than ever for those with the right connections.
Unlike many lobbyists who take almost any client who is willing to pay their fee, Mr. Abramoff says he represents only those who stand for conservative principles. They include three Indian tribes with big casinos and, until recently, the Northern Mariana Islands.
"All of my political work," he said, "is driven by philosophical interests, not by a desire to gain wealth." 
Mr. Abramoff argues that Indian reservations and the island territory, which is exempt from United States labor laws, are "just what conservatives have always wanted, which is enterprise zones -- tax-free, regulation-free zones where with the right motivation, great industry could take place and spill out into the general communities."
His success in making this case to Republicans in the House has paid off handsomely.
At the beginning of last year, Mr. Abramoff left Preston Gates Ellis & Rouvelas Meeds, the law firm where he had worked since he became a lobbyist in 1995, and joined the Washington office of Greenberg Traurig, a firm based in Miami. 
Mostly as a consequence, Greenberg Traurig, which received only $1.7 million in lobbying fees during the first half of 2000, had $8.7 million in the first half of 2001, fifth most of any firm in Washington, according to rankings by National Journal. Preston Gates, which had been ranked fifth, saw its lobbying fees cut in half and fell out of the magazine's top 10.
As is often true of the work of lobbyists, it is hard to tell how much influence Mr. Abramoff really has over government decisions, and his recent victory for the Coushattas is a case in point.
Indian reservations are not covered by state laws regulating gambling. The Bureau of Indian Affairs in the Interior Department has the final say on whether casinos can be built on reservations, and the decisions have not always been free from political influence. 
Mr. Abramoff did not even directly approach the Interior Department himself, but instead organized a group of lawmakers and other Indian tribes with gambling interests to express to the department their opposition to the new casino. 
For lobbyists, perception of influence can often be as valuable as actual influence. 
Mr. Worfel, the vice chairman of the Coushattas, said he was delighted with Mr. Abramoff's representation and happy to pay his firm's retainer of nearly $300,000 a month.
Mr. Abramoff's fee of $500 an hour is matched by few if any other lobbyists in Washington. 
Mr. Abramoff's background and personality hardly fit the mold of the typical Washington lobbyist. 
He is an Orthodox Jew who says that even more than politics, his religion is a central element of his life. He is a teetotaler with a soft voice and a gentle manner who once held a high school weight-lifting record in California. He spent several years in Hollywood producing movies -- "Red Scorpion," an anticommunist thriller, was the most successful -- before becoming a lobbyist. 
Most unusual, he is, by his own description, a committed ideologue.
In the early 1980's, Mr. Abramoff was chairman of the College Republican National Committee, where he made important contacts. Among those on his staff were Grover Norquist, now a leading conservative strategist here and president of Americans for Tax Reform, and Ralph Reed, the former director of the Christian Coalition, who is a prominent Republican political consultant.
Mr. Abramoff tries hard to persuade his fellow Washington lobbyists to give more generously to the Republican Party, its candidates and conservative organizations. He expects to raise as much as $5 million this year, he said, and plans to donate as much as $250,000 personally.
Mr. Abramoff's rising influence is also illustrative of another trend in lobbying: success can be built on a strong relationship between a lobbyist and a single, powerful lawmaker. His interest in raising money for Republicans and conservative causes is the foundation of Mr. Abramoff's relationship with Mr. DeLay, who is determined to meld the lobbyists on K Street here into the Republican Party's political, legislative and fund-raising operations.
Mr. Abramoff described the bond this way: "We are the same politically and philosophically. Tom's goal is specific -- to keep Republicans in power and advance the conservative movement. I have Tom's goal precisely."
Mr. Norquist, who is friendly with both men, said of Mr. Abramoff, "He walks in to see DeLay and DeLay knows that he is representing clients whose views are in sync with DeLay's views."
It is difficult to gauge the importance of this relationship to Mr. Abramoff's success. Some of his clients said in interviews that Mr. Abramoff did not mention the relationship when he was seeking their business and that it was not the reason they retained him.
"Everybody is important in Congress, not just DeLay," said Philip Martin, chief of the Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians. The tribe, which runs a large casino and resort, was one of Mr. Abramoff's first clients and is still one of the most lucrative.
The Mississippi Choctaws paid Greenberg Traurig more than $1 million in the last half of 2001. "Definitely we get our money's worth, or we wouldn't be doing it," Mr. Martin said.
Mr. DeLay did help put Mr. Abramoff on the lobbying map, assisting his clients on two sensitive matters in 1995, the first year Mr. DeLay was whip and Mr. Abramoff's first year as a lobbyist. But it is not clear that the whip was any more active on these measures than he was on other bills before the House that year.
One of Mr. Abramoff's issues was his opposition to a federal tax on Indian gambling revenues. The tax was included in the nonbinding budget resolution the House approved.
But on behalf of the Mississippi Choctaws, Mr. Abramoff said he went to Mr. DeLay and other Republican leaders and explained, "Regardless of what you feel about gaming, what you are creating here is a tax on these people, and conservatives should never be in favor of new taxes."
The proposed tax was killed, Mr. Abramoff said, "once they discerned a conservative principle." 
The other big issue for Mr. Abramoff in 1995 that promoted his career was a bill passed by the Senate that would have stripped the Northern Mariana Islands of their exemption from the United States minimum wage and immigration laws.
The main industry in the Marianas is textiles. Inexpensive clothes are made there, mostly by immigrant Chinese women who work for low wages in substandard conditions, and the garments are shipped duty-free to the United States with a "Made in the U.S.A." label.
With Mr. DeLay's help, Mr. Abramoff managed to get the legislation defeated in the House, using the argument that the Marianas represented low taxes and free enterprise and should be left alone.
Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who sponsored the legislation in the House, is still furious about Mr. Abramoff's action. In a recent interview, Mr. Miller said, "He spent a lot of time, effort and money to protect a system that was a growth industry for sex shops, prostitution, abuse of women, slavery, illegal immigration, worker exploitation and narcotics, and he did it all in the name of freedom."
Asked about this, Mr. Abramoff replied: "Congressman Miller has an agenda, and he wants the facts to fit his thesis. No lobbyist could have convinced Congress to support the system he describes."
After the bill was defeated, Mr. Abramoff took 150 lawmakers and staff members to the Northern Marianas, 200 miles north of Guam, and Mr. DeLay came back enthralled.
Unfortunately for Mr. Abramoff, turning the islands' economy into an ideological cause has come back to haunt him. In last November's election for governor, he supported the candidate of the garment industry, Benigno Fitial, against the Republican candidate, Juan Babauta. Mr. Babauta won and soon after he took office in January, he canceled the government's $100,000 per month contract with Mr. Abramoff.
"The U.S. territories have traditionally been handled in Washington in a bipartisan manner," an associate of the new governor said. "Abramoff marked an end to that approach. So in a change of government, it was only natural that he be dropped."

HEADLINE: U.S. to Back Scientist From India To Replace Global Warming Expert 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
After meeting yesterday with industry lobbyists unhappy about an international science panel assessing climate change, the State Department has decided to back an engineer from India to become the panel's new chairman.
 The current chairman, Dr. 
Robert T. Watson, whose term is expiring, is an atmospheric chemist who has long pressed for aggressive action to cut emissions of heat-trapping gases linked to global warming and released mainly by burning coal and oil. 
 Dr. Watson, who is also chief scientist at the World Bank, was nominated in 1996 by the Clinton administration.
His views on climate contrast sharply with those of President Bush, who recently proposed slowing, but not reversing, the growth of such emissions until there was more evidence of potential dangers.
The Indian engineer, Dr. Rajendra K. Pachauri, an economist as well as an engineer, is currently one of five vice chairmen of the group, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change. 
Under the auspices of the United Nations, the panel conducts periodic reviews of the causes and consequences of rising temperatures.
Auto manufacturers and oil companies have long seen Dr. Watson as a foe, and their lobbyists have said that Dr. Pachauri, who has worked with industry in the past, was clearly preferable.
Some panel scientists said Mr. Bush might end up regretting the choice, noting that Dr. Pachauri has repeatedly criticized the president for not acting more aggressively to cut emissions from the United States, which is the largest source of heat-trapping gases.
State Department officials said the decision was seen as a way to build American relations with India, which had been campaigning strongly for Dr. Pachauri.

HEADLINE: High-Cost Lenders Dominate In Black Areas, Study Finds 

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2 

 BODY:
A study of nearly 200,000 home loan applications in New York City has found that conventional banks are neglecting black neighborhoods, creating a void filled by high-cost and abusive lenders.
 The study was conducted by the office of Senator Charles E. Schumer. It concluded that the situation in black neighborhoods had not improved in the two years since Mr. Schumer commissioned a similar study into banks' lending practices. 
 In a recent interview, he said that the results suggested that racial discrimination continues to be a factor in the way banks issue loans. But he also cited a reluctance on the part of black residents to apply for conventional mortgages, partly because many expect to be rejected.
"After years of mistrust, years of discrimination, many black homeowners simply do not want to risk the humiliation of being turned down for a loan by the bank," Mr. Schumer said. "And as a result, so many black homeowners who are more than qualified to receive low-interest loans from conventional lenders don't even apply."
The situation has created a major opportunity for so-called subprime lenders, who charge high interest rates and hefty fees to borrowers who, for whatever reason, have limited access to credit from conventional lenders.
The analysis found that in 2000, subprime lenders dominated the market in black neighborhoods, providing 43 percent of the home loans there, compared with only 9 percent of the loans in white neighborhoods.
Critics have long described many subprime lenders as predatory, accusing them of using deceptive practices and imposing exorbitant costs that force countless victims into bankruptcy and foreclosure.
Indeed, the difference between a conventional and a nonconventional loan can be staggering, in financial terms. For a 30-year fixed mortgage of $150,000, the difference in total costs between a 7 percent prime rate from a conventional lender and a subprime rate of 9 percent from a nonconventional lender is $75,232.
The study also found racial disparity in the way loan applications are handled: banks denied loan applications from blacks at nearly twice the rate for whites, even when they had similar incomes. Over all, the rejection rates were 28 percent for blacks and 15 percent for whites.
Even blacks with incomes above $67,440 were rejected more often than whites with incomes under $45,000, with 26 percent of the blacks turned down compared with 19 percent of the whites. 
The study also found differences in the lending patterns of banks in comparisons that paired six mostly white neighborhoods with six mostly black neighborhoods with similar incomes in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.
In East Flatbush, a black neighborhood in Brooklyn with an average income of $60,010, banks rejected 33 percent of loan applications, and subprime lenders provided 46 percent of the loans. But in a white Brooklyn neighborhood, Sheepshead Bay, with an average income of $58,230, banks denied only 12 percent of the applications, and subprime lenders handled only 14 percent of the loans.
In Laurelton, Queens, a black neighborhood with an average income of $63,527, banks rejected 30 percent of loan applications, and subprime lenders provided 36 percent of the loans. But in a comparable white neighborhood in Queens, Bayside, with an average income of $57,212, banks denied only 12 percent of the applications, and subprime lenders handled only 8 percent of the loans.
Mr. Schumer said part of the solution was to bring banks into black communities and match them up with prospective home buyers. To that end, he is seeking a citywide expansion of a pilot program he introduced last year in which banks work with black churches to identify prospective homebuyers.
