HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
A Convention Center Race May Spawn Losers

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, March 27 

 BODY:
The Automobile Show was in full swing this week in a freshly completed section of the new $354 million convention center on the banks of the Allegheny River as steelworkers continued erecting the building's sweeping, cantilevered roof, which echoes the nearby suspension bridges known as the Three Sisters.
 With the center, full of skylights, glass walls and 330,000 square feet of exhibition space, Pittsburgh has plunged boldly into a hotly contested space race in which dozens of cities around the country are building new convention centers or enlarging the ones they have. Pittsburgh, like its rivals, has put out a siren call for teachers' conventions, biomedical meetings, industrial trade shows and religious gatherings. 
 "We're talking about protecting the convention market we had and supporting the economic development of the region," said Joseph R. McGrath, president of the Greater Pittsburgh Convention and Visitors Bureau. "We're also hoping to create the impression of Pittsburgh as a player on the national scene." 
But though Mr. McGrath and counterparts in other cities are armed with studies projecting a boom in travelers, hotel occupancy, restaurant spending and prestige, a number of economists say they are fighting for a larger share of what is essentially a shrinking industry.
The trade show and convention industry enjoyed double-digit growth in attendance in the late 1980's and early 90's, analysts say, but that has slowed considerably since 1997. In fact, attendance nationally was down last year, even before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
"To a significant degree, it's folly," said Robert A. Baade, a professor of economics at Lake Forest College who has analyzed the economic impact of convention centers, stadiums and casinos. "They're ignoring what other cities are doing, and they're doing it at their own peril. They could be left with a lot of white elephants."
Even Robert V. Canton, director of the convention consulting business at PricewaterhouseCoopers, which has done studies advocating construction of larger meeting halls, now agrees that a problem of overbuilding looms in the convention and trade show business. But he and others argue that cities must build or expand to keep up with the competition and maintain their market share.
So, Boston is putting up the steel framework for a center with 516,000 square feet of exhibition space, while Washington is going a step further with a new 725,000-square-foot operation. Hartford is also building a new center, and Buffalo is planning one. Even the industry's behemoth, McCormick Place in Chicago, is planning yet another big expansion beyond its 2.56 million square feet. By contrast, the Javits Convention Center in New York has 814,400 square feet of meeting and exhibition space.
All in all, Tradeshow Week, the bible of the industry, estimates that over the next five years the amount of convention space will jump 25 percent, as 96 new or expanded centers open a combined 16.8 million square feet of new exhibit space at a cost of about $12 billion.
People in the industry are debating which cities are most likely to be hurt -- destinations like Chicago, Las Vegas, New York and Orlando, Fla., or smaller cities with smaller halls. "I think the second-tier cities are going to feel the pinch much more than first-tier destinations," Mr. Canton said.
The competition is fierce. Pittsburgh has already hijacked three conventions from Cleveland. In response, Cleveland's Convention and Visitors Bureau issued a news release bemoaning the losses and highlighting its effort to replace the city's 80-year-old convention center.
The competition does not end with who has the biggest or best space. Heywood Sanders, a professor at the University of Texas, found that Los Angeles discounted rates at its convention center for the last five years to try to lure shows and conventions. The operator of the new center in Charlotte, N.C., has also been offering incentives. "It's a symptom of a zero-sum market," Mr. Sanders said. "They think they're competing by adding space, but they're only starting the process."
The problem is worsened by the slowdown in attendance growth and a decline in the size of trade shows. A 1997 study projected that trade show attendance would hit 140 million by 2000. But Tradeshow Week estimates that although attendance reached 140 million in 1999, it fell to 126 million in 2000. Last year, the average attendance at trade shows fell further, by 7.4 percent, the magazine reported, partly because of the recession, a slump in the technology sector and the terrorist attacks.
"In the 1990's, the trade show industry grew faster than the gross national product," said Michael Hughes, director of research for Tradeshow Week. "But about two years ago the rate of growth slowed and the industry matured. It'll now track the ups and downs of the economy more than in the past."
Many convention centers are run as loss leaders, justified by projected increases in spending at hotels, restaurants and shops. Convention center operators in Boston, Washington and Pittsburgh are finding that they must also subsidize convention hotels, raising more questions about the wisdom of bothering to compete in what is almost certainly a money-losing race, Mr. Sanders added.
Still, Stephen G. Leeper, executive director of the Sports and Exhibition Authority in Pittsburgh, and the Convention and Visitors Bureau say they believe that Pittsburgh can overcome the obstacles and win a bigger share of the convention market.
The building, known as the David L. Lawrence Convention Center, at the edge of the downtown district, is being built with a combination of state grants and hotel and other tax revenue. The authority hired an architect with a national reputation, Rafael Vinoly of New York, to design a distinctive structure, not your typical black box. The glass walls, skylights and rooftop garden give it a bright and airy feeling, while the sloped roof takes advantage of the wind off the Allegheny River to cool and ventilate the building.
The first phase opened in February with the Recreational Vehicle Show, the Home and Garden Show and the Automobile Show, all of which have drawn thousands of visitors from the surrounding area. But the Convention and Visitors Bureau is after bigger game: conventions, rather than public or consumer shows, that bring out-of-towners who fly in and spend far more money than the locals do on hotel rooms, dining, shopping and entertainment.
So far, the bureau has booked 57 conventions through 2008, although only 17 of them are too large to have fit into the old convention center. The conventions range from the Religious Conference Management Association, with 1,300 participants in 2004, to the rubber division of the American Chemical Society, which is expected to draw 12,000 in 2005.
"It's kind of like musical chairs," said Mr. McGrath, the president of the Convention and Visitors Bureau. "When the music stops, someone doesn't have a chair. I believe we will be among the winners."

HEADLINE: The Postpartisan Governor; 
Defying a Democratic Tide, Pataki Seeks a Third Term

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
When George E. Pataki first ran for governor of New York, as a junior Republican state senator taking on Mario M. Cuomo in 1994, he campaigned on a platform that was crisp and unmistakably conservative. Mr. Pataki pledged to reimpose the death penalty. He told voters he would slash spending, cut taxes and reduce the welfare rolls. And he promised to shrink a government that, he said, had bloated under 20 years of Democratic rule. 
 But the candidate who is now seeking a third term as governor is in many ways different from that little-known state senator from Peekskill who confounded Mr. Cuomo eight years ago. Nowhere was that more obvious than at his Manhattan campaign headquarters the other day, where he accepted the endorsement of a group of black ministers, most of them Democrats. 
 For 15 minutes, Mr. Pataki spoke passionately about how the state had enacted prescription drug subsidies for elderly New Yorkers. He urged a rollback of the Rockefeller drug laws that, he said to murmurs of approval, were too tough on first-time drug users. He spoke fervently about his efforts to expand health care coverage for the poor, holding it up as one of his proudest accomplishments. 
"Under our children's health-plus program, every child in New York State today is entitled to health care," Mr. Pataki said, evincing the kind of enthusiasm he typically displays when talking about cutting government bureaucracy. "We are proud that more than 540,000 low-income children have been enrolled since we've expanded this program. And we know that working families need to have insurance, the adults as well."
The ministers shouted, "Amen." Mr. Pataki beamed for the cameras.
To the pleasure of Republicans and the frustration of Democrats, with seven months to go until Election Day, Mr. Pataki finds himself in a remarkably strong position as he campaigns for a third term in Albany: a Republican who is defying the tide of an increasingly Democratic state. Justifiably or not, Mr. Pataki has established enough of an air of inevitability to his re-election that nearly 2,000 New York City sanitation workers turned out in downtown Manhattan on Monday afternoon to chant, "Four more years," and endorse their first Republican for governor since Nelson Rockefeller.
Mr. Pataki says his political strength today is testimony to his success as governor, mentioning his management of the state's budget, the decline in the crime rate while he was in Albany and the expansion of health care programs.
"People have heard a great deal of the world's best politicians come here and explain their vision," he said, in a sarcastic reference to the Democrat he defeated. "They've also seen what we've done over the course of the past seven years." 
But Mr. Pataki's formidable position these days is, in truth, as much a reflection of what even Democrats say is his adroit and largely successful effort to position himself in a state whose electoral dynamics have shifted notably, and increasingly to his disadvantage, in the last eight years. 
From what he says, to how he says it, to whom he has struck alliances with, Mr. Pataki has moved to blur his own party identification, casting the coming contest for governor as anything but the referendum between the Republican and Democratic views of government that served Democrats well in the 1998 and 2000 Senate races. A New York voter these days could be forgiven for forgetting that Mr. Pataki is running as the candidate of the Republican and Conservative parties.
"You have to give the governor credit," said Howard Wolfson, the executive director of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, who was communications director for Hillary Rodham Clinton when she won her Senate seat in 1998. "He has gone from being a death-penalty-loving tax cutter to an ally of hospital workers and gun control advocates. I have a lot of admiration for his political instincts. I can't think of anything he could have done to better position himself for this race."
In many ways, Mr. Pataki's strategy this year is an extension of the approach taken by Michael R. Bloomberg, also a Republican, to win election as mayor of New York City, in the view of Richard Schrader, who managed Mark Green's unsuccessful campaign for mayor last year. The elections for mayor and governor, taken together, suggest the extent to which New York has entered a postpartisan phase, at least in terms of local elections, in which party identification does not mean as much as it once did.
This change in ideological emphasis is reflected in the geographical focus of Mr. Pataki's campaign. There are weeks when he has more campaign appearances in Democratic New York City than do his two Democratic opponents combined.
Those two Democrats, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, and Andrew M. Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary, say Mr. Pataki has been forced to turn because the poor condition of the upstate economy has endangered his standing with Republican voters there. Whether or not that is the case, Mr. Pataki's standing in New York City, which is even more Democratic than the state as a whole, has only been strengthened because of his own visibility in the weeks after the attack on the World Trade Center. 
These days, Mr. Pataki has begun doing something that would have seemed inconceivable a few months ago: explicitly invoking the terrorist attack as he campaigns for his re-election.
"Let met tell you, there are quiet unsung heroes of Sept. 11 and afterward as well," Mr. Pataki said to the New York City sanitation workers at a raucous rally at the union hall Monday. "I was down there, in the evening of Sept. 11, when dust and debris covered Lower Manhattan from one river to the other. And it wasn't just the police officers and the firefighters and the emergency service workers. You were out there, too. You were the ones who cleared the streets so emergency workers could get to ground zero."
"It was the ordinary working men and women from this city and state who stood up to the most evil terror our state has ever faced, and looked it down, and said we're not going to let you frighten us," the governor said in embracing the union's endorsements.
Democrats said Mr. Pataki's attempt to reposition himself would ultimately undercut him with the electorate, raising questions about his own core beliefs. But Mr. Pataki asserted that he had not changed a single view since he rode in from right field in 1994. "The philosophy is essentially the same," he said, sprawled on a couch in his office in Midtown Manhattan.
"I believe in limited government, low taxes, a tough approach to crime," he said. "But I also believe in an activist government. I'm not one of those laissez-faire types."
"I believe there are fundamental differences in philosophy between those who believe in big government, and government solutions, and those who believe in empowering individuals," he said. "It's the difference between creating a welfare system and making the welfare system more generous."
Whether or not Mr. Pataki has drifted from his ideological moorings, he has certainly changed the emphases of his candidacy. As he moves around New York, he is more apt to talk about expanding health care coverage for the poor, or rolling back the Rockefeller drug laws, or gun control measures, than about cutting government programs or the welfare rolls.
His appearance with the black ministers was just one of many events that his advisers have set up with Democrats for this year -- most famously, with Dennis Rivera, the head of the state health care workers' union and a symbol of liberal politics in New York -- intended to make it easier for a Democrat to pull the lever for a Republican governor. (Mr. Pataki is also seeking the Independence Party line.)
In the course of a 45-minute interview about his candidacy, the words "Republican" and "Democrat" barely crossed the governor's lips. As the interview was drawing to a close, Mr. Pataki went out of his way to raise the issue of abortion, volunteering, "I disagree with many in my party" in supporting abortion rights.
"They would say government should make the decision about whether or not a woman can have an abortion," Mr. Pataki said. "How is that consistent with the belief in the individual and limited government?" 
"There are those who would say, 'Ha-ha! This is a liberal Democratic position coming from someone who is a Republican governor.' I would say it is consistent with the philosophy I believe in of empowering the individual and limited government. Maybe that creates a blur, because I'm pro-choice in what would traditionally be viewed in partisan terms."
For all that, it remains early in the race, and Mr. Pataki clearly has some problems in some quarters. Most notably, Mr. Pataki's position upstate would seem to have slipped, in no small part because the economy there has suffered so much distress while the rest of the state and the nation have prospered. In the last two statewide elections, Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton, both Democrats, were elected to the Senate after focusing much time upstate, and Mr. McCall and Mr. Cuomo have taken a lesson from those campaigns.
In fact, Mr. Pataki declined to respond when asked if he agreed with the declaration by the Republican senatorial candidate in 2000, Rick A. Lazio, that the upstate economy had "turned a corner," an assertion Mrs. Clinton turned against Mr. Lazio to devastating effect in the final weeks of that campaign. 
"I'll leave it to others," Mr. Pataki said after a pause. "But I know that our policies have helped to turn around from an economic climate standpoint where we were in 1994. But we still have to fight for every single job. But I'll leave the macroanalysis to the macroanalyzers. I know that in every single community, we have to fight for every single job. And that is what we're doing."
Mr. Pataki left little doubt about just how irritated he was that anyone would suggest that he of all governors would sacrifice his core beliefs just for the sake of re-election. At one point in the interview, he removed both shoes and chucked them halfway across his expansive office as he complained about a newspaper article that portrayed a $1.8 billion health care bill he rushed through the Legislature, which included money for raises for Mr. Rivera's union members, as a reward for Mr. Rivera's union's endorsing the governor. The bill, Mr. Pataki asserted, was part of his effort to improve health care in New York.
That said, even Michael Long, the chairman of the state's Conservative Party and one of Mr. Pataki's most prominent supporters, called the deal with Mr. Rivera "wrong" and "costly to the taxpayers," though he added that Mr. Pataki was doing what he had to do to win an election in a state like New York.
"Even though I disagree with some of the moves he's made, he's positioned himself well, and probably took a little steam out of his Democratic opponents," Mr. Long said. "I think it was deliberate strategy on his part, and it has worked. It has placed him in a very good position. Like I said, I don't agree with all of his strategy."
More than a few Democrats expressed admiration for Mr. Pataki's success at leaving his opponents so little space on the field. "Pataki is the George McGovern of Republicans," said Paul J. Feiner, a Democratic town supervisor from Greenburgh, in central Westchester. "If Pataki were a Democrat, he would appeal to liberal Democrats."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
F.D.A. Permits Others To Re-Inspect Factories
Even if government inspectors have found widespread problems in pharmaceutical factories, the Food and Drug Administration sometimes approves new medicines to be made in those factories without inspecting them again by relying on company employees or consultants to verify that the problems have been fixed, the agency said.
 The practice came to light after a trade journal reported that the F.D.A. had approved Clarinex, Schering-Plough's new allergy drug, based on factory inspections done by consultants hired by the company. Page C3. 

Credit Suisse Unit Cuts 300 Jobs
Credit Suisse First Boston eliminated 300 executive jobs, including those of about 50 managing directors, as part of its aggressive campaign to trim costs. The job cuts, which the investment banking group's new chief, Adebayo Ogunlesi, left, had said last month were imminent, come amid a continuing slump on Wall Street. All told, Wall Street fired 43,300 people in the year ended in February. C10.

Auto Sales Dropped 1.5% in March
Industry auto sales in the United States fell 1.5 percent in March from a year earlier, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank, a result that was on the optimistic side of most analysts' expectations in a healing economy. C5.

$5 Billion Deal by Royal Dutch/Shell
Royal Dutch/Shell agreed to buy Enterprise Oil for $5 billion in cash. Royal Dutch/Shell is trying to catch up after sitting out a wave of consolidation. World Business, Section W.

Technology Drags Wall St. Lower
Technology stocks dragged Wall Street lower after Goldman, Sachs voiced caution on big-name companies like Microsoft. The Nasdaq composite index declined 58.22 points, or 3.1 percent, to 1,804.40. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 48.99 points, or 0.5 percent, to 10,313.71. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index decreased 9.78 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,136.76. C11.

The escalation of violence in the Middle East is undermining investor confidence that the recovering economy will lead to higher stock prices. Market Place. C11.

Big Layoff Is Expected at WorldCom
WorldCom is expected to announce plans this week to cut about 7,000 jobs as it seeks to recover from a slowdown in sales and a federal inquiry into its accounting. C11.

Monsanto and DuPont Settle Suits
Monsanto and DuPont agreed to settle 11 lawsuits over genetically modified seeds and gave each other licenses to their patents. C2.

Factory Orders Eased in February
The Commerce Department said the value of orders for manufactured goods eased 0.1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $323.8 billion in February, in contrast to Wall Street economists' expectations of a 1.0 percent pickup in factory orders. The report was a sign that the economy might be recovering at a little less robust pace than some had thought. C4.

A Ratings Lift for Cable News
The latest ratings from Nielsen Media Research provide most all of the cable news networks something to brag about. Fox News widened its lead over CNN. Advertising. C10.

MSNBC is expected today to sign Phil Donahue to host a prime-time discussion program starting this summer. C10.

A Bitter Standoff at Cablevision
James L. Dolan, president of Cablevision, is locked into a bitter standoff with the YES Network, created by the Yankees. The dispute is depriving three million Cablevision subscribers in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut of access to most Yankees games. D1.

Expanded Real Estate Coverage
Today Business Day introduces expanded coverage of commercial real estate. This week: the nationwide convention center race, and Pittsburgh's new entry. C8-C10.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Software: PeopleSoft Warns On Sales 

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss) 

 BODY:
 PeopleSoft, the software company best known for its human-resources applications, said it had missed its first-quarter projections, sending its shares tumbling by a third. One of the most consistent performers in its market last year, PeopleSoft said it now expected to report earnings of 14 cents a share, 3 cents better than the period a year earlier but a penny less than expected by analysts. 
But more worrisome to investors was the company's software-license revenue of $130 million to $135 million, at least $25 million less than Wall Street had expected. The company, based in Pleasanton, Calif., said the license sales "reflected a cautious economic environment." Brent Thill, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston, said the results, coupled with a similar warning from Oracle last month, indicated that corporations remained reluctant to invest in new software despite recent signs of a brightening economic outlook. PeopleSoft shares fell $12.21, to $25.16. Chris Gaither (NYT)

HEADLINE: U.S. Will Shift Funds to Miss Debt Ceiling 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2 

 BODY:
In the latest turn in a game of political chicken, the Bush administration announced today that it would juggle some finances this week so the statutory ceiling on government borrowing would not be breached.
 In a letter to Congressional leaders, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said that because Congress had not granted President Bush's request to raise the debt limit, he would temporarily shift money from a civil service retirement fund to another account beginning on Thursday to avoid a government default. 
 The step has no practical consequences, but it is bound to have political ramifications. Democrats were quick to argue that the Treasury's action underscored the irresponsibility of the tax cut the president pushed through Congress last year. 
Lawmakers have long played politics with the arcane issue of the debt ceiling. The only reason they insist on a statutory limit on government debt is that it gives Congress political leverage against the president.
The issue last arose in 1995 and 1996. Led by Newt Gingrich, who was House speaker, Republicans blocked an increase in the debt limit in an effort to force President Bill Clinton to sign a Republican budget or risk sending the country into default.
Robert E. Rubin, then the treasury secretary, took action similar to Mr. O'Neill's, and some Republicans threatened to impeach him. For the rest of the Clinton presidency, the debt limit of $5.95 trillion was not a problem. The government was running a surplus, so the debt was falling. But the budget is now in deficit, and Mr. Bush has repeatedly asked Congress to raise the limit before the debt gets to a point where the government cannot legally borrow.
House leaders have refused to bring up such a bill. Not only would many Democrats vote against it to embarrass the president, but many Republicans who argued against lifting the ceiling when Mr. Clinton was president would feel compelled to vote against it now for consistency.
In his letter to Congress, Mr. O'Neill said the government would hit the ceiling on Thursday. To prevent default on government obligations, he said he would temporarily put up to $35 billion from the Federal Employee Retirement System in an account that did not draw interest. Moving the money in that way, from one government pocket to another, would mean that this money would not count as part of the national debt. Lost interest would be repaid.
The government's financial condition will improve after April 15 when a flood of income tax payments is received, and the money will be returned to its fund. At some point this summer, Mr. O'Neill said, another debt crisis will occur.
Democrats said today that the financial gymnastics showed how wrong Mr. Bush was when he said last year that the nation could afford his tax cut and still pay off most of the debt by the end of the decade.
Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the top Democrat on the House Budget Committee, accused the administration today of fiscal mismanagement. But for all their sniping, few Democrats are advocating in this election year that the Bush tax cuts be repealed.
Mr. Bush and his allies in Congress say the new deficits are primarily the result of the poor economy last year, the war in Afghanistan and the cost of domestic security.

HEADLINE: ONLINE SHOPPER; 
Why Kick the Tires? Just Click the Mouse

BYLINE:  By Michelle Slatalla; E-mail: Slatalla@nytimes.com

 BODY:
ANY vehicle that calls itself a family car should have a back seat big enough to divide into kingdoms. 
 The lumbering Cadillac my family took on vacation to the Wisconsin Dells in the 1970's illustrated this concept perfectly. By the time we hit the first rest area, my three brothers and I had carved out sovereign territories, demarcated by a no man's land of crumpled candy bar wrappers. As for accusations that I hogged the armrest and built an onerous Smiley Face pillow barricade, let the record show that I would have been happy to trade the window seat for the Mad magazine my brother was hoarding. 
 My expectations for back seat roominess have remained high. I mention this because I recently went to test-drive a Volkswagen Passat, which Consumer Reports rated the top family car this year. The only available test car (a sedan with automatic transmission) was not the car I really wanted to buy (a beautiful blue five-speed wagon that I had built from scratch on the Volkswagen Web site), but the dealer assured me that the interior dimensions were identical. If that is true, the Passat is a family car with a teensy back seat, barely big enough to accommodate two of my three kids even if one dared to colonize the legroom over the center hump. I couldn't buy that car, in any color. 
I was back to square one, having wasted a week of online research and negotiations with local and online dealers and hours comparing columns of specifications and prices onscreen at sites like Consumerreports
.org and Carsdirect.com. With the lease running out on my Audi wagon, I decided to give the Internet a second chance. After all, I needed a new car, but I was also determined not to be the only shopper in America who would disprove the assertion of J. D. Power and Associates that you can save an average of $500 by buying one through an online service.
The theory? You can get a better car deal online because the buying service negotiates competitive prices with dealerships in advance, in return for promising to send a substantial volume of customers their way. The dealership's profit may be smaller, but it sells cars to customers who otherwise might have bought elsewhere. 
The reality? A good price quote is only worth something if you actually buy a car. The evening after my test drive, I had a soul-searching phone conversation with a helpful, patient Carsdirect.com sales specialist who was starting to remind me of my old therapist. After I revealed the embarrassing truth about why I was set on a station wagon (the large expanse of windshield in a minivan makes my husband feel nauseated), the specialist advised me to consider a Saab or a Volvo. Carsdirect.com had negotiated special prices for those models with partner dealerships. 
I went to a local Volvo dealer to test drive a Volvo AWD XC wagon (now, there's a backseat that will accommodate three girls, their Harry Potter cassette tapes, a magnetic travel Scrabble board and selected headless Barbies). Then I compared the local dealer's price for a car on the lot with a similarly equipped vehicle on Carsdirect.com. 
The local dealer's price: $38,067.
Carsdirect.com's price: $36,567. 
The local dealer refused to match the lower price, saying it was $700 below its cost from the manufacturer. The best price he was willing to offer was around $37,600. 
Why the disparity? I phoned Chris Denove, the senior director of automotive research at J.D. Power, who explained. "If anybody is the loser with online buying services it's the dealer, because these services are narrowing the dealer's profit margin on each car purchased, but they aren't making more people purchase a vehicle," he said. "It's still 16 million to 17 million people a year who buy a car. 
"But who's to say what the dealer really paid for a car?" he added. "No dealer is going to sell you a car for a price lower than what they paid for it, so the simplest economic theory tells you that there's still some profit for a dealer in the Carsdirect.com price." 
This time I was willing to accept any color, but the Carsdirect.com specialist phoned to say he could not find a Volvo XC wagon without the Touring Package, a feature that would add $1,190 to the price, for such inscrutably silly items as a grocery-bag holder. (My local dealer didn't have one without the Touring Package either.) I could have placed a special order, but that vehicle might not arrive for about eight weeks.
My next question to Mr. Denove: Where were the cars without the Touring Packages? 
"There's the pressure for the manufacturers to put on the bells and whistles, to make more profit," he said. "So even with the added information you get online, you still pretty much end up settling for what's already on the lot, with unnecessary options." 
By this time the negotiations had nearly exhausted me. "What harm would a grocery-bag holder do?" I reasoned. 
The next hurdle: lease or buy? Since Consumer Reports New Car Price report (for which I had paid $12) raised concerns about Volvo's long-term reliability, I opted for a 39-month closed-end lease, which would allow me to drive 15,000 miles a year. Again, the lease terms quoted by Carsdirect.com were far less than what I had expected, including the down payment of $1,073 and monthly payments of $468. Why? 
"It's just a good deal that we negotiated," the sale specialist said. 
To learn more, I went to Edmunds
.com and read a tutorial on financing and leasing, which explained terms like "money factor" and "residual" and "gap insurance," details I had found mind-numbingly dull until my own money was on the line.
After determining that the lease's interest rate was low and the residual price I would pay if I purchased the car at the end of the lease was high, I understood enough to tell the Carsdirect.com sales specialist I wanted the Volvo wagon. 
He put me in touch with a dealer in Brooklyn, about a 90-minute drive from my house. The dealer installed another option -- a third seat to transport kids who weigh under 85 pounds -- which increased the monthly payments by about $18. 
The dealer offered to deliver the car to my house, which would have been convenient, but trying to coordinate a delivery time proved too difficult. It turned out to be just as easy to pick it up. I drove to Bay Ridge Volvo yesterday, where it took only about an hour to complete the paperwork, write a check and drive away in the new car. 
All it needs now are some crumpled candy wrappers.

HEADLINE: Novel's Sequel: Bridges Are Burned; 
'Madison County' Author Returns to His Best-Selling Characters

BYLINE:  By LESLIE KAUFMAN

 BODY:
Ten years after his "Bridges of Madison County" conquered the best-seller list (it sold six million hardcover copies in North America, which makes it the best-selling hardcover novel of all time), Robert James Waller has written what he describes as an epilogue to the original story. That book, "A Thousand Country Roads," will make it to stores late this month.
 Its prose style and pace will be familiar to lovers of the first book. It is 16 years later, but Francesca Johnson can still fit into the pink dress she wore for the candlelit farmhouse dinner that began the affair in the first book. Robert Kincaid, who rode into Francesca's life like "a leopard on the tail of a comet," has been injured in a photo shoot and is sick, but he still sports the signature suspenders, smokes prodigious numbers of Camels and drives his truck, Harry. 
 Despite the lovers' return and the platinum pedigree of "Country Roads," it makes its way to print with a surprising number of questions, commercial, artistic and otherwise. In addition to reissuing a book of essays and releasing a book of photographs and a country music CD, the prolific Mr. Waller has published three novels since "Bridges." The audience for each has been significantly smaller than for the one before. 
Warner Books, which made a bundle when it discovered the first book, passed on "Country Roads," largely because early drafts of the novel were so disappointing to its editors. Warner also feared that the book would frustrate audiences because despite some teasing near-misses, the love-tossed couple do not meet again. Mr. Waller insisted that a meeting would violate the integrity of the first book, which makes clear that they die without seeing each other again. After Warner passed, Mr. Waller decided to bypass the entire New York publishing machine and instead went with the little-known John M. Hardy Publishing.
"We felt that in some respects this book lacks emotional payoff," said Laurence J. Kirshbaum, chairman of Warner Books, a division of AOL Time Warner. "Unlike 'Bridges,' which had four wonderful days, this is less focused, and that concerned us."
Then there is Mr. Waller himself, who has frequently said Robert Kincaid is 80 percent him. Fame stung this business dean turned author. As "Bridges" grew into a national phenomenon, was celebrated on "Oprah" and became the subject of church hall meetings, publishing's glitterati and an array of incensed literary critics got ornery. He insists he does not read reviews and derisive articles, and he describes his own writings modestly as printed campfire tales, yet even a decade later his bruises from the critical beatings still seem bright purple and blue.
"I really do have a small ego," Mr. Waller said in a recent phone conversation. "I am open to rational discussion. If you don't like the book and can say why, I am willing to listen. But the criticism turned to nastiness. There were personnel attacks on my hair and on my bracelet. I was stunned." With the exception of one Iowa reporter and now The New York Times, he says, he has not given interviews since 1995.
That is not all Mr. Waller has changed about his life. He has left Iowa, where he grew up and lived most of his adult life and which he used to characterize as the unlikeliest of backdrops for a torrid bodice ripper. He moved to a ranch in the star-filled but far-removed outpost of Alpine, Tex. He also divorced his wife of 36 years, the woman he had described as the inspiration for Francesca in 1997, for a much younger women who was the family's landscaper. (He said he would not comment on the changes in his family situation, saying, "Affairs of the bedroom are off limits.")
Despite those wrenching changes, or perhaps because of them, Mr. Waller seems to have used his money to live as a real-life Iron John. Like Kincaid, who was sensitive enough to wipe the tub after he bathed in it yet man enough to bring Francesca to ecstasy, Mr. Waller writes poetry, tends a vast ranch, reads political economic textbooks for pleasure (he has a doctorate in economics), and cares for his girlfriend, Linda Bow, who has been ill.
A longtime guitar player and performer, he has self-recorded a new CD of bluesy twangy ballads in his pleasant smoke-cured voice, but he plans to make the collection available only to friends. He is also working on a book of photographs to be accompanied by his poems and essays someday. 
His alter ego, however, has not fared the passing of the years nearly so well. In "Country Roads," despite an ending that is too pat and feel-good, Kincaid for much of the book is a pathetic figure. He is so alone at the beginning that it is almost pitiful: a circumstance, Mr. Waller acknowledges, that cannot be separated from his own anxieties. 
"Now he is 68, and I am coming up on 63, so I had to think hard about how he would feel about being all alone and a little physically disabled," Mr. Waller said. "He is vulnerable. I think a psychologist would diagnose him as clinically depressed."
His decision to write another installment of "Bridges" has been long in coming. He says it was inspired by frequent mail and queries from fans who wanted to learn more about what happened to Kincaid and Johnson in the years between kitchen counter surrender and death. Although it develops its own plots and introduces other Kincaid love interests, Mr. Waller views this second book as a companion piece to the first. "Everything in the epilogue could have fit cleverly in the first book," he says.
But "Country Road" did not come as easily as "Bridges," which Mr. Waller famously wrote in 11 days. "The first book was given to me. It was a magical experience," he said. "This was harder." Then, after thinking about it, "but not real hard." Still, it was hard enough that when Mr. Waller completed a first draft more than a year ago, Warner Books made the unusual decision not to option the right to publish it, causing a collective giggle of vituperative glee in the New York literary world.
Yet Mr. Waller and his agent Aaron Priest are hardly shamed by the rejection. "It is exactly as well written as 'The Bridges of Madison County,' " Mr. Priest said defiantly. "I have no doubt it could have been sold to a major New York publisher. 'Bridges' sold six million hardcover. Suppose 9 out of 10 of those readers did not want this book, it would still sell 600,000 copies hardcover. That is a huge best seller."
Instead of going hat in hand to other New York publishers, Mr. Waller opted out of the system. He kept his manuscript in his desk for a year, then decided to go with the tiny Hardy company in Alpine, Tex. Mr. Waller and his agent will not discuss the details of the deal, which presumably involves some kind of percentage profit sharing. With the guidance of Jean Hardy, John's wife, who also works at the company, he substantially reworked the book.
In the end, the joke may be on New York's publishing elite and the literary critics who guard its gates so viciously. At first Hardy was to print only 25,000 copies of "Roads," self-consciously copying the build-slowly pattern that hoisted "Bridges," but the book-buyer response at the wholesale level has been so large that the first printing is now about 250,000, already positioning the book for best-seller territory.
Of course, just because bookstores stock it does not mean fans will buy it. But already one reader has read the new version and liked it. "It was a mistake," said Warner's Mr. Kirshbaum "If I had my life to live over again, we would have published it. I think it is going to be a big hit."

HEADLINE: Interactive TV Is Finally Here, Sort Of 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky. 

 BODY:
INTERACTIVE television has arrived. It is not widespread, but it is here -- right here, in the home of Steve and Vanessa Murphy. 
 When the Murphys don't feel like going out for an evening, they can curl up on the couch, pick up the television remote and choose from among 200 on-demand movies offered by their cable company, Insight Communications. The movie starts immediately, and they can pause, fast-forward and rewind it as if it were a Blockbuster video. 
 If their teenage son, Reinaldo, wants to go to the local multiplex with friends, he can browse showtimes on the television screen. On weekday mornings Mrs. Murphy can pull up the local weather report when she wants to know how to dress her two daughters, Lauren, 9, and Kayla, 7, for school. She can even call up the school lunch menu with her remote control. In the evenings the family gathers around the television set to play trivia games. 
All that and more than 100 television channels, too. 
After decades of false starts, interactive television is creeping into millions of American living rooms. If you have not seen it, you may think it does not exist, but to families like the Murphys, it has become part of their daily routine. 
"Before, you had a little black box that you could flip channels on," said Reinaldo, 17. "That was it. Now it's everything you could want." 
Forrester Research, a technology consulting company, estimates that by the end of this year, about 15 percent of the 105 million United States households with television sets will have some kind of interactive service -- almost double last year's number. The growth has been spurred by fierce competition among cable and satellite services and by the falling costs of the technology. 
Unlike the grandiose dreams of the past, interactive services currently available in the United States seem rather modest. They include video on demand, expanded content for channels like ESPN and the Weather Channel, and virtual channels to provide local information like restaurant listings or sell books, pizza and other products. 
What American viewers are unlikely to see anytime soon is two-way interactivity with programs through the television set, a longtime ambition of broadcasters and advertisers. Hybrid Internet-television services like AOLTV and MSN TV have experimented with interactive programming, but with fewer than one million users, they have not held much appeal for broadcasters. In two-way interactivity, the United States is far behind Britain, the country where interactive television is perhaps most advanced. 
In the United States, early experiments in interactivity were ambitious but disappointing. They included the Qube system from Warner Amex Cable Communications in Columbus, Ohio, in the 1970's and the Full Service Network from Time Warner in Orlando, Fla., in the mid-1990's. The Qube system allowed viewers to vote on issues during talk shows. 
Both services were stymied by cost. The set-top box for Time Warner's system cost $7,000, compared with the $200 to $300 for current digital set-top cable boxes. 
Now interactivity is gaining a foothold, though in less ambitious forms. In part, the earlier experiments taught cable operators what works and what does not. What works are features that satellite television finds difficult to match: video on demand and local content. 
The growth of interactivity is also furthered by the simple fact that no home electronic device is as pervasive as television. More than 98 percent of American households have a television set and more than 80 percent of households subscribe to cable or satellite television. Only about 60 percent of households have PC's. 
The PC has yet to achieve the shrinelike status of the television set. While people have been conditioned to pay for television content, there is still resistance to paying for entertainment on the Internet -- pornography and gambling excepted. For all the talk of convergence, consumers are bent on keeping PC and TV separate. 
So now, cable subscribers in Hawaii can perform karaoke and order pizza with their remotes. Many cable viewers can punch up "Shrek" or other popular movies for instant viewing. EchoStar satellite subscribers will soon be able to play games on their television sets. 
Few companies exemplify the trend toward interactivity better than Insight, the nation's ninth-largest cable operator, which has introduced such systems to its 1.4 million customers, most of whom live in Kentucky, Indiana, Ohio and Illinois. 
Insight's strategy is to think local. Its LocalSource application includes information on traffic conditions and local band performances. "You could look at this and think this is gritty, stupid little stuff," said Josh Bernoff, an analyst at Forrester Research. "When they say people love this, they are not just making it up." 
Patrick O'Leary, an Insight subscriber in Louisville, said: "Movie listings are so easy. I don't have to call some annoying voice system. I don't have to pull out some paper. I don't have to log on to the Internet. I can just come in and turn on the television." When Mr. O'Leary's 9-year-old son, Connor, is bored, he can order a movie or play a game on TV. 
Digital cable and interactive television were introduced in Louisville about a year ago. Since then, nearly one-third of Insight's customers have signed up for digital cable and two-thirds of its new customers are ordering it. Digital customers pay an average of $20 more per month than traditional analog customers. "Customers don't buy digital cable for the interactive television, but it is why they keep it," said Michael S. Willner, chief executive of Insight. 
Insight customers have Motorola set-top boxes with 6.8 megabytes of RAM running software from Liberate Technologies. 
Insight's flavor of interactive television is unlikely to become a national model. A major reason is that the cable landscape is geographically fractured, with companies pursuing different strategies.
Almost all large cable companies, however, have plans to offer some video on demand. Some companies are experimenting with subscription services in which viewers are offered unlimited access to programs for a monthly fee. Insight, for example, offers all the "Teletubbies" or other children's shows that a toddler can watch for $9.95 a month. Since July, Time Warner has been testing HBO on Demand on cable systems on Long Island and in Cincinnati, Cleveland, Austin, Tex., and Columbia, S.C. 
Rainbow Media, a subsidiary of Cablevision, has created an on-demand subscription service called Mag Rack that offers niche programming for birdwatchers, motorcyclists, vegetarians and Roman Catholics -- offerings that do not generate enough demand to justify a channel of their own. 
To compete with cable's video-on-demand services, the satellite operators EchoStar and DirecTV are building digital video recorders into their latest generation of satellite receivers that will record what the user wants to see for viewing at any time. They are also adding games and enhanced content on channels like ESPN and the Weather Channel. 
The rise of satellite services in the last few years has provided much of the impetus for developing new interactive features. In eight years, satellite providers have captured more than 20 percent of the pay television market. Cable companies are spending billions on digital services, not so much because they want to as because they have to. 
The focus on video on demand and channels for local content and commerce contrasts sharply with the interactive arena in Britain, which has focused on programming. 
"In Britain, interactive television is transforming the way people watch television," said James Ackerman, the chief executive of OpenTV, which provides interactive television software worldwide. 
Sports fans can choose from four camera angles for soccer games. Children can vote for which program they want Nickelodeon to broadcast on Sunday afternoon.
But the British have not neglected shopping: viewers can purchase products direct from QVC with a "buy now" button, which became available in September. Already, 10 percent of QVC sales in Britain are made through the television rather than by telephone or online. 
British Sky Broadcasting, which has more than five million digital subscribers, offers hundreds of channels as alternatives to the nation's five broadcast channels. That digital subscriber audience, nearly a quarter of Britain's television households, has given broadcasters an incentive to create interactive applications. 
In the United States, there is a hodgepodge of standards and a lack of dominant players, so widespread interactivity in television programs seems far away. 
That does not mean that viewers like the Murphys and O'Learys are unhappy with their service. They are quite satisfied, even if they wonder at times what all the fuss is about. Interactivity has become such a given to Insight customers that they do not realize that most viewers in the country do not have those services. 
"They assume that I have this too," said Mr. Willner, whose cable system in the New York area does not offer interactivity. "You want to jump up and down and say, 'Don't you realize what you have here?' "

HEADLINE: In Southeast Asia, a Wary Optimism 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, April 3 

 BODY:
The waves of America's apparent economic recovery are poised to break over Southeast Asia, many economists say. But despite the rosiest economic forecasts in years, skepticism abounds in the region.
 Michael D. Ruslim, a director at PT Astra International, is among those not holding his breath. 
 Astra manufactures and distributes the best-selling cars and motorcycles in Indonesia, the region's largest economy. Its vehicles are everywhere, from Toyota minivans grinding through city traffic jams to Honda motorcycles crisscrossing rural rice paddies. Even so, the company has found the going tough, its struggles emblematic of the region's post-1997 travails. 
Mired in debt, Astra survived the region's financial crisis only by laying off thousands of workers, selling some assets and taking on a foreign company, Cycle and Carriage of Singapore, as its largest shareholder.
Now, despite signs of recovery across the Pacific, Astra predicts that sales this year and next will be flat. Business prospects are drying up for the small enterprises and families that make up the bulk of the company's customers, Mr. Ruslim said.
After weathering the global recession in better shape than many economists had expected, Southeast Asia's economies are being fueled by heavy government spending, low interest rates and buoyant consumer spending. A recovery in exports to the United States will round out the picture, they say, providing a gentler rebound than the V-shaped recovery Southeast Asia experienced in 1999 after its financial crisis, but a rebound nonetheless.
"We are entering a period of sustained but gradual growth for the next two years," said William C. Belchere, head of economics and fixed-income strategy at Merrill Lynch in Singapore.
The question hounding skeptics is one shared by policy makers hoping to curb the kind of poverty that helps drive young people in Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim nation, and the Philippines into the arms of religious extremists: Will the rebound be strong enough to replace the thousands of jobs lost during the downturn and create enough new ones for the legions of young job seekers?
According to Mr. Ruslim and others, that depends in part on whether the rebound brings foreign investment with it and whether the economic woes of Japan, once Southeast Asia's biggest investor, and the increasing economic competition from China extend the decline. The biggest investment banks clearly are not optimistic: Credit Suisse First Boston, Goldman Sachs, Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch have all pared back their Southeast Asian operations.
Southeast Asia's stock markets are jumping as they expect a rebound, but the signs of the incipient rebound are subtle. Exports are still falling, but more slowly than before. Industrial production figures indicate that this trend may soon be reversed, economists say, and it is just a matter of time before American managers regain the confidence to start placing orders with Southeast Asian factories.
"You won't actually see the export numbers themselves look all that impressive until midyear," said David G. Fernandez, head of Asian sovereign research at J. P. Morgan in Singapore.
The signs can vary even within a single company. Hewlett-Packard, for example, says there is robust demand for its customer resource management and other systems from mobile phone operators and banks that are competing to offer new services. But from the region's export manufacturers, said Leong Han Kong, Hewlett-Packard's general manager for sales and marketing in Southeast Asia, "we're still not seeing a strong signal yet." He added, "Corporations are very cautious about spending."
Nowhere is that split truer than in Thailand, the region's second-largest economy. Though Thai banks and telecommunications operators are still spending, Mr. Leong said electronics manufacturers were cutting back as they lost business to China.
Though foreign investment in Thailand jumped last year, it has yet to recover to precrisis levels. Instead, Thailand's economy has been held above water by consumers, who have responded to record lows in interest rates by buying computers, cars and new homes.
Tiny, affluent Singapore is Southeast Asia's third-largest economy, and it is more dependent on demand in the United States for high-technology products than any of its neighbors. Because of that dependence, it was the only Southeast Asian nation to slip into recession as the American bubble burst. But it also means that Singapore has the most to gain from a recovery. Even so, the government is trying to steer Singapore into areas, like chemicals and pharmaceuticals, where it has an edge over cheaper competitors.
"We know we've got to reposition ourselves," said Tharman Shanmugaratnam, the senior minister of state for trade and industry. "China has basically changed the equation."
Indonesia remains Southeast Asia's biggest question mark. It is more than just the region's biggest economy.
Indonesia's troubles reverberate throughout the region. Its forest fires obscure its neighbors' skies. Its migrant workers seek jobs abroad, filling detention centers and putting pressure on other labor markets. And its pirates menace the region's shipping lanes.
Rising oil prices augur well for Indonesian exports. Moreover, Indonesia is less reliant than its neighbors on exports and large enough to survive on domestic consumption, provided that there is sufficient investment and growth to raise real wages. According to the World Bank's Indonesia economist, Vikram Nehru, "sufficient" means growth of 5 percent to 6 percent.
But real wages have stagnated, according to Mr. Nehru. And rural unrest, labor strife and bureaucratic intransigence combine to hinder investment, both foreign and domestic.
Mr. Ruslim knows this firsthand. A strike last year at one of Astra's suppliers halted sales for two months. And plans to sell its oil-palm plantations to foreign investors fell apart after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in the United States.
Some economists say investors can take comfort in what is bound to be a more lenient, post-Sept. 11 stance by Indonesia's official creditors, including the World Bank.
But Mr. Nehru said the onus was more than ever on the administration of President Megawati Sukarnoputri. Rekindling investment, he said, "depends on the government's ability to maintain steady reforms and bring back confidence in the economy."

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal; 
Sushi Comes Home, With Cream Cheese and Chili

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 29 

 BODY:
As a Japanese college student working in an expensive Chicago sushi restaurant a decade ago, Yoko Shibata was jolted with culture shock as she watched boisterous American customers drinking cocktails with their meals and shouting over loud music as they ate.
 Her surprise only deepened as she watched the regulars order custom-made sushi dishes -- combinations like eel, cucumber and cream cheese, or flying-fish roe, red chili and mayonnaise. 
 But in an era of boomerang globalization, with Starbucks selling espresso to Italians, and California cabernets airing on European tables, Ms. Shibata decided that when she moved back to Tokyo she would bring American-style sushi with her. 
Last year, Ms. Shibata opened her restaurant, Rainbow Roll Sushi, and in testament to her inspiration, business is booming, despite Japan's difficult economic climate.
Ms. Shibata was a pioneer in a culinary cross-fertilization that has brought several inventive sushi restaurants here recently, mostly in upscale neighborhoods like Azabujuban, where cosmopolitan young professionals often gather.
The high-speed ricochet of American and other influences across the Pacific is all the more remarkable considering that sushi itself was one of the more exotic transplants to the West.
The decor in Rainbow Roll Sushi reflects the global hybridization as brazenly as the food itself. Traditional Japanese sushi restaurants, especially upscale ones, display a Zen-like austerity dominated by sober cedar accents, from slatted doors to the glistening dining counters, where the food is often served without plates.
Rainbow Roll Sushi, on the other hand, has gray felt wallpaper and matching low slung chairs with a long marble counter and gently wafting Hawaiian music by day and bouncy Latin tunes by night. "I designed everything myself, from the uniform and menu to the tableware," said Ms. Shibata, 30, who calls herself Rainbow Roll Sushi's "producer" rather than its manager or director. "Ordinarily, with a decor like ours, you would expect to hear jazz, wouldn't you? We aim for anything but the ordinary."
At another flourishing, newfangled sushi restaurant, Central Mikunis, near Tokyo Station, the opulent design marries Renaissance Europe with contemporary Los Angeles, with its vaulting, painted ceilings and brushed aluminum walls.
The food at Central Mikunis is served at barside with revolving conveyor -- an innovation introduced to traditional sushi bars in the late 1960's -- that bring an array of delicacies within reach.
As with Rainbow Roll Sushi, though, the real departure from tradition is in the menu. One of Mikuni's specialties, for example, is a sushi sandwich, made with tiny croissants.
Rainbow Roll has succeeded with the affluent, well-traveled people in their 30's. But it has also been a hit with curious housewives. Men in their 40's and older, though, have mostly stayed away, except when dragged there by daughters or dates.
"In a traditional Japanese sushi restaurant, when you are finished eating, you must get up and leave," said Kinuko Sawayama, 23, one of two smartly dressed university students having lunch together. "Here, they have sofas and comfortable chairs, and in the evening there is a lively ambiance."
"You can really feel the internationalization that Japan is undergoing through places like this," said her friend Lisa Yanagisawa, also 23. "And the delicious combinations are changing the way that younger people, like me, think about Japanese food."
Many sushi chefs scoff at such recipes, as they stick to their traditional ways. "I can't comment on this, because the reaction of each sushi master is different," said Shigeo Mori, a famous chef who heads Japan's sushi chefs union. "Some of us accept the new imports, but others don't regard it as sushi at all."
At bottom, the blossoming of new forms like these in one of the most prestigious and tradition-bound areas of the country's cuisine reflects the tensions between profound, yet seemingly contradictory traits of Japanese culture: a reverence for heavily ritualized techniques, or kata, and an eager acceptance of imported innovations and trends.
Experts say that while maybe imperceptible to diners, sushi making methods have changed over, well, centuries.
"What we call onigiri today may seem traditional, but it doesn't have such a long history, only to the mid-1800's," said Kazunari Yanagihara, a television chef, teacher and culinary critic, referring to the vinegary rice -- squeezed into thumb-like segments -- that is the basis of most sushi.
Today fatty, succulent tuna, or maguro, is so popular in sushi cuisine that for most Japanese eating sushi means eating tuna. A little more than a century ago, however, Mr. Yanagihara said maguro was not popular at all.
"Since World War II our tastes and cooking methods have been changing more and more rapidly," he said. "If you compare the food of today to the food of the 1970's, there is probably twice as much fat being used. More and more, young people want fatty dishes, and these kinds of tastes are making foreign cuisines fashionable."
Mr. Yanagihara said critics who would dismiss the use of ingredients like cream cheese and mayonnaise in what many still call "re-imported sushi" as nothing more than trendiness should be mindful of Japanese culinary history.
"Upper-class people used to dismiss sukiyaki, too, which was invented a little more than century ago," he said. "Today, though, it is seen as genuinely Japanese cuisine. It is possible that some day this new sushi, with things like avocado and mayonnaise will become accepted, or even celebrated. Only time will tell."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES; 
Price ofCrude Oil Is Down For First Time in 6 Sessions

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil fell for the first time in six sessions yesterday after the American Petroleum Institute reported that United States inventories had their biggest weekly gain in 11 months.
 The increase came as tankers made deliveries to refineries in Houston after having been delayed by fog in late March. 
 Prices were up about 8 percent from a week ago as violence between Israel and the Palestinians added to concerns that Middle East supplies might be disrupted. 
"Prices fell after the inventory report, though with the unsettled Middle East we aren't getting as dramatic a move down as one might have expected," said Abe Glass, the president of Glass Futures, an energy brokerage firm in New York.
Crude oil for May delivery fell 15 cents, to $27.56 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices fell as low as $27.15 during the session.
Oil rose on Tuesday to $28.10 a barrel, the highest price since Sept. 18.
In London, crude oil for May settlement fell 39 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $27.27 a barrel on the International Petroleum Exchange.
Oil prices rebounded from the day's lows on reports that Egypt would limit diplomatic contacts with Israel. Egypt and Jordan are the only Arab states with embassies in Israel.
Israel reportedly expanded its West Bank offensive yesterday.
United States inventories of crude oil rose 6.5 million barrels, or 2.1 percent, to 322 million barrels in the week ended Friday, the highest level since June, the institute's report showed. The delay in tanker deliveries caused a decline of 6.2 million barrels in last week's report.
The jump in oil supplies has "taken some steam out of the rally," said Chester Irvin, a crude oil broker at ABN Amro in New York.
Prices had been rising as tensions in the Middle East escalated, not because of the fundamentals of supply and demand, he said.
Supplies of gasoline rose 3.87 million barrels, or 1.9 percent, to 209 million barrels, the first rise in six weeks, the institute said. Supplies were 8.7 percent higher than year-earlier levels.
Gasoline futures for May delivery fell 2.14 cents, or 2.5 percent, at 84.84 cents a gallon on the New York exchange. Prices reached their highest in nine and a half months on Tuesday.
"Gasoline is showing what should be happening in the market, based on stockpiles," said David Becker, energy derivatives trading manager at Citibank in New York. Turbulence in the Middle East provides "a solid bid underlying the crude oil market," he said.

PERSON: Wolfgang F. Stolper 

HEADLINE: W. F. Stolper, Trade Theory Economist, Is Dead at 89 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Wolfgang F. Stolper, an economist who more than 60 years ago inspired a theory about international trade that to this day helps to explain its effect on national economies, died on Sunday in Ann Arbor, Mich., where he lived. He was 89.
 The breakthrough insight, known as the Stolper-Samuelson theorem, came in 1941 when Mr. Stolper was a young instructor at Harvard and a colleague of Paul A. Samuelson. Mr. Samuelson was exploring trade theory, which held then that open trade benefited the economies of the trading nations and their work forces. 
 That was when Mr. Stolper came to Mr. Samuelson with a caveat. Trade stimulates greater economic growth, Mr. Stolper agreed, but is not necessarily beneficial for all workers. As trade between countries rises, prices change, scarcity and abundance come into play, and the wages of some workers -- the abundant ones -- fall.
"Stolper came to me with this very important insight," Mr. Samuelson recalled yesterday, "and I said: 'That is really important. It is not in the literature, and you should write it up.' "
"I was the midwife for the Stolper-Samuelson theorem, which is Stolper-Samuelson, not Samuelson-Stolper," he added.
Although trade theory has greatly evolved since the 1940's, the Stolper insight has remained an essential part.
In contrast to Mr. Samuelson, a Nobel laureate, Mr. Stolper never again achieved another breakthrough in theory equal to the insight that has made his name so well known in his profession. He went on to specialize in developing-country economics, an interest that grew out of his research on East Germany and a book, "The Structure of the East German Economy."
Mr. Stolper moved from Harvard to Swarthmore College in 1941 and to the University of Michigan in 1949, teaching economics there until he retired in 1983. Along with teaching, Mr. Stolper took on a parallel role as an adviser abroad, most notably in Nigeria. In the early 1960's, he served for a year as the chief economic adviser to the struggling government of that newly independent nation.
Out of that experience came a book, "Planning Without Facts." At his death, Mr. Stolper was preparing a memoir based on his Nigerian experiences, drawn from the letters he wrote almost daily to his wife, Martha Vogeli Stolper, who was in Ann Arbor. 
Wolfgang Frederich Stolper was born in Vienna on May 13, 1912. After World War I, the family moved to Bonn, where Mr. Stolper's father, Gustav, published a weekly economics journal, served one term in Parliament and introduced his son to the famous economist Joseph A. Schumpeter, who became the young man's mentor, not only in Germany but also later at Harvard. Mr. Stolper wrote a biography of his mentor, "Joseph Alois Schumpeter," which was published in 1994.
The Stolper family fled to the United States after Hitler rose to power in 1933. Entering Harvard as a graduate student, Mr. Stolper received a doctorate in economics in 1938. But economics was only one interest. An accomplished pianist, Mr. Stolper had two grand pianos in his Ann Arbor home and regularly invited guests to the house for chamber music concerts.
His first wife died in 1972. He is survived by his second wife, Margot Kaufmann; two sons, Matthew W., of Chicago, and Thomas E., of New Haven; a brother, Max, of Alexandria, Va.; and a sister, Joan Campbell, of Toronto.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Service Economy Slowdown Helps Send Shares Lower

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell to their lowest level in more than a month yesterday after a report showing a slowdown in the service economy added to concerns over fighting in the Middle East.
 Adelphia Communications and the Williams Companies dropped after becoming the latest companies to say the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating their accounting practices amid increased investor scrutiny since the collapse of Enron. 
 "The psychological overhang from the Middle East and corporate accounting issues will tend to keep us from doing as well as we should be for the next couple of months," said Alfred Kugel, a strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham, which manages $25 billion in Chicago. 
Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing led the Dow Jones industrial average down 115.42 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,198.29. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 11.36 points, or 1 percent, to 1,125.40, paced by Microsoft. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 20.05 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,784.35. All three gauges dipped to the lowest since Feb. 28.
Earnings at companies in the S.& P. 500 are forecast to rise 8.7 percent in the second quarter, according to Thomson Financial. 
"Investors have to ratchet down their expectations for earnings," said Stephen Atkins, who manages $2 billion at Northern Trust Value Investors. "It will be an average profit recovery, maybe not even that high."
Stocks slid after a report showed services, the biggest part of the economy, expanded at a slower pace in March than in February, citing a survey of purchasing executives. 
Since peace talks broke down March 21 between Israel and the Palestinians, daily trading on the New York Stock Exchange has fallen 13 percent from the average for the year as the fighting escalated.
"What's getting everyone nervous is what's going on in Israel," said Barry Savitz, a trader at Greenwich Prime Trading, which manages transactions for 40 hedge funds in Greenwich, Conn.
Minnesota Mining, which makes products ranging from Scotchguard to respirators, slipped $2.08, to $112.91. A Lehman Brothers analyst, Donald Zwyer, said 3M shares were richly valued and he was concerned about slowing sales and higher costs. The shares have risen 67 percent in the last six months.
Microsoft dropped 97 cents, to $56.33.
Adelphia dropped 79 cents, to $11.04. The company said the S.E.C. was investigating whether it adequately disclosed $2.3 billion in debt.
Williams, a pipeline company and energy trader, shed $1.09, to $23.08, after saying the S.E.C. asked about third-quarter earnings. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
(By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, led by gains in short-term notes as tensions in the Middle East and a fourth day of losses in blue-chip stocks prompted investors to bet that the Federal Reserve would not be quick to raise interest rates in coming months.
By late in the day, the two-year note rose 5/32, to a price of 100 6/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 3.53 percent from 3.61 percent on Tuesday. The price of a 10-year note increased 16/32, to 96 31/32. Its yield dropped to 5.27 percent from 5.34 percent.
The 30-year bond also climbed, rising 20/32, to 94 6/32. Its yield fell to 5.72 percent from 5.76 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Two cable networks cooperate in a bid to cut through clutter.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
WHILE weather can be mundane, it can also be dramatic, and in that vein two cable television networks are joining forces to promote special, related programs on both channels this month.
 The unusual joint venture involves the A&E Network, which is presenting "Shackleton," a two-part, four-hour movie about a famous expedition to the South Pole in 1914, and the Weather Channel, which is presenting a five-part, five-hour program titled "StormWeek," about severe weather conditions. 
 The joint cross-promotional campaign, with an estimated budget of $10 million, is indicative of efforts being made in the crowded cable television universe to attract viewers to special programming. It comes after media conglomerates like the Walt Disney Company, the News Corporation and Viacom Inc. have been using their expansive holdings to promote shows among their various properties. 
For instance, A&E, which is owned in part by the ABC unit of Disney, is rerunning the daytime talk show "The View" the day after it appears on ABC. A&E, which is also owned by the Hearst Corporation and the NBC division of General Electric, cross-promotes with a sibling, the History Channel.
"In this day and age, where competition is so great, networks can't isolate themselves," said Michael Mohamad, senior vice president for marketing at A&E in New York. "They're going to have to reach outside for -- I hate to say this, I'm not corny -- 'out-of-the-box' opportunities."
"Little bits and pieces of your audience are going to different places because there are so many different special-interest networks," he added. "Now, you really need to get your message out there as broadly as you can."
Executives at A&E and the Weather Channel said they recognized that because the two networks shared an audience of men and women ages 25 to 54, it would make sense to promote weather-related programming on both networks.
"Shackleton," which will be shown on Sunday and Monday, is a dramatization of the South Pole expedition led by Sir Ernest H. Shackleton, portrayed by Kenneth Branagh, in which he and his crew survived gales and ice floes that trapped and crushed his ship.
"StormWeek," which returned on Monday for a second year, focuses on weather extremes like tornadoes and blizzards. The episodes will include a new segment meant to take viewers into the eye of a storm; there will also be additional film on the Weather Channel Web site, weather.com.
Cross-promotion can also be cost-effective.
"We're in the middle of a media recession," said Steve Schiffman, executive vice president for marketing at the Weather Channel in Atlanta, which is owned by Landmark Communications. "It wasn't like we had inflated budgets where we had extra resources at our disposal to build awareness of various programming initiatives."
The cross-network campaign encourages viewers to tune in to both programs with a television commercial as well as efforts online that include banner ads and links between the Weather Channel site and the A&E site, www.AandE.com.
In addition, Paul Kocin, a Weather Channel winter-storm expert, will talk about the conditions Sir Ernest faced in "Making of Shackleton" on A&E, and Charles Sturridge, the writer and director of "Shackleton," will be interviewed on the Weather Channel's Web site.
The channels, which will also have independent campaigns for their programs, worked with the New York office of the GEM Group, owned by CSS Stellar, to ensure the promotion was fairly balanced. A banner ad on the Weather Channel's Web site, for example, is not equivalent to a banner ad on the A&E Web site because weather.com has far more unique users each month. Similarly, a 30-second spot is more valuable on A&E than on the Weather Channel.
The partnership between A&E and the Weather Channel was a long time in coming. Mr. Mohamad and Mr. Schiffman had talked about a similar effort a few years ago, when A&E was beginning "Horatio Hornblower," a film about an 18th-century British naval officer.
"The timing wasn't right," Mr. Mohamad said.
Then, last July, Mr. Mohamad and Mr. Schiffman attended a conference in San Francisco for the Cable and Telecommunications Association for Marketing and were seated next to each other at a dinner also attended by John Zamoiski, president at the GEM Entertainment unit of GEM.
Mr. Mohamad started talking about "Shackleton," Mr. Schiffman said, and "beautiful music happened" because the movie was so closely related to the weather. Soon afterward, executives from both networks held a meeting and conference call to start the project.
"It was like one big blind date," Mr. Schiffman said, adding that they exchanged e-mail addresses and phone numbers.
The two networks are discussing future cross-promotions and are open to similar partnerships with other networks.
Though they still track results like ratings to see how successful the cross-promotion is, the executives are pleased.
"We just had lunch last week," Mr. Mohamad said, "to congratulate ourselves."
