HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
When it comes to income inequality, more than just market forces are at work.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
NEARLY 50 years ago, Simon Kuznets, the father of national-income accounting and a Nobel laureate in economic science, predicted that income inequality would follow an inverted-U pattern over time -- "widening in the early phases of economic growth when the transition from the preindustrial to the industrial society was most rapid; becoming stabilized for a while; and then narrowing in the later phases."
 New research that updates and extends this classic work, however, turns the Kuznets curve on its head. 
 Income disparities seem to follow no automatic pattern. Instead, for long stretches the degree of inequality appears to result from norms and social policy, especially taxes, at least as much as from economic forces of supply and demand. In the United States, the Kuznets curve -- the trend in inequality over time -- is better described by a U shape than an inverted U. In Britain and France, the curve is more like an L. 
As Gary Fields of Cornell observed: "The Kuznets curve is neither a law nor even a central tendency. The pattern is that there is no pattern."
The latest blow to the Kuznets curve was struck by Thomas Piketty of Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales, in Paris, and Emmanuel Saez of Harvard. In a study, "Income Inequality in the United States, 1913-1998" (available at www.nber.org), they provide estimates of the share of total income going to top earners. As did Kuznets, they calculated the share of total personal income earned by top income groups from tax records. Because only a fraction of citizens were required to pay taxes early in the century, they compute total income from other sources.
They found that the share of income going to the top 10 percent of families grew from 40 percent at the start of the 1920's, to 45 percent, and remained near that level throughout the Depression. The top 10 percent's share fell sharply at the beginning of America's involvement in World War II, from 44 percent in 1940, to 32 percent in 1944. 
The share of income going to the top 1 percent also fell a third from 1940 to 1944, to 11 percent from 16 percent. 
The sudden drop in inequality during World War II, though inconsistent with Kuznets's gradual process, is easy to explain: wage controls during the war compressed pay. What is puzzling is that the more equal distribution that emerged under the controls persisted for 30 years before inequality began to rise again in the late 1970's.
If wage controls artificially compressed market forces, one would have expected inequality to grow sharply when the controls were lifted. It did not. Indeed, the share of income going to the top 1 percent and top 0.1 percent drifted downward for 20 years after the war, before stabilizing for a decade or so and then surging in the 1980's and 1990's.
Why? Professors Piketty and Saez suggest that the new wage patterns established during the war were difficult to reverse, even with competitive forces pushing in the opposite direction.
They also discovered something quite unexpected about the composition of income received by the very rich. Before the 1940's, the wealthiest Americans earned the bulk of their income from returns on capital; now their primary source is wages and salaries. In 1916, for example, the top 0.01 percent of "tax units" earned 70 percent of their income from capital, 24 percent from business ventures and only 6 percent from wages. By 1998, wages and salaries accounted for 45 percent of the very top group's income; business activities, 33 percent; and return on capital, 22 percent.
Because capital's share of national income has been stable, this shift must involve a more equal ownership of capital. Professors Piketty and Saez argue that the shift came about because of progressive taxation on capital income. In 1931, the top marginal rate was 20 percent. The Roosevelt administration increased the top rate during the Depression, eventually to 91 percent in 1944, so that the wealthy would shoulder more of the financial burden of the war. Top rates remained high until the 1980's. Professors Piketty and Saez stress that capital taxation has a cumulative effect on top incomes because it reduces the net return on today's wealth, which generates tomorrow's wealth.
So today the rich are not so different from the rest of us after all: they work for a living, too.
But they earn a lot more money. In 2001, the average chief executive of an industrial company with approximately $500 million in sales was paid $1.9 million, according to the Towers Perrin Worldwide Total Remuneration Report. The average N.B.A. player will earn more than $4 million this season, and the average Major League Baseball player more than $2.1 million. 
After adjusting for inflation, salaries of chief executives grew about 6 percent a year in the 1980's and 90's, while those of basketball and baseball players grew more than 10 percent a year. Wage growth has been so strong at the high end that the top 1 percent of taxpayers have taken home 94 percent of the growth in total income since 1973.
Salaries at the top of the range seem to be particularly affected by prevailing norms and policy decisions. The pay of American chief executives is three times that of their counterparts in similar-size companies in Britain and four times those in France and Germany, according to Towers Perrin. The average chief executive is paid 24 times what the average production worker gets in the United States, but in Germany, only 8 times as much. It is hard to argue that their work or economic circumstances are so different to justify such large pay differences. 
Further, Kevin Hallock of the University of Illinois has found that chief executives are paid more in the United States if they sit on one another's boards, suggesting that buddies matter.
The pay of professional athletes has grown rapidly in part because public subsidies for stadiums increase team revenues, and barriers to entry prevent competition.
So the capital-rich rentier class has been replaced by handsomely paid executives, athletes and entrepreneurs.
But Professor Saez predicts, "If the estate tax goes away and top income rates are cut, a new generation of rentiers should reappear down the road."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
UBS PaineWebber to Settle A Pension Fund Dispute
UBS PaineWebber has agreed to pay $10.3 million to settle a two-year dispute with Nashville, which had accused the firm of charging excessive fees for managing its pension fund, understating the risks in the fund's portfolio and misleading it about recommended investment strategies.
 Central to the dispute was PaineWebber's role as exclusive investment consultant to the $1.4 billion fund and the manner in which it was paid for its services. Page C4. 

Kirch Teeters on Edge of Bankruptcy
The Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company run by Leo Kirch, left, teetered on the edge of bankruptcy after rescue talks with bankers and investors, including Rupert Murdoch, broke down. A bankruptcy filing would shake up Germany's entire media industry and would have important political implications. World Business, Section W.

Microsoft Case Revisits Key Issue
The hearings over Microsoft's antitrust case returned to what has been the most hotly contested question since the government filed its suit four years ago: can a court tell the software maker how to design its own code? C4.

Microsoft's president and chief operating officer, Richard Belluzo, will step down. C4.

A British Group Reprimands Pfizer
A trade group representing British pharmaceutical companies has reprimanded Pfizer for promoting several medicines for unapproved uses and marketing another drug before it received government approval. C5.

Gas Group Had President's Ear
President Bush signed an executive order last year that closely resembles a written recommendation given to the administration two months earlier by the American Gas Association, according to documents released by the Bush administration. A18.

Philip Morris Tries to Sell Miller
Philip Morris has put Miller Brewing on the block for about $5 billion, shaving $1 billion off its initial asking price, enough to draw South African Breweries back into negotiations, people close to the talks said. The companies have held intermittent talks for several years. C2.

Dow, Nasdaq and S.& P. Drop 1%
Stocks fell to their lowest level in more than a month. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 115.42 points, or 1.1 percent, to 10,198.29. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 11.36 points, or 1 percent, to 1,125.40. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 20.05 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,784.35. C7.

Crude Oil Ends Its Five-Day Slide
Crude oil fell for the first time in six sessions yesterday after the American Petroleum Institute reported that United States inventories had their biggest weekly gain in 11 months. Crude oil for May delivery fell 15 cents, to $27.56 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Prices were up about 8 percent from a week ago as violence between Israel and the Palestinians added to concerns that Middle East supplies might be disrupted. C7.

Services Expands at Slower Pace
Services, the biggest part of the economy, expanded in March at a slower pace than the previous month, a survey found. C13.

Former Economic Czar Is Arrested
Domingo Cavallo, who as the all-powerful minister of the economy was the architect both of Argentina's rapid economic growth in the 1990's and its collapse late last year, was arrested in Buenos Aires on suspicion of involvement in "aggravated contraband." A3.

Income disparities seem to follow no automatic pattern. Over time, the degree of inequality appears to result from norms and social policy, especially taxes, at least as much as from economic forces of supply and demand. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

PERSON: JACKIE MAXWELL 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A Union Maid? Actually a Nanny, Organizing

BYLINE:  By LYNDA RICHARDSON 

 BODY:
JACKIE MAXWELL, hands shoved deep into her jean pockets, is telling the story sitting down. That's a good thing, because she is truly peeved as she recounts what she heard from a fellow nanny. The nanny, a Salvadoran woman who accompanied a little boy to a play date in the home where Ms. Maxwell works, mentioned how a former employer used to lock her in an apartment basement at night, not letting her out until the next morning, not even offering a bed.
 As she recalls the story, Ms. Maxwell is getting more furious by the minute. But with 22 years in the business, she's heard and seen many things. 
 On this morning, she's working at her other part-time job, that of Cain-raising advocate for Domestic Workers United, a fledgling coalition in the city that wants basic labor rights for housekeepers, nannies and companions to the elderly. The group shares space in an airy four-story building, a former convent in the Bronx. Ms. Maxwell told the Salvadoran woman about a meeting on April 6 in which workers would testify before City Council members about abuses.
"It's like holding her prisoner," says Ms. Maxwell, whose wide, freckled face is framed by close-cropped gray hair. "This is like the 20th story I've heard of how people who employ domestic workers use it as a power surge to treat them like a slave."
Ms. Maxwell, 52, recently presided over a news conference on the steps of City Hall. She has become one of the group's most outspoken leaders, yet she's an anomaly. She's the only African-American in an 80-member group of immigrant women from the Caribbean and Latin and Asian countries. She reflects a quiet shift in the industry's demographics over the last 15 or so years. As the civil rights movement has opened other doors for African-American women, immigrants have largely taken their place.
Dressed in black jeans and a black sweater, Ms. Maxwell has a quiet air about her, but she is far from shy. She has a robust laugh and is quite a talker.
The conversation turns to "Gone With the Wind" and Mammy, that stereotypical image of black servitude played by Hattie McDaniel. "It put knots in my stomach," Ms. Maxwell says, squirming, her face scrunched. It's hard to imagine anyone pulling a Scarlett O'Hara on her.
Ms. Maxwell gets downright explosive when she talks about the industry she wants to change. She is trying to win support for a bill that was introduced last week in the City Council that would require employment agencies to tell families hiring workers about their legal obligations to pay minimum wage and overtime, and to follow a code of conduct.
I WANT things to be better for the women who come after us," she says in a rush of words. "I just feel I can be an active tool to express their grievances and concerns. In this industry, we all suffer the same problems."
Ms. Maxwell, who is single and has two grown children, was raised in Brownsville, Brooklyn, by a grandmother who was a housekeeper. She moved there after her father, a police detective, and her mother, a department store cashier, separated when she was 8. She says her grandmother worked very hard, never complaining.
"In that era," she says, "it might have been a lot tougher for her, but she just accepted it."
Ms. Maxwell, who now lives in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has no complaints about the job she has held for nine years. She likes her employers on Roosevelt Island, a college economics professor and a foundation executive. She is paid $10 an hour for a 25-hour work week to watch over two children, ages 5 and 8. Even so, Ms. Maxwell says she has learned never to be complacent. "Working in this industry, I'm always vulnerable to losing my job. If I walked in now and my employer said, 'I no longer need you,' I'd have nothing."
Ms. Maxwell can afford to go public. She's a citizen, unlike many workers, who fear retaliation from employers and deportation. At news conferences, Ms. Maxwell is often the first to pipe up. She's unafraid to confront politicians.
"She's fearless," says Ai-jen Poo, a labor organizer who has no domestic work experience. "She's not afraid of anything. Nothing."
The two women are sunk deep in donated floral couches in "the chilling room," a spacious area where people hang out between meetings in a building that is also the home of the Committee Against Anti-Asian Violence.
The chat shifts to the legacy of racism permeating the industry. "People feel it's more appropriate for women of color to be doing this work," Ms. Poo says. "They still see domestic workers as this product that you purchase as part of a lifestyle, and that has a lot to do with racism and sexism in our culture."
"Yeah," Ms. Maxwell agrees. "They don't see you as thinking or feeling. In fact, you have no life because your life is what they want it to be."
In her advocacy role, Ms. Maxwell works the telephone and the fax machine, reminding members of meetings, setting up appointments with politicians. She also sets out on foot to parks and playgrounds, handing out booklets to workers on how they can protect themselves.
"It gives me joy," she says with a sunny smile. "I feel like I can speak for them because I have nothing to fear. I feel like I'm coming out again. That's what my daughter said, that I'm like a bird being set free. My kids are grown and I can focus on myself. I've found my niche."

 INTERNATIONAL A3-13

U.S. to Press Harder For Mideast Peace Deal
The Bush administration promised quicker and deeper involvement in searching for a political solution to Israeli-Palestinian violence, perhaps even before the fighting ends. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said for the first time that Israel's expanding military operations in the West Bank should not be open-ended. He also said he was open to meeting with Israeli and Palestinian leaders next week. A1

Israeli tanks and armored vehicles entered Nablus, giving Israel control of all major Palestinian-ruled centers in the West Bank except Hebron. A1

Egypt, Israel's largest and most important peace partner, said that it was suspending "all contacts," but that it would keep open a diplomatic channel to deal with the crisis. A12

Argentine Ex-Minister Arrested
Domingo Cavallo, who resigned as minister of the economy in December, was arrested on suspicion of involvement in illegal arms deals during the early 1990's. Some said he was being made a scapegoat for the country's economic crisis. A3

Afghans Say Plotters Sought To Topple Government
Security officials in Kabul said they had arrested hundreds of political opponents, thwarting a conspiracy to mount a bombing campaign whose targets were the government of Hamid Karzai and the former king, Mohammad Zahir Shah. Afghan officials said the conspiracy was linked to a warlord, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. A1

Arrest May Deter Attacks
The F.B.I. director said the arrest of Abu Zubaydah, the Al Qaeda field commander, would help deter terror attacks. Officials said evidence seized in raids in Pakistan showed that the network was intent on launching a new strike at the United States. A14

Prisoner Says He Is American
The Pentagon said that a prisoner from Afghanistan being held at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, had told American officials that he was born in Louisiana, and that the Justice Department had found a birth certificate that seemed to corroborate his claim. A14

Bomb Detectors Ordered

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York gave the Manhattan district attorney a list of all its priests who had been accused in the past of the sexual abuse of minors. It also spelled out guidelines for evaluating new accusations and backed off an earlier policy that it would only report cases to prosecutors with the consent of the accuser. A1

Bush Welfare Plans Faulted
Many of President Bush's welfare proposals are not realistic and would encourage states to place poor people in menial, unproductive jobs to meet stringent new work requirements, officials say in a survey by the National Governors' Association. A18

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Flying Shoes, Health Care And Politics

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
At one point in the interview, he removed both shoes and chucked them halfway across his expansive office as he complained about a newspaper article that portrayed a $1.8 billion health care bill he rushed through the Legislature, which included money for raises for Mr. Rivera's union members, as a reward for Mr. Rivera's union's endorsing the governor. The bill, Mr. Pataki asserted, was part of his effort to improve health care in New York.
-- from an interview with
Gov. George E. Pataki in 
yesterday's New York Times
 IN other words, Mr. Pataki argues that the health care measure is not political. This is something the voter should decide, based on the facts. Here are some facts: 
 It is an election year, Mr. Pataki is expected to seek a third term, he is a Republican and New Yorkers are increasingly voting Democratic. In January, Mr. Pataki rammed a health care bill through the Legislature that includes raises for thousands of health care workers. Most are members of 1199/S.E.I.U., a largely black, Latino and Democratic union led by Dennis Rivera, a Democrat credited with being able to deliver votes.
Last month, Mr. Rivera endorsed Mr. Pataki, citing his commitment to health care. It was not a thank you, Mr. Rivera insisted.
Some additional facts: The new health care initiative will, the governor's Health Department estimates, cost about $3.5 billion over more than three years. Of that, $1.8 billion is for the recruitment and retention of health workers, which means salary increases, benefits and other programs.
With New York still in recession, where is the $3.5 billion supposed to come from? The most money is supposed to come from Washington -- $1.8 million from Washington if Congress raises its contribution to Medicaid as the state has asked. The second-largest source is Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield -- $1.1 billion from its conversion to a for-profit company.
Critics cite a few fundamental problems. The chance of Washington increasing its contribution to Medicaid is next to nil, lawmakers say. And the money from Empire is a classic one-shot: three years and it's gone, leaving the state with (or in) a deep hole because the costs don't go away because the money to pay for them does.
Nor is this use of the Empire money what the insurer or many health care advocates have long recommended. They wanted New York to emulate other states and use the conversion money to create a foundation, a permanent endowment for the poor and uninsured. 
Based on models in California and elsewhere, the $1.1 billion could have been invested and the investments could have yielded at least $50 million a year in perpetuity, Consumers Union has estimated. 
The governor's new package does include modest health programs: expanded Medicaid coverage for disabled recipients who work and for breast and cervical treatments; more prescription drug coverage for the elderly; less red tape in the application process for Medicaid and other government health insurance programs. And, as Mr. Pataki notes in those state-financed television ads in which he stars, he has worked to broaden health coverage for the poor.
BUT the state still has more than three million uninsured residents, 600,000 of them children. A well-endowed foundation could have helped reduce that number, but it was never formed; the governor's plan provides just $50 million for a small foundation, created under pressure from health care advocates and with no clear mandate. 
"It's the biggest taking of nonprofit assets by a state government seen anywhere," Charles Bell, programs director of Consumers Union, said of the anticipated $1.1 billion in conversion money. "New York is about to miss a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to expand health coverage for the uninsured." 
Instead, at Mr. Pataki's behest and with the full cooperation of legislative leaders (also up for re-election), New York is spending most of that generous windfall on a politically potent labor force, passing up the chance to create a new and permanent health care fund, and is relying on Washington dollars that are not expected to materialize.
Might make someone want to throw a shoe or two for sure.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Man Is Charged With Strangling His Uncle 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N.J., April 3 

 BODY:
A 19-year-old man has been charged with strangling his uncle, a well-known wrestling coach and civic leader, during a robbery here on Sunday night, the police said today.
 The teenager, Jonathan Moorman, fled in a stolen car with two heavy jugs full of coins after killing his uncle, Roger Cassett, 59, and leaving him bound with electric cord and gagged with duct tape in the den of his home here, the police said. Although robbery was Mr. Moorman's motive, the police said, he did not take an estimated $300 in cash from Mr. Cassett's pocket. 
 Mr. Moorman was charged with murder.
For relatives and friends of Mr. Cassett, that added an element of oddity to what many called the "senseless and tragic" death of a man who for nearly three decades had coached youth wrestling in nearby Plainfield. A former two-time state wrestling champion as a bantam weight during his high school years, Mr. Cassett was himself a master of the discipline he urged on his teams.
"I can't say what drove him, but he was driven," said Martin Cox, a friend of Mr. Cassett's and his colleague in youth recreation efforts. "He was focused and determined."
Mr. Moorman was arrested late Monday by the police, who said they found the stolen car parked around the corner from the house here where Mr. Moorman lived with his father and grandmother. He is unemployed and had recently been released from jail, according to relatives of Mr. Cassett and The Associated Press, which cited court records. He was carrying jugs of coins when arrested, the police said.
Mr. Moorman was arraigned Tuesday in Middlesex County Superior Court before Judge Frederick DeVesa, who ordered him held on $750,000 bail. An assistant Middlesex County prosecutor, Thomas Capsak, said his office would present the case to a grand jury within the month.
According to the police and relatives, Mr. Cassett had returned to his small saltbox house here on Sunday night after watching a movie at a relative's home in Plainfield when he was accosted by an intruder who tied him up and gagged him in a chair. The intruder was interrupted by the arrival of Mr. Cassett's 80-year-old stepfather, Raymond Dutton, who lives with him. The police said Mr. Moorman bound Mr. Dutton as well, strangled Mr. Cassett and then fled in Mr. Dutton's car.
Roger Cassett Jr., the victim's son, said that as the patriarch of a widely scattered family, his father held annual picnics that Mr. Moorman might have attended. Everyone who knew the elder Mr. Cassett knew of the jugs of coins he added to daily and which he liked to point out to others as a measure of his personal discipline and determination.
Donald Wynn, director of the Plainfield recreation programs where Mr. Cassett had long been a volunteer wrestling coach until three years ago, said that same intensity helped Mr. Cassett persuade good black athletes to choose his wrestling programs over football and basketball, sports that are more glamorous and popular in urban America.
"He was tough," Mr. Wynn said. "He was strict and commanded that things be done his way."
His son, sitting in the room where his father was found, had only to look around on the wall to be reminded of his father's principles. There were plaques with sayings by Frederick Douglass as well as the coaches Vince Lombardi and John Wooden.
"He had his own Web site called Roger-Man-With-a-Mission.com which carried some of his favorite sayings," Mr. Cassett recalled. "That's what he was, a man with a mission."

HEADLINE: Growth in Service Sector Slowed in March 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3 

 BODY:
Services, the biggest part of the economy, expanded in March at a slower pace than the previous month, a survey of purchasing executives found today, adding to evidence of a gradual rebound from recession.
 The Institute for Supply Management's index of retail, financial services, construction and other nonmanufacturing companies fell to 57.3 last month from 58.7 in February. 
A reading above 50 indicates growth. A companion survey of factory executives this week showed two months of expansion. 
 "We do have an economic recovery, but this is a recovery that is not yet showing evidence of turning into an economic boom," said John Silvia, chief economist at the Wachovia Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. 
The new-orders index showed a slower pace of expansion. While demand increased at retailers, consumers may have reached their limit after a spending spree in the last quarter of 2001 and the first two months of this year. 
Investors read the index by the Institute for Supply Management, formerly known as the National Association of Purchasing Management, as evidence that the Federal Reserve might wait until midyear to increase the rate for overnight loans between banks. The central bank cut the benchmark rate 11 times last year to stimulate growth.
The purchasing executives' index of prices paid for raw materials exceeded 50 for the first time in nine months, reflecting demand for computer memory, copper, polyvinyl chloride pipes and furniture, and price increases for fuel. The factory index earlier this week also showed more manufacturers paying higher prices for the first time since February 2001.
Analysts had expected the total index to drop to 57.

HEADLINE: Feud Put Aside, Grammy Awards Will Return to New York Next Year 

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES

 BODY:
The next Grammy Awards ceremony will be held in New York City on Feb. 23, 2003, after four years in Los Angeles. The announcement was made yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Michael Greene, the president and chief executive of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences, at a news conference in the Theater at Madison Square Garden. 
 The ceremony will be televised by CBS from the Garden arena. "It couldn't be better for New York City, and it couldn't be better for the Grammys," Mr. Bloomberg said. 
 Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said at the news conference: "We've started to recover from Sept. 11, but we're still clearly on the mend. We're still looking for support, for tourism dollars and for symbols that the country and the world stand behind our city. In other words, New York always wants the Grammys, but this year New York needs the Grammys."
He added, "It pumps millions of dollars into the local economy, money this city, as the mayor well knows, could really use."
More than 100 other events, including school programs, performances, exhibits and parties, take place around the awards ceremony. The recording academy, which gives the awards, estimates that having the event in the city brings $35 million to $40 million to local businesses.
"Welcome back," Mr. Schumer said. "The red carpet is waiting."
The 2003 broadcast, which will be the 45th annual Grammy Awards, will move from the Grammys' longtime Wednesday-night slot to a Sunday night. The Academy Awards shifted to Sunday, the night that has the highest number of homes watching television, in 1999.
"The biggest event of the year for us is the Grammy Awards," said Leslie Moonves, president of CBS Television, adding that he expected the move to Sunday to "broaden our base."
The Grammys left New York after a widely publicized feud in 1998 between Mr. Greene and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Greene reportedly lost his temper and threatened a mayoral aide, an accusation he has denied. 
Relations with the Giuliani administration had improved after 1998, Mr. Greene said. He cited programs sponsored by the recording academy in city schools and music-therapy and mentor programs organized by the academy after Sept. 11.
"We never left New York," Mr. Greene said. "We have been here the entire time with our folks." Until 1998 the Grammys had generally alternated between New York and Los Angeles, and yesterday Mr. Greene called New York "our other hometown."
Mr. Moonves said that after Sept. 11 Mr. Greene had considered moving the 2002 awards to New York, but it was too late to change plans. Mr. Greene said that he had asked Mr. Giuliani to present an award at this year's ceremony alongside Tony Bennett but that the former mayor had said he was busy.
Madison Square Garden and the city had been negotiating with the recording academy for 18 months to return the awards to New York, executives said. But Mr. Greene suggested that the attitude of the new city administration had been a factor. 
Mr. Bloomberg called Mr. Greene the week after he was elected, Mr. Greene said, "in the most humble of tones." Mr. Greene continued, "With a passion, with a spirit, and as I say, a humility, we talked about the importance of bringing the Grammys back to New York."
The deciding factor that has kept the awards in Los Angeles for four years, Mr. Greene said, has been the availability of the Staples Center there, an auditorium that was designed to accommodate the Grammy Awards, from its stage elevators to its seating. Among other things, the Staples Center has 300 luxury suites that bring in $30,000 each for the awards show; Madison Square Garden only has 100 luxury suites. Mr. Greene said it cost an extra $2.5 million to produce the Grammys in New York rather than Los Angeles.
The 1998 awards were also marred by security breaches, including a stage crasher during Bob Dylan's performance, but executives said those problems did not contribute to the Grammys' absence from New York.
At the news conference Mr. Greene and Seth Abraham, president of Madison Square Garden/Radio City Entertainment, both said that the arena's unions had been cooperative in making it possible to present the awards in New York. "They understood the importance of bringing it to New York," Mr. Abraham said. 
With its elaborate sets and production numbers, the Grammy telecast requires 10 days of preparation for the arena. That means that Madison Square Garden's basketball and hockey teams, the Knicks and the Rangers, will have to stay on the road during that time.
At today's news conference, a Les Paul electric guitar with a scene of Sept. 11 painted on it by a firefighter was presented to the mayor by the singer Marc Anthony and Thomas D. Mottola, chairman and chief executive of Sony Music Entertainment. Mr. Bloomberg said he would donate it to an auction that would benefit the fire department's widows and orphans fund.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tries out a Les Paul guitar at a news conference yesterday announcing the Grammys' return to New York. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)(pg. E5)

HEADLINE: The Mayor And His Firm Use This Card 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
During his first address to the City Council in January, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that he was so pleased that American Express was returning to its New York headquarters that he was urging New Yorkers to use only their American Express cards.
 And yesterday, his company, Bloomberg L.P., sent its employees an e-mail message saying that "Bloomberg is switching to the American Express Corporate Card." (The company has been using Diners Club, whose headquarters are in Chicago.) 
 There was no connection between the speech and the switch, said Christine Taylor, spokeswoman for Bloomberg L.P., an information services company that Mr. Bloomberg founded in 1981. It now employs more than 8,000 people.
Ms. Taylor said the company decided to switch to American Express before Mr. Bloomberg became mayor, a move based on where the cards are accepted, not where the companies are based. She said that the mayor had not made the decision.
The saga of the mayor and the card he will not leave home without began in January when, in his state of the city address Mr. Bloomberg praised the chairman of American Express, Kenneth I. Chenault, for pledging to return to the company's headquarters in Lower Manhattan.
"I've started to use only my American Express card after Ken made that commitment," Mr. Bloomberg said, sounding a bit like Karl Malden in those old television ads, "and I urge you to do it, too."
That unusual product placement was just another moment as the city adjusted to being run by a billionaire businessman, and a billionaire businessman adjusted to being mayor. Mr. Bloomberg said later it was all just a joke.
The mayor's aides have said that he will follow directives from the city's Conflicts of Interest Board. Last year, Mr. Bloomberg announced that he was stepping down from a management role in his company. He has also announced that the company would not accept tax breaks from the city in exchange for a promise to stay in Manhattan.

HEADLINE: Last Acts of the Giuliani Era Stall in Bloomberg's City Hall 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
In the three months since Rudolph W. Giuliani left City Hall, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and his administration have quietly changed the way the city does business, reviewing several complicated deals that were completed or left lingering in the waning days of the Giuliani administration. 
 Mr. Bloomberg has also adopted a new management style at City Hall, evidenced perhaps most starkly in a decision, disclosed by city officials last night, to abolish the Vacancy Control Board, a panel that Mr. Giuliani used to exercise tight control over hiring by all city agencies. 
Administration officials would not discuss the reasoning behind the decision to disband the board, which had existed since the Abraham D. Beame administration. It was not clear whether the shift was intended to reflect Mr. Bloomberg's hands-off management philosophy or to curtail what critics had charged was patronage. It was also not known how hiring will now be controlled. 
But the decision follows a series of moves to reverse or stall deals made in the final months by the Giuliani administration, including agreements to build new baseball stadiums and a plan to move a museum into the Tweed Courthouse. 
Just this week, Mr. Bloomberg said he would kill a deal to sell three city-owned buildings near the United Nations, scuttling a contract brokered more than a year ago that was strongly supported by Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Bloomberg's press secretary, Edward Skyler, said the new administration was not aiming to undo Mr. Giuliani's actions. "None of these decisions are part of any systematic review of the policies made by the previous mayor," he said. "Rather they are a reflection of changing needs and priorities in difficult times."
But other deals are coming under scrutiny. Among them is a proposed lease of city land at the Brooklyn Navy Yard to Joseph Spitzer, a developer and major Giuliani political supporter, who hopes to build one million square feet of commercial space. 
Although lease negotiations were approved in mid-December, the deal may already be in trouble. Mr. Spitzer has not secured an anchor tenant for the project, and financing for the project is still in the works, with a sizable payment due on the lease at the end of this month. 
The land in question is a prime parcel at the Navy Yard, an area that the city has long sought to redevelop. Supporters say the deal could bring hundreds of jobs to a neighborhood that lost its manufacturing base decades ago. Critics question if Mr. Spitzer got a sweetheart arrangement. 
Another long-planned deal benefiting Mr. Spitzer was not left to chance. On Dec. 31, the Giuliani administration closed the sale of the old Schaefer Brewery site in Williamsburg, where Mr. Spitzer and several partners plan to build 350 new housing units. 
These two Brooklyn deals illustrate how even with the burden of overseeing the recovery at ground zero, which required giving daily briefings to the White House, Mr. Giuliani worked with purposeful urgency up to his last moment in office. 
"It was the whole philosophy of you don't pull up at first base, you run through the bag," said one high-ranking Giuliani aide. 
On the morning of his last day as mayor, Mr. Giuliani drove himself to City Hall in a Police Department Humvee. The ride in the multipurpose military vehicle was a lark, but it was also symbolic: Mr. Giuliani was as hard-charging on his final day in office as he was on his first. 
Mr. Giuliani began that last day with live appearances on the morning television programs, followed by his customary staff meeting precisely at 8 a.m. The only nod to the end of his term was that each aide was given a few moments to speak about what an honor it was to work with him.
Otherwise, the meeting was all business, including a last-ditch effort to reach a deal on a new headquarters for the New York Stock Exchange and preparations for the New Year's festivities in Times Square that night. Mr. Giuliani even insisted on releasing citywide crime statistics one last time.
Some of the final efforts by Mr. Giuliani are now well known. From making appointments to maneuvers involving the Stock Exchange, these ventures in the administration's final weeks represented a microcosm of Mr. Giuliani's eight years in office, with each effort placed in the hands of a member of his tight-knit cadre of loyal aides. 
Deputy Mayor Robert M. Harding struggled to reach a deal for a new headquarters for the New York Stock Exchange, with Mr. Giuliani vowing to announce it even at 5 p.m. on Dec. 31. Ultimately, the clock ran out. Joseph J. Lhota, the deputy mayor for operations, supervised transition issues. Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles handled the arrangements on Mr. Giuliani's archives and dealt with a huge push by the Bechtel Corporation for control of work at ground zero. 
Dennison Young Jr., the mayor's counsel and a close adviser, oversaw appointments. Mr. Young was also working with Michael Hess, another confidant, to set up Giuliani Partners, the consulting firm that now employs much of Mr. Giuliani's inner circle. 
The final weeks actually saw the return to City Hall of several former loyal aides. Cristyne Lategano-Nicholas, the former deputy chief of staff and communications director, who left to become president of NYC & Company, worked on post-Sept. 11 economic recovery issues. John Dyson, the former deputy mayor for economic development, oversaw the final details of the agreement to move the Museum of the City of New York to the Tweed Courthouse, a deal that Mr. Bloomberg has now quashed in favor of moving the Board of Education and a school into the building.
"There was no difference in level of intensity in the last three weeks than there was in the first three weeks of the administration," said Mr. Lhota, the former deputy mayor. "It was a conviction on the part of the mayor and his senior staff that the mayor was elected to turn around the city of New York. There is no doubt in my mind that he worked up until 11:59:59 on Dec 31." 
Mr. Giuliani was not the only one racing to get things done. Baseball officials were equally intent on closing a stadium deal before the mayor, a huge fan, left office. Mr. Spitzer was just as intent on his deals. 
Several aides said Mr. Bloomberg's victory in the mayoral race, secured in no small part with the help of Mr. Giuliani's endorsement, had actually alleviated a substantial amount of pressure at City Hall. Had Mark Green, the Democrat and a longtime enemy of Mr. Giuliani, beaten Mr. Bloomberg, these aides said, Mr. Giuliani would have sought to handcuff him. 
"We could have done the stadium deal," one top aide closely involved in the negotiations said. "We would have created an L.L.C., funded it, gone to Albany and got it certified, and it would have been done. But Rudy said: 'I am not going to hamper Bloomberg. I trust him to use his judgment. At least he'll have an open mind.' " 
Mr. Skyler, the spokesman, said any differences between the two teams reflected natural changes between different administrations. "Mayor Bloomberg believes that Rudy Giuliani left this city in much better shape than he found it and he intends to build on those successes," Mr. Skyler said. "There will obviously be areas where different paths are charted as is the case with any new administration."
But there were areas in which Mr. Giuliani was not so deferential, in particular his appointments to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the state agency responsible for rebuilding downtown Manhattan. He chose Mr. Harding; Paul Crotty, his former corporation counsel; Richard Grasso, the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange; and Howard Wilson, the chairman of the School Construction Authority.
Mr. Bloomberg at the time said he had been consulted by both Mr. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki. But Mr. Bloomberg had no real say. That he and his staff found this nettlesome was clear, as Mr. Pataki expanded the board in recent weeks to to give the city three more members. "It was annoying," one Bloomberg aide said of the appointments. 
Mr. Giuliani appointed 20 judges to fill a variety of vacancies on the bench. Among them was Marybeth S. Richroath, a veteran prosecutor, who was second-in-command of Mr. Giuliani's Office of Criminal Justice Coordinator and is also married to a cousin of Mr. Giuliani's. Also appointed to the criminal bench was Richard M. Weinberg, the longtime counsel to Peter F. Vallone, the former City Council speaker. 
Anthony V. Carbonetti, the former chief of staff, who is also at Giuliani Partners, became the point of contact for Karl Rove at the White House and other senior presidential advisers who wanted updates on ground zero and for national security officials providing warnings about terrorist threats. 
In addition, Mr. Carbonetti was responsible for keeping an eye on two deals involving Mr. Spitzer. The Brooklyn deals involved the housing and retail project on the Schaefer site in Brooklyn and a planned office building and light industrial complex at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. 
In both cases, the projects had been under way for some time and had to clear several regulatory hurdles. Local officials including former City Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, had long sought the construction of housing on the old brewery site, as had the United Jewish Organization. 
Demolition of the old brewery took place in 1999. The City Council approved the required land use changes in early December 2001. But to guarantee that nothing could hamper the deal, the sale of the city-owned property was concluded, for the assessed value of $9 million, Dec. 31. 
The Navy Yard deal involves the lease of city land for construction of a million square feet of commercial space. On Dec. 17, the board of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Corporation approved the start of lease negotiations with a development group led by Mr. Spitzer. Because of the delay in finding an anchor, Mr. Spitzer had to pay $250,000 in rent on the undeveloped property Jan. 31, officials involved in the deal said. Another large payment is owed to the city on April 30, and it is unclear if the deal can survive.
A spokesman for Mr. Spitzer, Isaac Abraham, said he was firmly committed. "We are committed to continue to make sure that this deal is finalized and bring those 300 jobs to the community," Mr. Abraham said. 
In the latest developments, the Bloomberg administration is seemingly doing away with the main gate-keeping mechanism for filling city jobs in the Giuliani administration. Edward I. Koch, the former mayor, said the Vacancy Control Board, dated to the fiscal crisis of the 1970's so that city commissioners could appeal for exceptions to a blanket hiring freeze. 
The board does not appear in the city's Green Book, the official directory. Critics have charged that it was sometimes used to fill posts with political appointments, and for promoting the mayor's agenda; for example, to weaken some agencies by denying them the ability to fill positions. 
Under Mr. Giuliani, the board exercised extraordinary control over city hiring. Mr. Carbonetti was chairman, and the board included the budget director and the deputy mayor for operations. 
A senior Giuliani adviser said the board was crucial to keeping agencies' hiring within budget. "Not patronage control," the adviser said. "Fiscal control."

HEADLINE: Sharon on Survival 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
"I told Vice President Cheney I'm aware of the challenges that confront your president," Prime Minister Ariel Sharon told me after he launched Operation Protective Wall a few days ago. "There is seemingly a conflict of interests between America's need to establish a coalition against Saddam Hussein and Israel's need to fight Palestinian terror." 
 The Israeli leader believes this is only a "seeming" conflict, not a real one. "I'm confident we'll find a way to achieve both goals, taking no steps that undermine the other's security. If the U.S. goes after Saddam, Israel will stand behind you. You will win your war with Iraq -- and it will be a short one -- and then you will leave the region. But we have to stay and live here. We both must be careful not to make decisions that might harm the security of future generations of Israelis." 
 Many in Europe and the media are seized of the notion that Israel's counterattack on West Bank terrorists will only further radicalize the Palestinian population, producing ever more suicide bombers and the triumph of Hamas. At the same time, they insist that sustained terror war by Arab extremists is sure to demoralize Israelis, forcing them to accept the total retreat demanded at the recent Beirut conclave. 
On that theory, the counterattack now under way will harden the Palestinians, whose Saddam-subsidized bombers have nothing to lose but their lives -- while softening the Israelis, who yearn for peace. 
Sharon is not buying that at all. "I saw that pessimistic evaluation in Newsweek about our morale," he says with some scorn. "I don't even consider that an issue. Through 4,000 years of continuity in our ancestral homeland, Israel's people have undergone hardship, persecution, Holocaust, terrible adversity. But the nation is stronger than others have estimated. We have overcome all our challenges. The Jewish people are indestructible." 
Before Sharon's strong military response to the Arabs' Passover wave of suicide-slaughter, much coverage dwelt on stresses within Israel's coalition cabinet. "This government of national unity will serve its full term until the coming election of Oct. 28, 2003," Sharon said with no hesitation. "That is because Israel needs a wide, strong, united government without internal struggles. I'm enlarging the coalition. One rightist party left, but they'll be coming back, and other opposition parties may join us if the leftist part of Labor leaves." 
What of polls showing a turn toward the hard-line Bibi Netanyahu within his own Likud party? "We'll have a coalition serving until the end of the term, and I'll be the candidate for prime minister next time as well. First we must bring security, and then put into action our plans to reach the end of this conflict. The day will come when we will. I'm an optimist."
With Israeli troops hunting down terrorist leaders in a dozen Arab cities and villages, he has a non-bellicose message to innocent neighbors: "I know it's hard to be a Palestinian, but Israel is not the source of your suffering. That source is one man: Arafat, who has brought only tragedy and pain upon your nation. 
"As a soldier who knows the horrors of war, I seek a peace with every Arab country. We are ready to share our know-how with Palestinians, to help you and be helped by you. I see a Marshall Plan for Palestine -- call it the Bush-Sharon plan -- to solve your problem of unemployment. Together we can make tremendous achievements. 
"These are the things I would have told the Arab leaders to their faces if they had let me come to Beirut. I am 74 now, with one thing left in my life to accomplish: security and peace for ourselves and our neighbors." 
This prime minister, after a period of painful forbearance under intolerable provocation, is now decisively fulfilling the mandate Israelis overwhelmingly gave him: to turn back the tide of terror. President Bush is resisting powerful pressure from many in the worldwide opinion mafia and the oil industry to "engage" and undermine him. Though demonized by extremist Arab dictators and despised by fanatics left and right, Arik Sharon is the average Palestinian's last best hope in this generation for a good life in an independent state.

HEADLINE: Mexico Ex-President to Lead Yale Globalization Center 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO 

 BODY:
Ernesto Zedillo, the former president of Mexico, will become the next director of the Yale Center for the Study of Globalization, an institute that focuses on what Yale defines as the increasing economic, cultural and political interdependence between nations.
 "Alleviating poverty in third world countries is an issue very dear to Ernesto's heart," said Richard C. Levin, Yale's president, in announcing the appointment yesterday. "He wants to make sure that the globalization process improves the welfare of the poor as well as the rich." 
 The center invites public leaders and potential leaders from around the world to the university's New Haven campus to give lectures, hold seminars and offer semester-long courses. It also sponsors research projects and conferences, such as the conference scheduled for next fall on the relations among Central Asian countries and how those relations affect the stability of the region.
Mr. Zedillo, 50, received his Ph.D. in economics from Yale in 1981. His own interest in the job seems to focus on how to bring the benefits of a more global outlook to third world countries, which have often been portrayed as being exploited by richer ones.
"Globalization is not the problem itself," Mr. Zedillo said in a telephone interview yesterday. "The problem is that we are lacking effective public policies regarding globalization. We want to make globalization inclusive and its economic consequences -- the good ones -- sustainable."
Mr. Zedillo has been credited with promoting the development of democratic institutions, to the extent that he presided over the defeat of his own party in Mexico's first fully democratic presidential elections, in 2000. The party had been in power for 71 years; his tenure began in 1994. He also carried out economic reforms that brought new stability to Mexico's financial situation. 
Mr. Zedillo has had a long-standing relationship with Mr. Levin, also an economist teaching at Yale. The two met when Mr. Zedillo took Mr. Levin's class on industrial organization as a graduate student. The university approached Mr. Zedillo after Strobe Talbott, a deputy secretary of state in the Clinton administration and the current director of the center, announced in January his resignation to become the president of the Brookings Institution. 
"I have the highest regard for my own university," said Mr. Zedillo, whose appointment is effective in September.
The center, begun last year, is part of the university's effort to become more international. It decided last year to admit international students without regard for their ability to pay. It also started the World Fellows Program, which will sponsor potential leaders from around the world to study for a semester at Yale. 
The university has long been an incubator of political leaders in this country. Four of the past six presidents -- Gerald R. Ford, George Bush, Bill Clinton and George W. Bush -- went to college or law school at Yale. 
Now the school is not at all shy about its ambition to cultivate leaders for other countries.
"That's exactly what we want to do," Mr. Levin said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ernesto Zedillo received an honorary degree from Yale last year. He will assume his new duties at a center there beginning in September. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: To Look and to Nosh 

BYLINE:  By MIMI SHERATON

 BODY:
 A sampling of places on the Lower East Side. Restaurant prices are for a three-course meal for two, with tax and tip but not drinks.

Hotel

HOWARD JOHNSON EXPRESS INN, 135 East Houston Street, (212) 358-8844 (www.hojo .com). Spankingly modern with all minimal necessities in minirooms. Double or queen with continental breakfast: $139 and tax; two double beds with continental breakfast: $149 and tax; various discounts available.
Historic Sites

BIALYSTOKER SYNAGOGUE, 7-13 Bialystoker Place, between Grand and Broome Streets, (212) 475-0165. Built as a Protestant church in 1826, this has been a synagogue for immigrants from Bialystok, Poland, since 1905. The stark exterior belies the interior's exuberant Italianate frescoes of biblical themes.

CONGREGATION SHAARAI SHOMOYIM, First Romanian-American Congregation, 89-93 Rivington Street, (212) 673-2835. An impressive, much neglected interior distinguishes this imposing Romanesque-Revival building, which began as a church in 1890.

ELDRIDGE STREET SYNAGOGUE, 12 Eldridge Street, (212) 978-8800. Built in 1887, this first major synagogue of Eastern European Jews is slowly being restored and encouraging vestiges of its former grandeur are already in view.

HAMILTON FISH RECREATION CENTER AND POOL, 128 Pitt Street, (212) 387-7687. The Beaux Arts community center sits in a huge recreational park. Opening as a gymnasium in 1900, it imitated the plans for the Petit Palais in the Paris Exhibition of the same year.

HENRY STREET SETTLEMENT HOUSE, 263-65 Henry Street, (212) 766-9200. Charming early 19th-century Federal and Greek Revival style town houses are the headquarters for the social agency founded by Lillian Wald in 1867.

KEHILA KEDOSHA JANINA SYNAGOGUE AND MUSEUM, 280 Broome Street, (212) 673-4441 or 741-3533 (www.kehila-kedosha -janina.org). Forgive the banal interior, but don't miss the small, intriguing museum of Judaica from this obscure Romaniote community, established in Greece 2,000 years ago.

LOWER EAST SIDE CONSERVANCY, 235 East Broadway, near Jefferson Street, (212) 233-6037 (www.nycjewishtours.org). Public or customized tours of Jewish sites, including synagogues, restaurants, shops and streets.

LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, (212) 431-0233 (www .tenement.org). Restored 19th-century apartments where Jewish, Irish and Italian families lived. By tour only, arranged at the museum's shop.

OUR LADY OF SORROWS ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH, 103 Pitt Street; rectory: (212) 673-0900. Flamboyant colors give this soaring 1867 church an operatic presence.

ST. MARY'S ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH, 440 Grand Street, (212) 674-3266. This venerable 1833 Roman Catholic church structure was built of gray stone and expanded in 1871 with idiosyncratic steeples atop an oddly proportioned brick facade.

SEWARD PARK BRANCH OF NEW YORK PUBLIC LIBRARY, 192 East Broadway, at Jefferson Street, (212) 477-6770. A stunningly grand library with elaborate masonry, built in 1909.

Theaters

ABRONS ART CENTER, 466 Grand Street, (212) 598-0400. Dance, drama and concerts are held in the Harry De Jour Playhouse, and fine and performing arts are taught and exhibited in this 1975 complex.

LANDMARK'S SUNSHINE CINEPLEX, 143 East Houston Street, (212) 358-7709. This former Yiddish vaudeville theater and movie house has been modernized into a multiplex for art films, with stadium seating and sharp acoustics.

MAZER THEATER, Educational Alliance, 197 East Broadway, between Clinton and Jefferson Streets, (212) 780-2300. A funky, campily sexy Wild West Show playing through April 27 in this 113-year-old theater is performed by the Bindlestiff Family Cirkus, vagabonds named for the bundle (bindle) on a stick (stiff) that hoboes carry.

ANGEL ORENSANZ CULTURAL CENTER, 172-75 Norfolk Street, (212) 529-7194 (www .orensanz.org). New York City's oldest existing synagogue building has been a National Landmark landmark cultural center since 1987, now with a calendar of music and stage performances and art exhibitions.

CLEMENTE SOTO VELEZ CENTER, (Milagro, Flamboyan, La Tea and Los Kabayitos Puppet and Children's Theater), 107 Suffolk Street, (212) 260-4080. Behind the imposing neo-Gothic facade of the former P.S. 160 are classes, studios and theaters. Performances range from "Little Red Riding Hood" to "Othello."

Night Life

BOWERY BALLROOM, 6 Delancey Street, (212) 533-2111. Once the Treemark shoe store, this trim little landmark building has an intimate downstairs bar with a conspiratorial feeling, where fans wait for the music to begin in the high-flown upstairs space. Admission: $12 to $20, depending on the band; for reservations, call Mercury Lounge (see below).

MAX FISH, 178 Ludlow Street, (212) 529-3959. Opened in 1989 by the pioneering Ulli Rimkus, this is one of the last vestiges of the first "new" Lower East Side. It seems like a big house party, with pool table, jukebox and pinball machines.

MERCURY LOUNGE, 217 East Houston Street, between Essex and Ludlow Streets, (212) 260-4700. A simpler, less dramatic space than its relative, the Bowery Ballroom, this is also a bar favored by fans of pop and rock music. Admission: $8 to $12, depending on the band.

SLIPPER ROOM, 167 Orchard Street, (212) 253-7246. At tables gathered intimately before a small stage, the attraction on Saturday nights is Mr. Choade's Upstairs Downstairs vaudeville burlesque show, with a show that does not go "past pasties and G-strings," as callers are informed. Other nights, other acts.

Shops

MARY ADAMS THE DRESS, 138 Ludlow Street, (212) 473-0237. Romantic party and wedding dresses are custom-made in gauzy silk organza, lace and the like.

ALLUSTRA JEWELRY, 100 Orchard Street, (212) 505-9868.Retro to ultra-modern jewelry includes chokers of chunky Asian beads or lacy silver, brass and plated pieces, plus hard-to-find clip-on earrings.

ALTMAN LUGGAGE, 135 Orchard Street, (212) 254-7275. Headquarters for a dazzling array of quality luggage, usually priced below sale merchandise uptown.

BECKENSTEIN MEN'S FABRICS, 133 Orchard Street, (212) 475-6666. Bargains in luxurious wool suit fabrics and shirtings, plus custom-made trousers, skirts and vests.

BLUESTOCKINGS WOMEN'S BOOKSTORE AND CAFE, 172 Allen Street, (212) 777-6028. Female writers and women's subjects are the stock-in-trade at this laid-back cooperative, which offers open house discussions and sells lights snacks.

DENISE CARBONELL, 154 Stanton Street, (212) 979-1613. Brilliant contemporary ceramic tableware plus pillows, coverlets and wall hangings, some vintage but most made by the owner.

CHA CHA'S HOUSE OF ILL REPUTE, 154 1/2 Suffolk Street, (212) 420-7450. A women's hat festishist's miniheaven, with custom versions of rakish fedoras and more ($100 to $250) by the milliner Deena Pisani.

FINE & KLEIN HANDBAGS, 119 Orchard Street, (212) 674-6720. Designer handbags and related leather goods at roughly one-third of their list prices.

FORWARD, 72 Orchard Street, (646) 264-3233. Original, ultrahip clothes in the tiny sizes favored down here, along with more serious suits for real men and women, by four young designers.

LAS VENUS, 163 Ludlow Street, (212) 982-0608. Vintage, reproduction and second-hand modern furniture, most by recognized designers and often at sale prices.

HARRIS LEVY, 278 Grand Street, (212) 226-3102. A four-generation business with name-brand linens at discount prices and luxurious custom imports.

LUDLOW GUITARS, 164 Ludlow Street, (212) 353-1775. Everything guitar-related is here, from vintage, new, used and custom instruments to recordings made by the owner, Robert Gary. Ditto all other picked string instruments

MARMALADE, 172 Ludlow Street, (212) 473-8070. New and vintage shoes, accessories and fanciful clothing. Some, like a festive flamenco skirt ($198), are designed by the owner, Hannah Kurland.

STRONGARM CLOTHING AND SUPPLY, 184 Orchard Street, (212) 353-8847. A museumlike shop of antique and old outdoor-wear like parkas, and Civil War campaign lamps, carpenters' workbenches and horse blankets.

HARRY ZARIN, 318 Grand Street, (212) 925-6112. If you can't find the home furnishings fabric you want in this staggering warehouse, it probably doesn't exist.

Restaurants

AKA CAFE, 49 Clinton Street, (212) 979-6096. Savory snacks in a casual setting include squash soup with spicy pumpkin seeds; roasted squid with chickpea puree; and lamb tongue sandwich and other sandwiches on pressed bialys. Skip the disappointing hangar steak. About $52.

BEREKET TURKISH KEBOB HOUSE, 187 East Houston Street, (212) 475-7700. Inexpensive, flavorful Middle Eastern salads, crisp falafel, hearty bean soups. Skip the leathery donner kebob and opt for spicy, meaty adana kebob; ground lamb kofte with onions and yogurt or tahini. About $25.

EL CASTILLO DE JAGUA, 113 Rivington Street, (212) 982-6412. Bright, friendly luncheonette with authentic Latino comfort food: chicken stew, shrimp in garlic sauce, fried green plantains and hearty egg dishes. About $35.

71 CLINTON FRESH FOODS, 71 Clinton Street, (212) 614-6960. With just 30 seats, this smartly trim, eclectic favorite is justly popular, making reservations difficult. Recent winners: chestnut gnocchi, duck consomme, black bass crusted with rye crumbs and edamame (Japanese soy beans), and lamb loin with Israeli couscous. About $110.

CONGEE VILLAGE, 100 Allen Street, (212) 941-1818. Wonderful Hong Kong-Cantonese food, with many versions of congee rice porridge, fried flounder, salt and pepper crabs, sugar snap pea leaves with garlic, beef noodles and much more. Long lines form early; reservations for six or more only. About $55.

ESSEX, 120 Essex Street, (212) 533-9616. A smart, jazzy setting for diverting multicultural fare. Winners include salmon tartare with wonton crisps, a gentle, soothing paella and roast chicken over polenta with a habanero chile sauce.

MOOZA, 191 Orchard Street, (212) 982-4770. Festive Arabian Nights decor with story-book depictions of the nine Muses (hence, Mooza) and a lovely garden. On the Mediterranean menu, stick to tuna tartare, shrimp tart, grilled tuna on eggplant caponata and rack of lamb. About $110.

PALADAR, 161 Ludlow Street, (212) 473-3535. In a convivial cafe with an enclosed garden, chef Aaron Sanchez grounds inventions in solid Latino roots, all at moderate prices. Appetizers are deliciously diverting as are great main courses like adobe-rubbed skirt steak and chicken stew in a pumpkin seed and epazote sauce. About $55.

SAMMY'S ROUMANIAN STEAK HOUSE, 157 Chrystie Street, (212) 673-0330. For a taste of the old Jewish East Side, try this jammed favorite. Live entertainment and shtick are as schmaltzy as the chopped liver, with indulgences of delicious grilled steaks, veal chops, flanken, potato latkes and kishka -- topped off, God willing, with an egg cream. About $95.

YONAH SCHIMMEL'S, 137 East Houston Street, (212) 477-2858. A time warp in its setting and menu. Share a kasha knish ($1.90) and save room for a cuddly, sweet cheese pretzel ($2).

SUBA, 109 Ludlow Street, (212) 982-5714. A magical setting: the basement dining room is surrounded by a rippling moat that casts reflections on the brick walls. Prettified food needs more seasoning; recent successes were grilled sardines, Serrano ham and cheese on pepper tuiles, lobster with a duck empanada, and crackling crisp crujientes de chocolate. About $90.

Food Stores

DOUGHNUT PLANT, 379 Grand Street, (212) 505-3700. I bypass big puffy doughnuts with cloying glazes in favor of long, fluted churros ($1), the cinnamon-scented Latino crullers.

EARTHMATTERS, 177 Ludlow Street, (212) 475-4180. This gleaming new mecca of excellent natural and vegetarian fare has an Internet cafe, salads, wraps and deliciously moist banana bread ($2.25 per slice).

ECONOMY CANDY COMPANY, 108 Rivington Street, (212) 254-1531. The big rock candy mountain with a floor to ceiling pile of almost every confection imaginable, pop and gourmet, all at bargain prices.

ESSEX STREET PUBLIC MARKET, 120 Essex Street, (212) 388-0449. On Fridays and Saturdays, this is a food festival of meats and fish and a garden of tropical fruits, roots and vegetables.

GUSS PICKLES, 97 Orchard Street, in the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. There's a constant line for the best, crunchiest kosher pickles, tomatoes and sauerkraut. For information, (516) 642-2634.

KADOURI & SONS, 51 Hester Street, (212) 677-5441. Middle Eastern exotica including dried fruits, nuts, coffees, spices and halvah of all sorts.

KATZ'S DELICATESSEN, 205 East Houston Street, (212) 254-2246. The city's best sputtering beef hot dogs ($2.40), hand-sliced pastrami and corned beef sandwiches ($9.95), tongue or salami omelets. This 114-year-old classic is almost always mobbed.

KOSSAR'S BIALYSTOKER KUCHEN BAKERY, 367 Grand Street, (212) 473-4810. The city's best bialys, what else? Answer: Bulkas, pletzls and superior bagels, especially the plain miniatures.

RUSS & DAUGHTERS, 179 East Houston Street, (212) 475-4880. A culinary landmark since 1914, this remains tops for impeccable smoked fish, herring, caviar and related salads, dried fruits and candies. MIMI SHERATON

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
The 'Star Wars' Effect, And the Part That's Art

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

 BODY:
HOW did I get the idea that "Star Wars: The Magic of Myth" at the Brooklyn Museum of Art might be a lark and not a witless fiasco?
 Chalk it up to a flush of nostalgia: hearing of the show jogged a memory -- the most hackneyed "Star Wars" memory, I'm sure -- of going to the first movie and feeling a kind of wonderment in those opening seconds of the film. It turned out to be the last instant before the world became spoiled by special effects. Even for a jaded teenager in New York, the sight of that enormous, seemingly never-ending ship unfurled from the top of the screen left its indelible mark. 
 The wonderment dwindled by the end of the third film and was gone after the fourth, which I even hesitate to admit I saw. But the initial feeling evidently lodged in my head. One of the salient qualities of art is to lodge in your head. Something you see stays with you, sometimes despite yourself, years after you have rationally decided that its presence is an embarrassment. That opening scene -- 13 seconds by my watch is the time it takes for the ship to pass overhead, a long time (count it) -- that scene was a work of art.
Wonderment is not what you derive from this implausible exhibition. What you get may be a throbbing in the temples from the noise of many competing video monitors and a jab in the side from some fellow visitor wielding a light saber, although museum officials alerted me to a Web site (http://boards.theforce.net /message.asp?topic=6077494&replies=0) where guidelines for appropriate behavior have been posted for members of the New York chapter of one of the "Stars Wars" fan clubs. The guidelines specify "NO DUELING of any kind!" and "NO Blasters! NO BLASTERS!"
Even considering that the event is pitched to preteenagers and "Star Wars" buffs, I had expected (and the Brooklyn Museum of Art ought to be expected to provide) something that at least pretends to be serious about art. A display of Princess Leia's slave girl outfit is not what I mean. I could have imagined an exhibition about the technology of visual effects, say.
A few months before the first "Star Wars" opened in 1977, the Academy Award for special effects went to "King Kong," which was just a big guy in a gorilla suit groping Jessica Lange. No wonder that the giant ship at the opening of "Star Wars" seemed like a hyperspace leap forward in visual sophistication.
Alternatively, a show about Saturday afternoon serials, comic books and "Star Wars" might have done the trick. Like all great visual cinema, "Star Wars" invented its own vocabulary of images, and it would have been instructive to see where they came from and how they evolved.
No such luck here. We're served up token drawings and paintings, which seem orphaned and overwhelmed amid an extravagant toy store of disappointingly ordinary-looking costumes, props and models, incongruously exhibited in fancy cases against cartoon backdrops as if they were the holy relics of St. John the Baptist presented by Mad Magazine. It reminded me above all of how film transforms mundane objects into magic.
Originally presented by the National Air and Space Museum in Washington and well-traveled across the country by the Smithsonian's traveling exhibition service, the show has naturally been an enormous box-office draw, its true purpose. So it bothers with a rationale only barely.
The rationale is not, as you might expect from the National Air and Space Museum, scientific. It is the mythology of the movies, presented straight-facedly as if it were a revelation that "Star Wars" is a cheerful testosterone-heavy Hollywood B-movie gumbo mixing high and low sources like the Bible, "Gunsmoke," "Beowulf," the "Nibelungenlied," King Arthur, Huck Finn, Buck Rogers and "The Odyssey."
The book accompanying the show dutifully enumerates these mythological connections via plentiful allusions to Carl Jung, Joseph Campbell and Bill Moyers, a work of deadpan prose that in its earnestness is unintentionally hilarious. The self-mockery of the original film, as Pauline Kael famously pointed out, entailed mimicking the tone of bad movies, turning "old-movie ineptness into conscious Pop Art." The "Star Wars" actors never let on whether their bad acting was really bad or ironic.
The book's credulous tone might seem to strike a similarly winking pose, except that it is apparently dead serious.
And speaking of dead serious, I have delayed, because it requires me to be earnest, too, the issue of commercial opportunism. The last straw for me was the room of masks of characters like Darth Maul that you can try on at the end of the exhibition, leading straight into the shop where you may then buy the same Darth Maul mask among much other "Star Wars" paraphernalia, so that the show and shop become indistinguishable.
All museums merchandise. But there are limits. Lucasfilm Ltd. has obviously provided its costumes and props knowing that shows like this help promote the films and goodies. Why shouldn't it? It's a business. The next "Star Wars" installment opens on May 16. The exhibition runs through July 7. Good for George Lucas. Why the Brooklyn Museum would mortgage its reputation to advertise for him is not so clear.
Museums justify this brand of show by waving the populist flag, talking about broadening audiences, getting new faces through the front doors.
Sponsors, trustees and government officials like to hear this. But it almost never works. Typically, this is just a quick, temporary means to make headlines, boost attendance figures and raise cash.
The Brooklyn Museum, one of the country's most distinguished cultural institutions, under its showman-director Arnold L. Lehman, is clearly searching for new visitors in challenging economic times. I love the museum. I have loved visiting it since I was a boy.
This show made my heart sink.
"Star Wars: The Magic of Myth" remains at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000, through July 7, then travels to Sydney, Australia.

HEADLINE: Andersen's Employees 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Arthur Andersen has been indicted by the Justice Department, thus sealing the fate of tens of thousands of creative, dynamic, hard-working Americans who will be unemployed (front page, April 2). 
 The law is the law, but it's time to realize the human costs.
Life has been traumatic for all Americans since Sept. 11. Enron was a major blow, too. Now it is time for Arthur Andersen! 
What good comes out of bringing the company to its knees?

DIEGO BANEGAS
Mexico City, April 2, 2002
