HEADLINE: The New Old World of the Lower East Side 

BYLINE:  By MIMI SHERATON; Mimi Sheraton's latest book is "The Bialy Eaters: The Story of a Bread and a Lost World."

 BODY:
Spending a weekend in another part of town may not seem like adventurous travel, but given New York's diversity it can be as intriguing as a visit to almost any other city in the United States.
 One can make ad hoc visits to museums, theaters or restaurants in a different neighborhood, but this may reveal only isolated pieces of the local jigsaw puzzle. For me, it is essential to stay in a neighborhood hotel. If it's luxurious, it becomes part of the treat; but even hotels with minimal comforts offer freedom from the home routine and total immersion in the new surroundings. 
 So a few weeks ago my husband, Richard Falcone, and I checked into the Howard Johnson Express Inn that opened on East Houston Street in December, the better to explore the complexities of the changing Lower East Side. The first surprise was the modern hotel, somewhat spare but quiet. It had all the basic necessities, minus a shower cap and extra pillows. This being Manhattan, low rates buy minuscule space. Although our bed was billed as queen size, it was barely a double and all the rooms I saw recalled the old Henny Youngman line on his hotel room being "so small, I had to go out to the hall to change my mind." 
This block of Houston Street, between Forsyth and Eldridge Streets, virtually summarizes the current Lower East Side story: the new, the old and the resurrected. Standing next to the hotel is the 92-year-old Yonah Schimmel Knish Bakery, with antique showcases and a cozily disheveled eating space hung with faded memorabilia. Share a ritual kasha knish and a far better sweet cheese pretzel and then walk next door to the lyrical brick facade of Landmark's Sunshine Cinema, a modernized art-film multiplex with stadium seating, which opened in December in what a century ago was a showplace for Yiddish vaudeville and films.
I reserved most of the area south of Delancey Street for Sunday, as Jewish-owned shops there close on Saturdays. But I did walk through the Essex Street Public Market on Saturday morning, when it is at its most exuberant as local residents, mainly Hispanic, shop amid a profusion of fresh fish, meat and tropical produce with amazingly low prices. I also checked out movie and theater schedules, to while away evening hours until the late club action got under way. "It's not your grandmother's Lower East Side" is the much-repeated warning -- or promise. But there is a lot that would be familiar to a Jewish grandmother of a certain age, if not to an Irish or Italian one. As became clear during an evocative tour of the restored apartments in what is now the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, those were the main ethnic groups who crammed into the area (sometimes with 12 in 2 rooms, one windowless) from 1863 to 1935. 
Other than a few Roman Catholic churches, like St. Mary's on Grand Street and the flamboyant Our Lady of Sorrows on Pitt Street, most of the aging buildings reflect Jewish origins. Many of the synagogues, generally in depressing disrepair or converted to other uses, can be visited independently; more convenient are the tours organized by the Lower East Side Conservancy. The Angel Orensanz Cultural Center on Norfolk Street, for example, has held art shows and theater performances since 1987 in what had been Congregation Anshe Chesed, built in 1850 as the first Reform temple in New York.
A virtual museum is being created in the once grand Eldridge Street Synagogue as its mix of Gothic and Moorish style architecture is restored. Florid Italianate frescoes are the surprise behind the staid stone facade of the Bialystoker Synagogue, built as a church in 1826 but bought by Jewish immigrants from Bialystok, Poland, in 1905. The unprepossessing interior of the Kehila Kedosha Janina temple includes a fascinating little museum of Judaica that includes Alephs, the delicately hand-painted birth certificates for boys (but not girls).
This was a congregation of Romaniote Jews, whose ancestors were shipwrecked off the Greek coast 2,000 years ago while being taken to Rome from Jerusalem as slaves. They established communities around Janina, and developed their own customs, foods and a language different from Yiddish or the Sephardic Ladino. Many surviving synagogues cannot attract the 10-man minyan (quorum) required for daily prayers. At the large brick First Romanian-American Congregation (Shaarai Shomoyim), with its shabby but impressive sanctuary graced with a curved balcony and a richly carved Ark, Rabbi Schmuel Spiegel searches the streets, as his father did before him, for any Jewish men who might join in. All worshipers on Saturday morning share the kiddush breakfast of cholent, a bean-and-meat casserole.
Orchard Street's genuine pushcart bargains in clothing have been replaced by merchandise that is merely cheap, and the shops and street stands are likely to be run by newly arrived Asians. But there are many vibrant reminders of a Jewish past, including the 114-year-old Katz's Delicatessen on East Houston Street. It's a bustling scene of nonstop noshing on spicy beef hot dogs and pastrami, which is hand-sliced "even if you don't ask," as a counterman assured me. Its famous World War II slogan, "Send a salami to your son in the Army," prompted a Midwestern friend to note that only in New York does salami rhyme with army.
In this neighborhood since 1914, Russ & Daughters remains the source of impeccable smoked fish, herrings, caviar and related luxuries. It is run by Mark Federman, grandson of the founder, who hopes a fourth generation will join him soon. Born on Ludlow Street, Mr. Federman has weathered the area's decline and subsequent rise. "I thought I was dreaming one Sunday in 1987, when I noticed many customers in their late 20's and 30's ordering the whole shmeer and saying they had just moved into the neighborhood," he said. "Most customers then had gray hair and drove in from Long Island and New Jersey."

All in the Family
The fourth generation is also waiting in the wings at Beckenstein Men's Fabrics, a k a Fabric Czar U.S.A.: Jonathan Boyarsky is preparing to take over from his father, Neal, at this 83-year-old mecca for superb woolen suitings and supple cotton shirtings.
These aspects of Jewish life contrast sharply with the savvy, creative and encouragingly polite Paper magazine bar and boutique crowds and to the daily activities of the Hispanic residents who are the mainstay of the streets not yet gentrified. By day, churches, schools, playgrounds, bodegas and luncheonettes suggest aspects of a quiet village, especially on tree-lined blocks like Clinton Street, between Houston and Rivington Streets, or in the expansive Hamilton Fish Recreation Center on Pitt Street, with its 100-by-80-foot swimming pool, game courts and gardens.
The backdrop for this cultural mix remains generally shabby, with tenements overshadowing the re-dos, some of which deliberately retain run-down exteriors to save money or preserve the area's character.
A case in point is Denise Carbonell's shop, with colorful ceramic tableware and fabrics made by the owner; it's cheerful by day but dismal at night when the security gates are locked and the only sign reads "Louis Zuflacht," a ghostly bygone haberdasher. Most depressing are the graffiti-splashed corrugated metal shutters that hide bars and restaurant by day, and shops at night. But if some parts of every block look deserted, they hardly seem ominous thanks to lively street traffic.

A Time to Shop
Saturday proved the perfect time to survey an array of boutiques, shops of ephemera and casual places to eat. The most encouraging fashion boutique is Forward, an unintended reminder of the Yiddish newspaper that originated in the landmark building on East Broadway. On an obscure stretch of Orchard Street, this boutique was sponsored by the local Business Improvement District to showcase four young designers who work at the shop, to gain business experience. Along with the bizarre and petite shrugs, dresses and pants are the contemporary classics of Franklin Rowe, whose smart suits and jackets can be ordered in realistically larger sizes.
Fanciful vintage clothing, shoes and accessories are displayed alongside house creations at Marmalade. Nearby, at Mary Adams the Dress, the owner custom makes romantic wedding and party dresses of dreamy silk organza, washed taffeta and lace. At the pocket-size shop called Cha Cha's House of Ill Repute, a milliner, Deena Pisano, creates snappy hats for women. If you feel in need of intellectual fare about now, enter the nearby Bluestockings Women's Bookstore and Cafe devoted to books by women and feminist interests; it's a countrified cooperative where discussion and readings are held, and snacks are sold.
Sunday was the day for Orchard Street bargains: designer handbags at Fine & Klein, luggage at Altman's (where I have shopped for 10 years) and the varied, reasonably priced jewelry at Allustra, where there are many clip-on earrings because the owner, Ilsa Totuh, does not have pierced ears. If home furnishings pale beside fashion offerings in this neighborhood, there are still a few places of special interest. Las Venus is crammed with vintage and second-hand modern classics, which always seem to be on sale. On Grand Street, on Sunday, miles of home furnishings fabrics can be seen in Harry Zarin's warehouse, and beautiful name-brand linens and imports are substantially discounted at Harris Levy.
Restore your energy with an onion-scented bialy from Kossar's, some fragrant dried fruit or Turkish pistachios and halvah from Kadouri & Sons or sugary cinnamon churros, the Latino crullers made at the Doughnut Plant. If not those, then spark your senses with Guss's legendary dill- and garlic-pickled cucumbers and tomatoes, now sold at the Tenement Museum.
Or satisfy a sweet tooth with the pop and gourmet candies piled on counters at the Economy Candy Company. Prices? "Mine have to be the lowest," said its second-generation owner, Jerry Cohen, "or no one would come way down here." Those looking for a more healthful snack can find it at a three-month-old natural food shop, Earthmatters, which has an Internet cafe along with everything vegetarian and organic, another sign of the area's resurgence.
Thus refreshed, consider esoterica. Start with the antique and used rough outerwear, like parkas and army uniforms, at Strongarm, which also sells utilitarian Civil War campaign lamps, old carpenter's workbenches and mellow horse blankets. For picked string instruments of all kinds, visit Ludlow Guitars, headquarters for the new, the used and the custom made, and guitar recordings of the owner, Robert Gary. 
Before getting totally lost in food shopping and bargain-hunting, remember to seek out landmarks in passing, among them the palatial Seward Park Branch of the New York Public Library built in 1909. This was part of a cultural center that flourished in the immigrant area. It included the 113-year-old Mazer Theater, where in 1906 Mark Twain shared the stage with Sholem Alecheim. Another architectural gem is the set of 19th-century town houses that serve as the headquarters of the Henry Street Settlement social agency.
In addition to the Angel Orensanz, other theatrical fare to sample includes theater, music and dance at the Abrons Center on Grand Street. Various dramas are performed in the three theaters of the Clemente Soto Velez Center -- named for the late activist Puerto Rican poet -- which is in the former Public School 160, a once beautiful building that deserves restoration. In addition to plays like "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," it offers popular puppet shows, often in both Spanish and English, in its children's theater. 

An Ethnic Smorgasbord
Which leaves nothing to do but eat, of course, and this neighborhood offers varied traditional and innovative choices.
In the first category is Sammy's Roumanian Steak House, with its nonstop bar mitzvah. The walls ripple with curling photos and press clips and the live music ranges from "Romania, Romania" to "Strangers in the Night." All the while, huge crowds devour delicious chopped liver and unborn eggs; flanken, in mushroom and barley soup; potatoes, in latkes or mashed with schmaltz; and -- the best -- grilled steaks and veal chops.
Being passionate about Chinese food, I'll never forgive myself for not trying Congee Village before this weekend escapade. In a series of rooms designed to suggest a village, this Hong Kong-Canton kitchen turns out delectable, traditional dishes. After sampling about 20, I found that all were at the very least good, and most were sensational. The simple breakfast rice porridge, congee, can be had in more than a dozen variations, from plain to chicken or crab or frogs or snails. But more elegant shellfish, meat, noodles and vegetable dishes are equally astonishing for their authenticity and flavor.
Among the innovative and eclectic, 71 Clinton Fresh Foods has become a coolly stylish legend in its own short time. With lovely food like savory chestnut gnocchi and tender lamb loin with Israeli couscous, it is better than ever. This is despite the departure of its original chef, Wylie Dufresne, who, with partners Phil Suarez and Jean-Georges Vongerichten, is preparing to open WD50, a further taste of sophistication at 50 Clinton Street. 
And as a culinary fusion work in progress, consider Essex, a high and handsome bar restaurant with successful choices like short rib ravioli, roasted duck breast on kasha varnishkes, crisp empanadas, and a lusty strip steak with charmula sauce and potato hash. 
But among the young chefs testing their skills downtown, my favorite by far is Paladar's rakish Aaron Sanchez, who spins gastronomic wonders based on a Mexican-Hispanic palate, honed by his mother, Zarela Martinez of Zarela's. Many inventions in this festive cafe are so skillfully realized that they seem to be classics. Among such are the frothy pumpkin soup, calabaza cappuccino, and an addictive seafood guisado, a saline soup-stew in a spicy coconut milk broth.
If atmosphere counts almost as much as the food, the clear choices are Suba and Mooza. Suba is a subterranean boite with a moat swirling around the dining platform, casting Venice-like shimmers on brick walls. The prettified food needs nothing more than seasonings to perfect it, and there are several winning choices.
Mooza is a journey into the Arabian Nights, with red-flocked gold wallpaper, exotic lanterns and campy paintings of the nine muses -- Mooza in Hebrew, according to the Israeli-born partner, Gil Elnatan.
The Italian chef, Gabriele Di Martino, does best by his native fare, but like so many chefs in the area is stingy with salt. But there are enough good choices to warrant sitting inside or out. The beautiful garden, with fountain, will open in a week or so.
For casual snacking, consider Middle Eastern salads, falafel and kebobs at Bereket, which is inexpensive and crowded at mealtimes. Or more stylishly, try the AKA Cafe, an offshoot of 71 Clinton Street that is best for savory small appetizers and sandwiches, especially on pressed bialys. 
Finally, there is the gentle Hispanic comfort food at the friendly luncheonette El Castillo de Jagua, where local families and friends gather for a taste of home.

Sweet Dreams
Not being much of a barfly, I leave you on your own for the dozens lined up here, suggesting only an hour or so at Max Fish, whose owner, Ulli Rimkus, was a pioneer in the neighborhood when she opened on Ludlow Street in 1989. Nothing thematic or cutesy here, just one big house party with pool table, pinball machines, a jukebox and a mishmash of carnival accessories.
Some bars add music and performances, like the Bowery Ballroom in its trim landmark building with a soaring music room upstairs, and the affiliated Mercury Lounge. Both places feature up-and-coming pop and rock bands.
For a finale to your weekend adventure, wind up close to midnight at the big Slipper Room and catch Mr. Choade's "Upstairs Downstairs," a vaudeville burlesque show. Then nod off up at Howard Johnson's and be glad you stayed close by.

HEADLINE: JOURNEYS; 
A Fallen Saigon Rises Again In the West

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

 BODY:
THERE are no old battlefields here, no red flags with the gold star of communism, no monuments to Ho Chi Minh.
 Here in the Los Angeles suburb of Westminster, Calif., in a community known as Little Saigon, Vietnamese refugees have created something entirely new: a Southern California version of the country they left behind. 
 Drive 45 miles down the 405 freeway from Los Angeles, swing through the 22 freeway, curve around an off ramp and -- what is this? -- everything is written in Vietnamese.
There are miles of pastel mini-malls where all the shops have Vietnamese names. The sales pitches on billboards are in Vietnamese. Quavering Asian melodies float from storefronts. A woman power-walks through a park wearing the conical straw hat of a rice farmer. 
Everything looks clean, new and well-to-do, from the polished cars that jam the parking lots to the grocery stores with exotic foods wrapped in plastic. 
It is like an episode of "The Twilight Zone," a slice of alternative reality: this is what Saigon might have looked like if America had won the war in 1975.
The giant, climate-controlled Asian Garden Mall, at Bolsa Avenue and Brookhurst Street, is its centerpiece, Vietnam in a bottle, spic and span and celebrating the Vietnamese passions of food, music and jewelry -- including not one but two separate emporiums of gold and gems surrounded by dozens of stalls selling fast-food delicacies like xoi (sticky rice with sausage and other fillings) and banh cuon (tender dumplings with ground pork).
The 27 years since the fall of Saigon are telescoped here into a world that blends the past and the future. At the Chua Vietnam Buddhist temple, monks and nuns in saffron and white light their incense sticks and perform their rituals oblivious to time and place. At the Cafe Brodard restaurant, tucked away at the back entrance of the Mall of Fortune, at Westminster Avenue and Brookhurst Street, diners eat pork wrapped in rice paper as a large-screen television plays music videos of traditional songs.
It is early in the morning -- at cafes like the Coffee Factory (15582 Brookhurst Street) and Le Croissant Dore (9122 Bolsa Avenue) -- that the ghosts of the past emerge. Sad, aging veterans of a lost war drink strong French coffee and murmur about the lives and the land they left behind.
There are men like Lt. Henry Le, a former South Vietnamese air force pilot, who seems to still be standing by for orders and who carries business cards reading: "Anywhere anytime. All weather attack bomber. Freedom fighter."
But there are others who have moved on vigorously, like Nguyen Thi Ngoc Thuy, 47, who runs Nuoc Mia Vien Tay, a shop specializing in a Vietnamese treat, sugar-cane juice sweetened with a squeeze of orange. She has placed the past on a back shelf of her shop: a model of a fighter plane her husband flew during the war. In the future, she plans to leave her business to study interior design, just as soon as her son finishes law school.
There is nobody more energetic than a Vietnamese immigrant. This town is a sort of Alice's Restaurant crowded with florists, fortune tellers, dentists, tennis instructors, nail salons, bottled-water outlets, chiropractors, driving schools, travel agencies.
There is nothing like it in Vietnam, in the struggling communist society produced by the people who won the war, where private enterprise is still a new toy to play with and where there is still no need for such a thing as a parking lot. 
It is on weekend nights that the truly successful crown their achievements with lavish wedding parties -- gate crashers are welcome -- at gigantic restaurants like the Grand Garden. As Little Saigon has grown richer, the guest lists have swollen to as many as 600 and the evening's tab to more than $15,000.
About 135,000 ethnic Vietnamese live in Southern California's Orange County, and Little Saigon is their hub for shopping and socializing, for reading Vietnamese papers and listening to Vietnamese radio programs, for adding their voices to the town's passionate emigre politics.
"This is my home away from home," said Tracy Pham, 49, a software consultant who lives in Irvine, and visits almost every weekend. "When I am at work, I am an American. When I head back to Little Saigon I'm 100 percent Vietnamese."
On weekends, thousands of Vietnamese from around the state and the country converge here, jamming even the most spacious parking lots. And as much as anything, they come to eat. All along the streets of Little Saigon are shops with numbers in their name: Pho 76, Pho 86, Pho 79, Pho 54, -- lucky numbers chosen by their owners.
Each of these noodle shops sells pho (pronounced Fuh), the fragrant soup served with beef, chicken, pork or tripe and eaten with chopsticks and a spoon. It is a staple without which no Vietnamese could subsist for long. The secret is in the broth, and some shop owners hire Hispanic waiters for fear a fellow Vietnamese would steal the recipe. 
It is not difficult for an outsider to do as the locals do: to spend the day sampling the cuisine from cafe to food stall to restaurant.
There are French-Vietnamese restaurants like the Green Papaya (15691 Brookhurst), with its fragrant Vietnamese rice, an import that is often labeled "Thai rice" to dodge the fury of hard-liners who oppose anything coming from communist Vietnam. And there are specialty restaurants like Pogolac (14580 Brookhurst), which serves "beef cooked seven ways," a banquet of beef grilled, simmered, stuffed or wrapped, with herbs and sauces served on the side.
The year's high point -- in late January or early February -- is Tet, the Vietnamese lunar new year, a time when there is a crowded parking-lot fair and a parade with floats that fly the yellow-and-red flag of a nation that no longer exists, South Vietnam.
Little Saigon -- which has spread from Westminster, block by block, into parts of Garden Grove, Santa Ana, Fountain Valley and Midway City -- really did start out little. The first refugees in early 1975 were housed at the Camp Pendleton military base in San Diego, some 50 miles to the south. Their first forays into their new homeland were to visit the county's social welfare office, which was in Westminster. The refugees needed a place to sit down to help each other decipher the forms for welfare, food stamps and health care, and so the first noodle shop was opened. It was soon followed by dozens more.
Now, among the 1.3 million registered voters in Orange County, about 16,000 have the last name Nguyen. Little Saigon is home to 3,000 businesses.
At a moment when America is finding itself condemned in many foreign countries, the scene here is a reminder of the nation's continuing magnetism.
"The story of Little Saigon is the story of America," said Yen Do, editor of the 18,000-circulation Nguoi Viet Daily News, the largest Vietnamese-language newspaper in the country. "What happened here in a few years is what has happened in America in 200 years. Everybody around the world wants to repeat this experience, this refugee experience."

SIDETRIPS
Traveling the World (But Without Leaving the Country)

IN ST. PAUL, A TASTE OF THE HMONG

In the late 1970's, Laotian refugees of the Chinese Hmong clans began arriving in St. Paul. The largest Hmong population in the United States has its nucleus in a 10-block area called Frogtown, near the University of Minnesota.

* Foodsmart Restaurant; 544 University Avenue West, (651) 665-9105. A Hmong buffet is served daily, with roast chicken, pork sausage, quav iab nyuj, (a soup with galangal, chili peppers and beef intestines) and nqauj xyaw qhiav (a rice dish with ginger, green onion, black mushrooms, and your choice of meat).
* Hmong Vientiane; 469 Anita Avenue, (651) 222-4258. This small diner serves vegetarian meals as well as pigeon and fish specials.
* Bangkok City Supper Club; 733 Pierce Butler Route, (651) 488-0037). This nightspot combines a restaurant serving Hmong food with a bar and live music.

ETHIOPIA ON THE POTOMAC

The area along 18th Street NW is among the most multicultural in Washington, with a high concentration of Ethiopian immigrants who began arriving in the early 1980's. The district is now flush with restaurants featuring traditional fare like the spongy, slightly sour pancakes called injera that are used to scoop up thick meat stews, mostly served communally and sans silverware.

* Addis Ababa; 2106 18th Street NW, (301) 251-7878. This mainstay serves classic injera with chicken or lamb stews.

* Fasika's Ethiopian; 2447 18th Street NW, (202) 797-7673. Offering chicken, lamb or beef stews (either hot or mild), light pastry appetizers as well as seafood.

* Meskerem Ethiopian; 2434 18th Street NW, (202) 462-4100. Consistently rated among the city's best in Ethiopian dining; low stools on the third floor offering the best view of the neighborhood. Appetizers include beef-stuffed pastries, steamed shrimp with a spicy sauce and a beet, potato and chili salad.
* Red Sea Ethiopian Restaurant; 2463 18th Street NW, (202) 483-5000. Large faded travel-agency posters of Ethiopia give this inexpensive restaurant a lived-in atmosphere. The menu features classic Ethiopian, as well as kik wat (yellow split peas with ginger root and nutmeg) and temiser azefah ( a spicy puree of lentils).

IN ATLANTA, KOREAN CULTURE

Many of the more than 70,000 Koreans who live in Atlanta today are concentrated in the community of Doraville, which stretches northeast of the city along Buford Highway, where the malls and storefronts house Korean businesses, groceries and, of course, restaurants. Bars, nightclubs and karaoke parlors keep the parking lots full at night.

* 88 Tofu House; 490 Buford Highway (770) 457-8811. This bargain restaurant allows diners to create their own versions of tofu soup.

* Asiana Garden; 5150 Buford Highway (770) 452-1677. In addition to sushi, this mid-priced barbecue has an extensive meat selection for tableside grilling.

* Harue Cafe; 58-72 Buford Highway, (770) 220-3013. The menu includes Korean, Japanese and Western fare, and there's a glassed-in garden room.

* Pung Mie; 5145 Buford Highway, (770) 455-0435. Steamed or fried dumplings, san shan seafood noodle soup and squid or shrimp with nida (similar to a green onion).

IN CHICAGO, SOUTHEAST ASIA

A thriving South Asian population has made the area home in the area bisected by Western Avenue, with Pakistanis on the east side of Western Avenue and Indians -- and Indian restaurants -- on the west.

* Arya Bhawan Restaurant; 2508 West Devon Avenue, (773) 274-5800. The only all-vegetarian buffet on Devon; daily lunches and weekend evenings.

* Udupi Palace; 2543 West Devon Avenue, (773) 338-2152. This South Indian restaurant is known for its extremely large dhosas (an Indian crepe).

* Tiffin the Indian Restaurant; 2536 West Devon Avenue, (773) 338-2143. With a more refined atmosphere, this restaurant serves both North and South Indian fare, featuring barbequed chicken, tandori king prawns and lamb shish-kababs.

IN DETROIT, PRIDE AND PIEROGIES

Poles were first drawn to Hamtramck, a two-square mile island within the city of Detroit, by the opening of the Dodge engine plant in 1910. The plant closed in 1980 but the community remained.

* Ivanhoe Cafe; 5249 Joseph Campau Street, (313) 925-5335. Located along the Detroit River, this cafe specializes in seafood.

* Polish Village Cafe; 2990 Yemans Street, (313) 874-5726. This subterranean restaurant beneath an historic Hamtramck home offers classic Polish dishes like nalesniki (crepes) and golabki (stuffed cabbage). During 1996, President Bill Clinton ate perogies here.

* Krakus Restaurant and Bar; 12900 Joseph Campau Street, (313) 368-4848. Traditional Polish fare, and a dance hall on Saturday evenings.

* Holbrook Cafe; 3201 Holbrook Street, (313) 875-1115. This site of the former Polish American Century Club is known for its Friday night fish fry.

* Under the Eagle Cafe; 9000 Joseph Campau Street, (313) 875-5905. In addition to roast pork loin, sauerkraut and pierogis, the restaurant is known for dill pickle soup.

IN THE AREA
Asian Tastes and Sounds In Southern California
Scattered throughout Southern California are other communities like Little Saigon. Here are some that are worth a visit:
* Little Phnom Penh in Long Beach, Calif., is a Cambodian enclave that dates back to the 1960's. These days, the population is about 50,000; the main thoroughfare is Anaheim Street.
Popular restaurants include La Lune, which has live music on the weekend, 1458 Atlantic Avenue, (562) 599-5457; Hak Heang, with dishes that include anchovy beef and curried fish, 2041 East Anaheim Street, (562) 434-0296; and New Paradise, which is known for both its catfish and its community fund-raisers, 1350 East Anaheim Street, (562) 218-0066.
* Little Tokyo in downtown Los Angeles was once home to more than 30,000 immigrants. It now has shrunk to a population of 1,500 and covers three square blocks.
But even if Little Tokyo is smaller, it still has a lot to offer. For instance, the Japanese Village Plaza, 347 East Second Street, is a 2.4-acre complex that is home to more than 40 stores. One of the plaza's establishments is Hama Sushi, a small restaurant known for its friendly staff and fresh fish; the number is (213) 680-3454.
* The first settlers of Koreatown were farm workers who arrived in the early 1900's. But immigration to the United States was soon severely curtailed. The population boom did not start again until 1965.
One of the neighborhood's big events is the Koreatown Festival, an annual celebration in the fall that has live music, a parade and floats. 
The Koreatown Plaza at 928 South Western Avenue, (213) 382-1234, has three levels of shopping with more than 70 stores offering things like books, clothing, jewelry and music.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Hybrid Arithmetic: Pay More, Fill Less

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW WALD 

 BODY:
FOR a vehicle designed primarily for policy wonks, the hybrid car is surprisingly cool. Hybrids, which use more than one power source (usually gasoline and electricity), are designed to be more environmentally friendly than gas-powered cars. But they also represent the vanguard of car technology and, with only two models on the road until recently, they were unquestionably exotic. 
 That has changed. Honda recently began offering a hybrid version of the ubiquitous Civic. The possibility that hybrids could become mainstream vehicles raises two complicated questions: do you try to save either your money or the planet? 
 The Civic offers an opportunity to compare hybrid and gasoline-only models. (Neither of the earlier hybrids, the Toyota Prius and the Honda Insight, come in a plain-vanilla version.) According to Honda, the new Civic hybrid will cost $19,990, about $1,500 more than the Civic EX, the most comparable gasoline-only model. Will that difference be made up at the gas pump? 
Ordinary cars burn gasoline in an internal combustion engine. The Civic hybrid has an internal combustion engine, but it also has an electric motor (actually a device that is both a motor and a generator), which assists the gasoline engine at high-load periods, like when a traffic light turns green. 
When the car stops at a red light, for example, the internal combustion engine stops. Touch the gas pedal, and the electric motor turns the internal combustion engine to start it instantly. This works better than the starter motor on a regular car because the hybrid's 13-horsepower electric motor is more powerful. 
Thirteen horses may not sound like much, but electric motors have very good torque, or pulling power, at low speeds, so that the hybrid will out-accelerate a conventional car going 0 to 30, according to Honda, and lag slightly going from 0 to 60. 
The interplay between the engine and the electric motor also means that a hybrid recharges without being plugged in. To decelerate, the driver steps on an ordinary looking brake pedal. Instead of engaging the brakes, the pedal engages the electric motor, which takes the car's momentum and converts it into electric current. The current is dumped back into the battery. The brakes are engaged only if the car decelerates sharply, so most of the energy wasted in braking in an ordinary car is recaptured in the hybrid.
This amounts to considerable savings on gasoline. The hybrid Civic is rated by the Environmental Protection Agency at 46 miles a gallon in the city, 51 on the highway. The conventional Civic gets 31 and 38 miles a gallon, respectively. 
But the question of whether hybrids save money is not simply about gas consumption. To measure the cost difference between the hybrid Civic and the EX, a spreadsheet was prepared by Daniel Goldman of New Energy Capital in Newton, Mass. 
Assuming that an owner drives the hybrid for 10 years an average of 12,000 miles a year, pays $1.50 a gallon for gas and borrows the extra $1,500 (for the cost of the car) at 3 percent on a three-year loan, and that the money could have earned 7 percent in the stock market, the Hybrid would save about $12 more than the EX. But when you calculate the present value of the $1,500 loan minus the money saved on gas, and invest the difference at 7 percent, the Hybrid costs about $274.74 more than the EX. The cost of gas will not have to rise too much for the car to break even. 
Some factors are not included in the spreadsheet. John Watts, a Honda spokesman, said that the company expected maintenance costs to be similar to the regular Civic's, until the hybrid's battery pack needed replacing (about 100,000 miles), estimated to cost $2,000, Mr. Watts said.
A proposed tax credit also comes into play: the House and Senate versions of the energy bill both include them. Some states offer a credit already; Arizona's is $3,000, Mr. Watts said. 
What may help tip the balance for some consumers are the environmental benefits. Both versions release extremely small amounts of smog-forming chemicals, but the hybrid releases less carbon dioxide. "It's hard to justify hybrids purely from a consumer economics' perspective," said John M. DeCicco, a senior fellow at Environmental Defense. "I'm sure some buyers will value saving more fuel, thereby reducing a key part of pollution, than they might value for pocketbook reasons alone."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Market Struggles but Manages to End 4-Day Losing Streak

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks withstood a day of fluctuating prices and managed a modest advance yesterday as investors tussled with worries about the strength of the economic recovery and a profit warning from the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb.
 The buying, which ended a four-day losing streak for the Dow Jones industrial average, was mostly attributed to lower prices after two weeks of strong selling. 
 The market struggled to hold its gains largely because investors were uneasy about Bristol-Myers. As a drug stock, Bristol-Myers should be considered less risky during economic uncertainty. 
"It brings up the question of what is safe," said Barry Hyman, chief investment strategist at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum.
The Dow closed up 36.88 points, or 0.4 percent, at 10,235.17. The blue chips had dropped 228.62 points, or 2.2 percent, over the previous four sessions.
The broader market also ended higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.40 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,789.75, having declined 78.27 points Tuesday and Wednesday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 0.94 point, or 0.1 percent, to 1,126.34.
Analysts said the market would have a hard time sustaining an upturn as investors had little reason besides attractive prices to buy shares.
Investors are concerned that first-quarter earnings reports will be disappointing and that corporate outlooks will remain bleak. Tension in the Middle East has also heightened fears in the market that the conflict will lead to higher oil prices.
Bond prices were mixed. By late in the day, the two-year note fell 1/32, to 100 5/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 3.54 percent from 3.53 percent on Wednesday. The benchmark 10-year note rose 2/32, to a price of 97 1/32. Its yield dropped to 5.26 percent from 5.27 percent.
The 30-year bond rose 1/32, to 95 8/32. Its yield fell to 5.71 percent from 5.72.
"People get fed up with not making any money," said Gary Kaltbaum, market technician for Investors' Edge Partners in Orlando, Fla. "You are maybe getting some of that. I think the upside is limited."
Bristol-Myers plunged $5.55, or nearly 15 percent, to $32.15 after warning late Wednesday that its first-quarter and yearly earnings would miss analysts' expectations. Bristol-Myers expects 2002 profits to decline 25 percent to 30 percent. Other pharmaceutical issues declined, including Merck, which closed down $1.49, at $55.80.
Among the biggest gainers, Bed Bath & Beyond rose $2.12, to $33.71, after reporting fourth-quarter earnings that surpassed Wall Street's forecast by 2 cents a share and raising its yearly outlook.
General Motors advanced 79 cents, to $60.14, after Merrill Lynch raised its second-quarter and yearly earnings estimates for the company, citing increased expectations for G.M.'s North American production.
The technology sector, which many analysts predict will be the last to recover, had the hardest time achieving its slim gain.
"Technology is not ready yet to be a leadership sector," Mr. Hyman said.
Microsoft rose 12 cents, to $56.45, despite news that its president and chief operating officer, Rick Belluzzo, was stepping down and that a company revamping would eliminate his job. A. G. Edwards upgraded Microsoft's shares to buy from hold.
I.B.M. advanced 88 cents, to $100.84, rebounding from two days of losses after Goldman, Sachs cut its first-quarter revenue estimate.
The Russell 2000 index, the barometer of smaller company stocks, rose 1.77, or 0.4 percent, to 498.37.
Declining stocks were even with advancers on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume came to 1.29 billion shares on the New York Stock Exchange, up slightly from 1.22 billion shares on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Poznan Journal; 
Polish Hip-Hop Rocks the Homies on the Blok

BYLINE:  By PETER S. GREEN 

DATELINE: POZNAN, Poland 

 BODY:
The view from Freedom Street in a Poznan housing project is not pretty. Unemployment in this relatively prosperous city 100 miles from the German border is near 20 percent. Drug use and petty crime are rife. Inflation is high, the underpaid police are generally regarded as corrupt, and the local Roman Catholic archbishop is in disgrace for allegedly molesting seminarians.
 In a ground-floor apartment here, Peja, Doniu, a couple of guys named Jacek and a tough-looking youth who calls himself Liber are discussing the local hip-hop scene in the four clean, cramped rooms where "D.J. Decks" -- a k a Dariusz Dzialek -- lives with his mother. 
 "It's absolutely sure that if I wasn't rapping, I'd be stealing," said Peja, Poland's leading hip-hop artist. "A lot of people think Polish hip-hop is only about the street, but we are talking about ourselves, our relationships, other problems."
To the hundreds of thousands of young Poles with little prospect of a good job or a secure future, Peja -- real name Ryszard Andrzejewski -- and dozens of other hip-hop rhymers who have emerged in the past several years are their generation's poets, expressing the hopes and despair of young men in the Polish projects.
They are known as "blokersi" (pronounced bloh-CARE-zhee) for the housing projects or "bloki" that circumscribe their lives. Day after day, they sit outside their cracking concrete towers, drinking vodka and beer, hanging around and looking for ways to make some cash. In winter, they favor the stairwells.
In some ways, the scene is a measure of how far Poland has traveled in the dozen years since the fall of a Communist system in which everyone worked even if the work was meaningless. The disillusionment of the jobless, and the way they express it, has clear parallels in the capitalist societies of the United States and western Europe.
The bloki of Freedom Street are a long way from the South Bronx, but the seething anger of young men facing an uncertain future is the same. So here in the all-white, all-Catholic, family-centered housing projects of Poland's inner cities, hip-hop has found a new audience.
"Hip-hop is the only electric current of culture," said Sylwester Latkowski, whose recent documentary on the Polish hip-hop scene was a big hit in movie theaters here last fall. "It's the only thing that reflects what young people really feel."
Hip-hop, Mr. Latkowski said, is a natural response to Poland's haphazard transition from Communism to free-market democracy.
"Throughout the period of transition, neighborhoods come up that are black holes -- bad schools, no cops, no playgrounds, graffiti, drugs," he said. "The only thing the government has done is proposed lowering the age of criminal responsibility so they can be sent to jail sooner."
Hip-hop is generally considered to have come to Poland courtesy of Bogna Swiatkowska, who spent a year traveling around the United States after Communism fell in 1989.
In 1993, she hosted a show about black American culture on one of Poland's first private radio stations. Soon, Ms. Swiatkowska recalled, young Poles were lining the studio corridors, begging her to play their own homemade hip-hop tapes.
Language, she said, was no barrier. "They are angry, too," she said of young Poles. "They don't have to understand the words. They can see it."
Today Polish hip-hop groups sell about 100,000 CD's a year to mostly impoverished fans, who buy about three times more pirated hip-hop disks at street kiosks, according to recording industry estimates.
The popularity appears driven by despair. "These aren't songs about a woman dancing or flowers growing," said Marcin Rapczynski, a 24-year-old aspiring rhymer who calls himself "Siwy," or Blondie, from Brodno, a grim sprawl of concrete-panel "bloki" on Warsaw's northern edge. "It's real."
"These young members of the culture don't know or don't care about the outside," said Arek Delis, editor of the glossy monthly hip-hop magazine Klan. "For many young people this seems to be the only escape from the stealing and dealing they see going on outside their windows."
Part of the appeal, Peja said, lies in the abundance of material and the lowest cost of making a hip-hop record. Turntables and a personal computer in a friend's bedroom suffice as a recording studio. Records cost as little as about $1,000 to make -- and rarely bring in more than about $2,500, said Mr. Delis, who also has his own record company.
While Polish hip-hop's anger may echo that of urban African-American youths, the lyrics barely touch on familiar American themes of police violence or racism (Poland is virtually all-white). Fancy cars, guns and gold chains are not part of the picture -- given the relatively small potential market in this country of 39 million, and the relative poverty of most fans, riches are out of the question.
Instead, hip-hop here celebrates the grimness of life in the bloki. Occasionally, the songs stray into political territory, bemoaning widespread corruption or efforts to join the European Union, a step that many in the Bloki believe will drive up prices more and drive away jobs.
Rhymers like Peja say they don't want to get rich fast, or even get out of the bloki, clinging instead to the life they know and casting themselves in the tradition of Poland's most famous 19th-century poet, Adam Mickiewicz, and the "Mloda Polska," or Young Poland movement that defined the country's national image in the decades before Poland won freedom in 1918.
"If Mickiewicz was alive today, he'd be a good rhymer," Doniu said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Polish hip-hoppers, from left, Peja, D.J. Decks, Wisniowy, Silent, Donik and Mejger, at the housing project where they live in Poznan, Poland. "It's absolutely sure that if I wasn't rapping, I'd be stealing," Peja said. (Piotr Malecki for The New York Times) Map of Poland highlighting Poznan: The unemployment rate in Poznan is nearly 20 percent.

HEADLINE: Extension of Benefits Contributes To an Increase in Jobless Claims

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4 

 BODY:
The number of Americans who filed initial claims for state unemployment benefits surged last week to the highest level in four months, the Labor Department said today. A law enacted last month permitted workers whose benefits had expired to apply for an extension. 
 State unemployment offices received 460,000 new applications last week, up 64,000 in the week that ended Saturday, the Labor Department said. A week earlier, initial claims rose 20,000. 
 The law, signed by President Bush on March 9, was intended to help cushion the blow of the recession that started last year. Analysts said the resulting jump in claims in the last two weeks was masking a slow improvement in labor markets. Unemployment fell in February to a four-month low of 5.5 percent.
"This is just a bad number," said Richard Yamarone, chief economist at Argus Research. "The labor market is slowly but surely improving. That's the true trend."
Joblessness typically rises for several months after the economy rebounds because most companies hold off hiring until they are certain the recovery will be sustained.
Under the new law, workers whose 26 weeks of benefits have run out are eligible to receive another 13 weeks of assistance. Some 116,860 Americans had filed for an extension as of March 16, according to 22 states that have reported so far.
Last week's level of claims was the highest since 480,000 in the week that ended Dec. 1. 
The four-week moving average of claims, which smooths out volatility in the weekly numbers, rose to 403,750 last week from 384,000.

HEADLINE: Columbia Gets Star Professor From Harvard 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Columbia University announced yesterday that it had poached another star economist from a major university, this time from Harvard, which has already been roiled by threats of defection by prominent professors.
 The newly recruited professor, Jeffrey D. Sachs, a prominent figure in international economics, had been at Harvard since he entered as a freshman 29 years ago. The opportunities offered by Columbia could not be matched at Harvard, Mr. Sachs said, adding that he was leaving his alma mater reluctantly. 
 In an interview, Mr. Sachs anticipated conjecture that he had run into the sort of conflicts with Lawrence H. Summers, Harvard's president, that recently alienated several celebrated scholars in Harvard's Afro-American Studies Department.
"I am an enormous admirer of Larry Summers," Mr. Sachs said. "We were in graduate school together and got tenure on the same day in 1983. We taught together, and while we have had disagreements, I left because he could not bring to Cambridge what Columbia and New York had to offer."
Columbia has been trying to regain its old glory as a teaching and research center in economics, a status it enjoyed a generation ago. Last year, it hired Joseph E. Stiglitz, a prominent Stanford economist, who joined the faculty last July and in October won a Nobel Prize. Now Mr. Sachs, 47, is joining Columbia with four titles, at a salary reported to be more than $300,000 a year, not counting benefits, which are still to be negotiated. 
The chief title he will bear, director of Columbia's Earth Institute, plays to Mr. Sachs's strength as an expert in the economies of developing countries and an outspoken advocate of policies that alleviate third world poverty. 
He has argued, for example, that if the industrial countries contributed 1 cent to a health fund out of every $10 of national income, $25 billion would be raised, saving millions of lives.
In a statement, Mr. Summers said that he would miss Mr. Sachs, but "the opportunity he is pursuing at the United Nations and Columbia is a very special one." Last December, Kofi Annan, the secretary-general of the United Nations, made Mr. Sachs a special adviser with the title of under-secretary general, giving him the task, as Mr. Sachs put it, of organizing an international response to poverty. That new role was an additional reason for coming to New York, Mr. Sachs said.
The Earth Institute -- providing Mr. Sachs with an operating budget of $10 million to $15 million annually, the university said -- is a relatively new operation at Columbia, organized several years ago by Michael Crowe, Columbia's executive provost. Mr. Crowe recruited Mr. Sachs away from Harvard, where he has been the director of its much smaller Center for International Development.
"What Columbia is offering through the Earth Institute," Mr. Sachs said, "is a chance to pursue my commitment to sustainable economic development in the third world on a scale that does not exist at any other academic center in the world."
The institute, financed partly through federal subsidies, draws on the resources of other organizations at Columbia, among them the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. Its goal, according to Mr. Crowe and to George Rupp, Columbia's president, is to integrate economics, natural sciences, environmental concerns, public health and similar disciplines.
"We are very interested in building up the economics department," Mr. Rupp said, "but the genius of Jeff Sachs is that he connects development economics with physical sciences and the biological sciences that the Earth Institute represents."
Mr. Sachs, a frequent adviser to governments in the developing world and an early architect of Russian economic policy when Boris Yeltsin was leading the country into capitalism, comes to Columbia with the additional titles of professor in the Schools of Arts and Science, International and Public Affairs, and Public Health, commencing on July 1, when he finishes up at Harvard. 
His peaceful parting from that university and kind words for Mr. Summers were in sharp contrast to the criticism that both Mr. Sachs and Mr. Stiglitz, equally renowned in international economics, leveled at Mr. Summers when he was treasury secretary in the Clinton administration. With Mr. Summers taking the lead, the administration insisted during the Asian economic crisis in the late 1990's that the suffering nations raise interest rates and cut government spending -- austerity measures that in the view of Mr. Sachs and Mr. Stiglitz only increased the hardship and added to unemployment.
Shifting from Washington to Cambridge last year as Harvard's latest president, Mr. Summers suddenly became Mr. Sachs's boss and they apparently buried their feud. "Larry has personally given me full support and my development agenda full support," Mr. Sachs said.
But Mr. Summers soon came into conflict with Cornel West and other black professors, including Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of the Afro-American Studies Department. They differed over research procedures, among other issues, and Mr. Summers made amends. But a black professor of philosophy, K. Anthony Appiah, resigned to go to Princeton, and Dr. West has talked of shifting to Princeton.
Columbia rolled out all the drums for Mr. Sachs. The university offered statements of praise not only from Mr. Rupp, the outgoing president, but from Lee C. Bollinger, who will soon replace him. Star economists rarely shift universities and now Columbia, offering top salaries, has lured two in its effort to rebuild its economics team and rank once again alongside Harvard, Princeton, Stanford, M.I.T. and the University of Chicago.

An article on Friday about Columbia University's hiring of a renowned economist, Jeffrey D. He is executive vice provost, not executive provost.

HEADLINE: Telecom Concern Cuts Jobs 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4 

 BODY:
Time Warner Telecom said today that it had released 140 employees, partly because of the sluggish economy, and had no further market expansion plans. 
 In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company, which is based in Littleton, Colo., and is partly owned by AOL Time Warner, said it expected to employ about 2,200 people after the release of the workers. 
 Time Warner Telecom said that over the last two years the company had expanded its reach to 44 markets from 21, but that it had no immediate plans for further expansion.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: VOICES; 
New Yorkers Tell of Fear, Anger and Fatigue Over Mideast

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Like a relentless drama too painful to watch but too compelling to turn away from, the conflict in the Middle East has put knots in New York-area residents' stomachs and suicide bombers in their nightmares. The turmoil is geographically distant, they say, but with its echoes of Sept. 11, and its passion, it is emotionally all too close. 
 People interviewed yesterday -- Arab-Americans, Jews and others -- talked of hopelessness, fear and anger, and the need for America to take a leadership role to try to end what looks increasingly like war. 
 Most had not yet seen or heard about President Bush's speech. Those who did gave it mixed reviews. 
Bassem Nassar, 30, an unemployed marketing professional who was born in Lebanon, said it came too late. "He gave the green light to Sharon to do whatever he wanted in the last six days," Mr. Nassar said, referring to the Israeli prime minister. "The U.S. is behind the curve," he said, pointing to European criticism of Israel's incursion into Palestinian cities.
Jay Hecht, assistant to the superintendent of Community School District 3 in Manhattan, disagreed, calling the speech the first bright spot in days of gloom. "I'm just heartbroken about what's going on there," he said, adding that he thought Israel's very existence was at stake. 
"I'm hopeful the president recognizes he has to apply some pressure" to both sides, Mr. Hecht said.
Mostafa Abou, 29, a lanky Egyptian who works as a waiter at the Bedouin Tent restaurant in the Cobble Hill section of Brooklyn, said he would reserve judgment, having been "very disappointed" in Mr. Bush's previous speech, which he considered biased toward Israel. Their differences started with semantics: Mr. Abou saw the Palestinians Mr. Bush called terrorists as fighters against an occupying army.
Mr. Abou's customers are Jews, Arab-Americans, Christians and more, a reminder that New Yorkers continue to coexist peacefully here. 
But some said they did not know how long the conflict could be kept at a distance. Dianne Lamonica, 45, works at an antique store in an Arab stretch of Cobble Hill and eats at the Bedouin Tent. "I try not to let these feelings influence me," she said, but confessed that when she sees an "Arab gentleman on the subway" carrying a large bag, she worries.
Some expressed simple impatience with intractability. Jose Lopez, 37, a mechanic in Paterson, N.J., who is originally from Puerto Rico, said he was tiring of the seemingly endless cycle of violent responses on both sides. 
"That's all you hear on the news," he said. "It get to a point where all you hear the same thing, the same thing, and you don't want to look at the TV. Those people, I hope they make peace quick."
He expressed bafflement at suicide bombers: "These people got to start getting real. You want to take your own life, go by yourself."
Sasson Nabi, 64, wakes up every day trying to think of a solution. Each day, he realizes there isn't one. A Jew from Iraq who built a career as a financial consultant in New York, he has grown depressed watching the region where he grew up darken with violence. 
"I don't want anyone to be killed," he said. "I don't want anyone to suffer unless there is a good reason. And there is no good reason there. In my belief, both sides are really losers."
Sowmya Parthasarathy, 34, an Indian architect and city planner, has been racking her brain, too, for an answer, saying that her sympathies switch sides almost daily. 
"It's heartbreaking," she said. The question, she said, is, "What is the way to stop the killing? That's just paramount." 
A number of people said the events of last week had shifted their views, radically or by degrees. Kelly Spitler, who owns a business, OfficeMavens, in Brooklyn, said Mr. Bush needed to recognize that the Israelis also bore responsibility for events, and that "the Palestinians are sort of getting a raw deal." She may have thought that before, she said, but she never would have said it until now.
Sheri Stein, 49, a Brooklyn writer, said that for the first time this week, she had concluded that Israel "can't go on like this -- it's an untenable situation."
"They don't want to feel like they're giving up because of terrorists," she said, "but on the other hand they can't just kill all the Palestinians. That's not going to work. Something has to change."
Arnie Mansdorf, 45, a New York City social studies teacher, said everything he taught his children had been based on "the joy of meeting other people." But he said: "I've been wondering about the validity of the lessons I've taught my three children. What kind of people sacrifice their own children to bombings?"
The very nature of suicide bombings seems to have set New Yorkers on edge. "There's nothing you can do," Ms. Stein said. "There's sort of a human pact based on the notion that no one wants to die -- but if they do?" 
Emily Giannussa, a 16-year-old from Midwood, Brooklyn, was standing in line at Tower Records on Broadway waiting to get a CD signed by the singer Lisa Loeb and worrying about how easily someone could throw a bomb into the crowd.
"Wherever there are people, they could throw a bomb," she said. "There's just not enough security to cover everything. Someone can still walk in and blow themselves up. But there's nothing we can do about it."
Mr. Hecht, the school official, said the Mideast violence was wearing on young students still recovering from Sept. 11, and wearing on him, too. 
"When you turn the news off every evening, you're left with a fear," Mr. Hecht said. "When is this going to end?"

When is this going to end?"; Sheri Stein, 49, a Brooklyn writer: "There's sort of a human pact based on the notion that no one wants to die -- but if they do?" HEADLINE: The President Steps In 

 BODY:
With Israeli tanks ripping through every West Bank city, Palestinian gunmen barricaded in the Church of the Nativity, Lebanese radicals shooting into northern Israel and civilians afraid of stepping into the street, the Middle East is under an intolerable siege of violence. Only the United States can force the sides back from the brink. After an agonizing week of contradictory signals, the Bush administration stepped forward yesterday to do just that with a pointed and powerful speech by the president. It came none too soon and, we hope, not too late.
 In reversing himself and announcing that Secretary of State Colin Powell would go to the region next week, President Bush did not flinch from spelling out truths that all sides in the region seek to avoid but that need to be stated explicitly. The Palestinians must abandon their twisted devotion to suicide bombing or watch their hopes for a state blow up with their young. The Israelis must withdraw their military from the West Bank, stop humiliating their neighbors and accept that peace can come only from an end to occupation. The Arab states must fight terror, promote economic development in Palestine and move forward with their recent offer to recognize Israel. Finally, Iran had better stop arming Palestinian Islamic militants and Syria needs to decide which side in this quite serious war on terror it is on. 
 That, in sum, is Mr. Bush's newly articulated vision for how to move forward in the Middle East, and we welcome it. It clarifies what was a rather confused policy until now and signals a reversal of an ill-advised hands-off approach that characterized his first 14 months in office. It was always illusory to think that the Palestinians and Israelis needed simply to tire of their mutual antagonism before returning to negotiations. Firm, focused American intervention over a period of months is the only path, and Mr. Bush appears now to grasp that difficult truth.
Only last Saturday, in the wake of four suicide bombings inside Israel, Mr. Bush was expressing understanding for Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's decision to call up 20,000 reserve soldiers and root out Palestinian terrorist networks that the Palestinian Authority had permitted -- if not encouraged -- to flourish. No one could blame Israel for its fury, but the decision to mount a major military offensive was a bad one.
The sense in the White House now is that in the last week, Israel has had a chance to make its military point and round up suspected terrorists. At the same time, the Egyptians have downgraded their relations with Israel; the Jordanians, with rioting in the streets to demand that the Israeli ambassador be sent packing, may do the same; and the Lebanese border has again grown dangerous. In other words, a tipping point is being reached. Israel has a right to defend itself against terror, the administration is saying, but not at the cost of regional chaos.
Secretary Powell has the unenviable task of seeking to persuade the leaders of the region to take painful but necessary steps. If Mr. Powell is to make progress, Mr. Sharon must begin immediately to withdraw his military from the West Bank and link a political solution to a cease-fire. As to the Palestinians, real leadership, not overheated talk of victimhood, is required to end terror and restart negotiations. Other Arab leaders, notably President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia and King Abdullah of Jordan, can help Mr. Powell by pressing the Palestinians to end their terror attacks and start building better relations with Israel.
This process is not going to be easy or fast. It will require enormous patience and work by all parties, including the Bush administration. A fine vision has been laid out. Without a sustained effort, however, the vision will not be realized.

HEADLINE: Palestinian Terror: What Is the Goal? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 One quotation in William Safire's April 4 column about his conversation with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon provides a productive possibility for peace in the Middle East: "I see a Marshall Plan for Palestine -- call it the Bush-Sharon plan -- to solve your problem of unemployment." 
 A large-scale, American-sponsored economic development program for the Palestinians, financed by the United States, Arab countries and the European Union, could create business and industrial opportunities. 
Such a program, combined with political and diplomatic initiatives, might be our appropriate response to the parties at this critical moment. 
A special economic authority could be set up to oversee the development program, perhaps organized by the United Nations.

MARTIN F. SCHWARTZ
Greenwich, Conn., April 4, 2002

HEADLINE: A Word From Trenton Translates Into 3: Higher Local Taxes 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 4 

 BODY:
Here in New Jersey's capital, governors and lawmakers don't even suggest raising taxes, no matter how dire the state's finances, as Gov. James E. McGreevey's new budget plan makes clear. But out in the towns and counties, where the better part of a voter's taxes are paid, local officials are projecting property tax increases on a scale not seen in 10 years. 
 New Jersey already has the highest per-capita property taxes in the nation. And in the spring ritual of presenting next year's budgets, including the school budgets that will go before voters on April 16, almost all towns are proposing increases in tax rates; a few are expected to raise the average tax bill by nearly $1,000. 
 The political heat is applied directly to local officials. Dave Fried, the mayor of Washington Township, near Trenton, said the last few weeks had been tough. "You wear a baseball cap when you go to the store," he said.
The local officials say they have no options, because the governor has proposed freezing state aid to local governments at its current level.
Mr. Fried said that many residents were dismayed, because when they moved into the township's proliferating new subdivisions they had no idea that the surge in school enrollment would drive up their taxes. The owner of a typical new house in Washington Township, with four bedrooms and two baths, pays $8,000 to $10,000 in property taxes and could expect to pay $16,000 in five years, he said.
Mayor Shing-Fu Hsueh of West Windsor, another fast-growing township, said local officials were trapped. "We cannot just go on like this," he said. "We feel totally powerless."
The immediate cause of the pain, made clear in the governor's budget address last week, is the freeze of state aid to local governments and school districts, a plan Mr. McGreevey hinted at even while campaigning last year on a pledge to ease New Jersey's property tax burden.
Other aggravating factors have converged: school enrollments have grown more than 5 percent in the last three years; swelling residential development has strained local resources; and rising property values have meant rising assessments. In addition, the cost of health care benefits for public employees has risen, and premiums for municipal liability insurance shot up after Sept. 11. 
But underlying all these is the persistent problem of how to tax people who have tried to move away from commercial and industrial development, only to find that they need it to pay the local freight. More and more, New Jersey is suburbia writ large, a skein of bedroom communities. And much more than most states, New Jersey relies on the property tax. In 1998, the last year for which figures are available, the average per-capita property tax payment was $1,744; income and sales taxes, combined, were less than $1,600. 
Hardly anyone is escaping the squeeze this spring. In Glen Ridge, an established North Jersey suburb whose school system has drawn affluent young families, the average property tax bill this year is $10,497. Voters have already approved a school bond that will add $300 to that bill; the proposed school budget would add $640 more; and the proposed municipal budget $97. 
In the South Jersey town of Pine Hill, where the average house is valued at less than $100,000, the proposed school tax increase would add $885 to the average homeowner's current bill of $3,191. . That is just the base school budget; in separate ballot questions, voters will be asked for even more. 
Englewood is asking for a 5 percent increase in school taxes in a budget that, to avoid a larger increase, would also cut 90 teachers and staff members. The proposed municipal budget would increase the tax rate by 3 percent. The average property tax bill in the city last year was $7,020.
"I think that when the dust settles, we will see some of the highest property tax increases we have seen in New Jersey in the last 10 years," said Robert A. DeSando, the director of government relations at the New Jersey School Boards Association.
The association, in compiling reports from about half of the state's 602 school districts, found most asking for increases that would raise the average homeowner's bill by several hundred dollars.
"A district that has been able to keep the tax rate stable is truly an exception to the rule," Mr. DeSando said, "and they were probably able to do that by spending down their surplus."
Most municipal and county budgets have not been adopted yet, although they are not subject to the voters' approval, so it is too early to say how many will raise rates. But municipal and county taxes together account for only about 30 percent of the total property tax, while the rest goes to schools.
In the expanding economy of the 1990's, state aid to towns and school districts generally rose to keep pace with inflation.
As state tax receipts exceeded estimates in the late 1990's, Gov. Christie Whitman, who took office in 1994, also started issuing property-tax rebates that further insulated officials in Trenton from taxpayer resentment.
Mr. McGreevey's budget continues the rebates, although they are frozen at last year's levels, at an average of $500. The average property tax bill statewide was $4,651 last year.
The statewide average property tax rate, a measure of local taxes used by the state government, was $2.32 per $100 of valuation in 2000, the last year for which statistics are available. Since 1992, when the rate rose nearly 12 percent, to $2.02 from $1.81, the rate has shifted between $2.02 and $2.46. In no single year did the increase reach 5 percent.
Some school districts are now proposing rate increases of $1 or more, and scores of districts are asking for rate increases higher than 10 cents -- by itself, more than a 4 percent increase. 
Ron Grayzel, a school board member in Metuchen, said his district needed a 6.3 percent rate increase. "That's modest when you look at other districts," he said, "but not when you're the taxpayer." 
In Glen Ridge, Jacqueline Yustein is one such taxpayer, and the proposed school budget for next year would raise her property taxes to about $17,000 for her Tudor house, which she describes as "not huge." 
"My husband and I just had a long talk," Ms. Yustein said. They have all but decided, she said, to move when her husband retires in two years.
"I don't know what the solution is," she said, "other than, when I get close to $20,000, I don't want to pay it."

HEADLINE: Report Says 10 Percent of Jobs Lost Post-Sept. 11 Were in Chinatown 

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
The effects of the World Trade Center attack on Chinatown included layoffs of about one-fourth of the area's 34,000 workers, and economic ripples in Queens and Brooklyn, according to a report released yesterday.
 Chinatown accounts for 1 percent of New York City's employment -- with half of those workers living outside Manhattan -- but 10 percent of the jobs lost in the city in the three months after Sept. 11, the report said. That amounts to about 7,500 of the 75,000 jobs lost in that period, the authors of the report said. 
 While the facts are interesting, what is more interesting is the existence of the report, a tool in Chinatown's attempt to gain a voice in the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan. Until now, much information about Chinatown's economy has been anecdotal and difficult to collect, because its immigrant economy is largely insular and cash-based. This report is arguably the most comprehensive economic analysis in the history of the more than 150-year-old neighborhood. 
Drawing on data from government, business surveys, newspaper reports and charitable organizations, the Asian American Federation of New York, a nonprofit public policy group, spent three months putting together a 60-page glossy report detailing the rates of unemployment, business closings, and lost revenues in Chinatown in the three months after Sept. 11.
"It will be a map and a guidebook for getting attention and support that are needed here," said C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president. 
Chief among Chinatown's priorities is gaining a representative on the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is in charge of the rebuilding effort. In addition, Chinatown's leaders have been frustrated that the line for economic aid has often been drawn at Canal Street, the northern border used to define the zone of the most severe restrictions after the attack, but one that slices through the heart of the neighborhood and neglects many of those in need.
The report estimates that wages lost after the attack totaled $114 million. In garment manufacturing, Chinatown's largest industry, 40 out of 246 factories have closed because of the sagging retail economy and restrictions on trucking, the report said. Details of the long-term impact of Sept. 11 are a bit murkier, since much of the information dates from December. The community, less than a half-mile from ground zero, was paralyzed in the immediate aftermath of the attack, when large swaths of the neighborhood were closed by the police. Businesses suffered from telephone and electricity cutoffs. 
When asked yesterday about what could be done for the unemployed in Chinatown, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pointed to the hotline and Web site the city has set up (in English) to help job seekers. 
"You want to have an advertising campaign, and we will focus that campaign on those communities where it is hard to get to," he said.
However, some neighborhood leaders feel that Web sites will not help much. Chinatown is a largely working-class community that is not particularly Internet-savvy. Most people speak little English, and the going weekly wage in most industries was about $350 before Sept. 11, the report said.
The situation in Chinatown nearly seven months after the attacks is mixed. Among the businesses hardest hit are jewelry stores. The garmet factories that remain have seen orders increase. 
One building at 265 Canal Street used to have 10 garment factories. Since Sept. 11, four of them have shut down. Now many are working at or near capacity, partly because others have closed.
One company, Bottoms Up, laid off 12 of its 56 employees after Sept. 11. But orders have started to come back in. The owner, Peter Wong, rehired those workers and has expanded the work force to 65. He has also taken over the lease of the factory next door, which went out of business. 
But workers who have not been able to get rehired still feel the strain. Wai Chun Ng, who is 62 and has four children, lost her garment job when her factory closed after Sept. 11. Her husband, also a former garment worker, has been retired for four years, so their 24-year-old daughter, who works part time at a hospital, supports the family.
Ms. Ng has been careful to budget, buying things on sale. If she buys meat, she also has to be economical. "Chicken is cheap," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Business is slow on Mott Street, left, in Chinatown, a neighborhood that lost one-fourth of its workers after Sept. 11. 195 Dragon Jewelry on Canal Street laid off three of its six employees. (Photographs by Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)
