HEADLINE: DRIVING; A Buick? You Must Be New To These Parts 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
DO you long to be part of the in crowd in Midland, Tex.? Drive a Chevrolet Suburban. One of every five Suburbans sold in the United States last year went to a resident of the Lone Star State.
 Want to make your own defiant personal statement in Detroit? Buy a Honda Accord. Though it was the best-selling car in the nation last year, it has not made much of a dent in the home of the American auto industry. 
 Or perhaps you want the perfect spot for your "Rosie: You Go Girl!" bumper sticker in Boulder, Colo., or Portland, Ore.? Then head right over to your Subaru dealer. 
Regional differences in the United States tend to be thought of mostly in terms of funny accents or food. (A hoagie? A hero? A grinder? A sub?) Or in how people vote, whether they carry guns or in how cold they think cold really is.
But the people who make, advertise and sell cars have long known that a map of the country can also be parsed another way, sometimes with unerring accuracy and unlikely results: by what people drive.
In West Texas, a car dealer gazes out over his lot and explains why you really should not call him a car dealer. There are seven cars, surrounded by a hundred pickups and Chevrolet Suburbans. "The only people around here who buy cars," said the dealer, Teddy Willis, "are high school kids -- sometimes."
In Boulder, six of the 13 employees of the branch office of the Wilderness Society own Subarus. ("Kind of funny, isn't it," one said.) And Mercedes-Benz is so strong in Los Angeles and the rest of Southern California that nearly one of every five sales made by the company in the United States is made in the region, giving verisimilitude to the old joke that the "Mercedes is the Chevy of Beverly Hills."
Some of the nation's automotive schisms are well known, of course, and stand to reason. Gas-hungry cars like Buicks and Cadillacs sell better in states with lower gas prices. German cars do not sell well among Jewish retirees in Florida. Pickups sell better in farm country, and four-wheel drives in snowy or mountainous places.
But explaining why Hondas are as plentiful as baked beans in Boston or why new Cadillac Escalades are popping up all around Brooklyn is not always so easy. Even car marketing executives, who spend their days endlessly polling the buying public, are often frustrated, surprised or mystified by the tenacity of regional differences.
Why, for example, does the Suburban, once called the "national car of Texas" by Texas Monthly magazine, remain so popular there? It certainly has something to do with its ability to carry your entire Little League team while simultaneously using four-wheel drive to tow your horses down a muddy farm road.
Dan Wall, a West Texas farmer who has owned four Suburbans since the mid-1980's, said the appeal for him -- and for other rugged individualists in Texas -- had never been trendiness. If anything, Texans shudder to think about how many other people are driving Suburbans. 
"I wasn't trying to keep up with the Joneses when I bought it," Mr. Wall said when he was reached by cellphone aboard his tractor outside Plains, a small town near Lubbock. "I just don't like cars. They're too low to the ground."
But Prof. Michael Marsden, an authority on car culture, said that the identification between place and car had always been stronger than most car owners realized. "Think about the Jeep Cherokee," he said. "It was first associated with the leisure economy of the ski country. When you move that vehicle out of that environment and into another, it takes that regional association with it. People buy it in a city and it says, 'My other home is up in the mountains.' "
(Professor Marsden, a provost and vice president at Eastern Kentucky University, kept his Jeep Grand Wagoneer when he moved from Michigan to Kentucky. "People in Kentucky look at me like I'm goofy," he said.)
Other associations between car and place, however, seem to have sprung up almost preternaturally. Why does Subaru do so well in Portland, upstate New York and Boulder?
In the Denver and Boulder area, the Subaru Legacy was the fifth-most-popular new car last year, according to R. L. Polk & Company, beaten only by mass-market favorites like the Accord and the Chevrolet Silverado pickup.
Part of the appeal, of course, is practicality. Subarus are relatively inexpensive and have all-wheel-drive systems that perform well in rugged terrain. But that does not really explain why they are also so popular among lesbian drivers. (Subaru has even capitalized on that demand, producing television advertisements with Martina Navratilova.)
Another example is Saab, the Swedish carmaker now owned by General Motors: Saab has long been extremely popular only in the Northeast. The company's officials explain that Saabs do well in cold weather and were first sold in New England.
But not even Saab is completely sure why two-thirds of its owners have dogs, why many are classical music lovers and why they are the group of American car buyers with the highest percentage of households connected to the Internet. (The Internet percentages for Cadillac, Lincoln and Buick buyers are among the lowest, partly because they attract the oldest buyers.)
As a spokeswoman for Saab, Tiffany Cook, put it, the image of the Saab driver is still that of "a pipe-smoking Dartmouth professor," despite growing sales in Texas and California.
"The Midwest is still pretty barren for us, except for Chicago," she said. "We're really trying to break out of that." So much so, in fact, that the company negotiated the placement of a Saab in an upcoming Reese Witherspoon movie called "Sweet Home Alabama," about a New York socialite who has to confront her rustic past in the South.
By and large, both the Saab and Suburban statistics conform with an overall national portrait that car experts say still largely holds true: Asian car brands hold sway on the West Coast, European brands on the East Coast and domestic makes in most places in between, with big cities having degrees of all three.
"I can go here for a day or two and not see a Honda or a Toyota," said Tom Libby, a director of industry analysis for J. D. Power & Associates in Detroit, which compiles sales data from dealers across the country, "whereas at a stoplight in California, I might not see a single domestic model anywhere around. "
For example, J. D. Power found that so far this year, two Honda models and a Toyota were the top-selling cars around San Francisco but that the list was topped by four Ford models, one after the other, around Cleveland.
While many other large cities with large immigrant populations have mixes of imports and domestics, the Chicago area seems to have remained a domestic bastion, with top sales this year going to Jeep, Chevrolet, Pontiac, Ford and Dodge.
R. L. Polk, which collects auto registration numbers nationwide, has found -- not a big surprise -- that domestic cars are the most plentiful in Alpena, Mich., on Lake Huron, where only 4 percent of car registrations are for imports, and least plentiful in Honolulu, where almost 64 percent are imports.
Automotive economists stress that the usual boundary lines on sales maps are not nearly as well defined as they once were. Cities' demographics are changing more rapidly, and the nation's car buyers, more of them women now, are increasingly willing to switch brands. 
But car makers still pore over their maps when deciding how to sell cars. To some extent, experts and dealers say, the differences around the nation can be as much a creation of the sellers as the buyers.
"The manufacturers tend to send cars to the areas where they know they are doing well," said Mr. Libby, "and so the popularity of a model can be a self-perpetuating thing."
Mr. Willis, the dealer near Lubbock in West Texas, has a dealer friend nowhere near farm country -- in Chicago, to be exact -- who complains that he can never get enough Chevrolet Suburbans to meet local demand. "Maybe they could make it the national vehicle of Chicago, too," Mr. Willis said.
Maybe. As Professor Marsden noted, hulking pickups and S.U.V's were showing up all over cities, proving that a sense of place can sometimes be more about your state of mind than the state you are in.
"You see these city guys in these huge pickups," he said. "Maybe he works in an office, but on the weekend, he's a working guy. He's doing something. He's building a deck."

New From Toyota for 2003: The Anomaly
THE pickup truck evokes an image of horses, trailers and cotton fields, of gun racks and special spitoons for Beech Nut chewers balanced on the floor boards.
Southern California evokes images of natty, fuel-efficient import cars, vying for the roads with muscle cars and lovingly restored Woodies full of surfboards.
But guess what vehicle has sold best so far this year in Southern California? It's a Chevrolet Silverado 1500, an imposing pickup that is also one of the best sellers in the Houston and Phoenix areas.
"If someone had asked me, I would have probably said the Honda Accord or the Toyota Camry in Southern California," said Tom Libby, a director of industry analysis for J. D. Power & Associates, which compiles sales data from dealers around the country. "It's a weird thing."
But he and other auto sales experts say that in a vehicle market that can be amazingly balkanized, anomalies appear all over the place, especially with the rise of light trucks -- sport utility vehicles, minivans and pickups -- which outsold passenger cars for the first time last year.
Unexpected sales numbers can also move in the other direction, too. One of the most successful Mitsubishi dealers in the country, for example, is in Houston. And Jeep Grand Cherokees, which cultivate an image of ski-country ruggedness and chic, actually sold best last year in the New York area, according to Jeep. (More than 37,000 were sold around New York but only 11,000 around Denver. The next best sales area after New York was Detroit.)
One of the biggest shifts in the country, however, is the slow invasion of foreign car markers into once solidly domestic bastions. Last year, Toyota's sales increased a robust 5.6 percent in an area that includes Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Michigan and Ohio, where Cadillacs and Buicks have long reigned.
"This was an area where once few Toyotas were sold at all," said Paul Taylor, chief economist for the National Automobile Dealers Association. "Or if you did see them, it was at a charity event where someone was paying $5 to take a whack at it with a sledge hammer. "

HOT CARS
Sound the Alarm: What To Steal for 2003
THERE are all kinds of ways to find out what people like to drive where. One is to ask the thieves.
Every year, CCC Information Services, an auto claims processor based in Chicago, releases a hit parade of the cars that are most frequently stolen, serving as a kind of shadowy survey of regional preferences in cars.
In the Midwest, the popularity of cars made by domestic companies was clear. In Indiana, no imports were to be found in the top 25; thieves collected Cadillacs, Buicks and Oldsmobiles. Michigan also had no imports in its list. In Texas, pickup trucks accounted for 20 of the 25 most frequently stolen vehicles.
Some of the findings, though, are mystifying. In Montana, for instance, the second-most frequently stolen car last year was the 1970 Cutlass.
When a car becomes popular, it is more frequently in accidents, creating higher demand for parts. Buying from thieves is a lot cheaper than buying from the factory. As one study found recently, a 2001 Chevrolet Cavalier that sells for $15,400 would cost $63,240 if completely rebuilt with factoryordered parts.
The demand for parts explains why nationwide, the most frequently stolen car is the Toyota Camry. Thieves like it because most of its parts are interchangeable among many Toyotas, making it easy to sell of the car in

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
AOL Official And Lawyer For Microsoft Spar in Court

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4 

 BODY:
An executive of America Online told a federal judge today that Microsoft was using its Windows operating system to "tilt" users toward its own versions of technology that both companies see as the gateway to a lucrative new business called Web services.
 John Borthwick, the vice president for advanced services of America Online, sparred with Microsoft's lawyer, Richard C. Pepperman, who displayed internal AOL documents acknowledging that Microsoft's .Net technology was open to all developers and designed to run on any platform, not just Windows. 
 ".Net today is a relatively open platform," Mr. Borthwick conceded. "The concern is that over time the platform will become more closed."
Mr. Borthwick testified on behalf of nine states that are pursuing curbs on Microsoft's business practices across a range of new technologies after a federal appeals court ruled last June that the software maker repeatedly violated antitrust laws.
Microsoft contends that a less-restrictive settlement that it reached with the Justice Department and nine other states is enough to restore competition in the computer operating system market, where its Windows platform holds a monopoly. The court said Microsoft illegally maintained that monopoly by sabotaging the Netscape Navigator browser and the Java programming language, which posed a threat to Windows.
After three weeks of hearings, Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of the Federal District Court in Washington has still given no indication of how she views the dissenting states' argument that an effective remedy must encompass nascent technologies that may eventually challenge Windows.
The states' argument is "a stretch," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution and a former Justice Department official. But he added that such contortions might be necessary to apply antitrust laws in the fast-changing technology industry. 
With Microsoft's .Net technology, for instance, there is hardly any market to dominate yet. The idea is that applications of all kinds will increasingly reside on the Internet rather than on personal computers. Instead of buying software, people will pay for services available to them from a range of devices. 
Unless Microsoft is required to continue to disclose information about .Net and allow competing providers of Web services to promote themselves on the Windows desktop screen, Mr. Borthwick contended, the company would provide Windows users an advantage over users of other operating systems.
Mr. Borthwick said Microsoft's newest operating system, Windows XP, continually prompts users to sign up for the company's "Passport" online identification system, which Microsoft hopes will serve as the access key to all the Web services an individual might sign up for.
But Mr. Pepperman was pointed out that AOL has a competing technology called Magic Carpet, to be released later this year. He suggested that AOL was primarily concerned with cornering the crucial consumer access point to Web services for itself.
AOL has negotiated an exclusive arrangement with Amazon.com, perhaps the most significant e-commerce site, Mr. Pepperman noted. He said AOL refused to discuss how Magic Carpet and .Net could work together after Microsoft declined to allow AOL to promote Magic Carpet on the opening Windows screen.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Big Board Weighs Changes For Corporate Directors
The New York Stock Exchange is considering taking steps to help shore up investor confidence in corporate governance in the aftermath of Enron's collapse.
 One change would require companies whose shares trade on the Big Board to limit participation on their audit and compensation committees to independent directors. The exchange is also discussing a requirement that would force companies to separate the job of chairman from chief executive. Page C5. 

Facing a New Kind of Retirement
American workers now put more money into pension and retirement-savings plans sponsored by their employers than the companies themselves do, showing how far companies have moved away from the system of decades past, in which employers alone financed the retirement savings of their workers. A1.

Dell Says Rivals' Deal Opened Doors
The president of Dell Computer said his company had "without a doubt" benefited from the uncertainty among corporate customers about the effect of Hewlett-Packard's planned purchase of Compaq Computer. Executives from Dell visited Wall Street analysts and sketched out plans to double revenue to $60 billion over the next four or five years. C3.

$2.5 Million Bonus for Kmart Chief
James B. Adamson, the Kmart board chairman who became chief executive last month, received a $2.5 million signing bonus and will be paid at least $1 million a year to restructure the company, a distressed retailer, according to documents filed with a United States bankruptcy court in Chicago. C2.

Steve Madden, the founder of the women's shoe line that bears his name, was sentenced to 41 months in prison on securities fraud and money-laundering charges. C5.

Key Gauges Manage Modest Gains
Stocks managed a modest advance, despite a profit warning from Bristol-Myers Squibb. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 36.88 points, or 0.4 percent, at 10,235.17. The Nasdaq composite index rose 5.40 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,789.75. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index inched up 0.94 point, or 0.1 percent, to 1,126.34. C6.

Columbia Lands Harvard Economist
Columbia University announced that it had poached another star economist from a major university, this time from Harvard, which has already been roiled by threats of defection by prominent professors. The newly recruited professor, Jeffrey D. Sachs, left, a prominent figure in international economics, had been at Harvard since he entered as a freshman 29 years ago. The opportunities offered by Columbia could not be matched at Harvard, Mr. Sachs said, adding that he was leaving his alma mater reluctantly. B1.

Snapple Refreshes Its Ad Campaign
Eager to put more snap into its flagship line of Snapple products, the Snapple Beverage Group is adding even more attention-getting elements to the brand's already offbeat selling efforts in a $40 million campaign that begins April 15. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C4.

Kirch Group Fails to Save Core Unit
The Kirch Group is preparing to declare today that its core business is bankrupt. A consortium of bankers may make one more effort to agree on a deal, but people involved in the negotiations said that seeking bankruptcy protection increasingly seemed better than throwing good money after bad. C4.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: OPIUM; 
Afghanistan to Pay Farmers for Uprooted Poppies

BYLINE:  By DEXTER FILKINS 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, April 4 

 BODY:
With this country's vast fields of poppies ready to flower soon, Afghan officials said today that they would embark on a novel plan to pay farmers to destroy their crops, whether they want to or not. 
 Ashraf Ghani, a senior adviser to Hamid Karzai, the chairman of the interim government, said that agents of the Afghan government would fan out across three Afghan provinces thought to produce about 90 percent of the country's opium. 
 The undisclosed cost will be borne by the United States, Britain and other Western countries, which have been pressuring the Afghan government to crack down on poppy production. In recent months, there have been some suggestions that Western nations would condition aid pledged to Afghanistan on efforts by the Karzai government to attack poppy cultivation. Mr. Ghani said this was not the case. 
Under the plan, the Afghan officials will offer poppy farmers around $500 per acre to destroy their plants. If the farmers refuse, Mr. Ghani said, the officials will destroy the crops anyway.
The initiative represents a last-ditch effort to forestall a big comeback for poppy production in Afghanistan, which had become the world's largest supplier of opium until the then-ruling Taliban cracked down on production, which led to a sharply reduced harvest last year.
After the collapse of the Taliban in the fall, many of the farmers who had successfully cultivated poppies rushed to plant again, and this year's crop is now expected to be as large as some of those in the mid or late 1990's, when the Taliban was encouraging poppy production, apparently to raise money.
The initiative announced today is designed to blunt the economic impact of curtailing the crop. One proposal is to provide jobs for farm laborers who would ordinarily harvest the poppies. 
Racing to beat the harvest, which would otherwise begin within weeks, government officials will begin handing out cash later this month in Badakshan Province in eastern Afghanistan, Helmand Province in the south and Nangarhar in the northeast, the three centers of poppy production here. The payments, which will be made on the spot, are designed to pay the farmer slightly more than what he would have made had he grown wheat, not opium poppies.
The initiative raises the possibility of a confrontation between the fledgling government and the poppy farmers, who are known for their sometimes violent resistance to attempts to prevent them from growing their prized crops. 
Still, Mr. Ghani said that if the farmers refused to destroy their crops, the government was prepared to do the job for them. "State power is based on the legitimate use of force," Mr. Ghani said. "We hope it doesn't reach that point." 
In impoverished, drought-stricken Afghanistan, the crop has proved to be one of the few reliable sources of a decent income. Poppies also use far less water than wheat or corn. 
For all these reasons, Western officials have largely abandoned hopes of eradicating Afghanistan's poppy crop this year. Even so, Mr. Ghani and Yunus Qanooni, the interior minister, said that the Karzai government was determined to eliminate poppy farming as a viable occupation. In a decree signed by Mr. Karzai earlier this week, the repayment of loans in opium was prohibited. The practice is widespread among poppy farmers and effectively imposes interest rates of as much as 500 percent per year on the farmer. Mr. Karzai also ordered the closing of opium shops. 
In his decree, Mr. Karzai said the cash payments to poppy farmers would be a one-time thing. "The ban on cultivation of poppy will be strictly enforced from now on," he said.

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL: WHITE HOUSE; 
BUSH DEMANDS ISRAELI PULLOUT; INSISTS ARAFAT OPPOSE TERROR; POWELL WILL GO TO THE MIDEAST

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 4 

 BODY:
President Bush reversed course today and thrust his administration into a central role in the Middle East crisis, demanding that Israel begin withdrawing from the West Bank and telling Arab nations and Yasir Arafat that they must actively oppose terrorism if they are to have any hope of creating a Palestinian state.
 Mr. Bush said he would send Secretary of State Colin L. Powell to the region next week, putting him in the center of negotiations that have been handled so far by a lower-level envoy. But several of the president's senior aides said the true importance of the speech was that it set Mr. Bush on a course of acting as a central mediator in the peace effort, a role which until now he went to great lengths to avoid. 
 "Decades of bitter experience teach a clear lesson," Mr. Bush said in the Rose Garden. "Progress is impossible when nations emphasize their grievances and ignore their opportunities. The storms of violence cannot go on. Enough is enough." Transcript, Page A12. 
Shortly after the president's speech, a senior aide to Mr. Arafat told CNN that the Palestinian leader accepted the president's remarks "without conditions." In Israel, however, Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said on television that the weeklong military operation in the West Bank would continue. "Negotiating before terror is subdued will only lead to its continuation," he said.
A senior administration official involved in setting the policy said Mr. Bush decided in meetings on Monday and Tuesday that he would have to intervene more directly because he feared that long-term allies in the region like Egypt and Jordan were facing destabilizing protests.
"The president felt we were at a tipping point, where the fundamental pillars of peace were endangered," the official said. "He decided at a national security meeting on Tuesday to send General Powell, and that he couldn't go without the president laying out a big vision of the Middle East."
Secretary Powell will take over the lead in talks from Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, the administration's envoy. Officials said the two would work together, but the secretary of state's presence clearly brings the American role to a new level.
The fighting in the Middle East has presented Mr. Bush with a difficult policy dilemma. To be coherent in the fight against terrorism, he has been virtually obliged to back the Israeli attempt to stop terror attacks by suicide bombers. But in seeking support in the Arab world for an eventual attempt to topple Saddam Hussein in Iraq, he has been obliged to try to shore up his position among Arab friends of Mr. Arafat.
Today, the president tried to extricate himself by suggesting that Mr. Arafat could play a role in the quest for peace, but only after he unambiguously renounces terror. 
While Mr. Bush's comments in recent weeks have veered from urging Israel to show restraint to giving it a virtual green light to defend itself however it deems necessary, today he tried to strike a far more delicate balance.
"I ask Israel to halt incursions into Palestinian-controlled areas, and begin the withdrawal from those cities it has recently occupied," he said. 
"Israeli settlement activity in occupied territories must stop," the president said at another point, his hand chopping the air from a podium just off the colonnade just outside the Oval Office. "And the occupation must end through withdrawal to secure and recognizable boundaries."
While making it clear that Mr. Arafat -- a man he openly distrusts -- will be a central player in the coming talks, Mr. Bush had blunt words for him and for the Arab nations that, he said, had blindly supported acts of terrorism, and never seriously thought about how to create a politically and economically stable Palestine.
"The situation in which he finds himself today," Mr. Bush said, speaking of the attacks on Mr. Arafat's headquarters in Ramallah and on his power base, "is largely of his own making."
For the first time, he also called for Israel to show "a respect for and a concern about the dignity of the Palestinian people who are and will be their neighbors." He added that it was "crucial to distinguish between the terrorists and ordinary Palestinians seeking to provide for their own families."
"The Israeli government should be compassionate at checkpoints and border crossings," he insisted, a warning the White House has never before issued to Mr. Sharon, "sparing innocent Palestinians daily humiliation."
Mr. Bush's announcement instantly created a crucial test of American influence in the region, experts said. Mr. Sharon, whom the president did not refer to by name, must ultimately decide whether to abide by Mr. Bush's demand for a withdrawal, or defy his greatest ally and protector.
Mr. Arafat and the Arab nations, in turn, have to decide whether to seek in earnest to halt terrorism, and unequivocally accept Israel's existence.
A senior aide to Mr. Bush said Secretary Powell would travel to the region with "a broad mandate." If talks go well, the aide said, the secretary may recommend a Middle East peace conference. Mr. Bush would almost certainly want to shape a conference in his own image, rather than replaying the one his father organized in Madrid in 1991 or President Clinton's conference at Camp David two years ago.
Just a few months ago, the Bush team poured scorn on such an approach. But that was before Mr. Sharon brought the full might of the Israeli military to bear on Palestinians in occupied West Bank towns and tensions in the region boiled.
Oil prices, a reliable measure of regional tensions, have soared, and America's friends in the region -- particularly Jordan and Egypt -- have faced a tide of protest. The possibility of broader instability in the region has become real.
It is not clear when Secretary Powell will be traveling to the region, though senior administration officials said he would still make some of his stops in his previously scheduled trip to Europe next week.
A senior administration official said that, in addition to Palestinian and Israeli officials, the secretary of state would meet with King Abdullah of Jordan, Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, though the official did not say where the meetings would occur.
The speech today amounted to a test for Mr. Bush at a time when domestic and international criticism of his foreign policy had risen to a pitch not seen since the Sept. 11 terror attacks on the United States.
As he has in the recent past, the president spoke in short declarative sentences and used simple phrases to describe complex issues. "I have no illusions, we have no illusions about the difficulty of the issues that lie ahead," he said. "Yet our resolve is strong. America's committed to ending this confilct."
But he spared no one -- not Israel, the Palestinians or the Arab nations -- in his criticism or his challenges.
He has still not talked to Mr. Sharon directly since the latest week of violence and retaliation. But he had harsh words for Mr. Arafat, whom he did mention by name, saying that though the Palestinian leader had repeatedly committed to renouncing terror and to control it, "he's not done so."
Mr. Bush said of Mr. Arafat, "He's missed his opportunities and thereby betrayed the hopes of the people he's supposed to lead."
It appeared possible that this accusation of betrayal would undercut support for Mr. Bush's efforts among the Palestinians or in the wider Arab world.
The president also spoke sternly to Arab and other Muslim nations, saying it was "not enough" for them to defend the Palestinian cause. "They must truly help the Palestinian people by seeking peace and fighting terror and promoting development."
He specifically named Iran, saying its arms shipments to the Palestinians "fueled the fire of conflict," and Syria, which he said, "has spoken out against Al Qaeda" but not against Hamas and Hezbollah, two of the major terror groups driving the attacks on Israel.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Dell Says Hewlett Merger Is Opening Doors

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
The president of Dell Computer said yesterday that his company had "without a doubt" benefited from the uncertainty among corporate customers about the effect of Hewlett-Packard's planned purchase of Compaq Computer.
 The executive, Kevin Rollins, said the main effect of the pending merger so far had been invitations to Dell to bid on large corporate accounts. The process of becoming an approved supplier to large corporations can be arduous and time-consuming, especially in Europe, and many companies are winnowing their approved vendors. In companies where both Hewlett-Packard and Compaq are approved suppliers, the merger -- if finally approved -- would open a place on the list. 
 "Companies will no longer have those two to keep each other honest, so we're getting invited in," Mr. Rollins said. "More and more doors are opening up to us."
His comments and similar ones from Michael Dell, the founder and chief executive of Dell Computer, came during a presentation to Wall Street analysts in which Dell sketched out its plans to double its revenue to $60 billion over the next four or five years. The strategy hinges on Dell's ability to extend its business, honed in the personal computer business, into the corporate world of large data-serving computers, storage systems and services.
The plan, analysts said, is ambitious and a formidable challenge. It would place Dell, the leading PC maker, increasingly in direct competition with not only Hewlett-Packard but also I.B.M. and Sun Microsystems. These rivals have a larger presence than Dell in the industrial-strength computing needed to run corporate data centers. They spend more than Dell on research and development, and they have much larger staffs of service workers to assist corporate customers in tackling complex computing chores.
Whether Dell's low-cost business model of direct sales to customers will work, without drastic changes, in the large market for heavy-duty computing is uncertain. Dell's bet is that industry-standard technology -- mainly machines powered by Intel's microprocessors, Microsoft's Windows operating system and the GNU Linux operating system -- will move steadily into corporate data centers, taking over tasks now handled by rivals' computers running Unix and mainframes.
The Dell strategy, in essence, is to take the low-cost economics of the PC business into the data center market. "We think we can grow the business without changing the business model," Mr. Rollins said.
That remains to be seen, analysts say. What is evident is the continuing efficiency of Dell in its current business. It has gained market share and continues to be profitable amid the slump in the PC business, even as its rivals have lost share and money.
Yesterday, Dell confirmed that its revenue in its first fiscal quarter, begun in February, would be slightly ahead of its earlier guidance at $7.9 billion, down 2 percent from a year earlier. Dell executives said that they expected a recovery in technology spending in the second half of the year but that they did not expect a sharp rebound to the growth levels of the late 1990's. Dell's longer-term growth targets depend on aggressively taking business from rivals.
The Compaq merger, according to Dell executives, should provide an opening for competitive gains. "There is a significant opportunity for us because of some of the confusion in the market," Mr. Dell said.
To date, however, there is no clear evidence that recent sales gains by Dell have come at the expense of Hewlett-Packard or Compaq. Both companies reported strong results in their most recent quarters.
"My biggest fear was that there would be a big hit to the business after the deal was announced," Michael D. Capellas, the chief executive of Compaq, said recently. "But that didn't happen."

HEADLINE: MIDEAST TURMOIL; 
In Bush's Words: 'Break Free of Old Patterns'

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's speech yesterday on the Middle East, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc.:
 Good morning. During the course of one week, the situation in the Middle East has deteriorated dramatically. 
 Last Wednesday, my special envoy, Anthony Zinni, reported to me that we were on the verge of a cease-fire agreement that would have spared Palestinian and Israeli lives. That hope fell away when a terrorist attacked a group of innocent people in a Netanya hotel, killing many men and women in what is a mounting toll of terror. 
In the days since, the world has watched with growing concern the horror of bombings and burials and the stark picture of tanks in the street. Across the world, people are grieving for Israelis and Palestinians who have lost their lives. 
When an 18-year-old Palestinian girl is induced to blow herself up and in the process kills a 17-year-old Israeli girl, the future itself is dying, the future of the Palestinian people and the future of the Israeli people. We mourn the dead and we mourn the damage done to the hope of peace, the hope of Israel's and Israelis' desire for a Jewish state at peace with its neighbors, the hope of the Palestinian people to build their own independent state. 
Terror must be stopped. No nation can negotiate with terrorists, for there is no way to make peace with those whose only goal is death. 
This could be a hopeful moment in the Middle East. The proposal of Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia, supported by the Arab League, has put a number of countries in the Arab world closer than ever to recognizing Israel's right to exist.
The United States is on record supporting the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people for a Palestinian state. Israel has recognized the goal of a Palestinian state. The outlines of a just settlement are clear -- two states, Israel and Palestine, living side by side in peace and security. This can be a time for hope, but it calls for leadership, not for terror. 
Since Sept. 11, I've delivered this message. Everyone must choose. You're either with the civilized world or you're with the terrorists. All in the Middle East also must choose and must move decisively in word and deed against terrorist acts. 
The chairman of the Palestinian Authority has not consistently opposed or confronted terrorists. 
At Oslo and elsewhere, Chairman Arafat renounced terror as an instrument of his cause, and he agreed to control it. He's not done so. The situation in which he finds himself today is largely of his own making. He's missed his opportunities and thereby betrayed the hopes of the people he is supposed to lead. 
Given his failure, the Israeli government feels it must strike at terrorist networks that are killing its citizens. Yet Israel must understand that its response to these recent attacks is only a temporary measure. All parties have their own responsibilities, and all parties owe it to their own people to act. 
We all know today's situation runs the risk of aggravating long-term bitterness and undermining relationships that are critical to any hope of peace. I call on the Palestinian people, the Palestinian Authority and our friends in the Arab world to join us in delivering a clear message to terrorists. Blowing yourself up does not help the Palestinian cause. To the contrary, suicide bombing missions could well blow up the best and only hope for a Palestinian state. 
All states must keep their promise, made in a vote in the United Nations, to actively oppose terror in all its forms. No nation can pick and choose its terrorist friends. I call on the Palestinian Authority and all governments in the region to do everything in their power to stop terrorist activities, to disrupt terrorist financing and to stop inciting violence by glorifying terror in state-owned media or telling suicide bombers they are martyrs. 
They're not martyrs. They're murderers. And they undermine the cause of the Palestinian people. Those governments like Iraq that reward parents for the sacrifice of their children are guilty of soliciting murder of the worst kind. 
All who care about the Palestinian people should join in condemning and acting against groups like Al Aksa, Hezbollah, Hamas, Islamic Jihad and all the groups which oppose the peace process and seek the destruction of Israel.
The recent Arab League support of Crown Prince Abdullah's initiative for peace is promising, is hopeful, because it acknowledges Israel's right to exist.
And it raises the hope of sustained constructive Arab involvement in the search for peace. This builds on a tradition of visionary leadership begun by President Sadat and King Hussein and carried forward by President Mubarak and King Abdullah. 
Now other Arab states must rise to this occasion and accept Israel as a nation and as a neighbor. Peace with Israel is the only avenue to prosperity and success for a new Palestinian state. The Palestinian people deserve peace and an opportunity to better their lives. 
They need their closest neighbor, Israel, to be an economic partner, not a mortal enemy. They deserve a government that respects human rights and a government that focuses on their needs -- education and health care -- rather than feeding their resentments. 
It is not enough for Arab nations to defend the Palestinian cause. They must truly help the Palestinian people by seeking peace and fighting terror and promoting development. 
Israel faces hard choices of its own. Its government has supported the creation of a Palestinian state that is not a haven for terrorism. Yet Israel also must recognize that such a state needs to be politically and economically viable. 
Consistent with the Mitchell plan, Israeli settlement activity in occupied territories must stop, and the occupation must end through withdrawal to secure and recognized boundaries, consistent with United Nations Resolutions 242 and 338. Ultimately, this approach should be the basis of agreements between Israel and Syria and Israel and Lebanon. 
Israel should also show a respect, a respect for and concern about the dignity of the Palestinian people who are and will be their neighbors. It is crucial to distinguish between the terrorists and ordinary Palestinians seeking to provide for their own families. The Israeli government should be compassionate at checkpoints and border crossings, sparing innocent Palestinians daily humiliation. Israel should take immediate action to ease closures and allow peaceful people to go back to work. 
Israel is facing a terrible and serious challenge. For seven days, it has acted to root out terrorist nests. America recognizes Israel's right to defend itself from terror. Yet to lay the foundations of future peace, I ask Israel to halt incursions into Palestinian-controlled areas and begin the withdrawal from those cities it has recently occupied. I speak as a committed friend of Israel. I speak out of a concern for its long-term security, the security that will come with a genuine peace. 
As Israel steps back, responsible Palestinian leaders and Israel's Arab neighbors must step forward and show the world that they are truly on the side of peace. The choice and the burden will be theirs. 
The world expects an immediate cease-fire, immediate resumption of security cooperation with Israel against terrorism, an immediate order to crack down on terrorist networks. I expect better leadership and I expect results.
These are the elements of peace in the Middle East, and now we must build the road to those goals. Decades of bitter experience teach a clear lesson. Progress is impossible when nations emphasize their grievances and ignore their opportunities. The storms of violence cannot go on. Enough is enough. 
And to those who would try to use the current crisis as an opportunity to widen the conflict, stay out. Iran's arms shipments and support for terror fuel the fire of conflict in the Middle East, and it must stop. Syria has spoken out against Al Qaeda. We expect it to act against Hamas and Hezbollah, as well. It's time for Iran to focus on meeting its own people's aspirations for freedom and for Syria to decide which side of the war against terror it is on. 
The world finds itself at a critical moment. This is a conflict that can widen or an opportunity we can seize. And so I've decided to send Secretary of State Powell to the region next week to seek broad international support for the vision I've outlaid today. As a step in this process, he will work to implement United Nations Resolution 1402; an immediate and meaningful cease-fire; an end of terror and violence and incitement; withdrawal of Israeli troops from Palestinian cities, including Ramallah; implementation of the already agreed-upon Tenet and Mitchell plans, which will lead to a political settlement. 
I have no illusions -- we have no illusions -- about the difficulty of the issues that lie ahead. 
Yet our nation's resolve is strong. America's committed to ending this conflict and beginning an era of peace. We know this is possible, because in our lifetimes we have seen an end to conflicts that no one thought could end. We've seen fierce enemies let go of long histories of strife and anger. 
America itself counts former adversaries as trusted friends -- Germany and Japan and now Russia.
Conflict is not inevitable. Distrust need not be permanent. Peace is possible when we break free of old patterns and habits of hatred. 
The violence and grief that trouble the Holy Land have been among the great tragedies of our time. The Middle East has often been left behind in the political and economic advancement of the world. That is the history of the region. But it need not and must not be its fate. 
The Middle East could write a new story of trade and development and democracy, and we stand ready to help. Yet this progress can only come in an atmosphere of peace, and the United States will work for all the children of Abraham to know the benefits of peace. Thank you very much.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
Bankruptcy Seems at Hand For German Media Giant

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 4 

 BODY:
The Kirch Group is preparing to declare on Friday that its core business is bankrupt, as the aging founder of the group, a German media conglomerate, assumes the role of a passive bystander while bankers and minority shareholders argue over who should contribute to a rescue.
 A consortium of bankers may make one more attempt on Friday to agree on a deal, but people involved in the negotiations said that bankruptcy increasingly seemed better than throwing good money after bad. 
 In Los Angeles, Rupert Murdoch and executives at his News Corporation met today with Kirch's bank creditors and other investors about a possible takeover of Premiere, the money-losing pay television network that is the biggest reason for the Kirch Group's collapse.
Mr. Murdoch indirectly controls 22 percent of Premiere through BSkyB, the British satellite broadcaster; News Corporation is the biggest shareholder of BSkyB. Mr. Murdoch has expressed interest in taking over Premiere, but people close to those discussions said that Premiere needed at least $1 billion in fresh money and that News Corporation was unwilling to provide it. 
All outward signs today suggested that the end was at hand for the Kirch Group, a Munich-based media conglomerate that Leo Kirch, born in 1926, started out of the back of his car 43 years ago. That empire includes a majority stake in Germany's biggest commercial television broadcaster, a library of 11,000 movies and television shows, broadcast rights to World Cup soccer and a big stake in one of Germany's most influential newspaper publishers.
If Kirch is forced to declare bankruptcy, it will be a milestone in the transformation of German business. For decades, Germany's biggest banks and financial institutions have helped rescue major corporations.
The banks have generally converted an ailing corporation's loans into shares and have often held those shares for decades. That was the way Deutsche Bank became the largest shareholder in what is now DaimlerChrysler and picked up holdings in dozens of other companies.
Some of Kirch's largest bank creditors have been trying to negotiate a deal to rescue KirchMedia, the Kirch Group unit that holds most of the company's media properties, except Premiere. But people close to the talks said that even the banks were becoming convinced that a bankruptcy would make it easier to break up the conglomerate and sell the valuable properties quickly.
The prospect of a Kirch bankruptcy is sending shock waves through professional soccer in Germany. KirchMedia has a four-year contract for broadcast rights to all German soccer teams, and many teams would go bankrupt if they stopped receiving licensing fees from Kirch.
The German economics ministry said today that it was prepared to provide credit guarantees to soccer teams to keep them afloat.
But that may not be enough. Smaller and less successful soccer teams get as much as 50 percent of their revenue from television fees because they attract much less advertising from corporate sponsors than top teams like Bayern-Munich.
Some sports executives predict that at least half a dozen teams would become insolvent if Kirch stopped making payments. Kirch executives have already announced that they need to reduce the payments under the existing contract, which provides 1.5 billion euros, or about $1.3 billion, over four years.
The heart of Kirch's problems lies in the poor performance of Premiere, which lost about $900 million last year. Kirch invested about $4 billion into Premiere's digital pay television service, but it attracted only 2.4 million subscribers.
Premiere is not part of the rescue talks in Munich because it is not part of KirchMedia. But KirchMedia owns the rights to soccer and to top Hollywood movies that are broadcast over Premiere.
Industry executives say Premiere needs to overhaul its technology because the digital set-top boxes it uses are difficult to use and expensive. And Kirch executives say that both the Hollywood movie studios and the soccer league need to accept lower television fees.
Kirch's problems could also affect the future of Formula One racing. Kirch acquired those rights last year, paying more than $1 billion. Now it is trying to sell those rights, but there are few interested takers.
Some of Germany's biggest carmakers, including DaimlerChrysler and BMW, never did like the idea of Kirch's acquiring Formula One rights and then broadcasting the races only on Premiere's pay television network.
But the carmakers have been content to watch Kirch try to slip out of its problems, and they insist that they are simply going ahead with their own plans to start a rival racing group as soon as the current Formula One contract expires.
Kirch executives seem reconciled to the idea that their company may indeed go bankrupt. "Nothing will happen today," one executive said confidently. But when he was asked about reports that Kirch would have to come up with the money or declare bankruptcy by Friday, he added, "I didn't say anything about tomorrow."

HEADLINE: U.S. Union Accuses Kirov 

 BODY:
The American Federation of Musicians has accused the Kirov Opera and Ballet Orchestra of stealing work from American musicians by recording a film soundtrack while in Washington in February to perform at the Kennedy Center.
 In a letter to the Immigration and Naturalization Service on March 4, Thomas F. Lee, the president of the musicians union, called the act "economic terrorism which victimized hard-working American musicians." 
 Asserting that the recording sessions were not listed in the Kirov's visa application, he asked that no further visa be issued for the orchestra until the union was "assured they are not entering this country to ruin established employment for our membership." He added, "They do not receive our wages, benefits or residual rights, nor do they pay taxes that we are aware of."
Russ Bergeron, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said: "Clearly this is not the kind of thing that one can or should make a snap judgment on."
The Kirov Orchestra is scheduled to appear at the Metropolitan Opera House from July 8 to 20.

HEADLINE: Postal Official Says Overhaul Of the Service Is Essential 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5 

 BODY:
The postmaster general said today that if universal postal service is to remain practical, the Postal Service must change the way it functions, with more flexibility to raise rates, to close post offices and to reduce the number of days it delivers mail.
 The postmaster, John E. Potter, sent a plan to Congress on Thursday that he called "a blueprint for modernizing every aspect of the way we do business." 
 The 400-page plan was requested by lawmakers last year after the General Accounting Office concluded that the Postal Service was in a dangerous financial situation, confronting rising costs and shrinking business.
Mr. Potter proposed aggressive cost-cutting measures -- about $5 billion in savings through 2006 -- to shore up finances that have been shaken by the economic slowdown and the mailed-anthrax scare last year. 
"We need to go through a transformation -- perhaps one of the most important in our history," Mr. Potter said. "A transformation that will help us secure the future of universal mail service at affordable rates and give us the tools to protect regular mail and ensure a sound national system well into the future."
Postal rates are set to increase this summer as a result of an agreement between the service and many of the businesses and organizations that send bulk mail. The cost of a first-class stamp will rise to 37 cents from 34 cents. The most recent increase in first-class stamps was a 1-cent rise in January 2001. 
The Postal Service's board is expected to approve the rate change next week, officials said.
Once that increase is in place, Mr. Potter said, "I am committed to maintain that rate schedule until at least calendar year 2004."
The broad postal plan would overhaul the agency's operations, granting the service more autonomy in consolidating facilities, phasing in rate increases and scaling back delivery from the current six days a week. In addition, the service proposes that it become a "commercial government enterprise," which would reflect the operational and financial flexibility and corporate structure found in the private sector.
Though the service receives no taxpayer money for its operations, it is a government agency that works under guidelines set by Congress. Changes affecting the six-day schedule or mail facilities would require Congressional approval.
"We need the help of policy makers to legislate postal reforms," Mr. Potter said.
Senator Daniel K. Akaka, Democrat of Hawaii and chairman of the Senate panel with oversight of the Postal Service, said he would call Mr. Potter to testify at a hearing this spring. Mr. Akaka said he intended to consider some of the ideas in the plan.
The issue of service reduction has been widely criticized by members of Congress, who said it would inconvenience customers and threaten the economy. 
The Postal Service lost about $1.7 billion last year, Mr. Potter said, and it could lose as much this year. It has cut 30,000 jobs in the past two years.
"Mail volume is down," Mr. Potter said. "Our revenue cannot cover the increase in costs, and it shows in our bottom line."
But Mr. Potter said he would not recommend widespread closings of post offices or an immediate reduction in the six-day mail service. 
William Burrus, president of the American Postal Workers Union, said the service could improve its financial condition by shifting discounts to consumers instead of bulk mailers.
John F. Sturm, the president of the Newspaper Association of America, called for President Bush to appoint an independent commission to assess the postal service's finances.
"We support its efforts to conduct business more efficiently," Mr. Sturm said of the post office. "The plan before us, however, is not the appropriate path."
H. Robert Wientzen, president of the Direct Marketing Association, said: "The reality is that the plan, while ambitious, can only work on the margins of existing law without Congress's help. The Congress, not just the plan, must help right the sinking ship that is the Postal Service."
Congress has not acted to set standards for the post office since 1970.

HEADLINE: A Quiet Town Confronts Toxic Dirt 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, April 5 

 BODY:
Residents of Canon City, a small town in central Colorado, are accustomed to taking in the worst society has to offer. The 13 nearby state and federal prisons are filled with examples, like Theodore J. Kaczynski, the so-called Unabomber, and Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, one of the 1993 World Trade Center bombers.
 But prisoners are one thing. Up to 470,000 tons of radioactive dirt -- enough to fill 9,700 rail cars -- are quite another. The possibility that the dirt may be headed there from New Jersey has set the town on edge, making Canon City the latest community in the West to join the nationwide debate over what to do with toxic waste. 
 Political battles over the storage of radioactive and nuclear material are not uncommon in the West. In Nevada, for example, residents are fighting the government over the use of Yucca Mountain as a site for the storage of radioactive waste. But there and elsewhere, people opposed to waste storage almost always knew what was coming and who was bringing it.
That has not been the case in Canon City, a town of 15,000 on the Arkansas River. People there never even knew they would have a fight until they read about the shipment in a local newspaper. The newspaper reported that a local processing plant operated by the Cotter Corporation, a division of General Atomics, a nuclear technology company based in San Diego, had contracted with the Army Corps of Engineers to receive the radioactive dirt from a Superfund cleanup site in Maywood, N.J. The dirt would fill existing disposal ponds of uranium tailings, residue from processing. Otherwise the company would have to buy ordinary dirt.
The deal is worth millions of dollars to Cotter -- company officials declined to say how much -- and psychological comfort to people in Maywood, where neighborhoods were built on ground contaminated with thorium, a radioactive mineral once used in gas lanterns, from a chemical plant that operated from 1916 through 1959.
But residents of Canon City say the deal was a sucker punch, because Cotter failed to share details with them. 
"We're scared, really scared," said Lynn Dillon, a member of Colorado Citizens Against Toxic Waste, a group that was formed to stop the shipment. "We're a sleepy little town. We don't want to become a dumping site."
The group organized quickly. Its members began complaining to local, state and federal officials, insisting that the town had never been informed about the possible health and safety risks of bringing such a large quantity of toxic material into the area, which itself became a Superfund site in 1983. (Leaching from the Cotter ponds contaminated air and water near the plant.)
Responding to the complaints, Gov. Bill Owens asked the State Department of Public Health and Environment to review Cotter's deal. That request was enough to delay shipment until Cotter addressed concerns raised by the department. Doug Benevento, the department's director of environmental programs, said the company had not yet responded.
In addition, state lawmakers moved a bill quickly through the legislature that would make public input and environmental reviews a requirement of any deal to bring toxic waste into Colorado. Governor Owens, a Republican, signed the bill into law today.
The new law could further delay the shipments, although Patrick R. Mutz, the plant manager, conceded that the company had not expected smooth sailing. 
"It's part of the cost of doing business," Mr. Mutz said in an interview, referring to delays. "We'll do what they ask us to do."
But delays, he said, would do more harm than good. He argued that the Maywood dirt would benefit the community because it had a lower level of radioactivity than the materials it would cover.
"As a result," Mr. Mutz said, "it would reduce the radioactivity in the area."
That is the kind of answer that leaves opponents gnashing their teeth. Cotter, they contend, has never had community interest in mind. They base that assertion on the federal lawsuits the company has lost over health and property damage. A 1989 case was settled eight years later, with 542 plaintiffs winning a large settlement -- the amount was sealed by the court -- and other judgments against the company are now under appeal.
Residents also say they were never told about the recent revision of Cotter's license to allow for disposal.
Mr. Mutz said the change, made 18 months ago, was approved by the state and the Environmental Protection Agency. But to that point, the plant had been relatively dormant for years, owing to the decline in the nation's nuclear energy industry. Expecting no major new activity there, developers began building large single-family homes on the hills within a mile of the plant, selling them for as much as $500,000.
"Cotter made the change in license with no public input, with no environmental impact studies, with no communication with the community," said Larry LaBuda, a member of the citizens group. "We formed the group to make sure that doesn't happen again."
Once public outrage began building over the Maywood deal, Cotter invited residents to a meeting to discuss the issue, a session that grew so heated that the police were called in. Other meetings are planned.
Mr. Mutz said that residents' overheated emotions had clouded their thinking about the proposed deal, and that if they truly understood what Cotter was doing, they would see the operation in a better light.
"This is a controversial subject," he said. "We appreciate people's fears. It's not something we hold against anybody."
Mayor H. Ben Johnson, a lifetime Canon City resident who took office in January, said he sympathized with his upset neighbors but believed that many people were reacting to fear, not facts. 
The mayor said Cotter had become a better neighbor after losing the lawsuits, and he predicted that no matter what the plant did, Canon City would continue to thrive as a tourist attraction. Thousands visit the city every summer to gaze at the Royal Gorge and the suspension bridge above it, the highest in the world, at 1,050 feet, and to raft along the river.
"My wife and I were talking about this the other day," Mr. Johnson said. "We've traveled all over the world and, as she reminded me, I can't remember the last time I called ahead to ask if they have a uranium dump."

HEADLINE: A Florida Candidate Battles for Recognition and Votes 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 3 

 BODY:
As Bill McBride ventured into South Florida this week to raise his profile as a Democratic contender for governor, he was both at home and a bit out of place.
 Speaking before the Broward Trial Lawyers' Association, Mr. McBride was the well-known insider with a storied reputation for building the largest law practice in Florida and the fifth largest in the country. 
 "I feel comfortable here," Mr. McBride told the group. "I was trained as a trial lawyer. I'm running for governor of Florida, and I'm going to run as a lawyer." 
But when he headed across the street to have coffee with representatives of the local Haitian community, Mr. McBride was just another politician looking for votes. "When he decided to run," said Francois Leconte, president of the local Haitian Community Center, "I got contacted by his people offering to meet with him. But I said no because I didn't know enough about him."
Mr. Leconte eventually agreed to hear Mr. McBride's political pitch.
Therein lies the problem for the McBride campaign. Democratic Party insiders say Mr. McBride, a native son with an impressive professional record and a centrist political stance, is their best hope for unseating Gov. Jeb Bush in November. But in South Florida and much of the rest of the state, few people have heard of him. 
While Mr. McBride prefers to focus on Mr. Bush, saying in an interview, "I am running one race and he's the target," he must still defeat Janet Reno, the former attorney general, in a September primary to have a shot at the Republican governor.
"He's been making public appearances and bashing Jeb, and that is not bad for this stage of the election," said Aubrey Jewett, a political science professor at the University of Central Florida. "But I suspect at some point he will have to take off his gloves and start running attack ads against Reno if he wants to win."
Mr. McBride, 56, grew up in Leesburg in central Florida and went to Florida State University on a football scholarship but gave it back and washed dishes to pay for college after he suffered a major knee injury in his freshman year. As a marine, he won the Bronze Star in Vietnam before returning to Florida to attend law school. In 1992 he became the managing partner of a 300-member firm, Holland & Knight, in Tampa. He has never held public office.
Though his up-by-the-boot-straps image might appeal to some voters, Mr. McBride is facing celebrity candidates in both the primary and, if he gets that far, the general election.
The younger brother of the president, Jeb Bush is one of the highest-profile governors. He has solid support among conservative Republicans and the Florida business establishment but has angered many black voters and unions over some of his policies on Civil Service job security and affirmative action.
Ms. Reno, 63, has become a pop-culture figure, attending Elton John's Oscar party in Hollywood last month and getting fund-raising help from Rosie O'Donnell. She appeals to blacks, the elderly and die-hard Democrats, but has virtually no support among conservative Republicans and Cuban-Americans.
The Republicans say Mr. McBride has yet to articulate an agenda. 
"I don't understand his strategy," said Al Cadenas, chairman of the Florida Republican Party. "Most people have no idea where he stands. You would think he would want to elaborate and start gaining ground but we haven't seen that."
In some respects Mr. McBride has emerged as a stealth candidate. He has spent months working the phones in his Tampa campaign office speaking with potential donors. His phone blitz has helped him raise more money than Ms. Reno, $987,000 to $664,000. Mr. Bush has far outpaced the Democratic candidates, raising nearly $3 million, according to campaign reports.
Mr. McBride is also running a grass-roots operation that has already paid dividends. While Mr. Bush offered to send either his lieutenant governor or a video to represent him at a candidate forum of the Florida Education Association, for example, Mr. McBride not only showed up but also had been calling teachers months in advance, pointing out that his two children were enrolled in public schools.
Mr. McBride won the teachers union's support and last month picked up another major endorsement, the Florida A.F.L.-C.I.O. The two unions, with a combined membership of more than 600,000 in Florida, are a powerful voting bloc.
Ms. Reno's campaign said she was still the favorite among Democrats and would gain wider union support after she won the primary.
"We feel very confident that we will get past the primary because Democrats are behind Janet," said Mo Elleithee, Ms. Reno's campaign manager. "People want to know that their governor has a record of dealing with issues and of running government agencies."
Mr. McBride has honed his talking points to emphasize education, the environment and other popular campaign themes. He says Mr. Bush has not done enough on those issue or to look out for Florida's large population of the elderly.
The Bush campaign paints Mr. McBride as an armchair athlete who picks apart a coach's game plan from his living room. 
"He has not proposed any specifics at all detailing what it is he plans to do as governor, other than the fact that he doesn't like Jeb Bush," said Todd Harris, a spokesman for the Bush campaign. "We're going to run on a record of accomplishments, be it McBride or Reno. We are spending a historical record amount on education; we have a strong record on economic growth and job creation."
But the possibility that Mr. McBride's centrist views could appeal to swing voters concerns the Bush camp, Mr. Jewett of the University of Central Florida said. "If I were Jeb Bush, I would want to run against Janet Reno," he said. "Republicans are more familiar with her and her strategy, but with McBride there is an element of surprise."

HEADLINE: Calpers to Invest $100 Million in Vineyards 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: NAPA, Calif., April 5 

 BODY:
The California Public Employees' Retirement System plans to invest $100 million to develop vineyards in California, Oregon and Washington with the closely held Premier Pacific Vineyards Inc. 
 The investment, part of Calpers' $13.3 billion real estate portfolio, is the pension fund's first investment in agriculture. 
Premier Pacific said it would put up $10 million. 
 The venture plans to acquire land, and plant, harvest and sell grapes, then sell the developed parcels to wine producers within five to seven years. 
Calpers, the biggest pension fund in the nation, and Premier Pacific, which is based in Napa, are betting wine makers will find it more economical to buy existing vineyards rather than invest the time and money to develop their own. 
"The benefit to wine makers is that they don't have to tie up capital for a long period," said Richard Wollack, 56, a chief executive of Premier Pacific and an executive of CB Richard Ellis Services, a commercial property broker based in Los Angeles. By buying existing vineyards "they can get wine to market quicker." 
Calpers and Premier Pacific said they would invest 80 percent of the venture's capital in northern California and the remainder in Washington and Oregon. They plan to grow grapes for wines that cost at least $20 a bottle. 
"The principals of PPV are experienced developers of vineyards with a successful history of selling to notable wine producers," Michael McCook, Calpers' senior investment officer and head of real estate investment, said in a statement.

HEADLINE: Rethinking Reagan: Was He a Man of Ideas After All? 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 31 

 BODY:
Ronald Reagan has been out of office for 13 years, and American academics, one group that steadfastly resisted his political charms, are beginning to re-evaluate him.
 A few dozen professors, mostly historians and political scientists, gathered last week at the University of California at Santa Barbara, a few miles from his beloved Rancho del Cielo, to ponder his place in history. Most were cautious. In the keynote address, James T. Patterson, a history professor at Brown University, said the president's reputation was only "marginally higher in 2002 than it was in 1989." 
 On a campus that features palms, not ivy, other scholars discussed how much credit Reagan deserved, compared with Mikhail A. Gorbachev, for ending the cold war, what his impact was on the tax system, and how his attack on the welfare state compared with similar moves in Western Europe. 
But the single most striking argument came from Hugh Heclo, a political scientist at George Mason University, who complained that "the tradition in academia has been to belittle Ronald Reagan."
Mr. Heclo argued that Mr. Reagan "is among that handful of American politicians, and an even smaller group of presidents, who have conducted their careers primarily as a struggle about ideas." Contrast that to what Mr. Patterson called the view of "virtually all students of Reagan's ideas," that the 40th president offered no more than "the well-traveled baggage of anti-statist, anti-Communist conservatism."
Mr. Heclo maintains, however, that the core Reagan idea was a "sacramental vision" of America; "God's unique relation to America was the central chord from which all else followed."
Mr. Heclo cited phrases familiar to anyone who listened to Mr. Reagan's speeches: America as "the last best hope of man on earth" and (borrowing from John Winthrop's sermon aboard the Arbella on the way to America in 1630) as a "shining city on a hill," a beacon to mankind. But he also drew on speeches Mr. Reagan gave before he was deeply involved in politics, like a 1952 address when he said, "I believe that God in shedding his grace on this country has always in this divine scheme of things kept an eye on our land and guided it as a promised land."
Mr. Reagan conveyed this vision through storytelling, Mr. Heclo said. In his final Oval Office speech, he spoke of the aircraft carrier Midway as a metaphor for America as the redeemer nation, "rescuing a tiny boat of refugees adrift in an open sea."
Mr. Heclo, who said he had never voted for Mr. Reagan and disagreed with many of his policies, said that when "Reagan's more intellectually sophisticated critics in mainstream academia" dismissed these ideas as "nothing new," they missed the point.
"The important point is not that Reagan ever said anything fundamentally new, but that in the new context created by the 60's, Reagan continued to uphold something old," Mr. Heclo said. "For all its positive accomplishments, the 60's mentality," he said, "went a long way in undermining respect for inherited values and beliefs. America's special mission in the world was unmasked as exploitation and oppression. The hand of providence appeared as pompous nonsense in a world now seen to be ruled by the calculated exercise of power."
This was not all abstract, Mr. Heclo said. Mr. Reagan saw the United States as confronted by evil, "whereby the nation's chosenness stood over against the powers of darkness." Mr. Reagan, he said, "saw Communist states as simply the latest enemy on the offensive against the American idea of freedom, an enemy that needed to be defeated rather than accommodated."
His vision also drove his view of government as a threat to individual freedom. The idea that the government should not tell people what to do could seem nonsensical at one level, Mr. Heclo said, but it was also "true to the Lockean tradition of American liberalism." Thus, Mr. Heclo said, Mr. Reagan would say such things as "Legitimate government was a created instrument of the people, lacking any independent existence," and, "It was the people who told the government what it was allowed to do, not the other way round."
Mr. Reagan's vision, Mr. Heclo said, had three major blind spots, however. One was in failing to see that government was more than an institution of bureaucracy, that Americans believed in the government and liked many things it did. "The positive, constructive role of constitutional government was profoundly and incurably lost on Reagan."
A second was the failure to see that it was not just government that could "devour individuals' freedom and the traditional values of their communities." This meant that Reagan could be used as camouflage by "selfish business interests" that could not have cared less about "the shining city."
Finally, he said the president's view of America "sailed dangerously close to idolatry." Mr. Heclo said, "For Reagan, the oversoul of the nation, intrinsically innocent, is assigned an ultimacy that seems indistinguishable from worship."
The conference had been scheduled to come about a year after a major release of Mr. Reagan's presidential papers at his library in Simi Valley, south of here, with the expectation that those documents would provide new insights. But the Bush administration delayed the release of most of them until this year, so relatively little research from new sources was presented. One of the conference's sponsors, University Press of Kansas, plans to collect the papers in a book next year.
On more confined subjects than Mr. Heclo's, some fresh perspectives were offered. W. Elliott Brownlee, a professor of American economic history at Santa Barbara, argued that despite Mr. Reagan's deep antagonism to the income tax, dating from his days as a successful movie actor who paid a marginal rate of 91 percent, he actually "strengthened the political foundation of the income tax system."
Mr. Brownlee, whose paper was written jointly with C. Eugene Steuerle, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute in Washington, said this occurred because Mr. Reagan insisted on across-the-board tax cuts in 1981, when supply-siders were more interested in slashing the top rates, and then backed the elimination of loopholes (and with it more rate-cutting) in 1986. The outcome was not the burst in economic activity he had promised (growth rates in the 80's were about what they were in the 70's) but rather broad popular support for the income tax Mr. Reagan himself loathed.
Several papers examined the end of the cold war and how important Mr. Reagan's arms buildup, particularly the Strategic Defense Initiative, was to it.
Samuel F. Wells Jr., the director of West European studies at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, said Mr. Reagan's belief in a ballistic missile shield should not have come as a surprise, because it knit together his belief in unlimited American technological ability and his desire to eliminate nuclear weapons. But he and several others disputed the idea that the Soviet Union had agreed on major arms reductions because they could not afford to spend enough to match the American shield. And there was a distinct inclination to give Mr. Gorbachev more credit than Mr. Reagan for the end of the cold war. Sheldon Anderson, an associate professor of history and international studies at the University of Miami in Ohio, observed that in Eastern Europe, where Communism fell, scholars do not give much responsibility to Mr. Reagan.
Despite Mr. Brownlee's conclusion about building support for the tax system, there was little favorable comment on economic and domestic policies. Mr. Patterson offered only faint praise when he said, "It is hard to know whether the huge deficits were altogether a bad thing." He said that "however frightening they seemed at the time," the economy survived them.
Bruce J. Schulman, an associate professor of history at Boston University, argued that cuts in welfare state provisions were more significant in the United States than in European countries that were also retrenching in the 80's because other countries maintained a more effective safety net, "but the United States distinguished itself for its lack of solicitude for its worst-off citizens."
But perhaps the single most important lesson for the academics was offered by Lou Cannon, a retired Washington Post reporter and the author of four Reagan books. He said: "Reagan invited us to underestimate him. He felt that gave him an advantage."
