HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
Three Seasons Will Do Just Fine

BYLINE:  By NEIL GENZLINGER 

 BODY:
THIS being April, it now seems safe to draw the following meteorological conclusion: 
 We had, essentially, no winter. 
 And from that conclusion we can extrapolate the following consensus: 
Good!
Sure, there are global-warming crybabies and a maybe few skiers who actually lament the lack of winter this year. And admittedly if this kind of thing were to continue there might be some adverse consequences, like the melting icecaps would cause the Atlantic to rise, and everything from Long Branch to Freehold would be underwater. 
But that's a sacrifice I think most of us are willing to make, because frankly, winter as it used to be was a poor idea, a miserable season full of fender benders and frostbite and avalanches. 
Anyone who doubts it is invited to recall the second week of January 1996, when we were buried up to our bellybuttons by one of the worst snowstorms of the century. I use the term "we" somewhat loosely since I actually got trapped at work in New York and was forced to spend two nights in the Midtown Marriott while the wife and daughter and every other New Jerseyan dug out. But even from that distance, I could feel your pain. 
Who wants to go through that kind of hardship again? Yet I'm not one to endorse radical alteration of the climate cavalierly. So I've consulted some actual experts on what it would mean for life in New Jersey if every winter were like the one just gone by. And there's good news: if it never snowed here again, we'd all feel a lot sexier.
"There really is something called spring fever, and we probably would see a good deal more of that," said Helen Fisher, an anthropologist at Rutgers University who has explored the primal side of our 21st-century selves in books like "The Sex Contract: The Evolution of Human Behavior."
Our ancestors, if what the scientists say is true, morphed into humanness in warm parts of the world, deeply attuned to nature's rhythms. That wiring, Ms. Fisher said, is still there, buried under millenniums of civilization and its hangups. 
"We evolved in a tropical climate where the smells of plants and flowers were all around us," she said. "We spent a lot of time in the trees with a lot of sunlight and no clothes."
Replace the old-style winter with an extended autumn and we would edge back toward our true tropical selves, pulsating with warm-weather urges. The state would be alive with the types of mating rituals normally seen only in movies aimed at teenagers.
"We would see more parading for longer periods of time, and more of the sensuousness that comes from parading," Ms. Fisher said.
Who doesn't love a parade? We might also feel more generally alert, she said, because with warmer weather we'd spend more time outside in the winter months and thus get more exposure to sun, a proven energizer. 
Fred Kelly, dean of the School of Business Administration at Monmouth University, sounded as if he would be one of those leading the charge into the outdoors if we lost winter as we've known it.
"I wouldn't put my golf clubs away nearly as early as I did," he said. 
Knowing that owners of ski areas and snowplowing services would whine if my proposal to abolish winter were to become law, I asked Mr. Kelly for an economic assessment. Yes, he said, there would be disruption, but there would also be new possibilities.
"Part of the concept of the free enterprise system is that as these changes occur, people step up to see them as opportunities," he said. So resorts would alter their sales tactics, clothiers would change the types of goods they make and sell and some entrepreneur might even come up with an indoor ski slope.
What little agriculture we have left would also be affected, Mr. Kelly said -- badly if the future nonwinters were like the one that just ended, but perhaps for the better if it started raining regularly again, since the growing season would be extended. (And I want to here point out that I'm not advocating a moistureless winter, just a snowless one. It could rain from time to time, preferably at night.)
The bottom line economically? "It's an ill wind that doesn't benefit somebody," Mr. Kelly said.
So there you have it: more golf, fewer clothes. What's not to like? Yeah, there would probably be a few thousand environmental consequences if we went winterless, like the Pinelands would become the Scrub Maple-lands. But, as previously noted, most of the Pinelands would be underwater anyway, so we'd hardly notice.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Brownfields Luring Builders With Good Locations

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
BROWNFIELDS. The name is not pretty, and neither, usually, is the kind of property it describes: previously developed land in need of environmental cleanup.
 But brownfields in New Jersey are becoming desirable again, developers say. As the supply of virgin land shrinks, brownfields are attracting builders because many are in excellent locations. 
 "If a site is well situated, with transportation access, it can always make a comeback," said Tom Barrett, president of Barrett Builders, citing as examples the Raritan Center shopping mall, once the site of a military arsenal, and Jersey Gardens outlet mall in Elizabeth, built on a former landfill. 
Currently, brownfield properties near the ports at Elizabeth and Newark are getting heavy attention from developers. Dredging to 50-foot depths to accommodate huge container-carrying ships is set to begin this spring at the ports, and import business is expected to double in the next decade. That means the need for warehouse/distribution space will mushroom.
"There are properties in play in places like Elizabeth, Linden, Cartaret and Newark," said Robert L. Sager, Insignia/ESG's managing director of its industrial services group, "that nobody would even have thought about five years ago. "The focus is on the brownfields now, because there's not much else to focus on."
Those seeking to expand port industrial operations will have to compete for space with other development interests. The city of Elizabeth, for example, is making a concerted effort to transform a 177-acre site at the southern end of Ports Newark and Elizabeth that had been used for heavy manufacturing and distribution into a mixed-use hotel, retail and high-technology center. The property is being marketed as a "vibrant" locale with "prime intermodal transport access."
State transportation officials are considering installing a toll road for truckers between the ports at Newark and Jersey City, as well as the addition of a freight rail stop. A ferry stop is also planned for shipment transfers to New York City. There is already easy access to Newark Airport, interstate highways, and passenger light rail in the port region. 
"Especially in northern New Jersey, especially near the ports, revitalization of brownfield properties has become a must for developers," Mr. Barrett said. "We now have to accept brownfields as a key part of the development process."
Years ago, Mr. Barrett said, a site designated as contaminated carried "the kiss of death" for developers. "Builders wouldn't touch the property," he recalled, "and lenders would run for the hills." 
In 1976, New Jersey became the first state in the country to start a contaminated site cleanup program, pioneering on very difficult terrain, Mr. Barrett said. "Everybody was a novice," he said, "and trying to figure out what would work, and how to do it, and how much it should reasonably cost."
It wasn't until four years later, in 1980, that the federal Superfund Act was put in place, establishing basic standards and practices.
Then, in 1983, New Jersey passed its own Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act and Bureau of Underground Storage Tanks Act Just after those laws took effect, Barrett Builders was faced with having to excavate fuel tanks and contaminated soil at a truck distribution site it operated in Carlstadt. "It was unbelievably difficult," Mr. Barrett said, "trying to make our way through the maze of regulations and get the job done right." 
In 1993, New Jersey put into place a new law, the Industrial Site Recovery Act, which set standards for permissible levels of contamination in groundwater and soil, and for proper site testing, investigation and work plans. 
IMMEDIATELY after the Industrial Site Recover Act went into effect, Barrett Builders faced its first "site remediation" job, at Greenville Yards in Jersey City, where about a fifth of the total land has been identified as known or potential brownfields. Greenville Yards is a former Conrail and Penn Central rail yard, and lies near Global Marine port, in the heart of Jersey City's industrial area. 
Preparing the site for redevelopment meant removing or treating contaminated material, capping it with two feet of certified clean soil, and digging wells that would tap into groundwater for continued required testing, Mr. Barrett explained. 
It also meant dealing with a general stigma against contaminated property, and pervasive fear and uncertainty about whether it could successfully be decontaminated.
"Today," he said, "contamination is no longer a dirty word. The challenge today is how to accomplish site reclamation in a way that meets the complex federal and state requirements, boosts the local economy, improves the environment and still provides a profitable opportunity for a developer."
One plus factor is increasing government support for reclamation efforts, Mr. Barrett and other developers said. Gov. James E. McGreevey has positioned state government firmly in support of redevelopment over new development and state regulators are studying proposals for streamlining site approvals. Under the previous administration led by former Gov. Christie Whitman, state officials moved to widen and extend highway interchanges at New Jersey Turnpike Exit 13A to help the development of Jersey Gardens and adjacent businesses, including an Ikea furniture store and the Rex Plex sports entertainment center.
The local government in Elizabeth also worked to provide financial incentives for 13A redevelopment. For instance, Elizabeth agreed in advance to allow the developers of Jersey Gardens to defer paying a portion of sales taxes on mall proceeds in order to finance site cleanup.
Several developers said these sorts of measures should be considered for redevelopment of Exit 12 in Cartaret, where large brownfields behind the Holiday Inn are being offered as warehouse/distribution sites. Formerly a tank storage area, it will require "major cleanup," Mr. Sager of Insignia said.
Although traffic is awful at Exit 12, he said, "It is, however within 10-mile radius of a port."
Mr. Sager added that, "Some of the smart money, the REIT's, are shifting focus away from Exit 8A and starting to look at properties closer to ports." 
Exit 8A further south has been the state's most popular industrial warehouse/industrial site for the last few years. With open land plentiful and no cleanup costs, rents are cheaper than in northern New Jersey. But Mr. Sager noted that for companies based in New York City, Exit 12 has significant advantages: Not only does it have port access, but it is also 25 miles closer to the city than is Exit 8A.
"Companies looking to save costs in logistics will pay higher rent," he said, "because it doesn't affect the company as much as operating cost." He cited the going rent in Secaucus, which averages more than $6 per square foot for 25-to-30 year-old buildings with ceilings no higher than 24 feet.
"There are a lot of companies from New York City who will pay that rent instead of $4.50 per square foot at 8A for newer, taller buildings that hold 20 to 40 percent more product in the same square footage," Mr. Sager said, "because a closer site makes distribution costs more attractive."
Mr. Barrett also spoke of personal satisfactions for developers involved in bringing back brownfield sites.
"I get a real kick out of bringing properties back into the active market," he said. "I don't know how it affects most people, looking at vacant land or decaying buildings year after year in a certain place. But it concerns me. I worry about my children, and if a contaminated place will still be there when they grow up and are driving by."
Mr. Barrett said that he realized that many properties were tied up for years in lawsuits against the original polluters or their descendants, and that he understood the need to seek justice. As a teenager, he said, he recalls driving a truck for his father's company in the summer and literally getting sick when he entered some chemical company sites.
"But a lawsuit doesn't stop leeching into the groundwater," he said. "It doesn't create jobs or change the landscape. It takes a developer to do that."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Barrett at his Greenville Yards in Jersey City. Well-situated brownfields, he said, can make a comeback. (Timothy Ivy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Westchester; 
White Plains Tries to Reverse Rise in Office Vacancies

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WITH the economy struggling to rebound, job cuts continuing and vacancy rates on the rise in the central business district of White Plains, building owners and managers find themselves competing hard for available tenants.
 In the months ahead, brokers say, a combination of landlord savvy and luck will determine whether office buildings lose or gain tenants. 
 "The ability to make deals, to convince tenants that a building's location and amenities, among other things, are right for them will be critical," said Howard E. Greenberg, the owner of Howard Properties, a national tenant representation and consulting firm in White Plains. "But those aren't the only variables in the equation."
White Plains, which was slow to recover from the recession of the early 1990's, had a 30.2 percent vacancy rate in its central business district even in 1998, when the rate for the rest of Westchester County was 18 percent. Several corporations, including I.B.M., that had a large presence in the city restructured in the 1990's, leaving large blocs of empty office space. 
By the end of 2000, the vacancy rate for the city had dropped to 15.1 percent, according to figures from the Stamford, Conn., office of Insignia/ESG, the commercial real estate company. Much of the space was taken by smaller enterprises, including dot-coms. But the boom in White Plains was relatively short-lived. By the end of December the vacancy rate was 21.8 percent. 
"The real estate market was bad to begin with, and the events of 9/11 didn't help," said Al Gutierrez, a past president of the Building Owners and Managers Association of Westchester and a senior associate at the Stamford office of CB Richard Ellis, the commercial real estate services firm. The terrorist attacks caused a sharp slowdown in the economy, which was already in a recession.
At the end of February, the vacancy rate in the central business district was 22 percent; it was 14.8 percent in the county as a whole.
Dean J. Shapiro, executive director in Westchester and Fairfield Counties for Insignia/ESG, said some problems in White Plains reflected general trends in the economy, but many were specific to the city. 
"White Plains saw a dramatic increase in the amount of available space taken up in 2000, in large part because it attracted a disproportionate number of new-economy deals," Mr. Shapiro said, referring to the high technology companies and dot-coms. "The city cut its vacancy rate in half, and that's a huge accomplishment."
"But conversely," Mr. Shapiro added, "when the market slumped, there was an implosion in its market."
Brokers said the fortunes of four Class A office buildings reflected the commercial real estate market in White Plains.
One building, at 445 Hamilton Avenue, was formerly the home of Prodigy Services, the online company. 
The 320,688-square-foot building, owned by MetLife, is mostly empty, in large part, its managers said, because a rewiring and redesign of the 32-year-old structure took place too late to benefit from the uptick in the market several years ago.
The second building, at 44 South Broadway, once housed I.B.M. employees and now has large blocs of vacant space, as well as several tenants -- I.B.M., Oxford Health and Prodigy -- trying to sublease space they no longer need in the 26-year-old building. 
The 850,000-square-foot building, owned and managed by the Pepe family, of which Nick J. Pepe is the managing member, is the farthest of the four from the Metro-North Railroad station, putting it at a disadvantage.
A third building, at 360 Hamilton Avenue, was rewired and redesigned in 1999 by its owners, Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust in Melville, N.Y. I.B.M. moved out of the building in 1989, and the 380,000-square-foot building was seen as a relic from a time when corporations dominated the market. Now 23 years old, it is mostly occupied, although a tenant, Metromedia Fiber Network, is facing financial difficulty and has considered filing for bankruptcy protection. If it does file, it could opt out of its lease, leaving 20 percent of the building empty.
The fourth, the 525,175-square-foot Gateway Building at 1 North Lexington Avenue is 98 percent occupied, in part because of its proximity to the train station and the flexibility of its design. Built in 1984 and owned since 2000 by the Alaska Permanent Fund, the 18-story structure lost AT&T as a tenant in 1994 -- it had occupied two-thirds of the building -- and went into foreclosure. 
A T the end of the day, filling up a building and keeping it filled is all about fundamentals," said William V. Cuddy, a senior managing director for Insignia/ESG in Stamford, which is the leasing agent for 1 North Lexington. An example, Mr. Cuddy said, is the management's policy of diversifying its tenant base and not relying on a single sector of the economy. 
Also, the structure of the building allows the management some flexibility in configuring each of the 30,000-square-foot floors to accommodate a variety of tenants -- whether it be a company seeking "a bullpen-type operation" with many cubicles in a large open space or one in need of only 2,500 square feet in a traditional office. 
By contrast, the typical floor size at 44 South Broadway, which is also known as Westchester One, is 42,571 square feet, the largest in downtown White Plains and a limitation when it come to leasing. 
Because of the basic design, the building is not suited for tenants requiring small spaces, said Gregory V. Frisoli, associate director for Cushman & Wakefield, the building's leasing agent. Also, the 23-story building is about seven blocks from the train station, which sometimes is a deterrent to prospective tenants. There is a shuttle bus to and from the station.
Brokers said occupancy rates for the building would depend in large part on the management ability to negotiate leases for the 252,000 square feet of space that current tenants want to sublet. "We're working closely with I.B.M. and Prodigy and new tenants, and if we get the right one, we'll take back the current leases," said Mr. Pepe, the managing member, referring to new tenants willing to sign long-term contracts. There is also another 208,000 square feet of vacant and available space in Westchester One.
Mr. Shapiro at Insignia/ESG said Westchester One is "an extreme example reflecting the forces at work in the market," specifically buildings that were hurt when technology tenants downsized.
MetLife's building on Hamilton Avenue is often cited as an example of a structure that was not ready for the market when the market was ready for it. John R. McCarthy, president of McCarthy O'Callahan, the leasing agent for the building, said MetLife spent $2 million to upgrade the structure, which is about five blocks from the train station, but it did not do so fast enough to capitalize on the rush of the late 1990's. As a result, it has only three tenants who occupy 70,000 square feet, leaving 260,000 square feet available.
Diagonally across the street, 360 Hamilton Avenue is almost full, an example of the benefits of bringing a building to market at the right time -- if not in the best place; the 12-story building is about five blocks from the station. Mr. Greenberg of Howard Properties said the remodeling of 360 Hamilton, once considered an eyesore on a side street in the downtown, was "an example of making lemonade out of a lemon."
Salvatore Campofranco, managing director of Reckson's Westchester division, who helped revamp the old I.B.M. building, said a landlord's business savvy will not be the only variable affecting occupancy rates. 
In the coming months, he said, other economic forces will affect the commercial office market in the city. Specifically, Mr. Campofranco pointed to a $300 million movie, residential and retail development in downtown White Plains by the builder Louis Cappelli, which should benefit the city as a whole and the commercial office market in particular. That project, along with residential construction, is expected to create 1,600 residential units.
Mr. Cuddy at Insignia/ESG agreed that business savvy and forces outside a landlord's control would affect vacancy rates. 
"You always have to constantly benchmark yourself against your competition, but that's not everything," he said. "Sixteen hundred new residential units coming online has to leave us with a healthier White Plains. And that can't be anything but a plus for the office real estate market."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The building at 1 North Lexington Avenue, left, is 98 percent occupied, in part because of its proximity to the train station. Building at 445 Hamilton Avenue, right, is mostly empty. (Photographs by Chris Maynard for The New York Times) Map of New York State highlighting White Plains and surrounding areas.

HEADLINE: State's New N.A.A.C.P. Leader Turns Up the Volume 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY B. COHEN 

 BODY:
QUIET and complacent. Stuck in old ways. Content to use honey, not vinegar.
 James (Jimmy) Lee Griffin, the recently elected president of the Connecticut state chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, is not likely to be described as such. Mr. Griffin said those qualities better describe his predecessors who served admirably but who are on their way out. He calls himself part of the "new guard." 
 "Let me put it like this: there's a different style," said Mr. Griffin, 58, also president of the N.A.A.C.P.'s Greater Waterbury branch. "I turn up the volume, I turn up the heat. The only way you can address civil rights issues is to be vocal." 
Mr. Griffin was born in South Carolina, reared from 9 months on in Waterbury, and is a one-time resident of Bridgeport, New York City and New Haven. He is a veteran, a graduate of Housatonic Community College, a former candidate for Waterbury mayor and the state legislature and now a community relations manager at New Opportunities for Waterbury Inc., where he has worked for 10 years.
His friends say Mr. Griffin remembers where he comes from. Equally important, he says, is not losing sight of where he wants to go. Recognizing that the N.A.A.C.P. is a private organization with a very public face, Mr. Griffin plans to keep that face in the spotlight. Because he can't run a protest organization without a little protest.
"There's been an age-old debate in the N.A.A.C.P. between the activists and the actual bureaucrats," said Scott X. Esdaile, the New Haven branch president. "Jimmy is on the side of the activists. He gets out in the streets and he gets involved. He's tangible."
And he is "more assertive and more aggressive" than his predecessors, Mr. Griffin said. "The law hasn't always been enforced, and the reason it hasn't been enforced is because no one has raised the issue. We're raising the issue."
By Mr. Griffin's account, "no one" includes Ben Andrews, a member of the national N.A.A.C.P. board who Mr. Griffin said got too comfortable during his 28 years as president of the state chapter. Mr. Andrews has been under indictment since October 2000 for racketeering in the corruption scandal of the former state treasurer, Paul Silvester. He did not return a call for comment.
In the October 2001 election, when Mr. Andrews supported the president at the time, Lisa Scails, for re-election and declared two votes of the first vote-count spoiled, he called for a second vote among the roughly 100 delegates to the state conference who vote for the state presidency. Ms. Scails won. So Mr. Griffin, a candidate in the election, filed a complaint with the organization and pressed for a revote, all the while making the issue known in the news media. Mr. Griffin won the revote in February. 
"One of the most effective tools you have at your disposal is the use of the public media because it gets your message out," Mr. Griffin said, adding that the only way he felt he could counter Mr. Andrews's national influence was by making the matter public.
But Mr. Griffin's style does not please everyone. "I feel that our N.A.A.C.P. problems should be internal and not public on everything," said Maxine Watts, former Waterbury branch president, adding that there was a "different feeling" when she was in office.
Ms. Watts said that she and Mr. Griffin agree on the issues and really differ only when it comes to Mr. Griffin's style. Whether he will produce results is still to be determined, Ms. Watts said. "I'm sure every branch right now is wondering how he is going to handle their local issues. Can they count on him to be there? Time will tell," she said.
For her part, Ms. Scails, the president Mr. Griffin unseated, is not sure. "I think it's just a bunch of words being thrown out there, and you can interpret it any which way," Ms. Scails said, adding that her 18-month tenure in office and that of her predecessor, Roger Vann, are not comparable to Mr. Andrews's long rule.
"He's apparently lumped us all together. Roger Vann was very assertive, and Mr. Andrews was, as well, up to a point."
Results, not words, are what matters, Ms. Scails said. "We'll see what happens; it's easy to say what you say," Ms. Scails said. "Of course, he has his own unique style, and hopefully it will work for him and the organization."
Other members are quicker to endorse Mr. Griffin and welcome his style of getting his message out in the news media. 
"I think it's healthy at times," said Cicero Booker, a retired Waterbury police officer and Griffin-supporter. "And this election process was healthy, because the major brass had to take focus." Mr. Booker said the issue was made public, which the organization "didn't want, and it made them do what they were supposed to do."
And to those who would ask Mr. Griffin to tone it down? "When you get the person that says, 'tone it down,' that person is controlled by someone, they are looking for self gain," Mr. Booker said. "It doesn't work. Jimmy is his own man." 
Mr. Booker added that Mr. Griffin "won't sell himself down the river to get support from the major political parties. Jimmy has the nerve to take the unpleasant issue and go with it, smile, and enjoy the negative flak." 
Because negative flak, Mr. Booker said, can bring positive results. Now, municipal officials often come to Mr. Griffin instead of waiting for him to come to them, the new president said. When, for example, a Waterbury police officer recently shot and killed David Chipwata, who was black, the police called Mr. Griffin to explain the police department's understanding of the events, he said. 
"Because they know that Jimmy Griffin, O.K., doesn't like injustice," Mr. Griffin said. "And if there's injustice, I'm going to speak out. And they know that."
Hector Riollano, president of the Hispanic Democratic Club of Waterbury agrees. "Now people want to know, 'What does Jimmy Griffin have to say about it?' " Mr. Riollano said. "Because he is outspoken, people think twice. And if he thinks he's right, he goes all the way."
Naturally, Mr. Griffin thinks he has been right on several Waterbury issues, from the still unsuccessful alderman-by-district battle to city charter revision to public education. When the Waterbury Republican-American ran a two-part series on unfair teacher hiring practices and the lack of minority teachers in April 1999, Mr. Griffin called for a state investigation, which he got.
But he is also a realist. "There is a lack of black teachers," he said, weighing in on the side of programs that encourage teaching as a career. "So on the flip side of that, even if we were to have 100 openings, can we fill them?"
In addition to education, Mr. Griffin will advocate for economic development and political empowerment, he said. He is also pushing an enrollment drive to double his state membership numbers within a year. Currently, he estimates membership to be at about 4,000. But don't mistake his message, he said.
"The misconception is that we're only concerned with our own upward mobility," Mr. Griffin said. "But we're dealing with the equalization of rights across the board, and everyone benefits from that."
Yet to be seen is how well Mr. Griffin will be able to incorporate the entire state membership in his plans, even those left alienated by his victory. But if the election of his slate of officers and committee people is a sign, Mr. Griffin is on the road to reconciliation. All 22 of his nominations were approved by the organization's executive board in early March, a body controlled in large part by the old guard Mr. Griffin unseated.
"We don't have to reinvent the wheel on any of these issues; the issues are there," Mr. Griffin said. "You just have to be the leader necessary to bring the organization forward. If you have to be low-key, then you're low-key. If you have to be outspoken, then you're outspoken. But I think we're going to be more outspoken than low-key."

GRAPHIC: Photo: James Lee Griffin, the new president of the state chapter of the N.A.A.C.P., says he is part of the "new guard." (Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Applications Soar at Universities 

BYLINE:  By LINDA F. BURGHARDT 

 BODY:
DESPITE tighter visa and travel restrictions, foreign students have been applying to Long Island's 17 four-year colleges and universities in unprecedented numbers. 
 "We've seen a 33 percent increase in foreign applicants so far this spring, compared to a 6 percent rise for the university overall," said Gary Bergman, the associate provost for enrollment services at the C. W. Post Campus of Long Island University in Brookville. 
 At Adelphi University in Garden City, applications from foreign students have risen 15 percent, and Della Hudson Tomlin, the assistant dean of student affairs, said that when all applications are in, she expected them to match or exceed the 31 percent increase recorded last year. 
Elizabeth Barnum, the assistant dean for international services at the State University at Stony Brook, cited a 22 percent jump. "An economics professor here, Egon Neuberger, puts it best when he says our reputation goes up by the square of the student's distance from campus," she said. "We may not be all that well known in Hempstead, but they love us in Beijing." 
What's fueling the increase? Daan Spoestra, a senior at Hofstra who grew up near Amsterdam, hopes to work for an American bank after graduation. Jennifer Onwochei, a sophomore at Adelphi from Delta, Nigeria, plans to become a physician. Basek Ersen, a graduate student at C. W. Post from Istanbul, wants to be a political-science professor. Felipe Barbosa, a senior at Hofstra from Rio de Janiero, plans to make movies. While each has a different goal, they all say they believe an American education is a first-class ticket to success.
Some students may be disappointed. Allan Goodman, the president of the Institute of International Education in Manhattan, said that in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks, the federal government is taking a harder look at foreign students in an attempt to rout out terrorists. The man identified as the pilot of the plane that crashed into the Pentagon had entered the United States on a student visa. 
"There's a real worry about whether they will be granted visas," he explained. "Once schools send out the visa authorization forms, kids will start lining up at the U.S. embassies, and then we'll know how high the visa rejection rates will be and how long they'll make the kids wait. Will they give up and go to a school in Australia instead of coming here? These are all the unknowns we have to grapple with."
Mr. Goodman, a former dean of the School of Foreign Affairs at Georgetown University, added: "It used to take no longer than three weeks to get a visa. Now we expect it will take six to 10 weeks." 
Mr. Barbosa, the film student at Hofstra, in Hempstead, said foreign students should not be daunted by the obstacles. "No matter how long it takes, it's worth the wait to go to school here," he said. "Where else can you get resources like the libraries, computer centers and art studios the U.S. schools have?"
Mr. Spoestra, the Dutch student at Hofstra, agreed. "I believe studying at an American college will make me more attractive to big corporations when I go looking for a job," he said. "It opens up more options."
For many students, Long Island is the ideal location. "I wanted a school that was close to New York City but without all the hustle and bustle," said Anya Smith, a graduate student in hospital administration at C. W. Post. "It's not as laid-back as my hometown in the Bahamas, but the facilities are much larger than anything we have there, so I can learn more and take those experiences back with me to get a better job."
Uchechukwu Obianyo-agu, a sophomore at Adelphi from Lagos, Nigeria, believes that an American university can provide valuable contacts and an up-to-the-minute curriculum. "Computer science is a field that changes all the time," she said. "Going to school here, I get to meet people working in the area, and I get to learn what's new as soon as it happens. That'll help qualify me for work when I graduate."
For Mr. Spoestra, what he learns about the United States is as important as what he learns in class. "To get a job in an American bank, I have to know everything I can about American culture," he said. "Like when kids say, 'Hey, how are you? What's up?' they don't expect a long-winded reply. I didn't know that at first, but I do now."
Last year, the 550,000 foreign students in the United States constituted 3.9 percent of the total college enrollment, up from 2.8 percent 10 years ago, according to the Institute of International Education, a nonprofit group that administers the Fulbright scholars and other foreign-exchange programs. On Long Island, there were about 4,000 foreign students, or 4.7 percent of the total student population of 86,000. Stony Brook, the largest of the Island's universities, also has the largest number of foreign students, about 10 percent of its 18,000 students. 
During the 2000-2001 academic year in the United States, New York University had the largest number of foreign students (5,399), followed by the University of Southern California, Columbia, Boston University and Purdue. 
The top three countries of origin for foreign students were China, India and Japan. The institute says that almost half of the foreign undergraduates concentrate their studies in four fields: business and management, engineering, math and computer science. 
Although no national figures are yet available on applications from foreign students for the next academic year, John Beckman, an N.Y.U. spokesman, said that applications there were running about the same as last year.
Foreign students are not eligible for state or federal financial aid, of course, but they are eligible for scholarships from private sources. "International students here who are qualified are eligible to receive the same merit scholarships as domestic students," said Rory Shaffer, the admissions director at Adelphi.
But at C. W. Post, Mr. Bergman pointed out that the scholarship issue was often more complex than it might first seem. "At our school academic scholarships are available to foreign students the same as they are to domestic students," he said, "but they rarely get them. That's because eligibility is based on a combination of academic average and SAT, G.R.E. or G.M.A.T. scores, and few international students take these standardized tests."
But financial support sometimes comes from unorthodox sources. "I was lucky to obtain a tuition boost at Post by winning a monetary award from my department for academic excellence," Ms. Smith said. And at Hofstra, Mr. Barbosa has a United Nations scholarship.
Nationally, 67 percent of foreign students (or their families) pay for their schooling, 20 percent receive aid from their colleges, 9 percent from private sponsors or international organizations, and 4 percent from their home governments, according to the Institute of International Education.
While financial aid can be a stumbling block for some foreign students, an even larger problem since Sept. 11 is obtaining a visa. "There are extra security clearance requirements for everyone, particularly males between 16 and 45 from Middle Eastern countries," said Brian Buccinna, the admissions officer for international students at Stony Brook. "Now when we admit kids, we won't know for sure they'll be allowed to come."
Applicants are now asked what countries they have visited in the last 10 years and if they have "any specialized skills or training, including firearms, explosives, nuclear, biological or chemical experience." 
Mr. Bergman of C. W. Post explained how the process works: "When we accept a student, we send a form that allows him or her to apply for a visa. Say the student gets the visa, buys a ticket and boards a flight to Kennedy but never shows up at school. What are we to do? A year ago, we might not have noticed right away. Now we pay strict attention and notify the Immigration and Naturalization Service at once. It's their job to find the kid, but believe me, it's a problem for them to know where to look."
Sometimes, students face problems from their own governments. At the State University College at Old Westbury, Mary Marquez Bell, the vice president for enrollment services, said: "Students who came to us for the spring semester certainly had a harder time getting here because some governments simply suspended granting exit visas. We are alerting our incoming fall students to get their paperwork done early, in case the delays get even worse."
Several African nations, Ms. Marquez Bell said, have become reluctant to let students leave out of fear that they will never return to their homelands. At Old Westbury, the number of foreign students has tripled in the last three years: there are now 51, or about 2 percent, out of a total of 3,000. 
Ms. Marquez Bell warns students who go back home for vacations to take sufficient documentation with them to ensure that they can get back to the university. "We tell them to always have proof that their tuition bills are paid and to carry a transcript and a school calendar when they travel," she said. "Everyone is looking at students more closely now, tracking them more rigorously. We don't want the kids to have any trouble."
While colleges welcome international students, both for the income and diversity they bring, some schools have cut back on their recruiting since Sept. 11. "We still go to Latin America and Asia to tell students about opportunities at Hofstra," Mr. Haynes said, "but we no longer recruit in the Middle East. It's too politically sensitive and, frankly, too dangerous." Of Hofstra's 13,400 students, 350 or 2.6 percent are foreigners. 
Although Stony Brook has the largest international enrollment on Long Island, admissions officers there do virtually no recruiting, Ms. Barnum said. "Many of our faculty are engaged in international research, and this draws students to us from overseas," she said. "Most of our foreign students come here to do research with a particular professor."
Mr. Bergman said that C. W. Post finds qualified foreign students by nurturing close ties with overseas high schools, especially in Korea and Taiwan. The university's Web site helps, too. "We have students here from 42 countries, and many of them found us themselves on the Internet," Mr. Bergman said. Out of a total enrollment of 10,000 at C.W. Post, 400 are foreign students, three-quarters of them graduate M.B.A. candidates. 
In contrast, Adelphi has an active recruitment program, and 194, or 3.3 percent, of its 5,900 students come from foreign countries. "We join educational touring groups going to South America and Southeast Asia to tell students about our university, and we travel to Trinidad on our own," said Rory Shaffer, the admissions director. "Our biggest concentration of foreign students comes from India, Pakistan, Korea, Japan and Taiwan."
Ms. Shaffer explained that the emphasis on foreign recruitment derives from the university's philosophy that a diversity on campus helps prepare students for the realities of the work world. "Kids will have to work in a global society once they graduate, and they might as well learn about it here so they'll be prepared for it," she said. "It's nowhere near as effective to hear a professor lecture about different cultural attitudes in foreign countries as it is to have the student in the next seat tell you about it himself. If you're in a marketing class, for example, it's very informative to learn from foreign students that what works here might not work in their country, and why."

HEADLINE: Milford Studies Rate Of Infant Mortality 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH BEST 

 BODY:
HEALTH officials in Milford wonder whether they have a statistical problem or a real problem. 
 A state study shows that the infant mortality rate in the city in 1998 was twice the Connecticut and national averages, and the city's Board of Aldermen voted last week to accept a grant to find out why. 
 The grant, for $38,000 from the Connecticut Department of Public Health, is the first step in trying to determine whether the state report has found an insignificant statistical variation or a real problem in the city's health care.
The state's infant mortality report for 1998, the last year with complete data, showed Milford with an average of 14 infant deaths per 1,000 live births, twice the average statewide and nationally. There were 641 live births reported for Milford in 1998. 
Similar reviews of infant mortality rates, based on the 1998 numbers, are also under way in Hartford, Middletown, New Britain, Windham and the combined Manchester-Vernon region, said Lisa Davis, Connecticut supervisor of the National Fetal and Infant Mortality Review Program. 
Under the format developed by the national program, a team of social workers, nurses and physicians, using medical records and information from interviews with the families of babies that died, try to determine if there were unusual circumstances involved in the deaths. If the review identifies a communitywide problem, a team will be organized to develop a solution. 
Milford's public health director, Dr. Robert England, said the $38,000 grant will be used to hire a nurse who will conduct the initial review of medical records and will meet with family members to gather other information about each death. The complete review will take place over the next 16 months, he said. The members of the review committee and community action team have already been identified, he said. 
"Infant mortality is a very basic measure of health status in a community," Dr. England said. He said Milford does not have some of the factors usually seen in a community with a high rate of infant mortality, like a low overall socio-economic level or poor access to health care. "The devil is going to be in the details, figuring out why we might have a higher than average rate," Dr. England said. "Because of the one-year snapshot, it could be a statistical variation."
Most of the infants in the 1998 report died in the newborn intensive care units of either Bridgeport Hospital or Yale-New Haven Hospital, he said. 
Dr. England said a review of 1999-2001 infant mortality statistics for Milford, which are incomplete, shows that potentially half of the infant deaths were of babies in minority groups in a community with a 94 percent white population. He said the review might help explain why this occurred. Milford has a population of 52,300, according to the United States Census Bureau.
Some help in determining whether the 1998 information is simply a statistical variation could come later this year, when 1999 data becomes available, said Lloyd Mueller, senior epidemiologist in the Office of Policy, Planning and Evaluation in the state Department of Public Health, who coordinates the analysis of Connecticut's vital records data.
"If the rate goes down for 1999, it would indicate that is not a systematic problem within the community," Mr. Mueller said. 
He noted that a recent report on the health of Connecticut women indicated that while the number of births between 1988 and 1998 declined by about 4,000, the percentage of babies with low birth weights increased, in large part because of an increase in multiple births. 
"Between 1988 and 1998, the risk of having a low birth-weight baby increased by 15 percent in Connecticut," according to "Connecticut Women's Health," a 2001 report by the state Department of Public Health. About 90 percent of this increase was attributed to the increase in multiple births.
Physicians who specialize in treating women with high-risk pregnancies and newborn babies with problems said the closer review of the infant deaths would help determine if the situation in Milford and elsewhere is anything more than a statistical variation.
"It's appropriate to do the study," said Dr. Richard Ehrenkranz, clinical director of the 50-bed newborn special care unit at Yale-New Haven Hospital. "The majority of kids that die that we care for are very pre-term or have birth defects or congenital malformations."
Dr. Robert Herzlinger, director of the 20-bed newborn intensive care unit at Bridgeport Hospital, said multiple births, complications during pregnancy, infections and other factors can result in the death of an infant.
One key to delivery of a healthy baby appears to be prenatal care during the first seven months of pregnancy and monitoring the mother for potential complications such as high blood pressure or pre-term labor, said Dr. Joshua A. Copel, chief of high risk obstetrics at Yale-New Haven and professor of obstetrics and gynecology and pediatrics at the Yale University School of Medicine. 
"We know that prenatal care works," Dr. Copel said. "It means that women who get prenatal care tend to have larger babies and babies closer to term. We don't know why it works, but some of it might be they're motivated to take care of themselves."
Access to prenatal care is one of the issues that the Milford review will consider, Dr. England said. 
The state report on births for 1998 found that 9 percent of babies born to teenage mothers in Milford were either low or very low birth-weight deliveries and 14 percent of those teenage mothers had either late, inadequate or no prenatal care.

HEADLINE: Winning Games But Not Hearts 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD 

 BODY:
JOE ENTENA had driven from Bloomfield, and his friend Alisa Disabunjong made a slightly shorter drive from Bogota. They arrived at the Continental Airlines Arena more than an hour early, but it was worth waiting around to get a chance to stand courtside to see their favorite player before a recent New Jersey Nets game.
 "Yeah, the reason why we're here is No. 15," Entena said, pointing to the purple jerseys, displaying that No. 15, that he and Disanbunjong were wearing. Down the row of fans, at least a half-dozen others wore the same kind of jersey, with the same number. The problem, at least for the Nets, was that purple-jerseyed No. 15 is worn by Vince Carter, a star for the visiting Toronto Raptors, who, having grown up in Florida and played college ball for the University of North Carolina, does not have even a tenuous New Jersey connection. 
 "Oh, yes, we're from New Jersey and I sort of like the Nets, but, you know, well, it's the Nets," Entena said. 
If there was ever a major sports franchise with an identity problem, it is the New Jersey Nets. As they wind up what is undeniably the best regular season in its N.B.A. years, they have garnered less respect, even from those who allegedly love them, than a squad of Rodney Dangerfields.
The Nets have led the National Basketball Association's Eastern Conference for most of the 2001-2 season, a significant improvement over last year, when they went 26-56 under Byron Scott, their third coach in three disastrous seasons. With their regular season over April 17 -- with a game at Madison Square Garden against the Knicks, pathetic on the floor by comparison but drawing bigger crowds -- the Nets have clinched a spot in the playoffs.
But there have been few true believers, at least among those who spend the money to buy tickets at Continental Airlines Arena. On March 12, the night the Raptors and Vince Carter came to town to play an exciting game, won by the Nets 86-84 in the last second to put them four games ahead of their nearest competitors, the team announced a crowd of only 16,105 in the 20,049-seat arena. Even that count was belied by swaths of empty seats; the N.B.A. counts tickets sold, not actual attendance, and apparently a lot of those who bought seats stayed home this Tuesday night.
That might not have seemed so bad had not the New York Knicks also played at home that night. The Knicks have been far closer to last place than first this season, winning about half the number of games as the Nets, yet they were able to sell out their game -- and they were again woeful, giving up a third-quarter 20-point lead to lose to the Philadelphia 76ers.
The Nets have the fourth-lowest average attendance in the league, a bit under 13,000 a game, about 7,000 fans fewer than the Knicks and 8,000 fewer than the 76ers, 80 miles to the south. (The Devils hockey team, having a much less successful season than the Nets, averages more than 16,000; the arena holds 19,040 for hockey games.) It took the Nets until their 19th home game -- at which point they were 15-4 at home -- to get their first sellout, and that was only because Michael Jordan was in town with his Washington Wizards. Their season low was 5,631 on Nov. 10 against the Cleveland Cavaliers.
"I think we've done a lot better in the last month and a half," said the Nets' president, Rod Thorn. "It just takes a while. I think there is a market here in New Jersey. We just have to prove ourselves over a longer period of time."
At least on the court, the Nets have done what they can to improve things. Jason Kidd, the point guard acquired in a trade from the Phoenix Suns for the perennially disgruntled Stephon Marbury, has been often mentioned as a league most valuable player for his inspired play this year. Guard Kerry Kittles is back averaging more than 13 points a game after sitting out all last season following knee surgery. Todd MacCulloch, another new player, over from the 76ers, has been the team's best center in ages. Young players like Kenyon Martin, Richard Jefferson and Jason Collins have blossomed. Coach Scott, who has known winning as a player, having been on three championship teams with the Los Angeles Lakers, will probably be the N.B.A. coach of the year.
But off the court, things have been a bit more shaky. The team's owners have been in a wrangle with the state for years over whether to build a new arena in Newark and over who will pay for it. Fans in several areas of the state close enough to drive to the arena can't get Nets games on their cable systems. The promotion of the team, in the meantime, has been hesitant or at least low-key. The chairman and principal owner of the Nets, Lewis Katz, for instance, referred all questions to Thorn. Two assistant coaches who played for the Nets in less glorious times, Eddie Jordan, who had played for Rutgers, and Mike O'Koren, who grew up in Jersey City, were not made available for this article because, a Nets spokesman said, assistant coaches shouldn't be a focus.
In addition, there are the rumblings of longtime fans that their steadfastness is being ignored by the current administration.
"They are clearly less fan-friendly now," said Bob Gaydos, of Woodbridge, who was sitting courtside at the Nets-Raptors game and said he has had season tickets since the 1979-80 season. "I was here when being a Nets fan was like being a drug addict. You paid for your misery.
"But the front office treated you with real courtesy if you did come," said Gaydos. "All year long, they would call you up and offer you little perks, a hat or a discount or something. There was always a lunch with coaches for what were then few season ticket holders. Now, nothing. It was different. Now it's just corporate like everywhere else." 
Thorn said he wasn't comfortable with that assessment, and pointed again to the improvement on the court, which, he said, is what fans wanted most.
"The team worked for so long with people who had plans to turn things around but never stayed around to do it," said Thorn, who was an assistant coach with the Nets in the early 1970's, when they were in the American Basketball Association. He came back to the Nets in 2000 after 14 years in various positions with the league office in New York. "There were some blips up, but nothing truly ongoing. Now we think we are on the right road. No question, we have work to do. The ultimate goal is that arena in Newark. We think that will solidify our image as New Jersey's team."

An Arena in Newark
A move to Newark is neither assured nor, in the case of potential fans, apparently all that desired. The potential building of an arena in downtown Newark was on track with a combination of state and private money during the Whitman and DiFrancesco administrations. But it seems to be a back-burner project for Governor McGreevey, who has repeatedly said that his main mission right now is not finding new projects to spend on, but on closing the state's budget gap. The proposed arena would cost $355 million and the Nets ownership wants the state to provide at least half of that.
An Eagleton Institute/Star-Ledger poll in 1999 found Nets fans lukewarm about a move. Of those who said they had actually attended a Nets game in the previous two years, 24 percent said they would be more likely to attend a game if the team moved to Newark, 25 percent said they would be less likely to go to Newark for a game and the other half were not sure what they would do. 
Lately, there have been reports of negotiations among the league, the Knicks and Madison Square Garden about moving home Nets games to the Garden if a new Newark home isn't built for the team. If that happens, say some marketing experts, it would probably solve some sort of identity crisis for the Nets.
"The fact is that when you look at basketball teams, they are identified with cities: the Los Angeles Lakers, the New York Knicks. Even the Utah Jazz is really Salt Lake City," said Cliff Zukin, the acting director of the Center for Public Interest Polling at Rutgers. "We are a state with eight million people, true, but we are a suburban state, and that makes it very difficult to have a kinship with this kind of team.
"Now a move to Newark might change things in some way," Zukin continued. "You know you are in a place. There are tall buildings. There is a different kind of clientele. There is no buzz at Continental Arena like there should be a buzz at a basketball game. At the Garden, there is a buzz. People have come for the night, maybe dinner, maybe a drink afterwards. There are other people milling around town. In Newark, maybe the team would have that."
D. Randall Smith, a professor at Rutgers who teaches a course in sociology of sports, said he did not think that being a state-based team, rather than a city-based one, is a negative, except, perhaps, in New Jersey.
"We're the only state completely engulfed by two metropolitan markets," he said. "If you were in, say, Lincoln, Neb., you wouldn't have the same sort of identity problem. The baseball team may be in Phoenix, but there is no downside calling themselves the Arizona Diamondbacks, for instance."
Then he paused for thought. "On the other hand, there is no real downside I can see in New Jersey either."
Smith said there were other factors at work with the Nets. For one, though there is some same-day bus service from the Port Authority bus terminal in Manhattan, Continental Arena is essentially accessible only by car. Madison Square Garden and the First Union Center in Philadelphia are at confluences of many mass transit lines and, instead of being on the edge of population centers, are in the middle of them. It would be hard to think of someone coming from Long Island, or even Brooklyn, across the East and Hudson Rivers, to see the Nets.
Another issue is corporate support, in the form of luxury boxes or blocks of tickets to the good seats for clients, a prime source of revenue for teams, especially with the price of N.B.A. tickets. While seats to the Nets games ($10 to $100) are considerably cheaper on average than those to the Knicks ($10 to $285) or the 76ers ($15 to $235), the Nets' recent success is coming on the back end of a slide in corporate profits. Corporate spending is down, said Smith, as companies cut back.
Then there is television.
"I live in Jersey City, five minutes from the Continental Arena, and I can get Knicks games on my cable, but no Nets," said Monica McDermott, who runs the Eagleton Poll at Rutgers. "You have to think that is a problem for developing a fan base."
MSG Network, which broadcasts Knicks games, reaches 8.5 million homes in the metropolitan area, while Fox Sports Net, which broadcasts Nets games reaches only seven million. Cable ratings are up for the Nets this year by 31 percent, but they are viewed by only half the number of people who view Knicks telecasts. Many of the systems that do not carry Fox Sports Net in New Jersey are owned by Comcast, which has its own sports network, Comcast Sports Net, that primarily broadcasts Philadelphia-oriented games and programming. But Comcast says that if there were enough clamor, it would certainly carry Fox Sports Net on its systems if only for the economic benefit.
"You can't think it's because people in the state don't like pro basketball, since they obviously support the Knicks and the 76ers," said Jon Shure, president of New Jersey Policy Perspective. "I love pro basketball and would go see games, but I live in Mercer County and get the Knicks and the Sixers on my cable, but no Nets. Not having saturation coverage has got to hurt. I think it has to be more than just having a good team for one year. The team has to market itself."
Kenneth Shropshire, a professor at the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania who advises teams and players on marketing, said that now was clearly the time for the Nets to seize the moment, while the Knicks are in a down cycle.
"It's going to be difficult because, presumably, people who care about basketball at each end of the state are already Knicks or 76ers fans," Shropshire said. "I think you have to go with a direct assault, a big campaign. 'This is Our Team' or something like that.
"The problem is that where the regional approach has worked, like, say, for the Carolina Panthers football team, it was in an area starved for a good team," he said, noting that this region is loaded with good teams in the major sports, like the Giants and Eagles in football to the Yankees and Mets in baseball and the Flyers, Islanders and Devils in hockey.

Possessing 'Retro-Cool'
To the Nets' advantage, though, is that professional basketball is the hip sport of the moment. The N.B.A. All-Star Game Weekend in Philadelphia last month attracted fans from young Hollywood and the music world, from Will Smith to Britney Spears to rock and rap artists galore. The Nets starting five appear on the cover of the latest issue of Slam, the hippest young sports magazine on the market.
"As far as hipness, I think the Nets have a retro-cool," said Lang Whitaker, an editor of Slam, which is based in Manhattan. "Down so long, winning now, so they can be the cool team to like. But they still have that big problem of real estate: location, location, location."
"Jason Kidd was on Letterman, so that was good, right?" Whitaker said. "So he tells Letterman that he is looking forward to him coming to a game. Letterman says, 'So where do you play?' and it gets a big laugh.
But then, Whitaker said, a little obscurity can mean a lighter touch on fans' wallets.
"I was covering a game and there was a family in the seats right behind me," he said. "Kids got to sit up on the court. You couldn't do that at the Garden. And I like it that they make celebrities pay for their tickets. Why should James Gandolfini" -- Tony Soprano on the "The Sopranos" -- "have to get in free when that kid has to pay? 
"So maybe the Nets can have something going," Whitaker said. "The place where the game still belongs to the people."

HEADLINE: IN PERSON; 
Where Commuting Is the Job

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
THERE is an aging fleet of railroad cars and buses. Legions of passengers are more than happy -- and annoyed -- to share their nightmarish tales of overcrowding and delays. Even though fares just went up, officials bemoan the fact that there is almost no money to make repairs.
 But George D. Warrington, who is about to take the top job at New Jersey Transit, is used to all of this. For the past four years, he has been the president of Amtrak. Unfortunately, Mr. Warrington, who is scheduled to take over on May 6, does not come bearing any type of magic bullet. 
 For now, the Bayonne native is not even sure where he plans to live when he moves from Washington with his wife and three children, though he says he plans to move somewhere "I will be able to use the transportation system." About all he is sure of is that, as a die-hard Rangers fan, he is looking forward to catching some games. 
Declining to offer a preview of his strategy for the troubled agency, Mr. Warrington said "it is premature for me to make judgments" about New Jersey Transit.
That is not to say he is unaware of its problems, particularly overcrowding on rush-hour trains. 
"Clearly, my short-term immediate focus will be around customer service and understanding how we can come to grips with short-term capacity," he said.
Simply put, New Jersey Transit is dealing with too many passengers and too few seats on a system that carries around 380,000 passengers each day -- 258,600 by bus, 110,500 by rail and 11,000 by light rail. And it is trying to do it at a time the state is scrambling to save money, making it harder to ask the state legislature for extra cash to buy more buses and trains. New Jersey Transit, which operates the third-largest transit system in the country, after New York and Chicago, has roughly 10,000 employees and an annual budget of $1.1 billion.
The 49-year-old Mr. Warrington, was recruited by Transportation Commissioner James P. Fox, and at an annual salary of $275,000 will make about $80,000 more than his predecessor, Jeffrey Warsh, who lasted less than three years.
Mr. Warrington comes to the embattled agency with decades of experience running transit agencies. He was one of the group of state policy experts who helped to form New Jersey Transit in the late 1970's. Martin Robins, who served as the transit agency's first executive director, remembers Mr. Warrington as a hard-working young man who quickly made himself invaluable.
"I had two critical aides in getting New Jersey Transit started, and George was one of them," said Mr. Robins, who is now director of the Transportation Policy Institute at Rutgers University's Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center.
Born in Bayonne and raised in Ridgefield, Mr. Warrington received a bachelor's degree in journalism and a master's degree in public administration from Syracuse University. He joined the New Jersey Department of Transportation as a policy analyst in 1975, where he caught the eye of Louis Gambaccini, then commissioner of transportation. Mr. Gambaccini assigned him to a group developing the new transit agency. 
"He was a strong right arm," said Mr. Gambaccini, who recalled the immense difficulty of creating a working transit system out of a collection of failing passenger railroads. "He was never daunted by any of the challenges."
Mr. Warrington rose through the ranks at New Jersey Transit, working as manager of rail operations and eventually becoming deputy director. In 1992, he left to become executive director of the Delaware River and Port Authority. Two years later, he left the authority to take over operations on the Northeast Corridor for Amtrak.
At Amtrak, Mr. Warrington was responsible for the railroad's highest-profile project, the Acela high-speed train, which makes the trip between New York and Washington in 2 hours and 43 minutes. The project has been well received -- about 53 percent of passengers traveling by rail or air between Washington and New York use Amtrak. But Acela was not without setbacks, including problems with the undercarriage and electric system,. By the time the project is completely phased in this summer, it will be about 18 months behind schedule.
Mr. Warrington took the helm of Amtrak just as the railroad was entering a difficult period. Congressional critics demanded that Amtrak become self-supporting at the same time the railroad was responsible for massive expenses for track and equipment upgrades. Mr. Warrington has received generally high marks for his management, although some union officials say he did not provided the necessary leadership.
"He approached his Amtrak role thinking that passengers had to ride Amtrak as they had to ride transit," said Frank Wilner, director of communications for the United Transportation Union, which represents Amtrak conductors. "In fact, Amtrak faces substantial competition that Warrington never understood."
Like most transportation experts, Mr. Warrington argued that it is impossible to run a rail system, whether at Amtrak or New Jersey Transit, without some government support. He pointed out that other forms of transportation were also subsidized, whether through highway construction or airport management. 
"There is not a transit system in the world that can operate profitably in the commercial sense," Mr. Warrington said. "The underlying economics of transit service require a public investment."
Experts say financial problems will probably be the biggest headache Mr. Warrington faces at New Jersey Transit.
"It all comes down to money," said Jeanine G. Bauer, executive director of Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a transportation watchdog group. "He has some problems with service and crowding and deciding which projects to choose, but all of that pales in comparison to the fiscal gap that New Jersey Transit is facing."
Even with the 10 percent fare increase that took effect last week, New Jersey Transit still faces a massive shortfall. Mr. Robins said the agency had been paying for daily operations by using about $230 million each year from its capital budget, which is supposed to be reserved for long-term construction and equipment. 
"They have an uncovered operating deficit somewhere over $600 million," Mr. Robins said. "The fare increase only gives them $38 million."
There are no easy ways to close the gap, especially at a time when the state is struggling with a $5.3 billion budget deficit. 
At the same time, the transit agency is facing demands for more seats along its most popular lines, the Northeast Corridor and Midtown Direct. To a certain extent, the crowding has been worsened by the terrorist attacks in September, which closed the PATH connection between Newark and lower Manhattan; as a result, passengers who used to transfer to PATH now stay on the trains. There are proposals to lessen the crush, including bi-level railroad cars, but those will all cost money. 
Another challenge will involve some of the large expansion projects already underway at New Jersey Transit. The grandest of the projects, the $400 million Secaucus Transfer, is scheduled to open next year, allowing riders from northeastern New Jersey to ride directly into Penn Station in New York. New Jersey Transit has estimated that 16,200 riders will use the new station each day to transfer to incoming trains. 
The problem is that those trains have little room for the passengers who would get on at the new station. New Jersey Transit officials say that the timing for opening the new station is "under review."
Mr. Warrington said it would take time to come up with a solution to this problem, and others.
"I need to spend some significant time listening, to the public, to policy makers, to the staff and management," he said. "I need some time to digest the issues."

GRAPHIC: Photo: George D. Warrington, who is moving into the top job at New Jersey Transit, at the Trenton train station last week. (Christopher Barth for The New York Times)
