HEADLINE: Launching a Flotilla of Ferry Terminals 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
IT took only one morning, Sept. 11, to change the image of ferry service from a pleasant anachronism to a sensible and urgently needed means of mass transit. With tunnels crippled, roads blocked and bridges closed, tens of thousands of workers and residents moved on a nimble fleet over natural, impervious and far-reaching highways. And many have stayed on board ever since.
 "We've seen five years' growth compressed into a six-month period," said Arthur E. Imperatore Jr., president of Arcorp Properties of Weehawken, N.J., and its affiliates, including New York Waterway, the nation's largest private ferry operator. He said the daily ridership had grown to 55,000 from 32,000 since the attack and the loss of the PATH terminal at the World Trade Center. 
 But it will take more than the shattering events of last fall to permanently alter travel patterns around the metropolitan archipelago. With a few bright exceptions, like the new Pier 11 near Wall Street, ferry terminals and landings around New York and New Jersey are a barren and uninviting lot: often hard to reach from the land side, almost amenity-free and with little visual or physical access to the waterfront. 
In 2004, however, that environment is expected to change radically, with the planned completion of more than $300 million worth of projects: an extensively renovated St. George Ferry Terminal on Staten Island, a completely reconstructed Whitehall Ferry Terminal and a new floating World Financial Center Terminal in Lower Manhattan, a new West Midtown Ferry Terminal at West 39th Street and a new Port Imperial Intermodal Ferry Terminal in Weehawken. Smaller terminals and landings are also planned, as is a restoration of the historic ferry slips at Hoboken Terminal by New Jersey Transit.
"The theory was if we build the infrastructure, the ferry service will come," said Iris Weinshall, commissioner of the New York City Department of Transportation, which is working with the City Economic Development Corporation on three terminals and numerous landings.
All of the new buildings are designed in one way or another to make the experience of ferry commuting easier and more beckoning, to increase the presence of stores and restaurants, to capitalize on the waterfront surroundings with wavelike forms and broad expanses of glass and to acknowledge the public's stake in the waterfront with walkways and viewing points.
City-financed terminals will not be affected by budget cuts, said Daniel L. Doctoroff, the deputy mayor of New York for economic development and rebuilding. "Ferry service is a big priority for us," he said. "We don't, in the short term, have a lot of options for getting people to Lower Manhattan faster than we can with ferries."
And in the longer term, expanded ferry service is an underpinning of the city's bid for the 2012 Olympics, as a way to move athletes and spectators to far-flung arenas.
Another long-term impact is on development. "Expanded ferry service is sure to be a big boost to the economic rebirth along the Hudson County waterfront," said James P. Fox, the transportation commissioner of New Jersey. The Weehawken terminal, to be built by New Jersey Transit, sits in a cove on a 360-acre parcel that Arcorp and Marshall B. Tycher's Roseland Property Company are redeveloping as Port Imperial, with 6,000 housing units and 1.4 million square feet of commercial space.
"It will be very much the center of the community," Mr. Imperatore said, "a transit-village model of development similar to the old railroad suburbs." That same approach may be taken at the development planned by Roseland on the former site of the General Motors assembly plant in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., Mr. Imperatore said.
Landings could serve as spark plugs for development in the city, too, said David Yassky, a Brooklyn Democrat who heads the City Council waterfronts committee, citing Greenpoint, in his district, and Hunters Point and the Rockaways in Queens.
The Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance, an umbrella group of civic, community, transportation and environmental organizations, envisions 15 new ferry stops around the upper bay to create a harbor loop system.
City officials are looking at the possibility of a terminal around Kent or Java Street in Greenpoint. They are working on an East 34th Street terminal and small-scale ferry landings, basically ticket booths with shelters, in landscaped areas along the East River in Manhattan. These are being designed by Kennedy & Violich Architecture of Boston, Ken Smith Landscape Architect and the marine engineers of M. G. McLaren.
On the West Side, the Riverside South Planning Corporation is planning to renovate an abandoned railroad float bridge at 69th Street as a ferry landing. That proposal is among 15 city projects under consideration for state-awarded federal financing.
THE Economic Development Corporation is close to announcing the designation of a developer to renovate the interior of the landmark Battery Maritime Building, north of Whitehall. Coast Guard ferries sail from this building to Governors Island, now apparently destined to become an offshore City University campus. The request for proposals required that ground-floor space be set aside for continuing ferry operations. The corporation will undertake a $36 million exterior renovation, designed by Jan Hird Pokorny Associates.
Mr. Imperatore said he was exploring an intermodal terminal in the planned commercial center of Queens West, to be developed by LCOR, connected to the Long Island Rail Road's Long Island City station.
At Weehawken, construction may begin in late fall, Mr. Imperatore said. The site has already been conveyed to New Jersey Transit for a nominal amount, he said, as the company's equity contribution. New York Waterway will lease the terminal for 38 years. The project has a budget of $30 million -- $25 million for the terminal and $5 million for dredging -- which is about $3 million to $5 million short of what will be needed, Mr. Imperatore said. "We're confident we can obtain that," he said.
New York Waterway's current Weehawken terminal, about 500 yards south of the new site, is a former ferryboat called the Jamestown, which sailed between Jamestown and Newport, R.I., before the completion in 1969 of the Claiborne Pell Bridge. Rescued from a shipyard in Philadelphia by Arthur Imperatore Sr., it now sits -- or rather lists -- at anchor off New Jersey.
In contrast to this dank, claustrophobic vessel, the new terminal would have a glass-enclosed waiting room with a floor plan shaped like a cat's eye, 40 feet high and 160 feet from tapered end to end. Rather than gang all four bow-loading slips together on a single barge in front of the terminal, the architects at Gruzen Samton would pull the slips apart into two barges on either side.
"We thought we should have a waiting room with a clear view of Manhattan," said the architect, Jordan Gruzen. "The thing that characterizes this design has been the attention to making it an experience rather than just a convenience. That's part of this competition for the traveler."
The lanternlike form of the waiting room will create a strong nighttime presence on the water, said Ivan Ilyashov, an associate at Gruzen Samton, which is working with the structural and marine engineers of M. G. McLaren. They are also collaborating with Nicholas Goldsmith of FTL Happold, designers and engineers of tensile structures, on canopies to shelter the barges.
An esplanade will surround the cove. A waterside terrace will be open to the public. A station on New Jersey Transit's Hudson-Bergen Light Rail line, 600 feet away, will be connected to the terminal through a commercial building. "The real future of this ferry and others is establishing mass-transit connections," Mr. Imperatore Jr. said.
Across the Hudson, construction is to begin late this summer on the six-slip, $30 million West Midtown Ferry Terminal on Pier 79 at the foot of 39th Street, which will wrap around the imposing ventilating towers of the Lincoln Tunnel. This glass pavilion will be immediately north of the existing New York Waterway terminal at Pier 78, a jumbled grab bag of structures and slips.
About 60 percent of the cost is being met by the federal Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century and 30 percent by the city's capital budget, with the rest from the state and New York Waterway, which will also make an average annual lease payment of $750,000 over 30 years. Three slips will be controlled by New York Waterway and three will be open to other services. Operating costs will be defrayed in part by landing fees and advertising revenues. There will be 4,100 square feet of retail space.
The architects are William Nicholas Bodouva & Associates, designers of the four-year-old Terminal 1 at Kennedy International Airport. Thomas Balsley Associates are the landscape architects; Thornton-Tomasetti Group, the structural engineers.
The terminal has been shaped by more than passenger traffic, since it straddles the Lincoln Tunnel tubes and stands in the middle of the Hudson River Park and alongside the reconstructed Route 9A.
"We tried very hard in our design to make the building as open as possible, allowing both ferry terminal users and the public to move in and out easily," said Darko Hreljanovic, the project designer. That includes plazas to the north and south, a cafe from which seating can spill outside in pleasant weather and an elevated walkway over the ferry slips so that pedestrians can trace an uninterrupted waterside path.
The main waiting room will be clad in a structural glass system for highest transparency. Curving vestibules on either side of the vent stacks are intended to signal the terminal entrance clearly and to create a kind of architectural transition between the 145-foot-high towers and the low-rise terminal and plaza, Mr. Bodouva said.
Farther down the Hudson, anchored off the Battery Park City esplanade, across from the New York Mercantile Exchange, will be the Port Authority's five-slip World Financial Center Ferry Terminal, designed by the authority's engineering and architectural division, working with marine engineers at M. G. McLaren and structural engineers at Severud Associates.
"The key word is 'terminal,' " said Robert I. Davidson, chief architect for the Port Authority. "What we're embarking on is to make ferry service equivalent to other modes of transportation, where people feel comfortable in the facilities."
This terminal will be a 160-by-200-foot barge with 14,000 square feet of public space under an undulating, peaked roof of Teflon fabric made by Birdair Inc. The roof conjures canvas sails and will glow at night as a navigational aid. Broad expanses of glass are meant to preserve as much as possible of the view from the esplanade at high or low tide. "We worked very hard to arrive at a solution with the least amount of visual intervention," Mr. Davidson said.
New York Waterway would manage this terminal, but slips would be available to other operators. "This is the most critically needed piece of ferry infrastructure in the city," Mr. Imperatore said. While awaiting its completion, Mr. Imperatore wants to be able to use the North Cove Yacht Harbor at Battery Park City, a plan that has run into strong opposition.
Around the tip of Manhattan, the new Whitehall Ferry Terminal for the Staten Island ferry service is under construction. The exoskeletal curtain wall of the new waiting room is taking form next to the existing building. On the water side, the east slip has been renovated and is now in use, topped by a V-shaped canopy on which photovoltaic panels will be installed.
Schwartz Architects are the designers, with TAMS Consultants, which has been acquired by Earth Tech, and the structural engineers at Robert Silman Associates.
Just finding the footings was an intricate task, since three subway lines and the Battery Park underpass run beneath or near Whitehall, said Scott Hughes, the project manager at Silman. That ruled out pile driving because vibrations might threaten the tunnels. Instead, triple-sleeve caissons serve as the foundation, some down about 60 feet below grade. Each has a concrete core poured within a steel ring that is surrounded by two outer rings to eliminate side-to-side pressure on the surrounding soil, which could push against the tunnels.
COMPOUNDING the complexity of the assignment is the requirement of the Transportation Department that two of the three slips always stay in service.
When completed, the terminal will have a viewing platform on its roof and 7,500 square feet of retail space.
At the other end of the line will be the substantially renovated St. George Ferry Terminal on Staten Island, with 20,000 square feet of retail space and 100,000 square feet of new terraces. The $89 million project was designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, working with the structural engineers at Thornton-Tomasetti.
Greeting passengers on their arrival will be a broad arch made of a metal screen cantilevered from an array of steel tubes.
"Our charge was to create a state-of-the-art intermodal center that would become a gateway to Staten Island," said Kenneth H. Drucker, the senior principal and director of design in the New York office of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum. The current terminal is more like a gateway to a bus ramp, offering views of a solid wall of glazed brick where Lower Manhattan should be.
Given the logistical and environmental complexity of the site, the architects were limited in what they could do. The slips could not be changed, the existing columns and foundations had to remain and the structure could not exceed 90 feet.
Nonetheless, while the new waiting room will occupy exactly the same space as the current one, it should emerge from renovation almost unrecognizable. The architects plan literally to raise the roof, about five feet on the land side and 20 feet on the harbor side, creating a new glass curtain wall in place of the narrow clerestories. "We wanted to bring natural light into this dismal building," Mr. Drucker said.
The floor of the waiting room is planned as a map of New York Harbor in blue and green terrazzo, with inset brass markers pinpointing terminals and historic fortifications. And, of course, ferry routes.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
McGreevey Budget Takes Page From Whitman Book

BYLINE:  By David Kocieniewski; David Kocieniewski is Trenton bureau chief for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
When James E. McGreevey was sworn in as governor three months ago, a lot of the Democrats cheering at his inauguration were quietly bracing themselves for a very bumpy ride.
 Mr. McGreevey took office just as the state was coming to grips with a staggering budget crisis, and the Democrats' previous experience with that dynamic wasn't a pretty one. When Jim Florio took office in 1990, he closed a budget gap by ramming a huge tax increase through the Legislature, and so infuriating voters that Democrats were cast from power for nearly a decade. 
 Mr. McGreevey assured members of his party that he would spare them that cruel fate, and, so far, it is a promise he has kept. In fact, a close reading of Mr. McGreevey's seems less like the second coming of Jim Florio than a sequel of Christine Todd Whitman. 
After blasting the Republicans for "runaway spending," Mr. McGreevey's budget called for his own increase in expenditures and while the Governor said the increase was 1.5 percent, other analysts say the actual number is either 4 or 9 percent, depending on what accounting method you use. 
Having railed against the Republicans for "irresponsible borrowing," Mr. McGreevey calls for the state to raise more than $1 billion by borrowing against New Jersey's share of the tobacco settlement. Mr. McGreevey's proposal to drain hundreds of millions of dollars in surpluses from several of the state's special funds is also likely to force New Jersey to increase borrowing in future years. 
And after accusing Republicans of passing "an Enron budget" last year, by basing their spending plan on inflated estimates and overoptimist economic projections, Mr. McGreevey's budget is built on assumptions as rosy as the magenta suits Mrs. Whitman liked to wear when she made major televised addresses. 
Mr. McGreevey's Democratic colleagues may be relieved by the fancy dancing the governor used to avert a political crisis in the short term. In the long term, however, the prospects of Mr. McGreevey's budget plan are murky at best because he lacks one important weapon Mrs. Whitman had at her disposal (two, if you counting the magenta suit).
Republicans had the good fortune to rule Trenton from 1993 to 2001, during the most robust American economic expansion in history. The state's computer and pharmaceutical industries flourished. The dizzying rise of the stock market helped enrich tens of thousands of New Jersey residents who worked on Wall Street or in financial service businesses on this side of the Hudson. Mrs. Whitman was able to spend freely because the state enjoyed a dramatic jump in tax revenues year after year. 
Mr. McGreevey has argued that it was imprudent of Mrs. Whitman to finance her tax cuts by increasing the state's borrowing during flush economic times, a point that many economists, and even some former members of Mrs. Whitman's cabinet, concede. But that philosophical victory will be little use to Mr. McGreevey when it is time to convince Wall Street that the state's long-term finances are sound and its bond rating should not be downgraded. 
On the contrary, the fact that Republicans allowed the state debt to double during the roaring 90's will limit Mr. McGreevey's ability to borrow his way out of the problem. The state's debt will also force the Governor to make more -- and more difficult -- choices to solve the perennial gap between the amount New Jersey spends and the amount it can realistically expect to collect in taxes. 
Mr. McGreevey had begun doling out the pain. He cut 5 percent from the budgets of all state departments, laid off 600 state workers and proposed slashing aid to public universities, freezing aid to schools and municipalities and raising the cigarette tax. He is also attempting to dismantle some of the tax incentives Mrs. Whitman offered to businesses, by revising the state's corporate tax in an effort to collect an additional $500 million from companies doing business in the state
Already, the municipal leaders are warning that the McGreevey budget will lead to drastic increases in property taxes. Business leaders are ominously suggesting that the corporate tax plan could cause companies and jobs to flee to Pennsylvania. Democratic legislators from South Jersey have vowed to fight Mr. McGreevey's proposed commuter tax on Pennsylvania residents, arguing that it will force thousands of New Jersey residents who work in Philadelphia to pay higher wage taxes there. 
Even if the governor wins all those political battles, however, there is likely to be more bad news later this year. Mr. McGreevey's budget assumes a faster rate in growth. His budget plan counts on the federal government providing nearly $500 million in aid for nursing homes and prescription benefits for the elderly even though that money has not yet been committed. 
Maybe all of those things will happen; after all, many people scoffed five years ago, when Mr. McGreevey, then the mayor of Woodbridge, said he would be governor one day. 
But after breaking his leg during his first month in office, Mr. McGreevey should be careful not to dislocate his fingers during the coming months, by crossing them too hard as he prays for a speedy economic recovery.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Kocieniewski

HEADLINE: COMMUNITIES; 
Differences of Opinion

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
AS the formal-clad guests trooped into a hotel ballroom last week for the annual fund-raiser of the Boys and Girls Clubs of Newark, the glitter was dimmed somewhat by a dispute over the suspension of the charity's executive director last month.
 Some say the suspension of Simone Joye Venning has thrown the nonprofit organization's board into turmoil, baring the delicate fault lines in the relationship between the largely white and corporate-oriented board and benefactors and the largely minority staff that directs the group's programming. 
 But others, including the lawyers representing the organization's board, insist that what some perceive as turmoil is simply healthy debate. They insist that race is not a factor although they will not publicly discuss the issues that led up to the suspension with pay of Ms. Venning, who is black. That suspension could become a termination when the board meets tomorrow to discuss the future of Ms. Venning, who was brought in from a Bronx nonprofit group with much fanfare barely a year ago. 
She replaced Myles Farley, who spent five years at the head of the 64-year-old program, which serves an estimated 4,000 children at three locations in Newark.
"There are no villains here," said one board member who asked not to be named. "It's just that when there are limited resources, people start feeding on each other. Race is not even what this is all about."
However, Elizabeth McGrady, president of the neighborhood advisory board of the Broadway Boys and Girls Club and a strong supporter of Ms. Venning's, said many parents and minority board members disagreed.
"There is more to this than they are telling us, and it seems that they just can't deal with a strong, black woman," Ms. McGrady said.
Ms. Venning, through her lawyer, Donald F. Schneider, has refused to be interviewed.
She became the subject of an investigation by the board's executive committee more than three months ago when an administrative staff member accused her of reverse discrimination. According to Ms. McGrady and others on the charity's board who heard the results of the investigation, the conclusion was that she was innocent of those charges. But during that inquiry, board members turned up an allegation that Ms. Venning had transferred some $550 in a restricted budget account to an unrestricted account in violation of the group's rules.
Even that transfer of funds, which allowed a group of children in the club to travel to Westfield and participate in a table tennis tournament, was viewed by many of Ms. Venning's supporters as benign. All heads of nonprofits occasionally "rob Peter to pay Paul," said one board member who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Furthermore, there was no suggestion that the money had gone for improper, personal use.
Angelo Genova, the attorney for the board and its president, Thomas Dillon, refused to discuss the details of any of the charges, citing the confidentiality of personnel matters. He insisted that the board had followed proper procedure in all its actions.
Richard Roper, a board member for 17 years, disagrees, and two weeks ago he resigned from the board in protest. He said in an interview that Ms. Venning had been held to a higher standard than previous directors, to justify a clash of styles between her and many board members and contributors.
"She is direct, forthright and blunt," said Mr. Roper, a management consultant, "and while she could be engaging, she could also be off-putting."
Other board members, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said Ms. Venning had run afoul of some key contributors, "prickly corporate types" who were used to getting their way. She had run into "a subtle gender and racial discrimination" that would not have resulted from similar behavior by an assertive white executive director, they said.
"None of what the investigation found was actionable as far as we were concerned," said this board member, describing what he said were his views and those of a number of others among the 41-member board. "Simone's problem was that she was prickly, and sometimes prickly people can't deal with prickly people."
Prickly, perhaps, said Ms. McGrady and Mr. Roper, but competent as well. Among her accomplishments in her short time as executive director, they said, was to "give a face to the Boys and Girls Club for parents of the children." She had met with them, said Ms. McGrady, solicited their views on priorities and programs and begun an expansion of the club's efforts to once again focus on teenagers as well as preteens. The advisory board president conceded that in doing some of this, Ms. Venning had standardized procedures and cut into the independence of the organization's three club directors.
"Some staff felt that she was too harsh and maybe yelled at them," said Ms. McGrady. "But that's not something you deal with by suspending someone after less than a year. We wanted them to set some corrective action and set some benchmarks for improvement and additional review."
Ms. Venning's introduction to the world of Newark nonprofits was rocky, according to some accounts. For one thing, as someone new to the community, there was much she did not know about the well-developed network of connections among groups as well as the care and feeding of a philanthropic community that is well established and committed to a vision of the city's future.
Modia Butler, executive director of Newark Do Something, a youth leadership development program, said that from the start Ms. Venning did not seem to have the sort of personality' that the Boys and Girls Club of Newark seemed to favor in the past.
"She was not a schmoozer with the Newark philanthropic community and was kind of matter-of-fact," said Mr. Butler.
"I'm not from Newark either," he added, "but I understand the problem and dealt with it when I got here."
Vesta Godwin, a longtime manager of nonprofits in the city and now executive director of the social services program at St. James A.M.E. Zion Church, said she had rarely seen Ms. Venning "out and about and networking" with other nonprofit organizations and local civic leaders.
"She seemed a little introverted and while I am told that she was good with programs, my personal experience tells me that it is important to be out there so that people can see who you and your organization are," said Ms. Godwin. "It's politicking but it gives you credibility."
Maria Vizcarrondo-DeSoto, the president and chief executive officer of the United Way of Essex and West Hudson, one of the sources of funds for the Boys and Girls Clubs of Newark, said she was "taken aback" by Ms. Venning's suspension. She said the programs she had overseen had been "stellar" and while Ms. Venning had made mistakes in her dealings with the nonprofit and philantropic community, she seemed a quick study and willing learner.
"Most of their recent executive directors have seemed more corporate while she seemed more grass roots community organizing," said Ms. Vizcarrondo-DeSoto. 'At different times organizations require different types of people. I commended the board for hiring her at the time they did, but these are also times when there is a tremendous need for accountability, reaching targets and showing tangible results."
But any ability to show results, said Ms. Venning's supporters, has been short-circuited by the suspension and the bad blood it has created. One of those supporters said that the suspended executive director, with her expansion plans and greater outreach to parents, was probably on the right track, but at the wrong time. Because these are tight times economically for most nonprofits, executive directors are expected to make up for that with creativity and tenacious fundraising.
"But there was a rush to judgment here and it will deeply affect the credibility of the Boys and Girls Clubs in the Newark community," said one board member.

HEADLINE: F.Y.I. 

BYLINE:  By ED BOLAND Jr.; E-mail: bolande@hotmail.com

 BODY:
The Battery Is Up

Q. What's been going on at the Battery Maritime Building? There seems to be a lot of activity there.

A. There is a definite buzz at the long-sleepy Battery Maritime Building, just east of Battery Park and departure point for the now-infrequent ferries to Governors Island. Some 300 city employees are scheduled to vacate the building in a month and make way for a new use, still undetermined. Whatever that is, the building will still be the terminal for ferries to Governors Island, now proposed as the site of a City University campus. Proposals for the terminal space have been submitted to the city's Economic Development Corporation, which is spending more than $30 million to restore the exterior.
 The building, a 140,000-square-foot Beaux Arts landmark, is decidedly a fixer-upper. It was completed in 1909 and accommodated ferries traveling to 39th Street in Brooklyn. The Brooklyn ferry service shut down in 1938, and since then the building has seen various city tenants. 
 As the years passed, redevelopment schemes came and went, and the ravages of age and indifference obscured what was a jewel of the waterfront. The grandest part of the building was the waiting room, a 55,000-square-foot lobby with cast-iron columns and stained-glass windows, part of which was used until recently to store rubber bands and other office supplies. Today those windows and the glass ceiling are boarded up and the colorful moldings painted over. The lobby looks more like a warehouse, holding files as old as the building itself.

A Look at Little America

Q. I recently came across an advertising sign from 1930 that says "Visit Little America -- A Cyclorama of a New World at the South Pole -- Luna Park -- Coney Island." What's the story behind that?

A. Early in the 20th century, cycloramas like those at the Luna Park amusement area in Coney Island were a popular form of entertainment. Viewers sat in the center of cylindrical rooms, surrounded by a large painted canvas showing a landscape, a battle or another panoramic scene.
During the 1920's, the poles were unknown to most people, and polar exploration had a swashbuckling resonation. One of the most famous arctic and antarctic adventurers was Adm. Richard Evelyn Byrd, who in 1929 made the first flight over the South Pole. In that expedition, Byrd set up a camp that he called Little America.
In 1930, the country's largest cyclorama, depicting Little America, was shown at Luna Park. The cyclorama was 350 feet in circumference, 50 feet high, and animated with electrical effects, moving icebergs and dog sled teams. But as motion pictures became more popular in the 1930's, cycloramas no longer captured the public's imagination as they once did. Luna Park went bankrupt in 1933 and eventually closed. The real Little America, long abandoned, was carried out to sea by an iceberg that broke away from the ice shelf in the 1960's.

Straphanger's Doggerel

Q. In the walkway that runs from the A train at Port Authority to the Times Square subway station there is a poem that runs along the ceiling: "Overworked/So tired/If Late/Get Fired/Why bother/Why the Pain/ Just get up/Do it again." What's the meaning of this sign that hits uncomfortably close to home?

A. The sign is not meant as a cruel joke but rather to relay an artist's empathy for the commuting public. The sign was commissioned 10 years ago through the M.T.A.'s Art for Transit program as a temporary work. The artist, Norman B. Colp, said the work was inspired by the old Burma Shave advertisements that were seen along highways from 1927 to 1963. The signs were spaced a few hundred yards apart and were to be read one line after the other as you traveled along.
The piece in the walkway combines the Burma Shave model with Mr. Colp's experience as a commuter, one who recallls that he "made it to work barely on time." ED BOLAND Jr.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
After the Fury, Investors Are Adrift

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
THE average stock mutual fund barely changed in value during the first quarter, but small-cap funds were strong performers, and those specializing in emerging markets, natural resources, gold and other niches soared.
 For stock mutual funds as a whole, the panic selling that characterized the third quarter of last year was blissfully absent. On the other hand, the sharp rebound of the fourth quarter, one that recouped much of the money lost in the third, did not continue in the new year. 
 For the record, the average domestic equity mutual fund gained 0.2 percent in the first three months of the year, according to Morningstar Inc. On a quarterly basis, it was the first time that equity funds essentially treaded water since the first quarter of 1991. 
"There were a lot of land mines that you needed to avoid, like Enron, Tyco, Schering-Plough and Bristol-Myers Squibb," said Thomas F. Marsico, portfolio manager at Marsico Funds. "If you were able to avoid areas where there was substantial difficulty, you could find some spots in the market where you could get pretty good performance." 
Those spots did not include technology and telecommunications, the two worst-performing sectors. According to Morningstar, the average technology fund fell 7.3 percent in the quarter, while the average telecommunications fund sank 13.2 percent. 
But some long-neglected pockets did very well indeed. 
The best were gold-oriented funds, which gained more than 35 percent, on average, according to Lipper Inc., the fund research company. Emerging-market funds staged a comeback. And small-cap funds continued to be solid performers. 
"A lot of the best performers were in niche areas," said Russel Kinnel, director of fund analysis at Morningstar. "Not many people are going to have a big chunk of their money in emerging markets or precious metals."
Thomas McManus, chief equity strategist at Bank of America Securities, said that even though major stock market averages were little changed or slightly lower in the quarter, the last three months were very good for most stocks. The exceptions, he said, were technology and telecommunications. 
Mr. McManus said the Value Line Arithmetic index, an equal-weighted index of 1,700 stocks, reached a record high on March 19. The index "is being helped by the great performance of small- and mid-cap stocks," he said. 
"The market is not weak at all; it is very strong," he added. "The question is: Does the economic recovery justify strong earnings expectations?"
With the exception of health, telecommunications, technology and utilities, sector funds did well.
Natural-resources funds, helped by higher oil prices, had a good quarter, rising 11.6 percent, according to Morningstar. Real estate funds gained nearly 8 percent as investors sought hard assets. And financial services funds were up 4.8 percent. 
A HOST of factors, including the failure of Enron, at least indirectly helped emerging-markets funds, which gained an average of 12.2 percent, according to Lipper. 
"Enron has been a godsend for us," said Mark Mobius, managing director of Templeton Asset Management, which oversees all of Franklin Templeton's emerging-markets funds. 
"People began to realize that maybe emerging markets aren't that bad, and that they are undervalued relative to other markets," he said.
Emerging markets are trading at anywhere from one-third to one-half the price-to-earnings ratios of companies in developed-country markets like the United States, he said. And the flow of money out of emerging-markets funds has slowed to a trickle.
"After about a year on the sidelines, institutional investors are interested again," he said. 
Emerging-markets funds were the best performers among world equity funds, but funds focusing on particular parts of the globe also did well. Latin American funds gained more than 9 percent. Pacific funds that exclude Japanese stocks gained 12 percent. 
Over all, international stock funds rose 4 percent during the quarter, according to Morningstar.
"Clearly, the investor focus has shifted outside the U.S. for now, to find outsized performance," said Jeff Tjornehoj, a research analyst at Lipper. 
Investors were clearly interested in stocks during the first quarter, but they pumped a lot of money into taxable bond-market funds, too. 
According to AMG Data Services, which tracks flows of funds, $57.9 billion went into equity funds over the last three months, the biggest quarterly increase since the first quarter of 2000. 
"This is the first time since 1990 where the month of March appears to have instigated a greater inflow than in January and February combined," Mr. McManus of Bank of America Securities said. "It is completely different from last year's pattern. In March of 2001, investors clawed back the money they put in during January and February, whether to pay capital gains taxes or out of fear." 
Robert Adler, president of AMG, said that about 43 percent of the money directed to equities went into small-cap and aggressive-growth funds. For the seventh consecutive quarter, there were net redemptions from technology funds. 
Mr. Kinnel of Morningstar said: "It seems obvious that you are not going to get a smooth comeback in technology. It is amazing how many fund managers are low on technology right now." 
Mr. Marsico said he owned no technology stocks in his growth fund. The sector "remains overpriced," he said. 
Taxable bond funds, which attracted nearly $86 billion in new money last year, remained popular in the first quarter this year, even though market interest rates moved higher and the Federal Reserve indicated that it had reached the end of its cycle of monetary easing. 
More than $34 billion went into bond funds during the first quarter. In anticipation of an economic recovery, and attracted by higher rates, investors sank more than $5.7 billion into high-yield bond funds during the quarter.
"Investors are becoming lenders, shifting risk from equity to bonds," Mr. Adler said. "In an environment of declining default rates, investors are locking in fairly substantial returns." 
Although bond funds attracted a lot more money, they did not have a particularly good quarter: the average taxable bond fund rose just 0.3 percent, according to Morningstar. 
The Vanguard Group, the nation's second-largest fund family, had a busy quarter. 
Brian Mattes, a Vanguard spokesman, said net inflows for the quarter were more than $17.5 billion, $10 billion of which went into equity funds. In the first quarter of 2001, Vanguard had net inflows of $14.9 billion, Mr. Mattes said. 
Flow figures at Fidelity Investments, the biggest mutual fund company, were not yet complete.
Through February, the company recorded $3.7 billion of net inflows into its equity funds, and $800 million into bond funds.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Sensible, Sure, but A Secret?

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
IT would be difficult to overestimate the need of a wide swath of America for a simple book of common sense. Judging by recent events, sample chapters might include: Do not twirl a loaded shotgun with house guests nearby. When giving orders to shred documents wanted by government investigators, avoid writing down the instructions. And do not bet your life savings on a mutual fund invested in companies with little more than an idea and a stock symbol. 
 Of course, few people line up to buy such books, although they might do so if they think they are getting something more, especially when it comes to financial advice. 
 James K. Glassman has dressed up a respectable array of common sense about investing in a book whose most intriguing aspect is its title, "The Secret Code of the Superior Investor" (Crown Business, $25). 
Mr. Glassman is a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, the conservative research organization in Washington. He also writes a weekly column for The Washington Post. Most famously, perhaps, at least among stock market aficionados, Mr. Glassman is co-author, with Kevin A. Hassett, of "Dow 36,000: The New Strategy for Profiting from the Coming Rise in the Stock Market" (Times Books, 1999).
"Dow 36,000" produced no small degree of snickering among Mr. Glassman's fellow financial journalists. On the book's publication date, Oct. 1, 1999, the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 10,273. Mr. Glassman and his co-author argued that the "proper level" was more than three times that.
Americans were too concerned about the risk of long-term investing in stocks, the authors contended, when in fact long-term investors have faced more risk investing in Treasury bonds. With their outdated notions about how much they should be willing to pay for stocks, investors were keeping the market from realizing its true potential.
For a while, it looked as if the authors were onto something. The Dow rose 1,500 points over the next three months. Since then, however, it has returned to about where it was when the book was published. Broader market indexes have fallen more sharply: the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down about 10 percent in that time, and the Nasdaq composite has fallen by about a third.
In his latest book, Mr. Glassman acknowledges that the timing of his last book was not good. But he, at least, is unrepentant. "In early 2001, we reviewed our theory to see if we should revise or recount, and instead we came away more convinced than ever that we were right, despite terrorism and economic slowdown," he writes in "The Secret Code."
In other words, the authors were not wrong. It was the other 39,999,998 American investors who are still clinging to faulty notions about where stock prices should be.
Mr. Glassman does not cling for long to his portrayal as Cassandra, however, to the benefit of readers seeking some sound investment advice. He dispenses that advice in language that is, for the most part, easy to understand and has been used to great success by legions of investors.
To wit: Buy companies that by nature of their dominance of an industry have strong defenses against competitors. Hold them for a long, long time. Keep a wish list of stocks that would be bought at a certain price. Never sell a stock short or buy on margin. Ignore Alan Greenspan. Buy bonds individually and hold them to maturity.
Why any of this advice constitutes a "secret code," however, is unclear. Mr. Glassman explains: "It's a code in two senses of the word: both as a group of rules to guide you and as a set of tools to decipher a mystery" -- that is, how to invest successfully. But it is far from secret, with many reliable guides, including much of the same information, available at the local bookstore. 
MR. GLASSMAN hits a couple of wrong notes. "At this point in history, I can't imagine a diversified 20-stock core portfolio that does not include at least one education stock," he writes. But many for-profit education companies have been less than stellar investments, and the political atmosphere seems to be turning against the companies, particularly in the kindergarten-to-12th-grade markets. 
He also praises one of his favorite stocks, Tootsie Roll Industries, which he highlighted in "Dow 36,000" as one of three stocks that illustrated his investment theories.
From the publication of "Dow 36,000" Tootsie Roll has gained more than 50 percent, a stellar performance. Mr. Glassman is less forceful in reminding readers of his other two picks -- Microsoft and General Electric.
A reader who bought equal dollar amounts of those three stocks when Mr. Glassman's previous book was published would have earned about 7 percent in the roughly two and a half years since, for an average annual return of less than 3 percent -- not much better than a savings account. Someone buying an equal number of shares of each of the three stocks would have fared much worse, losing 40 percent of his money. 
No doubt they will all turn out to be winners when the Dow does finally reach 36,000.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Inthe Maze Of Fees, Sizes Are Relative

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH mutual funds have long been known for giving small investors access to the financial markets, many fund families have begun raising the cost of admission.
 In the last few years, some funds have increased the minimum investment needed to open an account, others have added fees on accounts below a certain size and some have done both, industry analysts say. 
 For example, Vanguard, a favorite of cost-conscious investors in part because of low expense ratios, now has a $3,000 minimum for regular initial investments in the Vanguard 500 Index fund ($1,000 for I.R.A.'s and accounts that are gifts to minors or trusts for minors). The fund charges shareholders with balances of less than $10,000 an annual maintenance fee of $10; it deducts an additional $10 a year if the balance in a regular account falls below $2,500 and total Vanguard holdings are below $50,000. 
Many independent analysts say that even with extra fees, small investors may still be subsidized by big shareholders. Nevertheless, small investors should be aware of their total costs and the effect of fees on portfolio performance.
"The issue that the industry has grappled with all these years is that it is as expensive to administer a small account as a large one," said Geoffrey H. Bobroff, a mutual fund industry consultant based in East Greenwich, R.I. "Is it in the interest of funds to recruit small investors? Only if they are committed to more investments."
But they may not be. The industry's growth may be stymied, he added, pointing out that "the industry has penetrated 52 percent of households" and that after two years of market declines, new investors are not flocking to funds.
Mr. Bobroff said one alternative for an investor who did not have $3,000 to buy into a Vanguard fund would be to invest with TIAA-CREF, the big pension fund manager that also offers 11 mutual funds and plans to offer 5 more in the fourth quarter. TIAA-CREF has a $1,500 minimum for regular accounts (up from a former $1,000) and $500 for I.R.A.'s. It charges no maintenance fees.
Rather than shopping around for the lowest minimum, Mr. Bobroff said, investors should consider their financial goals and research funds to find one that is likely to suit those goals, then put money into a savings account until they have enough to invest in a chosen fund.
"One of the secrets of the industry is a very progressive pricing structure," said Mercer Bullard, a former assistant chief counsel for the Securities and Exchange Commission and founder of Fund Democracy, an advocacy group in Chevy Chase, Md. 
Referring to the expense ratio of 0.18 percent for the Vanguard Index 500, Mr. Bullard said, "Eighteen basis points won't cover the cost of handling a small account." But on a $100,000 account, Vanguard collects $180. "They make a lot on it," he said, "so the big guy was subsidizing the little guy." 
THIS disparity is behind the new maintenance fees. Recognizing the disproportionate burden for larger investors, Vanguard introduced the Admiral class of shares for all funds, with a $250,000 minimum investment. The expense ratio on those shares for the Vanguard 500 is a mere 0.12 percent.
If the value of a small investor's shares in the Vanguard 500 fell to $1,000, Mr. Bullard said, the additional $20 in fees would mean that the shareholder was paying the equivalent of an expense ratio of 2.18 percent. 
While that may be justified by the economics of the industry, it is important that shareholders realize what the costs are. Vanguard discloses all fees and costs clearly on its Web site. However, the S.E.C. does not require complete disclosure of flat fees in a fee table of prospectuses, and that distresses Mr. Bullard, for one.
"One thing the S.E.C. should do is require full disclosure of fees," he said. "The fee table is not up to date."
Similarly, I.R.A. account holders should be aware of custodial fees charged by banks and brokers, as well as those charged by the funds held in the account, he said.
Mr. Bullard advises shareholders, "It's much cheaper to consolidate your accounts." An index fund should be a core holding, he said, with perhaps three or four other funds to meet your intended asset allocation. "You don't need to be in 10 or 12 funds," he said.
Kurt Brouwer, president of Brouwer & Janachowski Inc., an investment advisory firm in Tiburon, Calif., said, "Fund expenses didn't get a lot of thought from investors in the past," when markets were chalking up big gains, "but today they are." 
Mr. Brouwer, who uses no-load mutual funds to put together portfolios for clients, added that even when fees appear modest, they can have a significant impact on how a portfolio's value compounds over time. 
Say an investor put $3,000 into the Vanguard Index 500, and it returned 8 percent a year for 10 years. After the 0.18 percent expense ratio and the $10 annual fee, she would have $6,226. If she invested in a fund with a 3 percent load and a 1.41 percent expense ratio (the industry average, according to Morningstar) and that same $10 annual fee, she would have $5,373, assuming the same 8 percent return.
Fortunately, Mr. Brouwer said, good no-load funds with low minimums are available. Four with $1,000 minimums for regular accounts are the Harbor International fund, Selected American Shares, the Harbor Capital Appreciation fund and the Legg Mason Value (Primary Class). Many more are available for I.R.A.'s.
If the experts are correct, the trend that all have seen is only beginning. "I foresee mutual fund slums, segregating large and small accounts," Mr. Bullard said, and perhaps more new fees that need not be disclosed in the fee table in fund prospectuses.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
3 Exclamation Points For a Quiet Quarter

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MOST stock mutual funds eked out meager gains in the first quarter, but there were notable, successful exceptions, particularly among funds that bought small-cap value stocks.
 Managers of some of the top-performing domestic stock mutual funds talked about the choices that drove their returns in the first quarter and about their expectations for the market for the remainder of the year. 

The Neglected Microcaps
Microcap stocks produced superior returns for the $423 millionBabson Enterprise fund. The fund, which concentrates on stocks with market capitalizations of less than $300 million at the time of purchase -- was the top-ranked diversified domestic stock fund in the quarter with a return of 16.9 percent.
Lance F. James, 47, the fund's manager, said many microcap stocks offered exceptional values. "These are companies that are neglected by Wall Street," he said. "It's partly because of their size and partly because often they have short-term operating problems. So we're able to find companies with superior fundamentals at low relative valuations."
One of his biggest winners was Sterling Financial, which rose 55 percent in the quarter. Sterling, a savings institution holding company in Spokane, Wash., operates mainly in the rural and suburban Northwest. The company's earnings are expected to rise to $2.04 a share this year, he said, from $1.59 in 2001. 
Mr. James also made money with J&J Snack Foods of Pennsauken, N.J. whose shares rose 52.9 percent during the quarter. The company, which makes and distributes frozen beverages and snack foods, dominates the market for soft pretzels. "If you go to a stadium, an arena or a mall, you're probably buying J&J pretzels," he said. Earnings slowed in 2000 and early 2001 because of manufacturing problems in its frozen-beverages business that have been corrected, he said. He estimated that earnings would rise to $1.85 this year from $1.33 a share in 2001.
The fund also held shares of the Intertape Polymer Group, a plastic-packaging manufacturer in Montreal. Its stock price rose 38.6 percent during the quarter, to $11.50. Because of the economic slowdown, it had fallen to less than $10 at the end of 2001 from more than $30 a share in late 1999, Mr. James said. "Our feeling is that as economic activity picks up, packaging is one of the first groups to benefit, and this company has a lot of operating leverage because it did a good job of cutting costs," he said.
He remains bullish on the outlook for microcap stocks. "We've seen five quarters of strong performance for microcaps, but that followed five years of underperformance," Mr. James said. "So we think we're still in the early stages of the microcap run."

Value Over Growth Stocks
Small value stocks propelled the N/I Numeric Investors Small Cap Value fund into second place for the quarter, with a gain of 16.7 percent. The fund closed to new investors on March 28. It has $61 million in assets, according to Morningstar.
"Our stocks are cheaper than the stocks in the Russell 2000 value index," said Arup Datta, 34, who manages the fund with Jerry Campbell, 43. They found bargains among industrial, financial services and consumer cyclical companies, Mr. Campbell said.
The stock price of ArvinMeritor, an auto parts supplier in Troy, Mich., rose 45.4 percent in the quarter. "They supply primarily to General Motors, which has been doing well," Mr. Campbell said. 
They also held shares of New Century Financial of Irvine, Calif., up 67.8 percent. New Century specializes in mortgage loans for people with credit problems. The mortgages are secured mainly by first mortgages on primary residences. "Even if consumers are in trouble, they're more willing to default on credit card debt than on housing mortgages," Mr. Datta said.
Shares of Media General of Richmond, Va., which operates newspapers and television stations primarily in the Southeast, rose 24.3 percent in the quarter. The company benefited from the rebound in the economy, Mr. Campbell said.
The managers expect small value stocks to continue to perform well. "Despite the run-up, small value stocks look much better than small growth stocks," Mr. Datta said.

A Rebound in Leisure
The recovering economy also drove the performance of the ICON Leisure and Consumer Staples fund. It returned 13.3 percent in the quarter, taking seventh place among diversified domestic equity funds. It has $84 million in assets, according to Morningstar.
Craig T. Callahan, 51, and Derek N. Rollingson, 29, co-managers, look for strong companies in the industries they believe will be leaders for the next year or two. Starting in 2001, they focused on cyclical, economically sensitive consumer-oriented companies. Companies specializing in leisure products account for the fund's biggest stake, at 22 percent of assets. Restaurants are second, at 19 percent. 
One of their biggest winners was the Action Performance Companies in Phoenix, a maker of motorsports merchandise. The stock rose 60.9 percent in the quarter. Mr. Rollingson said the growing popularity of professional motorsports had helped the market for licensed replicas.
Another holding, the Mandalay Resort Group, the hotel and casino operator in Las Vegas, rose 43.5 percent in the quarter. 
"Fears that travel behavior in the U.S. would undergo a permanent change after Sept. 11 led to an irrational sell-off of this and other hotel and casino stocks," Mr. Rollingson said. "It's merely been returning to what we perceive as fair value."
They also held shares in Lone Star Steakhouse and Saloon, based in Wichita, Kan. The stock of Lone Star, which owns and operates a chain of midprice, full-service restaurants, rose 40.9 percent in the quarter after a 377 percent increase in adjusted net income for the fourth quarter of 2001.
The managers are bullish about their current holdings and the broader market. "We expect the same theme to continue at least for the next few months into this summer," Mr. Callahan said, "so we're just partly through the rally that began last September."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Over Time, Statistics Look Better Than Life

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

 BODY:
IF an investor had bought $100 worth of American stocks at the market bottom in 1933, that modest portfolio would have grown to about $1 million by the end of 2000.
 Yet if long-term investing is so great, and everyone knows it, why aren't there more millionaires, or heirs of millionaires, walking around? 
 There are several reasons, as set out by Elroy Dimson, Paul Marsh and Mike Staunton in their book, "Triumph of the Optimists: 101 Years of Global Investment Returns" (Princeton University Press, $99.50).
First, studies of long-run returns often suffer from "easy-data bias," which results from using starting dates when the market was at very low points, thus overstating performance for the average investor. 
"Easy-data bias arises from researchers' preference for data that are not obfuscated by 'unusual' events such as war or government default, are based on good-quality price and income information, do not suffer from trading halts and are produced on a continuing basis," according to the authors, all from the London Business School. So much for random sampling.
They note that important studies calculate long-run returns from low points like 1918 in Britain and within a few years after the end of World War II for other European countries.
Returns are also flattered by what the authors call "success bias," reflecting the fact that stock-index components are usually successful, growing companies.
Then there is "survivor bias." Very long-term performance, going back to the years before major indexes were created, tends to be calculated for companies that are still in business; the ones that fail and drop off the board are not included.
The authors studied returns for the 101 years from 1900 through 2000, removing these biases as best they could. For some markets, returns fell by more than half, compared with studies of shorter periods.
Over the 101 years, the United States market, the world's biggest in 1900, as it is now, returned 10.1 percent annually, enough to turn each dollar invested into $16,797. The return for Britain, the other major market a century ago, would have been healthy as well, with $:1 growing to $:16,160.
But a dollar was worth a lot more in 1900, about 24 times as much, and a pound bought 55 times as much in inflation-prone Britain. The real return for each dollar over the century was $711, or 6.7 percent annually; each pound invested in British stocks grew to $:292, or 5.8 percent a year, adjusted for inflation.
A few markets did better than that, and many did worse. Of 16 markets studied, the best real returns were recorded in Sweden, Australia and South Africa. Then came the United States and Canada. All five had inflation-adjusted returns of 6.4 percent or more annually.
The worst markets over the last century were, in order, Belgium, Italy and Spain, with Germany and France only a bit better. Returns in these five countries were 3.8 percent a year or worse.
In each of the 16 countries, though, stocks did better than bonds. Swiss bonds did best, rising 2.8 percent annually after inflation, reflecting Switzerland's status as a haven throughout a dangerous century. Five countries' bonds showed negative real returns; the worst were those of Italy and Germany, at negative 2.2 percent. The others were those of Japan, Belgium and France.
While stocks fared better, the authors pointed to several reasons why investors would not have been able to receive returns approaching those found in the study.
One is trading costs -- not just brokerage commissions, but also the spread between a stock's buying and selling price.
Another drag on performance is taxation. Buying and holding for the long term may be wise, but most investors sell eventually, and then they are taxed. Even if they do not sell, their estates are likely to be taxed.
ONE solution to both problems is indexing. Buying stock index funds means lower costs because they trade infrequently, resulting in lower commissions and capital gains taxes. But they will not reduce the tax burden on dividends, which have been a significant contributor to total return over the last century.
Actively managed funds do not seem to be the answer to either expense, and they add another: the high cost of management, which can lop 1.5 percentage points a year off returns. That would be acceptable if they produced significantly higher performance, but they do not. Barton Biggs, global strategist for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, cites one study showing that from 1984 to 2000, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 16.3 percent a year, on average, while investors in United States equity funds achieved an average annual gain of 5.2 percent.
"It would be heartening for our business if active investment management beat the index," Mr. Biggs said. "But that has not been the case."

HEADLINE: Personal Business: ExecutivePay; 
Consultants Find Autonomy, With a Grain of Risk

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON 

 BODY:
CAROL CHRISTENSEN feels as if she has aged five years in her first six months as an independent consultant. She woke up with the jitters her first few mornings and lost sleep over a recent job offer, which she ultimately turned down.
 But she loves her independence and says she is making more money now than she did in her last job, as the manager of new-product development at Sargento Foods in Plymouth, Wis. 
 The pay for solo consultants can be lucrative, with some people earning six-figure salaries for short-term project work. But the fees and workload are sometimes inconsistent from one month to the next, which can make consulting a risky proposition in both bad and good economic times. 
"There's no safety net, and that can be a rush, but it can be daunting," said Ms. Christensen, 34, of Sheboygan, Wis., who quit her job at Sargento in September.
It's hard to predict what consulting will pay because fees vary widely by industry and region. They also depend on experience, contacts and the timing of the work.
"It really is all over the map, because different skill sets and levels of expertise demand different fees," said Jack Sweeney, editor of Consulting magazine, a monthly publication. "It can be a matter of finding a client who is in need of your services at that very moment."
Perhaps that is why few people succeed in this field for an extended time. Kennedy Information in Fitzwilliam, N.H., a research company focused on the consulting industry, puts the number of long-term solo practitioners at 70,000 to 80,000. Of course, there are many more independent consultants who work short term, often between jobs or after layoffs.
"One reason people fail is that they overdeliver and undercharge," said Alan Weiss, author of "Value-Based Fees: How to Charge -- and Get -- What You're Worth" (Jossey-Bass). 
Independent consultants are usually paid a fixed fee for a project or by the hour. Those starting out will need to investigate the marketplace to determine proper rates. Some resources may be other consultants, industry groups and the Internet. Realrates .com, for example, keeps a running survey of pay for information technology consultants at its Web site, www.realrates.com.
Doug Florzak, 43, a technical writer and consultant in Westmont, Ill., who maintains a Web site for independent consultants (www.SuccessfulIndependent.com), said he earned just $35 an hour on his first project a decade ago. Now, despite a downturn in his field, he works 30 to 40 billable hours weekly, earning $65 to $75 an hour. He says he has to spend an additional 10 to 20 hours a week, though, on marketing.
But the payoff can be big. Technology consultants earned salaries that were, on average, 60 percent higher than those of full-time employees in their field, according to a recent survey by Dice Inc., an online recruiting service.
A Web design consultant, speaking on condition of anonymity, said she recently turned down a job with a $100,000 annual salary because she was in the running for a project that paid $55,000 for eight weeks of work. Consultants in human resources, meanwhile, can bill clients $1,500 to $2,000 a day, veteran consultants say. 
Principal consultants at firms with fewer than 10 employees had a median total cash compensation of $80,000 in 2001, according to Abbott, Langer & Associates, a research firm in Crete, Ill. Ten percent of those principals earned more than $230,000, it said.
Ms. Christensen says she charges by the project. While she said she was making more than she did at her old job, she hasn't been able to project her 2002 earnings since her month-by-month pay has fluctuated.
To obtain lucrative projects, Ms. Christensen will need to promote her services regularly. Many newcomers underestimate the amount of time they must spend marketing themselves -- time that takes away from their consulting projects. This is one reason consultants, like entrepreneurs, can become shackled to the demands of running their businesses.
"Traditional selling strategies don't work, the brochures and such," said Peter Block, an independent consultant since 1966 and author of "Flawless Consulting: A Guide to Getting Your Expertise Used" (Jossey-Bass). "You have a product that's hard to describe. You have to differentiate yourself from other people."
 TO cope with this often-dreaded aspect of the work, more independent consultants of all types are banding together, forming working alliances on projects and sharing tips about new work, said E. Michael Shays, a solo consultant since 1990 who is also chairman of the Institute of Management Consultants USA, a 2,250-member professional association. 
Mr. Shays said he recently traveled to Florida with four other independent consultants to help managers at an accounting firm better market their products.
Some consultants who loathe marketing subcontract with the larger consulting firms to do specialized work. "That gets me in front of larger clients with more interesting work than I could usually get as an independent consultant," said Brenda VanderMeulen, 46, who started River Hills Consulting, a human resources consulting business, in Holland, Mich., after leaving Herman Miller, the furnishings company.
For those who set up a consulting business, becoming their own bosses is an enormous motivation. Solo consultants often complain about past experiences with office politics. Many people rose through the corporate ranks only to become saddled with managerial chores, so they went into consulting to return to the work they love.
"The last work I did at my old company was lay off 200 people -- that was not particularly fun," Ms. VanderMeulen said. 
For Ms. Christensen, who voluntarily left her job at Sargento during a downsizing, being an independent consultant means flexible hours and the chance to work at home and spend more time with her 6-year-old daughter and 5-year-old son. She said she used her severance package to start Christensen Marketing and Innovation. 
"It's different from being in an office, and being in meetings all the time," Ms. Christensen said. "I wear the fuzzy slippers, sometimes well into the afternoon; I'm here for the kids." 
During the last year, demand for consultants declined in some fields, like financial services, as companies tightened their belts, consultants say. Still, a weak economy doesn't necessarily spell disaster for independent practitioners.
Sometimes it can mean more work. Companies that are skittish about hiring when the economy is weak often turn to consultants in the meantime. Some consultants have expertise that appeals to budget-conscious corporations, or they can adapt their skills to meet clients' needs. Other consultants, like executive coaches, have skills that can fit any economic cycle.
Dave Woods, 50, left his job as director of marketing at the Shearman & Sterling law firm in New York a year ago to open a specialized consulting practice that helps law firms nurture relations with key clients. He went out on his own -- a step he had long considered -- after paying his daughter's last college tuition check. While the recession worried him, he felt ready to take the risk of going solo. 
"The recession made my potential clients more risk averse, but at the same time, law firms have become so much more aware and conscious of how valuable their clients are," said Mr. Woods, who started Creating Key Clients in Allendale, N.J. 
Despite their success, some consultants decide that independence is not for them. Joseph Furando, 36, now the director of employee development at the McGraw-Hill Companies, said he closed his human-resources consulting practice in 1998 and returned to a permanent job in the corporate world because he grew tired of worrying about his next contract. "The latitude, freedom, flexibility were a joy," he said. "But I had five years of sweating it out every year. It wears on you." 
STILL, he said, the taboos against going solo have eroded since he went out on his own. When he quit his job, someone in his former company told him, " 'You're never going to get another corporate job; they'll never see you as a team player,' " Mr. Furando said. "The stigma is not there anymore." 
Ms. Christensen agreed, noting that former colleagues and business contacts have been supportive of her venture. A top executive at Sargento even helped her fine-tune her sales material, she said. "People I don't even know are so interested," she said. "I see a sparkle in their eye; they've thought about this, but haven't taken the plunge." 
Her initial fears of failure are fading, yet she remains mindful of the risks of setting up shop on her own. "One question I have," she said, "is if my worries about the business will ever truly go away."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW: EXECUTIVE PAY; 
Will a Deck Of Options Always Be Stacked?

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
ECONOMISTS make a big deal out of "asymmetric information," the imbalance that results when one party in a transaction has more information about a deal than another party. Used-car salesmen know more about the cars they sell than the buyers. If they overcharge too often for lemons, trust is lost and the marketplace breaks down.
 These imperfections in a market system cannot be helped. For decades, we have used government intervention to protect the party on the short end of an asymmetric transaction. Many states mandate warranties for used cars, requiring dealers to repair, at their expense, cars that break soon after the dealers sell them. Supermarkets, to cite another example, must stamp expiration dates on containers of milk as evidence that it is fresh. 
 So why, when asymmetric information is hard enough to deal with in its natural state, do we deliberately create this headache by paying chief executives astronomical sums through stock options? Chief executives know more about their companies than others do, and options have become an incentive to prop up the stock, or to be less than frank about a company's shortcomings.
"When you give chief executives too much compensation in stock options, they concentrate too much on the stock price and there is a perverse incentive to raise the stock price, particularly when the chief executive wants to exercise his own options," said George Akerlof, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley, whose work on asymmetric information won him a Nobel Prize last year.
Stock options have a laudable goal. By giving a chief executive an ownership stake and thus tying his fortunes to those of his company, options should be an incentive to work hard. In fact, psychologists and economists have yet to come up with empirical evidence that the incentive works as advertised. The negative incentive, on the other hand, became quite visible in the 1990's. That is when the pay of the nation's top executives multiplied obscenely. Stock options were the multiplier; they grew from a small portion of pay to the principal portion.
 "The downside incentive becomes really serious," Mr. Akerlof said.
Arthur Andersen's undoing is evidence of the pressure that top executives applied to accountants to approve books that raised profits in false or misleading ways. They had the asymmetric advantage, and their apparent goal was to drive up a company's stock price. Enron's chieftains offered more evidence of this behavior. "When you realize that stock prices can be manipulated, then stock options become an incentive to do this," said Sandhil Mullainathan, a behavioral economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Thomas R. Horton, a retired I.B.M. vice president and a former chairman of the National Association of Corporate Directors, describes a deeper malfunction in the stock option incentive.
"I have known C.E.O.'s who reported a healthy quarterly increase in net income of, say, 11.2 cents a share, which was good, but some Wall Street analyst said it should have been 13 cents and the stock price dropped, " he said. "So the C.E.O. pushes to get the stock price up. His options gave him a stake in this endeavor. He cut back hiring and R.& D. and postponed investment spending for a couple of years, thereby postponing the potential profit from that investment."
THAT is quite an indictment. Efficient markets, the goal in America, are supposed to produce optimal results. But that is not happening at the company run by the chief executive in Mr. Horton's example. Multiply his behavior by that of hundreds of others across America and you have a corporate sector that is less than optimal, at the very least, in capital spending, research and staffing. Clearly, stock options have distorted the incentives that should be embedded in an open market system.
The knee-jerk reaction is to scrap stock options. That is not the best solution; it is like outlawing used-car salesmen because the supposedly efficient market furnishes them with a perverse incentive to hoodwink buyers. Government-mandated warranties put the incentive back on track, in effect preserving the market by balancing the interests of buyers and sellers.
That balance is the sort of optimal outcome that open markets promise but seldom deliver without government rule-making, Mr. Akerlof finds. A better incentive would emerge, hopefully, from rules that restrict the number of options awarded and regulate how they can be exercised.
"Asymmetric information, unregulated, is driving out an incentive that we need," Mr. Akerlof said. "That does not have to be."
