HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Once Bold, Janus Shows Its Conservative Side

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
INVESTORS are searching for the real Janus. 
Throughout the bull market of the 1990's, the mutual fund group was closely identified with an aggressive growth style -- outsized bets on fast-growing companies with little regard to price. It delivered spectacular returns.
 After more than two dismal years, however, Janus has made big changes in its investments, in the process confusing many shareholders. The company's biggest holdings as of Jan. 31 included several stodgy companies like insurers and banks, and it even owned Philip Morris, the food and tobacco company. Janus Enterprise, among the most aggressive funds, kept about one-fifth of its assets in cash. 
 "They seem to have made some pretty significant changes in the portfolios," said Jeremy DeGroot, director of mutual fund research at Litman/Gregory Asset Management in Orinda, Calif. "It certainly raises a question: What is their discipline now?"
Janus executives say their strategy reflects a changed market environment. "My hair stands on end when people say our strategy has changed," said James Goff, who was named director of research this year and was the only investment professional Janus would make available for an interview. "This strategy hasn't changed."
The company is caught in a difficult position. Among the 25 largest fund complexes, Janus, which is owned by Stilwell Financial, had the sharpest decline in assets in 2000 and 2001, losing some 35 percent of what it manages in stock and bond mutual funds, according to the Financial Research Corporation in Boston. Janus, now managing a little more than half the $300 billion in total assets it had accumulated at its peak in 2000, has repeatedly apologized for its poor performance and has vowed to do better. But if it shifts too sharply from its aggressive growth strategy, it risks alienating some investors. 
"What's going on here?" asked Bryan Spencer, a graduate student in Boston who lost confidence in Janus and sold his shares in the Janus Orion fund. Although he applauds Janus's recent efforts to protect investors from a downturn, he worries that a fund once aimed at finding growth companies has become something else. 
"To some extent, you expect your fund to be true to its calling," he said.
If Janus funds are not as concentrated in fast-growing companies, they may not enjoy high-octane performance when the market turns. Managers may also have trouble finding another style that works as well. 
"The risk is that they have kind of lost their moorings and are searching for an investment discipline," Mr. DeGroot said. 
In keeping with the iconoclasm on which Janus has traditionally prided itself, Mr. Goff resisted offering a simple explanation for the group's approach. He described Janus as "an eclectic growth manager" and contended that people have paid too much attention to what the group was doing in the late 1990's. People are also reading too much into specific stocks that are now in the portfolios, he said.
"We've generated good long-term performance," he said. "We've done it in a lot of ways."
But some of the funds' most recent declines put even the long-term success of Janus's approach into question. The Janus Fund, the group's flagship with $24 billion in assets, has underperformed the broader market by nearly a percentage point a year over five years and two points over 10 years. The Janus Worldwide fund is about even with the market over the last decade.
There is no question that Janus's main priority is to deliver solid returns again. Its executives say that turning performance around is more important than explaining their strategy.
Mark Whiston, president of retail and institutional services at Janus, who, unlike Mr. Goff, has no role in making investment decisions, said, "Getting back competitive performance on a three-to-five-years basis tends to cure a lot of ills and heal a lot of scars." 
Few analysts contend that Janus's two dozen portfolio managers have completely lost their touch in finding fast-growing companies. "The managers are skilled" and are still focused on growth, said Catherine Hickey, an analyst at Morningstar Inc. Companies like Nokia, the cellphone giant, and AOL Time Warner are still prominent in the portfolios, she noted.
"These people didn't all of a sudden become stupid," said A. Michael Lipper of Lipper Advisory Services, a longtime mutual fund observer. "The game changed."
If fast-growing stocks return to favor in the next couple of years, "it's not an unreasonable bet that they will be in a position to play that game," Mr. Lipper said.
JANUS did undergo something like a reorganization earlier this year when it shuffled some of its fund managers to create a new investment management structure. The moves followed the departure nearly two years ago of its chief investment officer, James Craig, who left to help his wife run their charitable foundation. Janus appointed a six-member executive investment committee that includes portfolio managers and Thomas Bailey, the chief executive. Now, Helen Young Hayes, who joined Janus in 1987 and is one of its most prominent managers, serves as managing director for investments. 
Ms. Hayes continues to help run two funds, Janus Overseas and Janus Worldwide, the group's second-largest fund, with some $19 billion in assets. The fund suffered a 23 percent decline last year, underperforming the market as well as its peer group. In 2002, the fund declined 0.9 percent in the first quarter.
Mr. Goff, who has been with Janus since 1988 and whose record at Janus Enterprise over the last two years is unimpressive, with declines of 40 percent in 2001 and 30 percent in 2000, was named director of research. He said he worked closely with Ms. Hayes, who provided much of the strategic direction for the funds. Mr. Goff focuses on helping individual managers and analysts. "I do most of the heavy lifting," he said. 
At the very least, Janus is now taking a much broader view of what constitutes a growth company than it did a few years ago. While there are some technology stocks in its portfolios, managers are studying more industries to find companies with increasing earnings. They are looking at areas like insurance, where profits have been improving because insurers had been able to raise their rates, Mr. Goff said. American International Group, the big insurer, was one of Janus's largest holdings at the end of January.
There are other distinctly untech names. The funds had sizable positions, for example, in Citigroup and Bank of New York. Citigroup was found appealing for its cash flow and powerful distribution, and Bank of New York for its profitable processing business.
Janus managers are also finding attractive prospects in health care, Mr. Goff said. Among the funds' big holdings is Tenet Healthcare, the hospital chain.
While Janus is not doing much in the way of soul-searching, at least publicly, Mr. Goff said it was tweaking how it picked stocks to try to avoid repeating the sharp declines of 2000 and 2001. Those years were painful: the flagship Janus Fund, for example, fell 15 percent in 2000 and 26 percent in 2001, and Janus Twenty, another popular fund, declined some 30 percent each of the two years.
The fund group's "principal mistake," Mr. Goff said, was in not seeing the coming downturn in capital spending by corporations, which affected many of the funds' investments in technology and telecommunications concerns, ranging from big companies like Cisco Systems to up-and-comers like Avanex.
The decision by managers to pay less attention to valuations was not as significant an issue, he contended. "If earnings had panned out, it wouldn't have turned out to be expensive," he said. But, of course, earnings did not pan out -- at all.
"The macro has dominated in the last few years," Mr. Goff said. "It has not been our forte."
Although Mr. Goff plans to think more about broad economic trends, he emphasized that Janus funds would continue to be run from the bottom up rather than according to some sweeping economic forecast. Individual managers have tremendous leeway. "It's a very collaborative firm," he explained. "It doesn't lend itself to dictators."
Which also brings into question just how significant a role Ms. Hayes or anyone else will play in directing Janus's investment strategy. While the portfolio managers may need a more disciplined hand in assessing risk or thinking about valuations, Janus's culture does not lend itself to accepting significant direction, said Geoffrey H. Bobroff, a fund consultant in East Greenwich, R.I.
Though Ms. Hayes has proved herself as a talented portfolio manager, she has no track record as an investment chief, Mr. Lipper noted. "I don't know if she's a leader or a builder," he said.
STILL, Janus is unlikely to see any big changes in how it operates soon. Mr. Bailey, who founded Janus a little more than 30 years ago, has indicated that he intends to remain as chief executive, despite his decision last fall to cash out his remaining interest in the group. Stilwell, the group's parent, which just gave senior Janus officials, including managers, $300 million worth of equity in Janus as a way of making sure they stay loyal, seems unlikely to make any moves soon to rein in the group. Stilwell declined to comment.
Jeff Morris, a portfolio manager at Invesco, which owns shares of Stilwell, said, "Longer term, you have to put equity in the hands of the people who are key to making things work." 
Acknowledging Janus's slowness in reacting to overall economic and market changes, Mr. Goff is trying to expand Janus's investment coverage and develop a broader array of potential investment ideas. "I really want to pump up the volume on new-idea generation," he said.
Despite its research prowess, Janus has been the victim of several recent stock market debacles, including Enron's implosion. As a result, Janus is also working on ways to identify problem companies. Mr. Goff plans to prod managers and analysts to talk more to outsiders about a company's prospects and be more wary of becoming too close to management.
"I'm an instigator," said Mr. Goff, adding that part of his responsibility is to delve more deeply into any investment that is performing poorly.
But while Mr. Goff said managers were paying more attention to valuations because the stock market has become more conservative, he also reserved the group's right to change its mind and return to buying high-priced stocks, if necessary. Otherwise, he said, "you're going to be suffering years where you are out of sync."
At the same time, though, he promised investors -- many of whom have lost more than half the value of their investments since the market bubble burst -- a less wild ride.
"We certainly intend to be steadier than we were and do better in downturns," he said.

HEADLINE: Where Have All The It Girls Gone? 

BYLINE:  By MARY ROBBINS 

 BODY:
I AM slumped on the couch squinting at the television, not because the reception is poor but because I don't understand. What I don't understand is the first few minutes of "It Girls," a documentary by Robin Leacock. The film opens with some quick shots of celebrities, then moves on, inexplicably, to a receipt being churned out of a taximeter. Up next, more celebrities at a Damien Hirst art show. Damien Hirst is asked, "What's an It Girl?" He looks genuinely perplexed as he says, "You're making a movie about what?"
 Excellent question, Mr. Hirst. 
 "It Girls," which will be shown on the Women's Entertainment cable channel tonight, is about those hard-partying post-debs in New York who seem to live to be photographed out and about. I point this out because some people in the film, which was shot in part during Fashion Week in the fall of 2000, did not seem to recognize the term, or at least were reluctant to discuss it. 
For their edification -- and for anyone contemplating an It Girl career -- Casey Johnson, the baby powder heiress and one of the film's subjects, gives some helpful advice. It Girls should never wear stockings in the winter, and they should always be polite to waiters.
I am always polite to waiters, but this has nothing to do with It-ness -- I'm just afraid that they will do something unpleasant to my food if I am rude. So I am not an It Girl, but luckily being an It Girl right now is not so much It as Out.
My sister Kadee, who has often been photographed at parties and is therefore highly qualified to comment, pointed out that in the late 90's, "there was even more excess than in the 80's, and It Girls were perfectly suited to that mood."
Back then, being an It Girl was a perfectly acceptable, if somewhat vague, occupation. People in New York were having fun, and why not? Earlier in the decade, people had felt compelled to be somber and reserved amid a recession, but as the 90's wore on the burden of conservative behavior was felt by all. When everyone became a billionaire courtesy of the stock market and the Internet, the time was right to celebrate.
Everyone seemed to get something out of It-ness. The girls got to be sort of famous and got some of the perks of fame, like lots of invitations and free designer clothes. The press got its photos. The fashion designers got their clothes noticed. And those who were so inclined were provided with excellent material for satire and gossip.
I do not think it is possible to pinpoint the moment that It-ness crested and began to crash earthward, but I remember one party, a black-tie affair, where I felt distinctly uneasy. I was standing on a balcony in Lincoln Center with a number of other guests, including several It Girls. Below, there were people looking up and pointing. I don't know whether they were discussing which dresses they liked, whether they should attempt to crash the party or whether they ought to erect a guillotine, but I do know that I felt a certain French Revolution queasiness. 
Some sense of proportion had been lost, and this became ever more apparent as the money slipped back to the fantasyland it had come from. The economic downturn made expensive parties, and girls who were famous for nothing, less and less appealing. As a former not-to-be-named It Girl says, "By last spring, things were out of control and some of the younger girls didn't get how frivolous the whole thing seemed." It-ness wasn't exactly over, but it was not doing well. After Sept. 11, many things that had been interesting, important or fun became not so.
"In the current economic and social climate, It Girls have no relevance," Tim Jeffries, a London-based art dealer who has dated Claudia Schiffer and Elle Macpherson, told me.
The news is not all dire. It Girls have been around for years, and although they don't wear stockings in the winter they are heartier than they look in Vogue. I polled a few former It Girls last week, and while they are not keen to wear the label (some denied ever having been It Girls), they all seem certain that It-ness will be back. Kate Reardon, a contributing editor for Vanity Fair, which named its own parade of It Girls in the September 2000 issue, points out: "There will always be a fascination with beautiful girls. The It Girl idea isn't gone; it's napping. It's just been put to sleep for a while."
I wonder how long naptime is?

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
Learning How to Talk About Salary in Japan

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
IN the button-down world of Japanese big business, comparing salaries is about as tasteless as pouring ketchup on sushi. For the Japanese, who dislike standing out in a crowd, talking about how much you make is certain to annoy friends and embolden enemies. And few companies disclose pay numbers.
 But ever so slowly, Japanese pay is both changing and moving more into the open. This spring, the government will make it easier for companies to distribute stock options to rank-and-file employees and outside directors. The government will also push companies to set up compensation and audit committees of outsiders, who might set pay more in line with performance. 
 Still, Japanese executives are paid far less than their American counterparts. On average, Japanese chief executives earn a salary of $300,000 to $500,000 a year, more in line with European chiefs, versus an average of $1.5 million for an American in the same position, according to East West Consulting, an executive search firm in Tokyo. Fixed salaries, on average, make up three-quarters of the pay of a typical Japanese company president, with the remainder in bonuses and stock options. In the United States, stock options make up three-quarters of a chief's pay. 
Executives here earn about 12 times more than the average worker, a gap that has grown gradually since stock options were introduced in 1997. By contrast, American executives earn 180 times more than their employees, a gap that has more than quadrupled since 1980, according to East West Consulting.
However, the outside world, including shareholders, is often in the dark about precise pay numbers here. As in many European countries, companies here have to report only a lump sum for what they pay all top executives, not each salary. The Orix Corporation, for example, a financial and industrial leasing giant, paid its 25 directors and in-house auditors a total of 466 million yen, or $3.5 million, in its 2001 fiscal year. The company lists how many stock options and warrants it gave them -- 300,900, twice as many as in 1998. 
By comparison, Canon Inc., the office automation and camera company, paid its directors 1.2 billion yen last fiscal year, or $8.9 million, an average of $357,600 each -- about two and a half times what Orix paid its directors. Sony was even more generous. Its 38 directors, auditors and top executives received 3.9 billion yen -- $29.12 million, or an average of $766,323. At the best-known companies, some executives make as much at $1 million a year.
The curious can go beyond those estimates by searching government records to see how much tax an executive paid in aggregate, an indication of pay. But those figures are imprecise, too, because they include capital gains and other income.
Many companies here use seniority-based pay scales; executives climb the corporate ladder at roughly the pace of co-workers. The tax system also had an impact on executive compensation: for years, the top personal income tax rate was 70 percent, while pensions were taxed at 20 percent. As a result, companies paid smaller salaries with incremental annual raises and a big pension payout at retirement.
These days, the top tax bracket is 50 percent, but the pay system remains largely unchanged because it allows companies to plan labor costs more easily. It also minimizes friction in the boardroom, where fat salaries can inflame delicate egos. In most cases, the chairman, president and director of human resources, who usually serve on the board, set the pay for all executives. "It wouldn't look good if they made their own salaries much higher than others," said Yuzaburo Mogi, president of Kikkoman, the food company, and vice chairman of the Japan Association of Corporate Executives. "Anyway, focusing too much on your income is vulgar."
This murkiness has kept salaries low, some contend, because executives have a hard time bargaining for a raise when they cannot pin down what their equals make elsewhere. And it keeps "sokaiya," or corporate extortionists, at bay. Sokaiya are in steady decline, but in the past they threatened to disclose potentially embarrassing information about executives if they were not paid off. 
"Management is afraid of releasing any potential ammunition that may come back to haunt them," said Curtis Milhaupt, a professor at the Columbia Law School and an expert on Japanese corporate law. 
In recent years, board members have been badgered more by shareholders than by gangsters. Japanese companies are still run basically for the benefit of employees, so grabbing market share and protecting jobs takes priority over raising the bottom line and paying dividends. But the decade-long malaise of the Japanese economy and a growing number of Western shareholders in Japan have forced many executives to improve their return on assets. 
THAT new focus, in turn, has pushed managers to justify expenses more precisely, make decision-making more transparent and promote the use of incentives to reward good performance.
To that end, companies are cutting bloated executive rolls and the size of their boards, which are filled with insiders and are two to three times larger than American boards. A survey by the Tokyo Stock Exchange showed that nearly half of its listed companies said they were shrinking their boards. In 1997, Sony more than halved its board, to 12; the directors now include three outsiders. 
Out, too, are dozens of the advisers and councilors, the retired executives who have offices, secretaries, golf memberships and limousines but have no legal standing in the company, and so do not have to have their salaries disclosed. "Japanese companies are now very hard-pressed and are trying to cut down on expenses, so advisers and councilors are also now being cut," said Nobuo Tateisi, chairman of the Omron Corporation, which makes factory automation equipment, and vice chairman of the Japan Federation of Employers' Associations.
To break down the clubby atmosphere, companies are also removing their in-house auditors in favor of independent committees that make decisions on executive compensation, management and auditing. The government will likely amend the commercial code this spring to certify formally what some have already started doing.
The independent compensation committees will set executive salaries and twice-yearly bonuses, which are driven increasingly by profits. At the NEC Corporation, for instance, bonuses make up 40 percent of pay for the chairman and president. The size of the bonus, however, can as much as triple if the company does well, or be eliminated in slow years. To set its bonuses, Kikkoman devised a performance index that lists each executive's contribution to the company's cash flow.
Stock options are another tool for prodding executives to put the bottom line first. Only 9 percent of the companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange now offer them, but the percentage is growing rapidly. The number of options handed out, though low by American standards, has grown ninefold since 1997.
As of last Monday, the government began to allow companies to grant options to rank-and-file workers, and it no longer required that a shareholders' meeting be called to win approval. A rule restricting options to employees of a parent company has been scrapped, allowing executives at subsidiaries and outside board members to receive them, too.
Still, stock options are unlikely to become a dominant part of executive pay packages. Decision-making is often a group exercise here, and companies are only just learning how to quantify individual executive performance. Companies generally limit the gap between the largest and smallest bonuses to about 30 percent of the average bonus.
"Stock options aren't really in the front of most executives' minds because they are such a small part of overall pay," said Makoto Maruyama, senior vice president and a board member at NEC. "Most people still think of their salary and bonus first."
There is another problem, too -- the market. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index is 70 percent below its all-time high, leaving many options issued in the technology-driven rally of 1999 and 2000 underwater.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
With Rates Low, Riskier Bond Funds Beckon

BYLINE:  By ERIC BAUM 

 BODY:
LOW short-term interest rates have dampened the performance of many bond funds, prompting investors to seek better returns, sometimes by unwittingly taking on greater risk. 
 Yields declined to 3.63 percent, on average, for short-term municipal bond funds by the end of March, compared with 4.05 percent a year earlier. For intermediate funds, the yield was down to 4.09 percent, versus 4.28 percent the previous year. 
 As a result, many investors have been calling financial planners like Douglas Hanke, president of Florida Financial Advisors, in Tampa, in search of higher yields.
"We tend to talk most of them out of it and tell them to wait it out," he said. "There are a lot of options you can take without having to stretch for yields that may not be real and lasting." 
Some investors have been attracted to bond mutual funds that use complex financial instruments that are intended to bolster returns when interest rates decline. These tactics share a similar problem: when rates rise, they often depress returns. 
Many investors are unaware that their mutual funds are using such techniques and are unprepared for the negative consequences. 
These methods involve the use of derivatives, investments that derive value from another investment or market. The most common examples include stock options and warrants, whose values rise or fall relative to the price of company stock. 
The mutual fund industry is divided over the use of these tools. Paul Disdier, director for municipal securities at Dreyfus, said derivatives, in general, were safe, but that the complex nature of these investments could be intimidating for some investors.
"It's kind of like making sausage," Mr. Disdier said. "You may not want to know what's in it." 
One of the most common derivatives, an "inverse floater," involves buying the coupon portion of a bond. Inverse floaters increase in value when short-term interest rates fall; many fund managers use them, but sparingly. 
"We're taking advantage of the fact that rates are low with a small portion of the portfolio, without taking undue risk," said Philip Condon, a fixed-income manager at Scudder Funds who uses inverse floaters to enhance yields.
THE Vanguard Group prohibits the use of inverse floaters in its funds. 
"They're not the friendly little puppies people think they are," said Brian Mattes, a spokesman for Vanguard. "At the end of the day, the only way you're going to get a higher yield is to take more risk, and unless you're prepared to do that, you probably shouldn't." 
Franklin Templeton Investments also bars derivatives aimed at offsetting falling short-term interest rates. "We take a plain-vanilla approach that's easy for our investors to understand," said Sheila Amoroso, co-director of the municipal bond department at Franklin Templeton. "When you're using a derivatized product, you're adding more risk to the portfolio, and we've chosen not to do that." 
Managers of closed-end bond funds, another type of fund, often use a strategy that relies on leverage, or borrowed money, to bolster returns. Closed-end funds, which trade on the open market in the same way as stocks, often sell at a discount to the value of their underlying assets, and many financial advisers consider them unsuitable for unsophisticated investors. 
Over the last 14 months, a group of fund companies that includes Pacific Investment Management, Alliance Capital Management, Nuveen Investments and BlackRock have started a total of more than 40 leveraged closed-end municipal bond funds, raising more than $10 billion.
Many of the new closed-end funds leverage an average of one-third of a portfolio's assets while short-term rates are low and reinvest the proceeds in bonds. The strategy is analogous to taking out a low-interest home equity loan and investing in an upbeat stock market -- a strategy that can have painful results if the market declines. 
Currently, the benefits of leveraged closed-end muni funds are obvious. The Nuveen Municipal Value fund, a closed-end fund that does not use leverage, earned 5.35 percent in the 12 months through March. The Nuveen Premium Income fund, a similar closed-end fund that uses leverage, earned 7.67 percent during the same period. The difference in their performances can be attributed to leverage, said William Fitzgerald, managing director at Nuveen Investments.
Leveraged funds are attractive when interest rates are declining, but history shows that rising interest rates can quickly erode higher yields. 
Donald Cassidy, a senior research analyst at Lipper, said the average market total return of a closed-end fund -- the change in the share price plus the dividend -- was a negative 23.6 percent from Oct. 29, 1993 to Nov. 11, 1994, a dismal market period for bonds.
The average loss for closed-end funds that did not use leverage was much less -- 13.6 percent -- during the same period.
"That was a nasty bear market for bonds," Mr. Cassidy said. "By adding leverage, portfolios did worse. It was pretty distasteful, because the average investor in these funds is risk-averse." 
Mariana Bush, an analyst of closed-end funds at First Union Securities, says short-term interest rates appear to have bottomed out again, and she advises investors who are considering leveraged funds not to forget what happened in 1994. She pointed out that leveraged funds buy bonds on margin, which amplifies losses and gains.
"Everything that looks wonderful when rates are coming down looks much worse when rates are rising," she said. "For people who need the money or are concerned about capital preservation, they should not chase these yields. If rates go up, they could lose." 
William H. Gross, managing director of Pacific Investment Management, which is known as Pimco, recommended leveraged closed-end muni funds last month to an audience of amateur investors. He said short-term rates were unlikely to rise quickly enough to undermine the funds.
"The benefit of the leverage of the closed-end funds will be reduced with Fed raising rates somewhat, but we expect short rates to move up perhaps to 3 percent, but not up to their previous 6 percent," he said. "This should enable investors in closed-end municipal bond funds to continue to receive above-market yields." 
Skeptical investors, including Stephen and Ruth Fox of Farmington Hills, Mich., who have lost at least 5 percent of their retirement income since 2000 because of a declining market, are staying away from leveraged closed-end funds and other more aggressive bond funds. Mr. Fox, who is 85, describes himself as a long-term investor who is leery of any funds sold on the basis of past performance. 
"I think it's a lot of baloney," he said. "There is no guarantee that it will continue that way. There has to be more to it than someone saying their past experience has been very good."
Mr. Fitzgerald said that Alliance was starting more leveraged closed-end funds but could not discuss the risks involved because of Securities and Exchange Commission regulations barring fund companies from discussing planned new offerings. Tom Chang, a spokesman for BlackRock, which is also starting leveraged closed-end funds, declined to comment for the same reason. 
JOHN CARL, senior vice president and director for global products at Alliance, was upbeat about the funds. 
Mr. Carl said Alliance's leveraged funds contained the risk of rising short-term interest rates by budgeting for spikes in borrowing costs and managing the portfolio holdings. 
Citing the Alliance Municipal Income fund, which has cut dividends only once since its inception in 1993, he said investors were missing out if they stayed away from closed-end bond funds.
"In environments like this, there are a lot of people sitting there and watching a percentage of their portfolios decline," Mr. Carl said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stephen Fox of Farmington Hills, Mich., is staying away from leveraged closed-end funds and other more aggressive bond funds. (Jeffrey Sauger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Investing; 
States Ease Rules on Tapping Into Trust Funds

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIMELMAN 

 BODY:
THE long bull markets of the 1980's and 90's frustrated many people who received income from trust funds that had been established three or more generations earlier.
 As the capital in their accounts swelled, their income often declined because interest and dividend yields dropped. Even when the income generated by a mix of stocks and bonds fell below 2 percent or so of the fund's total value, many trustees were not permitted to distribute any of that growing principal to the trusts' beneficiaries. 
 Help has begun to arrive for the tens of thousands of those beneficiaries, but the solutions are neither simple nor uncontentious. Many state legislatures have recently adopted laws allowing trustees to pay out some of that principal, as well as income. But the fiduciary responsibility of the trustees involves complex legal issues, as does the task of harmonizing the intentions of the trusts' founders and current and future beneficiaries. Many trustees are debating just how far laws should go to alter time-honored methods for distributing money. 
"These new laws mean trustees will have more decisions to make than before," said Robert Wolf, a trust lawyer in Pittsburgh. "And having choices can either be a great strength or a great weakness."
In the most common approach to the problem so far at least 24 states, including New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and California, have given trustees the power to adjust formerly irrevocable income-bearing trusts, many of which were established by long-departed family members. Under this system, a trustee has the discretion each year to decide how much of a trust fund's total value can be paid out.
In addition, four states -- New York, Delaware, Missouri and Maine -- have given trustees the choice of converting a traditional income-bearing trust fund into a legal entity known as a "total return unitrust," under which trustees must set a fixed portion of the portfolio's entire value as an annual disbursement to beneficiaries. Generally, that portion cannot be freely adjusted in later years. New York's law, which became effective at the beginning of this year, prescribes a 4 percent payout rate, while Delaware allows trusts to choose a rate between 3 and 5 percent. Lawmakers in Florida have passed a unitrust bill that awaits gubernatorial signature before becoming law. In Iowa, a new unitrust law wasexpected to go into effect shortly.
Some trust institutions, including PNC Bank and Wilmington Trust, are using unitrust laws to convert old-fashioned income trusts into accounts that pay out a total return. Other institutions, like State Street Global Advisors and Deutsche Bank, are focusing on using the power to adjust to give beneficiaries the ability to tap into principal.
BUT the total-return legislation has prompted a complex financial debate about how much of a fund's total value can be disbursed to current beneficiaries without endangering the solvency of the trust. Opinion is also divided about which legal approach -- the total return unitrust or the power to adjust -- is preferable. 
For trustees, the stakes can be huge. A trustee perceived as favoring, say, current over future beneficiaries, might face a court suit. Such actions, most of which are settled before they arrive in court, have become more common in the last two years, said Dominic Campisi, a fiduciary lawyer based in San Francisco. 
Some executives say laws that set or allow fixed withdrawal rates of 4 percent or more of an account's market value can jeopardize the account's viability. 
"We are in agreement with the power to adjust because it at least gives the trustee flexibility over the years," said Andrew Gallivan, a managing director in charge of trusts and estates for the private-banking unit of Deutsche Bank. "But we don't like laws like New York's unitrust law." 
Once a trustee chooses to set a certain payout percentage, Mr. Gallivan said, there is no other simple way to reverse the decision except by petitioning the court. "Someone is going to look back and say that while 4 percent might have looked good in 2002, it doesn't look so good at some point in the future," Mr. Gallivan said. 
Deutsche Bank contends that a trust that invests 65 percent of its assets in stocks and 35 percent in bonds has an 80 percent chance of maintaining its inflation-adjusted value over 20 years if the annual payout is 3 percent of market value. But if the payout is pushed up to 4 percent, the bank says, the probability of the fund maintaining its purchasing power falls to 40 percent. A payout of 5 percent lowers the probability to a mere 5 percent.
These calculations make four assumptions: a gain of 10 percent a year on stock investments that mirror the Standard & Poor's 500; a return on fixed-income investments of 5 percent a year, an annual inflation rate of 2.5 percent and annual trust fees of 1 percent. 
Charles Aulino, a first vice president for personal financial planning at Glenmede Trust, a trust company in Philadelphia, also questions the ability of an "all weather" payout rate of 4 percent or more to work for either current or future beneficiaries. His suspicions grew after he saw a study in an American Bar Association publication showing what would happen over 30 years to a trust that was invested 60 percent in the S.& P. 500 and 40 percent in government and corporate bonds. The results yielded a range of possible payouts and account balances after 30 years that were too divergent for comfort. 
BUT others regard the automatic payouts in a unitrust approach as having at least one clear advantage over the "power to adjust" approach -- more protection from legal action. A trustee who used his discretion to adjust a trust's distribution every few years would be exposed to lawsuits if current or future beneficiaries did not like the outcome, said Matthew Lynch, the chief fiduciary officer at Wilmington Trust. "That makes trustees really sweat," he said. 
Trust advisers including Mr. Lynch also see circumstances in which payouts of 4 percent or more are acceptable. Michael Kresh, a certified financial planner in Hauppauge, N.Y., has performed his own analysis using return data from the last 30 years and found that a portfolio with an average annual pretax return of 10.5 percent grew even with a yearly payout of 5 percent and adjustment for inflation. 
Mr. Kresh says the return assumptions in Deutsche Bank's calculations may be overly modest. Those assumptions are in keeping, he says, with the investment philosophy of most banks and trust departments. "For them to believe that a 4 percent payout will likely wipe out the trust's purchasing power, that means that they believe that they can't earn a yearly gross return of 7.5 percent before you take out for inflation and fees," he said. "But historically, going back 60 years, we have rates of return that are at least one to two percentage points higher for a portfolio like that."
Watching this debate from the sidelines are income trust beneficiaries, some of whom lead fairly modest lives. A 49-year-old software developer from Chicago believes that his late grandfather would have approved of a change in the terms of the family trust, which was set up in the 1950's when stock and bonds yields were higher. 
"My grandfather wanted our trust to last for three or more generations and he would want to make sure it was invested so it could grow," said the beneficiary who spoke on condition of anonymity. "With a total return trust, you can achieve the aims of the grantor, but in a different way than the fund was originally set up."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM; 
For a Onetime Jazz Palace, Nostalgia and Controversy

BYLINE:  By JUDITH MATLOFF 

 BODY:
When it opened in 1925, waiters dispensed drinks from full trays while dancing the Charleston on roller skates. After performing downtown, band leaders like Glenn Miller and Tommy Dorsey would jam at the neo-Gothic building on 135th Street and Seventh Avenue (now Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard). 
 Neighbors lamented when Smalls' Paradise closed in the 1970's. And their hopes withered further six months ago when they learned that the Abyssinian Development Corporation, a nonprofit organization begun by the Abyssinian Baptist Church, planned to transform the building into a public middle and high school (it would be leased to the Board of Education) and rent retail space to an International House of Pancakes. 
 Citing health concerns and history, neighbors objected to the plans, which would add three stories to the structure, saying they feared asbestos would be released during reconstruction. Community Board 10 proposed three alternate sites and in February asked the Landmarks Preservation Commission to protect the building by designating it a landmark.
Claiming that the construction had damaged her house, a neighbor, Marie Littlejohn, won an injunction on March 26 to temporarily stop work on the building. 
"Our chief concern is our health," said Eva M. Anderson, president of the 135th Street Block Association. "We would like to see some tests for asbestos."
She also expressed sadness that a part of Harlem's past would vanish. "They should not destroy the building," she said. "It's history."
Karen A. Phillips, Abyssinian Development's chief executive, said an asbestos review ordered by the Board of Education had been carried out. Two of the alternate locations were not available, she said, and she did not know about the third.
Ms. Phillips said it was not cost effective to run a club on the site and added that the plans would provide space for 700 students enrolled in the overcrowded Thurgood Marshall Academy, two blocks away.
"I understand that a lot of people want Smalls' Paradise back," she said. "I would love that, too. But it's not economically viable. This would benefit many children." JUDITH MATLOFF

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
Trailing the Chief in Pay, Too

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
CHIEF executives are not the only ones who once appeared destined to become endlessly richer. Until a year or so ago, the pay for chief operating officers, chief financial officers, legal counsels and other members of the chief executive's cabinet seemed to know only one direction, too: straight up. For that entire well-heeled group, hefty increases were common, often de rigueur.
 "The trend has always been for the pay of the chief staff functions to move up in lock step with the pay of the C.E.O.," said Frederic W. Cook, head of a compensation consulting firm that bears his name. 
 The numbers bear him out. According to Pearl Meyer & Partners, the total pay package, including stock options, for chief financial officers at 50 large companies averaged $2.92 million by the middle of 2001, up 50 percent from $1.95 million in 1997. Pay for top information technology executives, who are trying to play catch-up with their traditionally better-paid colleagues, rose nearly 50 percent, to $1.33 million from $889,000. Still, while none of those executive-suite occupants could justifiably cry poverty, their pay was far below the annual $10.63 million pay package that chief executives were receiving by last summer. 
Kevin J. Murphy, a professor of finance and business economics at the University of Southern California's Marshall School of Business, studied salary trends of top executives as reported in corporate proxies from 1992 through 2000. He found that the chief executive gets twice as much salary, two to three times as much bonus, and twice as many stock options as the four next-highest-paid executives in the company.
"The ratio just didn't change much over those nine years," Professor Murphy said.
In fact, the rate of increase has slowed for everyone. The Pearl Meyer survey shows that total pay for top legal officers jumped 13 percent in 1999 and 25 percent in 2000, yet rose only 4 percent in 2001. Pay for chief operating officers climbed 18 percent in 1999 and 13 percent in 2000, but only 1 percent in 2001. The pattern was similar to that for chief executives themselves: their pay, the survey showed, jumped 24 percent in 1999 and 14 percent in 2000, only to drop 1 percent last year.
"C.E.O. salary increases have slowed down and bonuses have been puny, and that's been reflected all the way down the executive ranks," said Warren L. Batts, a management professor at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business who serves on the boards of companies including Allstate, Cooper Industries. Sprint and Sears, Roebuck.
Few if any compensation experts have definitive information about current pay packages for that second tier of executives. The recession, combined with disillusionment about the reliability of published profit numbers after accounting scandals at Enron, Xerox, Tyco and others, could have meant skimpier pay packages for everyone. And if the recession is ending, as many economists say, the pressure on salary and bonuses may have already eased.
But many experts believe that the pressure will stay on stock options for reasons that have little to do with the economy. Several expect that companies will soon be forced to take charges against earnings for stock option grants, which could spur boards to scale back the number of options handed out to even the highest-level executives. Even without new rules, several experts say, shareholders are no longer automatically buying the company line that stock options tie management's fortunes to those of investors. Instead, the experts say, many shareholders worry that options provide executives with incentives to manipulate the numbers in ways that lift the share price just long enough for them to exercise the options. 
That will put a particularly strong damper on options for people with hands-on control over financial reports, said Robert M. Bushman, an accounting professor at the Kenan-Flagler Business School of the University of North Carolina. "Everyone's stock options will be under scrutiny," he said, "but options for the C.F.O.'s, who are most responsible for the accounting numbers, will be under really heavy pressure."
Still, for some second-tier executives, the pay packages may keep getting richer even if the board puts the clamps on the chief executive's pay. Executive recruiters say chief information officers, for example, are in huge demand as companies continue to grapple with ways to harness the power of the Internet. They say, too, that conservative chief financial officers with squeaky-clean records have gone way up in value in the wake of well-publicized accounting shenanigans.
"The rise of the information age has made chief information officers invaluable, and the Enron situation has put a huge premium on really good chief financial officers," said Thomas J. Neff, chairman of United States operations for Spencer Stuart, the executive recruiting firm. "There just aren't enough really good C.I.O.'s or C.F.O.'s out there, and market forces still affect compsation more than anything else."
Chief executives also tend to protect the pay of their favored aides. While directors, institutional investors and the news media evaluate chief executives' performance solely on the basis of financial results, chief executives are likely to include qualitative judgments when recommending pay adjustments for those who report directly to them. That alone offers the immediate subordinates a measure of pocketbook protection, consultants say.
"When the C.E.O. gets a big yearly increase, he makes sure that his staff does as well," said Jannice L. Koors, a Pearl Meyer vice president. "When his pay drops, his staff just sees somewhat less generosity."
FOR now, a foolproof way to derive concrete numbers for how much, on average, second-tier executives make remains elusive. Only a self-selected group of companies respond to surveys about executive pay packages. All publicly traded companies list their five highest-paid executives in their proxy statements, but by definition, that cuts lower-paid executives out of any comparative data. 
Chief executives always make the proxy, and chief operating officers almost always do. Chief financial officers who make it to that top-five list are among the highest paid of their professional peers. Even the best-paid general counsels, technology officers and human-resources types rarely rate a mention in the proxy. 
Where executives land in the compensation pecking order also varies widely by industry. For example, the operating heads of a diversified manufacturer's largest businesses are likely to be among the five best-paid executives, squeezing out support people at headquarters. 
Even the limited surveys, however, can offer a relatively good snapshot of comparative pay. The Pearl Meyer firm checked the rise -- and fall -- of top executive pay at 50 large companies, from July 2000 to July 2001. During that year, total pay for top information executives rose 15 percent, it found, while the pay for chief executives and the members of their inner circle remained relatively flat.
But when it came to cash -- bonuses that are supposed to be tied to performance -- the difference between chief executives and their flocks was marked. Chief executives' cash pay fell 14 percent that year, while the cash part of pay for top financial, legal and human resources executives was almost flat. Cash compensation for information officers rose, by almost 8 percent. 
Compensation specialists say that by making the cash part of pay the most volatile, companies are sending important messages to both executives and shareholders.
As Ms. Koors of Pearl Meyer put it, "Reducing or adding cash has a much greater psychological impact than dealing with some hypothetical present value of stock options."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The Overwhelming Allure of English

BYLINE:  By GREGORY RODRIGUEZ; Gregory Rodriguez is a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, a nonpartisan research institute.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
A GENERATION of large-scale Latin American immigration has turned Spanish into the unofficial second language of the United States. 
 In early March, Texas held the nation's first-ever gubernatorial debate in Spanish. President Bush never misses an opportunity to show that he, too, can speak the language of Cervantes. Meanwhile, with the press of a button, most automated teller machines can communicate with customers in digital Spanish. From the streets of Miami to Los Angeles, it sometimes feels as if Spanish is giving English a run for its money. 
 But even with this proliferation of Spanish, the United States is still, in the words of one prominent sociologist, a country that is a "language graveyard" for foreign tongues. While many Americans fret over the state of their nation's primary language, there are signs everywhere that English is triumphant both at home and abroad. 
As the United States strengthens its position as the world's economic superpower, the global reach of its popular culture -- and accompanying English language -- only grows. By mid-century, half the planet is expected to be more or less proficient in English, compared to roughly 12 percent now. Why should the American-born children of immigrants be somehow immune to the rising power of the international language of diplomacy and commerce?
Still, there is a growing concern that the rise of Spanish threatens the pre-eminence of English in America. Last month, Iowa became the 27th state to declare English its official language -- the 10th since 1995. While The Des Moines Register dismissed the act as "an embarrassment" perpetrated by a "bunch of yahoos in the Legislature," four out of five Iowans supported it. 
To be sure, the United States' proximity to Latin America combined with the sheer size and continuous nature of Latino migration has changed the nation's cultural landscape. Mass media, modern transportation and the Internet all nurture Spanish in the United States in a way inconceivable to earlier waves of immigrants. And unlike those who came before, today's immigrants can hear their native tongue on morning drive-time radio and watch soap operas from their homeland in the evening. Over the last decade, Spanish-language TV and radio boomed in the nation's largest media markets.
But while immigration has powered the rise of Spanish-language media, a new demographic trend is already shifting the balance in favor of English -- even in the heaviest immigrant media markets in America. In Los Angeles, home to the nation's largest Latino immigrant population, Spanish-language radio stations routinely topped the charts for most of the 1990's. But the growth of Spanish-language radio leveled off in the last few years. For the past nine months, KROQ, an alternative, youth-oriented rock station, has snagged the region's highest overall ratings. It is the first time since 1991 that an English-language station has remained No. 1 for three consecutive ratings periods. A fragmented Spanish-language radio market helped KROQ, but the station has a fundamental trend on its side.
"The Hispanic share of our listenership has increased gradually over the past 10 years," says Trip Reeb, KROQ's general manager. Without actively seeking to broaden its ethnic appeal, the station, long considered "white," now has a 40 percent Latino audience. In fact, a growing number of mainstream English-language radio stations find themselves with sizable Latino audiences. "Right when everyone is discovering the importance of using Spanish, we're seeing Latinos become the backbone of the English-language audience," said Patricia Suarez, president of Suarez/Frommer & Associates, an advertising firm in Pasadena, Calif.
Sometime in the 1990's, demographers say, the foreign-born portion of the Latino population reached its peak. In other words, on the basis of current projections, from now on the immigrant or first generation will be a smaller percentage of Hispanic America. According to Barry Edmonston, the head of the Population Research Center at Portland State University, the fastest-growing segment of the Latino population is the third generation, which is projected to triple by 2040. The second generation, is expected to double. "In every immigrant experience, there is a shift from immigrant culture to ethnic American culture," said Mr. Edmonston. "Hispanics are in the middle of that shift right now."
As American Latinos now become less an immigrant market and more an ethnic market, the equation of Latinos with Spanish is beginning to fade. While slower to make the shift than other immigrant groups, Latino linguistic assimilation is not entirely unlike that of immigrants at the turn of the 20th century. According to the 1990 Census, fully two-thirds of third-generation Latino children spoke only English. And while bilingualism does persist longer within Latino families, particularly along the border region, there is no indication this precludes the use of English as the primary language. 
As in past waves of immigration, the first generation tends to learn only enough English to get by; the second is bilingual; and the third tends to be English-dominant if not monolingual. 
"The big picture is that bilingualism is very difficult to maintain in the U.S., and by the third generation it is extraordinarily difficult to maintain," said Richard Alba, a sociology professor at the State University of New York at Albany. "This is because English is so dominant and so highly rewarded."
It makes sense that the shift to English is being felt first in the youth entertainment market. A two-year-old study by Nielsen Media Research shows that even in households where the adults speak Spanish, younger Latinos prefer to watch television in English. In fact, the preference for English over Spanish becomes more lopsided the younger the demographic. Nickelodeon, the children's cable network, has embraced mainstream Latino characters more than any other network. 
Two years ago, the Walt Disney Company failed in the first large-scale effort by a Hollywood studio to broaden its domestic Latino base. But after simultaneously releasing an English and Spanish-language version of the animated film "The Emperor's New Groove" in 16 theaters, the studio pulled the dubbed version for lack of interest. "The Latino audience clearly came out for the movie, but that audience definitely preferred to see it in English," said Richard W. Cook, chairman of Walt Disney Motion Pictures Group.
Similarly, even as the Latino population exploded, Spanish-language movie theaters in Southern California were closing. In the last half of the 1990's, a company that screens foreign and dubbed films cut the number of its movie houses dedicated to Spanish-speaking audiences by more than half. Like Americans at large, the average Latino moviegoer is a teenager. And the average Latino teenager is American-born and more eager to see a contemporary English-language action film than the art-house fare from contemporary Latin America. In fact, a recent study of the children of immigrants found that by the end of high school 9 in 10 preferred to speak English and 98 percent spoke it proficiently.
AT the same time, Spanish is certainly not going away in the regions of the country that serve as gateways to new immigrants. American-born Latinos can enjoy Latin-American soap operas or old-fashioned boleros on the radio. But like children of immigrants in the past, the descendants of today's newcomers will negotiate their work lives and create art and music in the language in which they are schooled. While bilingual education is often blamed for the persistence of Spanish in the United States, most such programs are designed to shift the child into English-speaking classes within three or four years. In addition, a few elementary school years in Spanish do not give students adult-level proficiency. Even in Miami, the nation's quintessential bilingual city, international corporations complain of a shortage of fully bilingual workers to conduct business with Latin Americans in professional Spanish. 
Thus, despite the obvious benefits of bilingualism in a globalizing world, English still overwhelms the languages that immigrants bring to these shores. Not unlike previous large waves of immigrants, Latinos are introducing words and phrases of their native language into mainstream English. But within generations of arriving in America, Latinos eager to read the classic works of Cervantes or Gabriel Garcia Marquez will most likely do so through English translations.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Kroger Sees a Shadow Lurking Over Aisle 3

BYLINE:  By LEAH BETH WARD 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI 

 BODY:
FOR years, the Kroger Company enjoyed the top spot in the grocery business, increasing sales through acquisitions and reaping the savings that come with size. The company rewarded investors with strong earnings growth and steady stock appreciation.
 Through acquisitions of independent neighborhood markets, convenience stores like Loaf 'N Jug and the popular food and general merchandiser Fred Meyer Inc. in the Northwest, Kroger amassed an army of store formats. It has become not only a national retailer of food, jewelry, clothing and gasoline but also a manufacturer with 42 food processing plants that turn out private brands aimed at shoppers across the income spectrum. 
 Along the way, Kroger executives asserted that the company was closer than ever to customers and in no danger from the entry of Wal-Mart Stores into the food business. 
But Kroger's days of comfort appear gone for now. Kroger executives no longer view Wal-Mart as only a remote threat.
While Kroger spent more than a year completing the $8 billion deal for Fred Meyer of Portland, Ore. -- the deal was not final until the end of 1999 -- Wal-Mart Supercenters gained a huge price advantage, selling groceries 30 percent cheaper, on average, according to the Boston Consulting Group, a research firm.
Kroger is still the nation's No. 1 grocery chain, with estimated sales this year of $50.7 billion, up from $49.9 billion in 2001, according to Supermarket News, a trade publication. But grocery sales at Wal-Mart Supercenters are increasing at the fastest rate in the industry. They are expected to reach $20.1 billion this year, up from $17.1 billion in 2001, and are on a trajectory that could vault Wal-Mart from its current No. 9 position in groceries to No. 1 by 2005, according to an analysis by Boston Consulting. 
To lure shoppers back, Kroger cut prices in December, sacrificing near-term sales and earnings growth in a shift that surprised Wall Street. It sounded like the start of a price war, and the stock prices of grocery companies fell. Kroger shares are now trading at $22, down from $25.85 before the change was announced.
"They said, in effect, 'We're putting on our boxing gloves and we're going to start beating up the competition,' " said Meredith Adler, a retail analyst at Lehman Brothers.
It is too early to tell whether Kroger's move will work. The company's chief executive, Joseph A. Pichler, said the brutal competition in the business had only intensified. "In 22 years, I've never seen anything like it," Mr. Pichler, 62, said in a recent interview at Kroger's headquarters here.
Kroger is reducing prices as the economy is starting to strengthen. The upturn could soften the impact on Kroger if its shoppers start frequenting the high-price deli counter instead of the low-price grocery aisles.
But some analysts say Kroger's timing could be wrong. Bargain hunters, the thinking goes, might skip the new Kroger prices to find cachet with a discount. That is the appeal of retailers like Target, which has built 37 SuperTarget stores with what it calls "unique, upscale and differentiated" grocery offerings and high-margin impulse-purchase products like vases designed by the architect Michael Graves.
Not for nothing do customers refer to Target using the mock-French pronunciation "tar-ZHAY."
Another wild card for Kroger is Kmart, which is reorganizing under bankruptcy protection after having fallen victim to Wal-Mart's dominance in the deep-discount arena. The closure of 284 of Kmart's 2,114 stores could provide an opportunity for Kroger and others to strengthen their market share. But Kmart, which entered the grocery business a few years ago through its Super Kmart centers, could start its own price war. "Kmart now has breathing space that will allow them to reconfigure more as a supercenter with potent price cuts," said Mark Husson, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. 
Then there is the main "mart" -- Wal-Mart, of Bentonville, Ark. It plans to add 185 supercenters this year for a total of 1,138. Moreover, Wal-Mart's incursion poses a stronger threat to Kroger, which has about 2,345 food stores, than it does to Albertson's, now No. 2 in grocery sales, or Safeway Inc., at No. 3
Neil Currie, a retail analyst at UBS Warburg, said Wal-Mart Supercenters compete on roughly 55 percent of Kroger's turf, compared with 40 percent of Albertson's and 22 percent of Safeway's. "The question for Kroger is: Is it too late?" Mr. Currie said.
Outwardly, at least, Kroger shows no sign of capitulating. Its offerings at the Queen City Center in Cincinnati, for example, include the decidedly hip -- sushi here, organic toothpaste there -- beside Kroger-brand pork and beans. Shoppers can peruse the latest John Grisham novel or, as some did on a recent day, listen to an in-store broadcast about preparing portobello mushrooms. It's a far cry from the "Let's go Krogering" jingle that Midwestern baby boomers grew up with.
The company has reinvented itself under difficult circumstances before. In 1988 -- the year that Wal-Mart introduced its supercenter concept -- Kroger repulsed a takeover attack from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the buyout firm. The scuffle left Kroger bruised by debt but more efficient. It remodeled stores, updated computer systems and expanded its private labels.
Kroger's price-cutting harks back to its roots in the 1880's, when its founder, Barney Kroger, defined making money as "giving full value for money received."
Some say Kroger strayed perilously from that tenet in recent years. "It will be very difficult for Kroger to catch up with Wal-Mart" in low prices, said Henry Vogel, vice president of Boston Consulting.
WHILE acknowledging that Wal-Mart has a "powerful format," Mr. Pichler contends that the average grocery shopper prefers to stay close to home. Most Kroger stores are within 2.5 miles of their customers, while Wal-Mart Supercenters draw from farther away. That is a drive most shoppers do not want to make, contends Mr. Pichler, who is known to talk at length with customers while shopping at a neighborhood Kroger.
Busy shoppers, he said, want groceries, razor blades and video rentals in one place. They also want the option of the one-time purchase -- say, computer printers, desk lamps or home-office furnishings. "We're not going after anybody," he said. "We're going after customers."
Kroger is also banking on shopper intolerance for Wal-Martish inconveniences, like navigating multiple aisles under one big roof, or traversing more than 160,000 square feet from potatoes to patio furniture.
"I like the way they are dealing with Wal-Mart," Ms. Adler of Lehman Brothers said. "They tell customers: 'We aren't Wal-Mart. Do you really want to struggle with that superstore experience?' I think that message has been working reasonably well." 
In the 22 markets where supercenters of various ownership are major competitors of Kroger, the company said, its share rose in 13 last year, fell in eight and remained unchanged in one. The numbers are less flattering when Kroger is compared only with the 13 Wal-Mart supercenters in those 22 markets. Viewed that way, Kroger's share increased in four, fell in eight and remained unchanged in one. 
Wal-Mart, not allowing Kroger to claim its neighborhood advantage unchallenged, is developing its own Neighborhood Markets. They are traditional-sized supermarkets that use Wal-Mart's corporate buying power but are in areas where customers would have to travel far to shop at a supercenter.
Some consultants say Fred Meyer could be the weapon that Kroger needs.
But others doubt that any retailer can take on Wal-Mart. Fred Meyer cannot catapult Kroger into the supercenter league, said Stephen Chick, an analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. "It's Target-like, and it's a vehicle, but it hasn't been used to its potential," Mr. Chick said.
For some shoppers, at least, Kroger and Fred Meyer came together at a good time. Irene and Ed Walters of Vancouver, Wash., say they are finding better prices and service at their neighborhood "Freddy's" -- as the chain is known -- under Kroger management. 
"There are more people out on the floor now to help since that big outfit back East bought them," Mr. Walters, a retired surveyor for the Bonneville Power Administration, said, referring to Kroger.
But if their local Wal-Mart added a grocery section, would the Walters comparison-shop? 
"Why, of course," Mrs. Walters said. "They're so reasonable."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
What to DoWhen There's No Up or Down

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
HOW to make money in a sideways stock market? 
 That is the question of the moment for investors. After a series of starts and stalls, most broad stock indexes are down for the year. The Standard & Poor's 500 has lost 2.2 percent and the Nasdaq composite is down 9.3 percent. While the Dow Jones industrials are up 2.5 percent and the Russell 2000 is up 2 percent, those gains are nobody's idea of great. 
 To be sure, sideways is better than down. But having endured the bumpy ride down the back side of the stock price peak of March 2000, many investors want the straight-up days to return. 
One stock market seer who has been more right than wrong recently thinks that the sideways days are here to stay. James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis, reckons that lackluster stock returns could last several years. 
Two things are keeping a lid on stock prices, Mr. Paulsen said. First, earnings growth is not likely to rebound significantly in the coming quarters and, second, current valuations remain relatively high, allowing no room for an expansion of price-to-earnings multiples.
Earnings will be sluggish, Mr. Paulsen expects, because there is little growth in sales and few costs to be cut. "A decade ago, we had 40 years of bloat that could be cut and we could invoke a new thing called technology to drive margins," he said. "So earnings growth is going to get caught at about the rate of sales growth, which has been 5 percent a year or less."
Examining the returns of stocks and bonds since 1925, Mr. Paulsen found that when the market multiple has fallen below 18, annualized returns have averaged 17 percent. When the market traded above 18 times earnings, returns have averaged 2.5 percent annually. "Where we're operating right now suggests very low returns in the stock market, mid-single digits," he said. The S.& P. 500 is trading at 20 times next year's projected earnings.
The good news is that inflation will remain tame, interest rate increases should be muted and P/E multiples may not have to contract significantly. "I don't really look for a disaster or a collapse but a prolonged feeling of doldrums," Mr. Paulsen said.
If such a period unfolds, a portfolio heavily skewed to bonds is likely to outperform stocks. But while some investors may be tempted by the higher yields that junk bonds now offer, Mr. Paulsen advises sticking with a portfolio of high-grade issues. United States Treasury bonds with maturities greater than 10 years should dominate the portfolio; high-grade corporate bonds and municipals should make up the rest. 
Treasuries that mature in 2012 yield 5.2 percent and those coming due in 20 years yield 5.83 percent. Mr. Paulsen says after-tax yields on Treasuries stand at twice the average since 1920.
BECAUSE there will be periods when stocks make good short-term moves, Mr. Paulsen thinks equities should remain a core holding, with a recommended weight of 45 percent. Stocks with high dividends are particularly attractive, he said, and may rise as investors realize that the old reliable growth stocks are not reliable anymore. Shares in utilities and the big integrated oil companies are good choices for their dividends. 
International shares are another piece of Mr. Paulsen's portfolio. He believes that the dollar will weaken over the next several years, translating to better performance in foreign companies' stocks. These should be bought through mutual funds, for low cost and diversification. 
"Since 1982, investors have learned to buy and hold, buy on dips, stay the course in equities," Mr. Paulsen said. "But the strategies that worked well in the past may be disappointing. It seems we are at a crossroads and going forward, the stock market's performance may prove far more choppy."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
When Small Funds Aren't Necessarily Better Funds

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to mutual funds, many investors think that small is beautiful. New research suggests that they are wrong.
 By "small," I am not referring to funds that invest in stocks of smaller companies, the so-called small-cap stock funds, but instead to funds that are themselves small, having relatively few assets under management. Many people believe that such funds enjoy a performance advantage over the largest ones. 
 The belief stems in part from the relative nimbleness of smaller funds. It is difficult, for example, for a large fund to buy or sell a sizable position in some stocks without moving their prices up or down significantly. In some cases, it would be downright impossible for a big fund to establish a position that it would consider worthwhile.
Imagine yourself in the shoes of Robert Stansky, manager of the Fidelity Magellan fund, which has $78 billion under management. His largest current holding is General Electric, of which Magellan owns $3.7 billion in shares. That amount exceeds the market capitalization of even the largest company in the Russell 2000 index, a benchmark for smaller stocks, and it is greater than the market caps of about half the companies in the Russell 1000, a large-cap benchmark.
So when it comes to around 2,500 of the 3,000 companies in these two Russell indexes, there is no way Mr. Stansky could buy as large a position as his stake in G.E., no matter how much he likes it. (By the way, these 3,000 companies represent more than 98 percent of the United States equity market.)
Even among many of the 500 remaining companies, Mr. Stansky would still have difficulty buying a position as large as his G.E. holding. The average daily trading volume of many of these 500 companies is but a small fraction of $4 billion, so any attempt to add such a large position would so distort the market as to make the trade untenable.
Mr. Stansky could still establish smaller positions in many of these companies. But he would face a trade-off: the smaller the stake in a given company, the smaller its potential contribution to his fund's profitability.
Small mutual funds, in contrast, are at a significant competitive advantage. Consider a fund that has $25 million under management -- which would hardly be the smallest fund in the universe. That level of assets, however, is just 0.03 percent of Magellan's assets. Virtually no publicly traded stock would be beyond the reach of a fund that small.
The ability to trade in small-cap stocks lets the smallest funds exploit the so-called small-cap effect -- the historical tendency of small-cap stocks to outperform large ones. Since 1926, on average, that performance difference has been about 1.2 percentage points a year, according to Ibbotson Associates. To qualify as a small-cap stock, under the definition of Ibbotson and others, a company must have a market capitalization of less than $200 million.
For years, the data confirmed the theory that small funds perform better than large ones. One study, for example, found that for every doubling in a fund's size, investors could expect a decrease of 21 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, in annualized performance. That adds up to a big difference, especially when considering that the largest funds are many times bigger than the smallest.
This is where the conventional wisdom stood until the late 1990's, when a fatal flaw was found in the historical comparisons of large and small funds. The discovery was made by Mark M. Carhart, then an assistant professor of finance and business economics at the University of Southern California and now co-head of quantitative research at Goldman Sachs Asset Management. Mr. Carhart found that the previous studies had used historical databases that ignored funds that had gone out of business.
That omission was significant, and for two reasons: Smaller funds go out of business much more often than larger ones, and funds that fold tend to be poorer performers than those that survive. Upon correcting this so-called survivorship bias, Mr. Carhart could detect no systematic difference in the performances of large and small funds. (His research has circulated for several years as a working paper: http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract-id=36091).
To understand his findings, consider that the average small fund is riskier than the average large one -- so risky, in fact, that there is a much greater chance that it will lose enough money to force it out of business. After all, when you bet aggressively, you have higher odds of winning big -- and losing big. On average, you end up no better off than you would have by going with a larger fund.
So where did conventional wisdom go wrong? Why can't the average small fund capitalize on its abilities to trade with lower transaction costs and to invest in smaller-cap stocks?
One major reason is now known: The average smaller fund spends a greater percentage of assets on administrative costs, advisers and managers, and on marketing costs like 12b-1 fees. In fact, according to research conducted several years after Mr. Carhart's paper, the smallest 25 percent of funds have average expense ratios that are 94 basis points higher than those of the largest 25 percent of funds. (This research was conducted by John M. R. Chalmers of the University of Oregon, Roger M. Edelen of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and Gregory B. Kadlec of Virginia Tech.)
Even with a higher expense ratio, a small fund still has fewer dollars to spend for luring a top money manager and buying the best research. To be sure, a superstar manager and expensive research do not guarantee success. But Mr. Carhart's finding suggests that they generally help.
Yet another factor diminishes the theoretical advantage of the smallest funds. The small-cap effect, it seems, is not as exploitable in practice as theory suggests, even by the smallest funds. Recent research by three finance professors -- Joel L. Horowitz of Northwestern, Tim Loughran of Notre Dame and N. E. Savin of the University of Iowa -- has found that the small-cap effect is being driven almost completely by the tiniest companies. 
How tiny? The three professors found that if companies with market capitalizations of $5 million or less are eliminated from the record, the small-cap effect disappears. That is devastating to the small-cap effect because it is virtually impossible to make money by investing in such companies -- they hardly ever trade, and their bid-ask spreads are prohibitive.
The bottom line is this: In choosing a mutual fund, you should not take its own size into account. Instead, search for a fund that has beaten the market over many years. If it happens to be a small fund, so be it.

Chalmers, University of Oregon; Roger M. Edelen, the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania; Gregory B. Kadlec, Virginia Tech)
