HEADLINE: No Reason to Line Yankees' Pockets 

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
 The papers have been filled with grumblings about the inalienable right of Yankee fans to watch the Yankees. The assumption seems to be that Cablevision must include YES in basic cable, passing along any fees to all subscribers, no matter that forced consumption ill suits our free-market system. 
 As a New Yorker, I would say no to YES. Although Cablevision may have proved itself incapable of managing sports franchises (witness the Rangers and Knicks), its management of cable systems is spot on. I have never seen any reason to line the plush pockets of the Boss, Clemens, Jeter or El Duque.
So, to Cablevision, I would suggest, stand by your convictions. If the Yankees want all their games televised, then they can go back to broadcast TV; if they want their own network, then consumers can buy it separately. To politicians, I would say, remember that more voters are not Yankee fans than are; demanding that Cablevision take $24 from me every year for Steinbrenner, well, it just doesn't look good in a recession. And to the Yankees, I would say, just play ball.

COLIN SAVAGE
New York

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
So You Lost Your Job. Feel Better Now?

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
ATTENTION, New Yorkers and those who work in the city! Are you feeling sorry for yourself because the economy here is still crumbling? Are you envious of your fellow Americans who live where the recession seems to be over? Are you seriously considering trading your co-op on Columbus Avenue for a cottage in Columbus, Ohio, just because of the unemployment rate there is under 4 percent?
 Christopher J. Ruhm has news for you: the local recession is good for your health.
 Professor Ruhm, who teaches economics at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, has spent years studying localized economic downturns like the one now afflicting New York City, where the unemployment rate now tops 7 percent.
 And he's found that as the unemployment rate rises, other things fall: deaths, smoking, obesity, heavy drinking, heart disease, and some kinds of back problems. Conversely, as one of his recent papers puts it, "Economic Expansions Are Unhealthy." 
 Sounds unlikely, doesn't it? After all, unemployed people often lose their health insurance, usually can't afford to go to a gym, and are sometimes found drowning their sorrows at watering holes that sell cheap drinks. (Given their lack of funds, some unemployed New Yorkers report, their vices are more likely to revolve around watching daytime TV and eating Cap'n Crunch out of the box.)
 But Professor Ruhm is persuasive. His work has been published in very scholarly journals, and he is associated with the National Bureau of Economic Research, home to the folks who decide when recessions have begun and ended.
 His papers are full of complex equations and sentences such as "Individuals maximize a utility function U(H,Z), where H is health, Z a composite consumption good and (with subscripts denoting partial derivatives) Uh and Uz (Uhh and Uzz) are positive (negative)." There are footnotes and appendixes and references to mysterious statistical thingles like the Huber-White sandwich estimator, which has nothing to do with lunch.
 And after running reams of health data through econometric models, he has consistently found that "short-lasting economic downturns are good for health," he said recently. And upturns are bad.
 For example, he found that a one percentage point rise in a state's jobless rate is associated with a 0.5 percent decrease in the total death rate. When the unemployment rate drops by a point, fatal car accidents increase by 2.4 percent and people are more likely to report that they have medical problems.
 Why might this be? "There are various possible explanations, none of which are completely convincing," Professor Ruhm said.
 One fairly obvious factor is that people who are not working are less likely to be injured or killed on the job. Another is that traffic congestion and pollution, both of which present health risks, often rise when the economy booms and subside when the economy swoons.
 While recreational drinking doesn't seem to change much in recessions, heavy drinking declines, perhaps because booze hounds have less money in their pockets, the professor found. The number of smokers also falls.
 Finally, when the economy is cooling, people have more time to take care of their health, by exercising, say, or eating at home rather than scarfing down fast food. When the economy is cooking, "people are so busy they don't have time to invest in health," Professor Ruhm said.
 "So they drink more, and eat unhealthily."
 To be sure, not all of a recession's effects are benign. Suicides tend to rise, as do some kinds of mental illness, he said, adding, "There's some evidence that physical and mental health might go in opposite directions."
 And no one is suggesting that New Yorkers would be healthier if the current economic pothole turned into a deep crater. The professor's work focuses on fairly short-term recessions and expansions, not on long-term trends.
"I'm not saying that if all our income was permanently cut in half, that would be good for our health," he said. In fact, he notes, higher incomes generally translate into better health, which makes it even more surprising that economic upturns still produce less healthy populations.
 So take heart, New York. The economy here may still be crummy, the number of jobs dropping, the unemployment rate rising. Things may be going a lot better in Modesto, Calif., or Missoula, Mont. But what's money when you have your health?

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I'm not saying that if all our income was permanently cut in half, that would be good for our health," said Christopher J. Ruhm. He does say a short economic slump helps it. (Karen Tam for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Judge Considers Power Cable 

BYLINE:  By John Rather 

 BODY:
Judge Carl J. Schuman of Superior Court in New Britain will decide this week whether to bar installation of a 330-megawatt electric cable across Long Island Sound until at least June.
 The delay would allow the judge time to hear a challenge to the project brought by the state attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, and the City of New Haven. 
 On Wednesday, the state House of Representatives approved a one-year moratorium on construction of utility crossings in the Sound, including the electric cable. 
The 138-11 vote calls for a comprehensive environmental assessment of all utility projects in the Sound, which is regulated by state and federal agencies. The bill now goes to the Senate.
The moratorium endorsed Wednesday would ban new construction of interstate pipe and cable lines, but would exempt maintenance on existing lines near Norwalk owned by Northeast Utilities.
Mr. Blumenthal and the city have filed suit to reverse an approval that the Connecticut Siting Council gave the project. The suit argues that laying the 24-mile cable from New Haven to Shoreham could damage shellfish beds and cause other environmental damage and would deliver power to Long Island without economic benefit to Connecticut.
Richard M. Kessel, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, said the authority was supporting Trans-Energie, the cable developer, in arguing that the cable not be delayed. He said that the Connecticut officials were being shortsighted. 
"If the court decides that they will not allow the cable until the whole case is heard, that would likely kill the cable for this summer," he said. "And that could lead to electric shortages in Connecticut and the Northeast as sure as on Long Island."
The Army Corps of Engineers approved the project last month but said the cable had to be in place by June 1 to avoid harm to shellfish and winter flounder. Failure to meet the deadline would delay the project until fall. The authority said that laying of the cable would have to begin by early May to beat the deadline.
Mr. Kessel has said that electricity delivered on the cable and produced by 10 small power units that the company is installing would be needed to avoid power shortages in heat waves this summer. John Rather

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: ESSAY; 
Investment Counseling From the 'Real' Pros

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
NOTHING gets my blood pumping, and imagination running, like a hot discussion of 401(k) plans. So here goes.
 A few weeks ago, Conning & Company saw fit to put out a press release telling the world of a "New Role Emerging for 401(k) Providers." You may not have heard of Conning, but it is -- the release says -- "one of the largest asset managers specializing in insurance company investments in the United States," as well as "a nationally respected provider of research publications on the insurance industry." 
 Despite Conning's unfortunate name, I have no reason to doubt its claims. Those are not the kind of honors one makes up.
Anyway, the release touched on the debate now festering in Washington about whether companies should be offering investment advice to their employees in their 401(k) retirement plans. The impetus for the debate, of course, is the Collapse of Enron, the most dastardly event in the history of business. As you may be aware, the Collapse of Enron left hundreds -- maybe thousands -- of upper-middle-class people out of work for weeks, if not months.
Some even lost their pools.
Most unfortunately, Enron's plunge into bankruptcy court also cost many of its rank-and-file employees their savings. They believed in Enron and placed all, or most, of their 401(k) savings in its stock.
Their plight prompted Conning to commission a study of 401(k) plans. It found that "in the wake of Enron's apparent demise and the loss of retirement funds suffered by many companies' employees, the need for investment advice is growing." When did an investment adviser ever find otherwise?
The release went on to suggest that the insurers -- Conning's clients -- that run 401(k) plans "have an opportunity now to increase their business" by offering more advice to the employees in those plans.
After all, Washington is pressing companies to educate their employees on investment issues -- and it may even try to force them.
But the press release failed to answer a crucial question: Who in the name of all that is good would want financial advice from an insurance company? Insurance companies have managed to miss every financial trend of the last two generations, which is why Hartford, the home of much of the insurance industry , is such a bustling metropolis today.
The only insurance company that has shown the slightest streak of innovation in the last 30 years was the Equity Funding Corporation. The Equity Funding Corporation was a fraud. Insurance is such a good business that Citigroup just got out of it.
On the other hand, if the financial companies that run the 401(k) plans are not allowed to give advice to the participants, workers may be left receiving tips from their employers, as Washington prefers, and with predictable results.
Imagine a scene at Enron headquarters, September 2001:
Jeffrey K. Skilling stands before a group of Enron employees, while Andrew S. Fastow sits at a nearby desk, riffling through stacks of $100 bills. The words "Today's Discussion: Your 401(k). Who Needs It Anyway?" are written in red Magic Marker on a white board behind Mr. Skilling.
An employee raises her hand. "Mr. Skilling, Mr. Fastow, how much of my retirement account should I invest in Enron stock?"
"Oh, I'd say 90, maybe 95 percent. Andy, any ideas?"
"Don't bother me. I'm counting my money."
"But isn't that risky, Mr. Skilling? What if the stock goes down?"
"Down? Don't be such a sissy. Go out there and buy some stock. In fact, I've got some shares I could sell you right now."
On second thought, this scene is too depressing to contemplate. So here's a better idea. Instead of depending on companies or insurers to help employees manage 401(k)'s, let workers get advice directly from Congress and the White House. After all, politicians on both sides of the aisle have had amazing success as investors over the years. No asset class seems immune from their magic.
TRADERS of oil, gas and pork bellies could be advised by Hillary Rodham Clinton, commodities investor extraordinaire: "My secret: The Wall Street Journal."
For penny-stock investors, Robert G. Torricelli and the no-longer-elected Alfonse M. D'Amato could share their success stories: "It's so important to have a broker you can trust, whether at Whale Securities or Stratton Oakmont."
For investors hoping to turn a small fortune into a large one, even after a couple of setbacks, President Bush, former general partner of the Texas Rangers, could teach: "What I'm talking about here, folks, is taxpayer subsidies and leverage. The evil one doesn't have taxpayer subsidies and leverage. You do."
With tips like those, employees should have no problem building their nest eggs for retirement -- without having to invest in their companies' stocks or risky names like General Electric. The Standard & Poor's 500 may rise or fall, but pork bellies are a sure route to riches. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 21, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on April 7 in the quarterly Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section, about investment advice for 401(k) retirement plans misstated the timing of a Conning & Company study of them. Research began on March 1, 2001, according to the company, months before Enron's problems became publicly known; the study was not prompted by those problems.

LENGTH: 1244 words

HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT; 
Their Words Are Our Bonds

BYLINE:  By ABBY SCHULTZ 

 BODY:
WHEN Gov. James E. McGreevey announced his first budget proposal last month to the Legislature, lawmakers listened intently. The press paid close attention, and taxpaying New Jersey residents were eager to learn how the new governor would meet his policy goals amid a budget deficit of nearly $3 billion this fiscal year and anticipated shortfalls to come. 
 But perhaps the most important audience was a handful of individuals at Wall Street's big bond rating agencies. The assessments of these men and women, who analyze the ability of New Jersey to pay its debts, can end up costing taxpayers a lot of money if they don't like what they see. 
 The bond rating agencies, which include Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's Corporation, rate general obligation bonds sold by the states to pay for road repairs, school construction and transportation among other state financing needs. The bonds are fully backed by the state. The job of the rating agencies is to assess the risk to investors who buy these bonds. 
Bonds with high ratings are considered less risky and carry a lower interest rate than bonds with lower ratings. A state like Virginia, which has the highest rating, triple-A, from S.&P. will pay less in interest costs to bondholders than a state like California, which has a single-A-plus rating. 
Early last week, in response to Mr. McGreevey's proposed budget, Standard & Poor's decided to maintain New Jersey's above-average bond rating of double-A-plus. The rating agency remains concerned, however, whether New Jersey can get out of its fiscal crisis and so has kept the bonds on "credit watch with negative implications." 
By placing an issuer's bonds on credit watch, whether it is a corporation like Enron or a state, S.&P. is alerting investors that it will carefully watch the issuer's progress for the next six to nine months and will downgrade the rating if warranted, said Robin Prunty, a director in the public finance department at Standard & Poor's. There are three other states -- Tennessee, Washington and Wisconsin -- currently on credit watch with negative implications. 
In New Jersey, S.&P. is concerned that the governor's revenue estimates rely on personal income projections that "are on the high side relative to other states that we've seen," Ms. Prunty said. The budget also relies on nonrecurring revenue, including a proposal to sell $1.1 billion in bonds backed by expected revenues from a settlement with tobacco companies. It is also unclear if the Legislature will approve proposals like the tobacco bonds. 
"Fundamentally, we think New Jersey has a pretty substantial economic base," Ms. Prunty said. "It's clearly one of higher rated credits. But I think there's lots of moving parts to that budget."
Moody's Investors Service, another big rating agency, downgraded New Jersey's general obligation bonds early last month to an average rating of Aa2 from above average, or Aa1. 
The effects of this so-called "split rating" -- above average from one rating agency and average from another -- could raise the interest costs that New Jersey taxpayers pay to bondholders by a relatively small amount of less than 0.1 percentage points, according to bond market participants.
Still, a state treasurer has good reason to be concerned about any perceived deterioration in credit strength. New Jersey, for instance, had maintained its above-average rating since it was downgraded from triple-A during the 1990's recession, said S.&P.'s Ms. Prunty. Another downgrade is clearly a move in the wrong direction.
"As you move down the categories, there's always the risk you are going to move further down," Mr. Friedlander said. "Any state guards their credit rating as one of the first things they have to do."
Given the stakes, the state Treasurer, John E. McCormac, who is responsible for putting together the state budget, takes the comments of Moody's and S.&P. seriously. 
"Every discussion we've had so far on different options has always at some point turned to what the rating agencies would think of these different options," Mr. McCormac said. 
The treasurer estimates he has spoken to analysts of each rating agency, including a third, Fitch, at least a dozen times by phone since he took office. He has also had face-to-face meetings with each. "We almost have a direct line," he said. 
Mr. McCormac says that though the rating agencies, as outside, unelected observers, have a big influence on the budget process, their approach shows reasoned and thoughtful analysis. "They ask questions," he said. "They try to get not just the numbers, but the story behind the numbers."
The process also benefits the treasurer as he learns how other states handle difficult issues. "It's good to talk to people who have experience across all 50 states in budgeting and financing," Mr. McCormac said.
At each agency, the state's finances are reviewed by a lead analyst and usually at least one other analyst. Any rating decisions, however, are made with the input of a committee of analysts versed in state credit trends. The resulting rating is a "relative measure of financial strength," which looks at how each state is doing relative to the others, said Timothy Blake, Moody's lead analyst for New Jersey. 
The rating agencies focus on four broad areas when they make state rating decisions. The first is the general economy of the state. The second is the debt profile: How much debt does the state have outstanding? What kind of debt is it? What is the size of the debt in relation to the total budget? 
The third area is administrative, the role of the governor and Legislature in the budget process. New Jersey combines a constitutional requirement of a balanced budget and strong gubernatorial power, for example. 
Moody's also looks at how well the Legislature solves problems. Moody's has noted that the New Jersey legislature has a difficult time limiting spending, singling out the court-ordered requirement to make massive improvements to poor school districts. 
The fourth area, the state's financial performance, is the most worrisome to Moody's and S.&P. New Jersey's revenues have plummeted as residents earn less from jobs in financial services and as they pay less in capital gains taxes from their stock holdings, Mr. Blake said. Meanwhile, spending isn't being cut enough, he said. 
As a result, the state's budget is out of "structural balance" -- spending is exceeding revenues. "That's $2 billion out of whack in 2002 and $2 billion in 2003, even after all the cuts and adjustments," Mr. Blake said. "And because we don't think stock markets and financial services will be zooming back, we think they'll be $2 billion out of whack in 2004. That sort of multiple period of out of structural balance, we didn't feel kept New Jersey among the upper tier of states."
At Moody's, only 8 states have an above average, or Aa1, rating. At S.&P., 11 states, including New Jersey, are above average. 
Though the rating agencies influence the budget process, they don't ultimately determine the outcome. Louis D. Greenwald, a Democrat and chairman of the State Assembly budget committee, isn't about to agree with Moody's view that the state should raise taxes to close the budget gap. 
"I look at them as a research tool, as part of the process," Mr. Greenwald said. "We check their information, and take the suggestions and analyze them according to our own personal experiences. It doesn't mean they have the right answers."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: AL QAEDA; 
Verses From bin Laden's War: Wielding the Pen as a Sword of the Jihad

BYLINE:  By DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
The poem is a tale of betrayal, exile and siege, cast as a mournful conversation between father and son.
"Why, father, have they sent these missiles, thick as rain," the child asks, "showing mercy neither to a child, nor to a man shattered by old age?"
 "It is a world of criminality, my son," the father laments, "where children are, like cattle, slaughtered." 
 The poem, "The Travail of a Child Who Has Left the Land of the Holy Shrines," was found last fall in an abandoned house in Kabul, Afghanistan, once used by Al Qaeda fighters. The three-page printed poem clearly notes its two authors, "the poet Dr. Abd-ar-Rahman al-Ashmawi" and "Sheik Osama bin Laden." 
Three Arabic literature experts who examined the poem for The New York Times said it appeared that Mr. bin Laden had written roughly half the verses, probably after the American bombardment of Afghanistan began in October. 
The poem alludes to Mr. bin Laden's nomadic exile from Saudi Arabia to Sudan and then to Afghanistan. It criticizes Arab nations for not rising up against the attacks on Afghanistan, saying, "They are America's henchmen, blinded and devoid of vision." 
The poem, reproduced as if for distribution, appears to be another example of Mr. bin Laden trying to use poetry, a revered art form in the Muslim world, to further his cause and burnish his image as a pan-Islamic warrior, savior and muse.
At his son's wedding in Afghanistan in February 2001, Mr. bin Laden read a poem celebrating the attack in October 2000 on the American destroyer Cole, according to American officials. In a homemade videotape from November, he hailed the attack on the World Trade Center by reading a poem. 
"The function of poetry in the Arab world is much broader and wider than it is in Western culture," said Issa Boullata, a professor of Arabic literature at McGill University in Montreal, who reviewed the bin Laden poem. "He wants to show he is a leader and he knows the culture, and he is using the medium which the traditional society accepts."
Professor Boullata and the other experts noted that the poem found in Kabul was written in the classical Arabic used in the Koran, which would give the verses religious authority and wider appeal. "Even those who are not literate people, who cannot read, when this kind of Arabic is read to them they understand it," he said, "because they recite the Koran every day." 
Writing and reciting verse is more common among nonpoets in the Islamic world than in the West, the experts said. More than a dozen poems apparently written by fighters in the jihad were found in abandoned safe houses, training camps and trenches in Afghanistan last fall.
The poems, most of them handwritten, were in Arabic, Urdu and Pashto, suggesting their authors were Arab and Pakistani volunteers and Afghan supporters of the Taliban. While the sophistication of the writing varies widely, the verses offer a glimpse into the fighters' thoughts and motivations.
One Arabic poem, signed by a Mukhtar Said, joyously hails the Sept. 11 attacks. "The cross has been smashed with the Koran's pick axe," the poem begins. "The hosts of the truth are striking with lances at the land of deviation, the abode of the devil." Philip Kennedy, an Arabic literature professor at New York University who translated the poem, said it then refers to the hijackers: "Their fingers turned, steering a plane towards the citadels -- the refuge of crows."
In another poem, this one praising the attack on the Cole off Yemen, Mr. Said writes, "Nothing will cause them weighty harm . . . except if their heads are shorn off and scattered about." He urges other young men to follow the path of those "who plunged into the seas, steadfastly."
Other poems reflect more universal emotions, like one apparently written by a Pakistani recruit that says, "My dear one is gone now, I can't live in this heaven without my beloved."
The origin of the bin Laden poem, like the others, is not clear. Neither an American intelligence official consulted by The Times nor the poetry experts recognized the name of Mr. bin Laden's co-author, Dr. Ashmawi. But they said it was not unusual for one person to add to the verses written by another. 
Nor is it clear just which verses were written by Mr. bin Laden himself. 
Professor Kennedy said he believed that Mr. bin Laden wrote the second half, beginning at line 22, where the father says, "I have migrated westward to a land where flows the Nile," a description that mirrors Mr. bin Laden's exile from Saudi Arabia. 
Pierre Cachia, a professor of Arabic literature at Columbia University who translated the poem for The Times, believes that the portion written by Mr. bin Laden begins several lines below, where the father begins speaking to the son: "Here are we, locked in tragedy: all safety gone." 
But according to Professor Boullata, it is possible that the Qaeda leader actually wrote the first half. "It's very difficult to say," he said.
The poem includes anti-American references and it praises Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader. "Kabul holds its head up high despite the hardship and the danger," he writes, and lauds "our commander, Mullah Omar" as "marked by manliness and pride." 
That portion also implies that Mr. bin Laden has been demonized simply because he was trying to recapture the purity of Islam. "Father, what has happened so your likenesses are on placards?" he asks. "Is your redeeming of an ancient house a crime that cannot be forgiven?"
The poem's classical Arabic is another sign of Mr. bin Laden's goal of recreating the caliphate, the era of Islam's ascendancy after Muhammad's death in the seventh century.
"It's purely favoring the classical tradition, not anything modern," Professor Cachia said. "We don't fight on horseback anymore, but they keep the images of old."
However much the poem's language favors the ancient form, it ends with the father's pledge to carry out the current fight. 
"I swear by God the great," the poet writes, "that I shall fight the infidel."

Of Exile and Betrayal
The introduction to this Arabic language poem, which was found with Al Qaeda documents in an abandoned house in Kabul, says,"Half of the verses of this poem are by the poet Dr. Abd-ar-Rahman al-Ashmawi, and the other half are by Sheik Osama bin Laden."

The Travail of a Child Who Has Left the Land of the Holy Shrines

"Father, where is the way out of all our troubles ?
 When are we to have a settled home?
 Oh, father, do you not
 See encircling danger?
 Long have you made me travel, father,
 Through deserts and through settled lands.
 Long have you made me travel, father,
 In many a sloping valley,
 So I forget my kinsfolk,
 My cousins, and all men.
 How is it our house has vanished
 From our sight, leaving no trace?
 Why has my mother not returned?
 How strange! Has she taken a taste to travel?
 And my dear brother -- may I be his ransom! 
 Time has passed and he does not appear.
 Why in our area do we see
 Nothing but parapets and pits?
 Is it because America has come
 Manipulating funds and media?
 You, father, do not crave
 An easy living from mankind.
 It is eternity that awaits us
 If God should will us to prevail.
 Tell me, father, for I find
 No brief, enlightening explanation."
"Forgive me, son, for I am struck
 Both powerless and speechless.
 My tongue is tied. My eyes are flowing springs.
 My consciousness is hell.
 What can I say when living in a world
 Of contention and of recklessness?
 What can I utter to a world bereft
 Of physical and moral vision,
 Where nations are bought and sold
 In an inflationary and speculative trade?
 Forgive me, son, for nothing do I see 
 In our terrain but a declivity.
 A decade has passed, whose years were spent
 In homelessness and wanderings.
 Of whom do you enquire? Of a people
 Reduced to stupor?
 I have migrated westward
 To a land where flows the Nile.
 Of Khartoum I love the character,
 But I was not permitted to reside.
 So then I traveled eastward
 Where there are men of radiant brows.
Kabul holds its head up high
 Despite the hardship and the danger.
 Kabul, with a smiling face,
 Offers all-comers shelter and help.
 Sheik Yunus there appears 
 A lion who strikes terror when he roars,
 As, marked by manliness and pride,
 Does our commander, Mullah Omar."
"Why, father, have they sent
 These missiles, thick as rain,
 Showing mercy neither to a child
 Nor to a man shattered by old age?
 Father, what has happened
 So we are pursued by perils?
 Father, what has happened
 So your likenesses are on placards?
 Is your redeeming of an ancient house
 A crime that cannot be forgiven?
 Here are we, locked in tragedy:
 All safety gone -- it does not show itself.
 It is a world of criminality, my son,
 Where children are, like cattle, slaughtered.
 Zion is murdering my brothers,
 And the Arabs hold a congress!
 They are America's henchmen,
 Blinded and devoid of vision.
 Nothing but ink on paper. They neither
 Are truthful, nor have they made a difference.
 Why have they not equipped a force
 To shield the little one from harm?
 This, by your Lord, is a major brand
 Of shame to be recorded,
 A treachery being pieced together --
 Is our defense to come from traitors?
 I swear by God the great
 That I shall fight the infidel."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF; 
Judge to Make Decision On Cable Across Sound

BYLINE:  By John Rather 

 BODY:
In a case with implications for power supplies on Long Island this summer, Judge Carl J. Schuman of Superior Court in New Britain, Conn., will decide this week whether to bar installation of a 330-megawatt electric cable across Long Island Sound until at least June. The delay would allow the judge time to hear a challenge to the project brought by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut and the City of New Haven.
 Mr. Blumenthal and the city have filed suit to reverse an approval that the Connecticut Siting Council gave the project. The suit argues that laying the 24-mile cable from New Haven to Shoreham could damage shellfish beds and cause other environmental damage and would deliver power to Long Island without economic benefit to Connecticut. 
 Richard M. Kessel, the chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, said the authority was supporting Trans-Energie, the cable developer, in arguing that the cable not be delayed. He said that the Connecticut officials were being shortsighted. 
"If the court decides that they will not allow the cable until the whole case is heard, that would likely kill the cable for this summer," he said. "And that could lead to shortages in Connecticut and the Northeast as sure as on Long Island."
The Army Corps of Engineers approved the project last month but said the cable had to be in place by June 1 to avoid harm to shellfish and winter flounder. Failure to meet the deadline would delay the project until fall. The authority said that laying of the cable would have to begin by early May to beat the deadline.
Mr. Kessel has said that electricity delivered on the cable and produced by 10 small power units the company is installing would be needed to avoid power shortages in heat waves this summer. John Rather

HEADLINE: Are You Ready for 'Survivor: The Hamptons'? 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
IN a Manhattan editing room, beneath a Warhol portrait of Mick Jagger, Barbara Kopple, the Academy Award-wining documentary filmmaker, soldiered away last week, piecing together her latest expose.
 Posters from her previous films decorated the walls, for "Harlan County, U.S.A.," a saga about Kentucky coal miners for which she won an Oscar in 1977 when she was 21, and "American Dream," a film about striking Minnesota meatpackers, Oscar No. 2. 
 If striking meatpackers are looking for a champion these days, they had better look elsewhere. On the other hand, if your last name is Hilton or Grubman: beware. 
Last week, Ms. Kopple was poring over several hundred hours of video footage of Alec Baldwin, Christie Brinkley, Lizzie Grubman, Kathy Hilton and Russell Simmons -- distilling the melodramatic summer of 2001 in the Hamptons into the stuff of cinema verite. 
Billing the project as the first "reality miniseries," ABC will broadcast "The Hamptons" in two two-hour segments on June 2 and 3. Viewers will see Ms. Grubman, the perennially tanned publicist, speaking of how the season doesn't really start for her until the Fourth of July weekend, in an interview recorded a few weeks before she backed her S.U.V. into a nightclub crowd, injuring 16. 
"The Hamptons" couldn't come at a worse time. It will be shown during a season of doubt and self-scrutiny in New York's wealthiest beach community. For many people who summer or live year-round on Long Island's South Fork, the months Ms. Kopple filmed began as mawkish Grand Guignol, with Ms. Grubman's troubles. The end of the summer brought no relief, only further scandal and sorrow that has continued into 2002. 
And this spring there are reports of a damaged rental market, which could dampen the local economy, and some owners are leaving, too. 
"I will miss the light and the sea and the air," said Richard D. Emery, a lawyer in Manhattan, who has put his Bridgehampton house, steps from the beach, on the market. The crowds and what Mr. Emery characterized as aggressive overbuilding have become too obnoxious. 
"A monstrosity was built next to my house," he said. "There is a three-car garage with a window out the back so when they sit by the pool they can see their cars. Essentially it is an acre and a half of paved-over lot which might as well be the courtyard of an apartment building."
Mr. Emery and his fiancee have bought a house in upstate New York. 
"The good things about the Hamptons are slowly being extinguished and eaten up and destroyed," Steven Gaines, the author of "Philistines at the Hedgerow: Passion and Property in the Hamptons," and a subject in Ms. Kopple's film, said last week. "I think this place is in danger of becoming a carnival."
At least since 1983, when New York magazine ran a cover story proclaiming the Hamptons dead, trend spotters have annually pronounced their verdict on the South Fork's well-being: the Hamptons are over! The Hamptons are back! 
Calling the Hamptons either passe or vibrant has become a cliche. But the tide of public opinion this year seems to be almost uniform: The Hamptons? Whether it's boom or bust, love it or leave it, the events of the last year have left a lingering bad taste in the mouth. 
Many point to the way the Grubman affair divided the community. According to police reports, Ms. Grubman shouted "white trash" at a doorman who would not allow her to park where she wanted outside the Conscience Point nightclub, then backed her Mercedes-Benz S.U.V. into the crowd. She has been charged with assault; her case returns to court April 29.
Old-money residents looked down at her as an example of arriviste bad manners, and the incident galvanized the belief of working-class residents that the rich treat everyone, especially them, with contempt. 
"That was the apotheosis of all the bad things happening out here, the sense of entitlement, the rudeness, hostility, even brewing violence," Mr. Gaines said. "I think people are angry at the Hamptons. People want to see it hurt and made fun of."
At the end of August, Jeff Salaway, an owner of Nick & Toni's restaurant in East Hampton, died in a car accident. The sense of community loss was swiftly overtaken by Sept. 11. In October, the banker Ted Ammon -- in the midst of a bitter divorce -- was found murdered at his East Hampton house. He had been bludgeoned, and the fact that the crime is unsolved has kept alive the community's anxiety. 
But in the world of documentary film, one person's tragedy, hostility or disgrace is another's material. 
The overall Hamptons vision of Ms. Kopple, a filmmaker with an acute social conscience, is not the standard media sound-bite -- playground of the spoiled wealthy. It is more complex, and even tender. 
Last week, as she entered the homestretch of her months of editing, she said she did not set out to take potshots at the well-to-do; that would be too easy.
Sure, there is the couple whose wedding was inspired by Sean Combs's "white party" of 1998, where all the guests were required to wear white, and there is the woman who has decided to spend the summer finding a husband. (Among her requirements: a Porsche, a full head of his own hair, and he has to be Jewish.)
But Ms. Kopple also focused on Marilee Foster, a farmer whose family has lived in the Hamptons for generations; Kenneth Brown, a retired police officer; Ms. Brinkley and her husband, Peter Cook, campaigning for safety at the Millstone Nuclear Power Station -- since renamed Millstone Power Station -- in Waterford, Conn., which they believe is a threat to Long Island. 
Just as Ms. Kopple looked at the lives of waitresses and millionaires, activity in the Hamptons also now tells divergent stories. Many summer renters seem to have decided to stay away this year. Peter Turino, an owner of the property company Dunemere Associates, choosing his words with care, said that prospective tenants are taking their time to sign up. 
"I think what we are experiencing is some sort of delay in the usual rush for rentals," he said. "Looking back on the events of the last year, we're still experiencing a little bit of, I don't know, what some call aftershock."
Suffering from both aftershock and sticker shock, Andrew Friedman, an author of cookbooks and one-time Hamptons renter, said that he and his wife will not return to the area. Instead, they just bought a weekend house in Chatham, N.Y. 
"In my mid-20's, it was where everyone wanted to be," Mr. Friedman, who is in his early 30's, said. "No longer."
He said his main reason for leaving was the high prices. 
"For half of what you pay in the Hamptons, you get something beautiful in Chatham, or Bucks County," he said. He and his wife, Caitlin Connelly, spent one weekend looking at Hamptons houses for sale, and what they saw for enormous prices, he said, "would just make you cry."
Jeff Jones, a carpenter whose family has lived on Flying Point Road in Southampton for 15 generations, said that he was considering leaving if a proposed house is built on swampland across the street. 
Pointing out a few red flags planted into the soft earth, he said: "If this goes up, I go. It's stuff like this, like all of last year, that leaves a real bad taste in my mouth." 
Some real estate agents, Judi Desiderio of Cook Pony Farm among them, say that sales are brisk. "One set of buyers has an investment mentality, and they are taking money out of the stock market and putting it in a house," she said. "The other set are people who want to own a home or retire here. Both are out in full force."
And local businessmen are optimistic. Phil Biscoglio, the manager of La Carezza, a beauty salon in Southampton, said that while the events of the last year left some traumatic memories, they did not necessarily leave commercial scars. The salon's clients, he said, are already booking their summer appointments.
"We are busy, we are starting to get e-mails and phone calls from people who will be out for the summer and are booking appointments through September," he said. "No one is saying, 'Take me out of the book because the Hamptons are dead.' "
Mr. Biscoglio said that the only person who would be affected was Ms. Grubman. "She probably won't be spending the summer out here," he said.
While Ms. Kopple's "Hamptons" is sure to reopen some wounds, it will also, the filmmaker said, show the side of the community that makes people want to return. "Every town has its tragedies, and deaths, and sorrows, no matter how wealthy," she said. "Wealth doesn't protect people from that."
"But people will see how beautiful it is," she added, with a regard for her own personal power that would make Hamptonites proud. "After this series runs, I bet there will be a surge of popularity."

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
The Few, the Proud, the Consistent Winners

BYLINE:  By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
IN stock mutual funds, as in many things, it's not very crowded at the very top.
 The last decade has been kind to many funds; they enjoyed some great years and high returns over all. Even so, only a relative handful have managed strong performance without losing money in even one year. 
 Of the 4,058 equity portfolios tracked by Morningstar Inc., just 54, or a little more than 1 percent, avoided losing money in any year from 1992 through 2001. Of those 54 funds, 31 also succeeded in beating the 13.3 percent average annual return of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over those 10 years. 
"You need a rather unique fund to pass these tests," said Gerald Perritt, editor of Gerald Perritt's Mutual Fund Letter in Largo, Fla. "This is a pretty elite group."
Members of it do share some characteristics, most notably the long tenure of their managers. At 14 of the top 31, the managers have run the fund for at least a decade. By contrast, the average tenure of equity fund managers is less than five years, according to Morningstar. Eleven of those 14 funds are open to individual investors.
Their managers use a variety of approaches, but most emphasize value in their stock-picking and say they have been chastened by years of market turmoil.
Experience "produces caution," said George A. Mairs III, who has run Mairs & Power Growth, one of the 11 funds, for 22 years. "You no longer have that youthful enthusiasm, and you've seen a lot of volatile markets over the years," Mr. Mairs added. His $823.4 million fund has returned 18.4 percent a year, on average, over the last 10 years.
In fact, these funds generally take a mild-mannered, risk-conscious approach. 
"We're trying to assess the value of a company relative to its stock price," said Joel C. Tillinghast, who has run Fidelity Low-Priced Stock, another fund on the list, for 12 years. "When the news is unfavorable, the stock should not go down as much, because the value is still there," Mr. Tillinghast said. The fund has earned 17.4 percent a year over the last decade.
A similar price-conscious approach characterizes Dodge & Cox Stock, which has a 10-year average annual return of 17 percent.
"We always ask ourselves, 'If things don't go well, how much downside does the stock have?' " said John A. Gunn, the president and chief investment officer of Dodge & Cox Investment Management.
"To me, it's a matter of avoiding mistakes," Mr. Gunn added. "The money manager who wins over time is the one who makes the fewest mistakes."
The average tenure of the eight managers who run the Dodge & Cox Stock fund is 23 years.
Attention to value extends to the few growth-oriented managers on the list. Mr. Mairs likes to buy attractive growth companies, but he waits until he considers the stock reasonably priced. Last year, he jumped on beaten-down drug stocks like Merck, which has typically sold for 28 times earnings in the last five years, but was selling for one-third of that multiple at the end of the first quarter.
The managers of the Federated Kaufmann fund, Lawrence Auriana and Hans Utsch, said a decision they made in 2000 -- to cut the fund's stake in technology stocks to 12 percent from 40 percent -- helped it avoid the major losses experienced by its growth-stock peers over the last two years. The managers said they believed that prices had gotten out of hand.
"When you get to 60 times earnings, that's pretty hard to justify even if the company is growing fast," Mr. Auriana said. Federated Kaufmann has returned 15.1 percent a year, on average, over the last 10 years. The two managers have run the fund for 16 years.
Many of these funds' managers look for companies that can generate steady earnings growth. That often means companies that have strong franchises or are market leaders -- characteristics that also help control risk. Mr. Tillinghast at Fidelity, for example, focuses on companies that have a high proportion of recurring revenue. In the technology sector, that leads him to outsourcing providers like Affiliated Computer Services, which offers back-office systems integration and transaction processing. The company's operating income has never declined in any quarter in the last seven years, Mr. Tillinghast said.
These winning funds are also distinguished by their relatively low levels of trading. The average money manager turns over his or her entire portfolio once a year, but these managers generally keep their stocks for two years or more. Until 2000, when turnover inched up to 15 percent of assets because of company takeovers, the average stock in Mairs & Power Growth had been in the fund for more than 10 years. Dodge & Cox Stock has tended to hold its investments for five years or more.
"There are some very long-term-focused managers here," said Russel Kinnel, director of fund analysis at Morningstar. That approach tends to focus these managers on business fundamentals.
THE managers of Dodge & Cox Stock, for example, say they always ask themselves whether they would be buying a stock if they could not trade it for four years. "The result is you end up looking to the company to provide the returns, not other investors," Mr. Gunn said.
Mr. Perritt, the newsletter editor, said: "I love funds with low turnover ratios. If someone takes the time to buy a stock, low turnover indicates they have confidence in the stock over the long term."
These funds are penny pinchers, tending to have low expenses. The average domestic stock fund has an expense ratio of 1.4 percent of assets, but the figure is just 0.54 percent at Dodge & Cox Stock and 0.8 percent at Mairs & Powers Growth. An exception is Federated Kaufmann, at 1.9 percent. "We've been able to justify that expense with above-average returns, and more importantly, with consistent returns," Mr. Auriana said. But these funds have not always excelled. Because of their low-octane approach, several, including Mairs & Power Growth, Fidelity Low-Priced Stock, Dodge & Cox Stock, and American Funds Washington Mutual Class A shares, posted only single-digit returns in 1998 or 1999 when the S.& P. 500 was up 28.6 percent and 21 percent, respectively.
Funds outside this group, of course, may be better overall performers. The Legg Mason Value Trust fund, for example, lost 7.1 percent percent in 2000 and an additional 9.3 percent in 2001, yet still ranks among the top 1 percent of large-cap value funds and has beaten the S.& P. 500 every year over the last 10 years, for an average annual return of 17.7 percent through March.
Nor are the funds that have not lost money in the last 10 years without risk. Many of them lost money in 1990, when the economy fell into recession and value-oriented stocks were hit hard.
In addition, management of some of these funds is likely to change in coming years. Mr. Mairs, for example, is scheduled to step down from his fund in June 2003. 
Some managers question whether it even makes sense to pick funds on the basis of their having not lost money in the last 10 years.
"A calendar-year scorecard is very arbitrary," said Charles M. Royce, manager of Royce Premier, which has returned 14.1 percent a year and has not lost money in a single year in the last 10 years. "We didn't set out to do that," he added. "It's a byproduct of sticking to our risk-management discipline."
Certainly, there are no guarantees that this elite group will not suffer losing years. "There will be periods when our style is out of favor, and sometimes we make mistakes," Mr. Auriana said.
Nevertheless, these funds deserve investors' attention, many analysts say. Dodge & Cox Stock, Dodge & Cox Balanced, Mairs & Power Growth and T. Rowe Price Equity Income are on Mr. Perritt's recommended list. 
Mr. Kinnel said, "If I were looking for dependable, high-quality, low-risk funds, Fidelity Low-Priced Stock, Dodge & Cox Stock, Washington Mutual and T. Rowe Price Equity Income would be at the top of my list."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MUSEUM MILE; 
The Mayor's Courthouse Plan Strands Yet Another Museum

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
Like a deceptive chess move, perhaps it was too good to be true. The Museum of the City of New York would move into the newly renovated Tweed Courthouse, and El Museo del Barrio, the cramped museum for Latino arts at 104th Street and Fifth Avenue, would move one block south into its stately and vacant space.
 The maneuver would have allowed El Museo, housed in a retrofitted orphanage, to oversee two sites, maintain close ties to its East Harlem roots and expand its gallery space sixfold. Its top donors wholeheartedly agreed, and pledged to underwrite the move, conservatively estimated at $8 million. 
 "El Museo is the ideal successor," officials from the museum wrote to the city earlier this year. "The plan would double El Museo's program space and transform it into the nation's leading museum for the display of Latin American and Latino art."
When the plan famously unraveled last month after Mayor Bloomberg reneged on his predecessor's promise and said he wanted the Tweed Courthouse to go to the Board of Education, sympathy cards landed at the Museum of the City of New York. But in some ways, out of the spotlight, El Museo has been hit just as hard.
"Everybody here was surprised," said Susana Torruella Leval, El Museo's director. "It seemed like a done deal, and we had a major commitment to do this."
El Museo was founded in 1969 by a group of Puerto Rican artists and activists from East Harlem, and was initially housed in a local classroom. In 1977, the museum moved into the city-owned Heckscher Foundation building, which it shares with a half-dozen other tenants, including the Parks Department. The gallery is on the ground floor, and its offices are scattered about the third.
A year ago, the city's Economic Development Corporation began reviewing proposals for the city museum's current building, a neo-Georgian landmark. Submissions arrived from other institutions, including the Museum of African Art in SoHo, but El Museo was widely considered the front-runner. 
"Should we vacate the building, it was our hope that El Museo would move in," said Patti Ogden, a spokeswoman for the Museum of the City of New York. The museum has "no immediate plans to move," she added, but she acknowledged that museum trustees were "in preliminary exploration of other spaces in Lower Manhattan."
Such talk has kept El Museo's hopes alive, even while it, too, is looking at other spaces. Among them is 2 Columbus Circle, the former Gallery of Modern Art, a space Donald J. Trump also has his eye on. 
"In a strange way, the fact that it didn't happen just made us react more strongly" that the museum needs to grow, said Tony Bechara, an artist who is chairman of El Museo. "We're trying to represent the art, culture and history of almost one-third of the city's population. We aspire to, no more or no less than, what the Asia Society or the Jewish Museum has." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
Did Pay Incentives Cut Both Ways?

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
FOR corporate directors and chief executives, 2001 presented a test: were they really willing, in a down year, to link executive pay to corporate performance?
 Just as the nation's top executives received fat raises during the 1990's boom, those who had tied pay to their companies' results were almost certainly going to receive leaner paychecks last year, when profits suffered their worst annual decline in decades. But in the clubby culture of the boardroom, many executives also knew that they could convince their directors to overlook the bottom line and keep the raises coming -- if the directors had not already taken it upon themselves to look the other way. 
 The results were a split decision: Companies divided into two roughly equal-sized groups. The first half, which appears to believe in paying for performance, cut the pay of the top executive for the first time in years. The other half, which seems to believe simply in paying a lot, reacted to a year of recession and war often by creating the impression they had reduced pay without actually doing so. 
At Boeing, Eli Lilly and nearly every large brokerage firm, executives and shareholders suffered the financial consequences of a disappointing year together. By contrast, Kenneth I. Chenault at American Express, Douglas N. Daft at Coca-Cola, John T. Chambers at Cisco Systems and top executives at many other companies received big raises or bonuses even though they had missed the goals they had set for themselves at the start of the year. 
Mr. Chambers, with a pay package of $154 million for the fiscal year ended June 30, finished at the top of a pay survey of 200 large companies conducted for Money & Business by Pearl Meyer & Partners, a consulting firm in New York. For the calendar year, Richard D. Fairbank of the Capital One Financial Corporation, made the most -- $99.7 million.
Over all, the average compensation for chief executives declined 8 percent, to $15.5 million, as the tough economic conditions wiped out many of the truly enormous paychecks, the survey showed. It was the first decline in nine years, Pearl Meyer said.
But as the largest awards became smaller, pay for the typical chief executive continued to climb. The median compensation rose 7 percent -- about twice the raise that the average American worker received -- to $9.1 million, at the 200 companies. Profits fell 35 percent at the typical company. 
"This was a year of separation," said Patrick S. McGurn, the director of corporate programs at Institutional Shareholder Services, which advises large investors. "We separated the pay-for-performance folks from the pay-for-failure folks."
The median base salary jumped 4 percent in 2001. Many boards also made up for declining bonuses, which are often directly linked to results, by awarding more valuable packages of stock options and more shares of stock. In some cases, directors called the awards "retention grants," meant to keep executives in place for the next few years.
Pay experts said external events played a role in determining last year's compensation packages, as executives had reason to avoid appearing greedy. "Political pressure had a huge impact on bonus decisions and salary decisions," said Jannice L. Koors, a vice president at Pearl Meyer.
As a recession weakened the American economy, chief executives oversaw the elimination of many of the one million jobs lost last year. In the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, the recession worsened and executives joined policy makers in saying Americans would have to make sacrifices during tough times.
The managers of mutual funds and pension funds, meanwhile, along with other large institutional investors, stepped up their criticism of stock option grants last year, saying they were badly diluting the stakes of existing shareholders. By the final month of 2001, executive pay occupied arguably its largest place in the public debate in almost a decade, after people learned that many Enron executives had made millions of dollars as their company was collapsing and that rank-and-file employees had lost their life savings.
"Boards are asking, 'Would this embarrass us?' " said Ira T. Kay, the director of the compensation practice at Watson Wyatt, the consulting firm. "They are incredibly sensitive."
MANY companies reacted in the most straightforward way possible: they cut executive pay. Some reduced the amount of stock and options they gave to executives, and others simply stuck to the formulas they had created to calculate performance-based pay. 
"These plans are doing what they were designed to do -- paying for performance," said Peter T. Chingos, the top pay consultant at William M. Mercer.
Although their compensation remains huge by any standard, executives of such companies took a significant reduction in pay. David H. Komansky, the head of Merrill Lynch, received $18 million, down 53 percent from 2000. F. Duane Ackerman of BellSouth made $14.2 million, down 19 percent. James D. Sinegal of Costco Wholesale made $3.3 million, one-third less than in 2000.
In all, one out of every five chief executives received no bonus in 2001, according to Pearl Meyer. The typical bonus fell 23 percent.
"It's very important that executive pay be aligned with shareholder interests," said Sidney Taurel, the chief executive of Eli Lilly, the pharmaceutical company that makes Prozac and other drugs. "This is the best way to create shareholder value." 
Mr. Taurel's compensation fell 49 percent in 2001, to $11.2 million, and for this year he has agreed to take a base salary of $1 and expects neither a bonus nor a stock grant, only stock options, he said. "Since I'm asking sacrifices of everyone," he said. "I thought I should provide an example."
Perhaps others will follow suit. But pay experts said 2001 offered further evidence that the system for determining executive pay is often a rigged game. 
Boards typically hire compensation consultants to help set pay, but chief executives usually work closely with the consultants to devise the proposal made to the board. By and large, directors approve the deal, perhaps because the chief executive knows far more about the company than they do or because they themselves are chief executives whose compensation is partially determined by average pay across the top ranks of corporate America. Nearly every company wants to offer its executives "above average" compensation, often in the top quartile of its peers, and that automatically ratchets up the entire scale year after year.
MR. CHAMBERS, at Cisco Systems, typified the ways that boards raised pay even as they appeared to be reducing it. He received $268,000 in cash, down from $1.3 million the previous year, as Cisco lost $1 billion and its stock fell 71 percent in the fiscal year ended last June 30. But Cisco's board gave him six million stock options, up from four million in 2000, allowing the estimated value of his pay to climb 32 percent.
Cisco's compensation committee, led by Carol A. Bartz, a technology executive, gave Mr. Chambers the options to keep him focused on the company's earnings, a Cisco spokeswoman said.
Raymond V. Gilmartin of Merck and Richard M. Kovacevich of Wells Fargo also presided over disappointing years but took home hefty raises.
Even some companies that did reduce executive pay still gave more than their initial announcements suggested. When John W. Creighton Jr. took the helm of United Airlines last October, he said he would work without salary for 2001, because the airline's parent, the UAL Corporation, was running up record losses, laying off thousands of employees and beginning to ask others to accept pay cuts. 
But Mr. Creighton received 400,000 options with an exercise price of $14.48, the share price on Oct. 28. He can exercise the options anytime in the next 10 years, and even if the stock recovers only to its Sept. 10 value of $30.82, they will be worth more than $6 million.
At many companies, chief executives did swallow pay cuts, but other top executives, whose pay attracts far less scrutiny, received raises, according to Executive Compensation Advisory Services, a firm in Alexandria, Va., that analyzes company filings. 
The Walt Disney Company, for example, failed to reach the goals that Michael D. Eisner, the chief executive, had set. So he received no bonus and $1 million in total compensation, $16 million less than he had received the previous year.
 But the board's pay committee, led by Thomas S. Murphy, a former Disney executive, ignored its performance standards for three other top executives -- Louis M. Meisinger, Peter E. Murphy and Thomas O. Staggs -- and paid them bonuses of $300,000 to $1 million. Because the pay was not tied to performance, Disney lost tax deductions on some of it.
"Sometimes, you have the C.E.O. falling on his sword while protecting the next level of leadership, who could be easily recruited away," said Steven E. Hall, a managing director at Pearl Meyer.
BOARDS that changed their pay standards in midstream often defended the switch by saying they thought the executives had done a good job, and deserved a raise, despite the company's financial results.
"While the company's 2001 financial performance fell short of its long-term objectives," the compensation committee of the American Express board wrote in its proxy statement, "the committee used its judgment about each individual's annual goal and leadership performance to make discretionary awards" as warranted. 
For Mr. Chenault, the chief executive, the board's judgment translated into $5.9 million in cash, $8.3 million of stock and an estimated $17 million worth of options.
That kind of policy change upset both small and large shareholders, as well as executives who did take a pay cut. During the long economic boom and bull market of the 1990's, compensation for the typical chief executive soared, and the executives often said the raises were rewards for their roles in creating the boom. 
Now, critics say the relationship between pay and performance should also hold in difficult times. 
"Our shareholders bore the impact of all that happened last year," said Jon A. Boscia, the chief executive of the Lincoln Financial Group, an investment company based in Philadelphia, and a director at Hershey Foods. "They have a right to expect that we, the hired help of the company, are always looking out for their best interests and not our own personal interests."
"We spent time making sure people understood they didn't do a bad job, that it was out of their control," said Mr. Boscia, whose pay fell by more than one-third last year, to roughly $9 million. "But we would be doing less than our fiduciary duty to shareholders if we pretended it didn't happen."
Still, the recent controversy over executive pay at Enron and a handful of other struggling companies could be a turning point, making pay panels more active, consultants say. 
In the past, said Gary M. Locke, a co-leader of the compensation practice at Towers Perrin, the management consulting firm, compensation committees tended simply to supervise the pay process, remaining in what he called a "nose in, fingers out" mode. But, he added, "they're definitely putting their fingers in now."
Mr. Kay of Watson Wyatt said he recently attended a board meeting of a company whose stock had dropped significantly. The directors decided not to allow employees to exchange seemingly worthless stock options for actual shares of stock because the board thought the swap would make the company look as if it did not believe in paying for performance.
Other consultants said the compensation committees of a few companies had recently hired advisers to work only with the committee, not with the chief executive. And at least one perk -- the sweetheart loans that many boards gave their top executives -- may be a thing of the past, because it was a revolving loan that allowed Kenneth L. Lay, the former head of Enron, to sell almost two million shares of company stock quietly.
"Loans are dead," said Frederic W. Cook, who runs a pay consulting firm that bears his name. "You're not going to see them again." 
OF course, executive pay received similar criticism in the early 90's, when the economy was stagnating. At the urging of a newly elected Bill Clinton, Congress passed a law limiting the tax deductions for pay above $1 million and not based on a company's performance.
It did little to restrain executive pay, however, and as the economy improved, compensation for chief executives took off. Even as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell during the last two years, the raises continued. While the fallout from Enron's collapse could reverse the trend, last year could also end up as a low point for executive raises, because the economy turned around so quickly.
Ms. Koors of Pearl Meyer noted that most companies award stock-option grants in the middle of the year, shortly after they determine the previous year's bonus. In coming months, executives still smarting from a reduced bonus may ask their boards to be generous.
"We may see option grants this year to make up for last year's bonuses," she said.
That, and an improving economy, could return executive pay to its previous, steep trajectory.
"Things will be back to normal next year," predicted Judith Fischer, managing director of Executive Compensation Advisory Services.

HEADLINE: U.S. Envoy Campaigns For Trade Pacts On Asian Trip 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: BINTAN, Indonesia, April 6 

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Robert B. Zoellick, toured high-tech plants on two tiny Indonesian islands just south of Singapore today to show that the countries of Southeast Asia could stand up to the looming economic force of China through trade cooperation. 
 Mr. Zoellick peered into microscopes used for checking for imperfections in plastic contact lens and chatted with Indonesian workers on an assembly line of memory chips designed for digital cameras. 
 The point of the exotic locale -- the islands of Batam and Bintan on the northern edge of the Indonesian archipelago -- demonstrated, he said, that if countries like Indonesia and Singapore worked together on trade arrangements, both would benefit from foreign investment. The contact lens plant that Mr. Zoellick toured is owned by an American company, Ciba Vision, that is headquartered in Atlanta. 
The visit today was part of an Asian trip by Mr. Zoellick intended to give confidence to Southeast Asian countries that were battered by the region's financial crisis five years ago and that now fear China's strengthening economic shadow. 
In less than a decade, according to Singapore government figures, China has managed to attract much of the foreign direct investment that poured into the 10 countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, known as Asean, during their years of expansion in the 1980's and 1990's. In the early 1990's, China received about 30 percent of the foreign investment in the region and the then-booming economies of Southeast Asia received about 60 percent.
Now, China is receiving about 60 percent of the foreign investment, Singapore says, and the investment has accelerated most markedly in the last several years as China's membership in the World Trade Organization became more certain. 
To help offset what the United States views as an unhealthy imbalance between China and the smaller countries to the south, Mr. Zoellick urged these countries to reduce trade barriers among themselves to attract more outside investment. 
Mr. Zoellick attended a meeting of Southeast Asian trade ministers in Bangkok on Friday, where the idea of an overall Asean free trade agreement with the United States was discussed. Because the countries of the region are in such varied economic stages, such a pact is a long way off, Mr. Zoellick said. 
A free trade agreement between the United States and Singapore, in the final stages of preparation, probably will be signed by the end of this year, he said. It will include a feature intended to benefit businesses in Indonesia, where the economy is limping after the 1997 Asian meltdown and from security concerns after Sept. 11 in this, the world's most populous Muslim nation. 
Within the free trade agreement, the United States and Singapore have decided that more than 100 information technology items manufactured in the industrial parks would be granted the same free trade agreement status as if they came from Singapore. 
The plants on the tiny Indonesian islands that Mr. Zoellick visited today are located in secure, clean industrial parks only an hour by ferry from Singapore. For American and other foreign companies, these islands provide the benefit of lower wages than Singapore but easy access to Singapore's air and shipping hub, Mr. Zoellick said. 
The Indonesian minister for trade and industry, Rini Soewandi, said her government would try to reproduce nationwide the conditions that made the two industrial parks attractive to outside investors. Indonesia provides speedy custom clearance, tax incentives and other advantages for businesses on the island, she said. 
For the Indonesian workers, most of them women aged 18 to 21, the jobs on the islands are highly prized. A starting salary at one of the plants is $60 a month, about twice the amount the women said they would earn in their home provinces.

HEADLINE: For Dogged German Challenger, It's Still About the Economy 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, April 6 

 BODY:
Starchy and dry, Edmund Stoiber, the conservative challenger to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, becomes really animated about two things: economic data, which he reels off like a relentless professor, and the humiliating pit into which he believes Germany has fallen during the Schroder years.
 Asked why he wants to become chancellor in the Sept. 22 elections, Mr. Stoiber, 60, finally lets loose: "We rank last in Europe in terms of economic growth. We have the biggest growth of unemployment in Western Europe. The stable Germany of the past gets a blue letter," a warning from the European Union about its increasing budget deficit. Moreover, he said, the president of Italy, Carlo Ciampi, "said he was worried about the stability of the euro because of Germany." 
 Mr. Stoiber says this with apparent shock, shaking his head, his eyes widening underneath his rimless glasses. 
"We are criticized by the Greeks and Spaniards and Italians," Mr. Stoiber repeats. "They all blame us. This is something new. Ten years ago, this would be impossible. And politicians are responsible for this."
A soccer team in last place normally changes its coach, he said, adding, "People are not masochists in our country."
Mr. Stoiber, known variously as a dour bureaucrat and the steely "Bavarian pit bull," is trying to ride Germany's economic malaise and fears of foreigners and crime to victory over the personable, television-friendly Mr. Schroder. Mr. Stoiber's own first campaign venture into television chat in January was a disaster, showing him anxious and even tongue-tied, feeding columnists and comics material for weeks.
"It damaged him in the beginning, but people will forget," said his biographer, Peter Kopf. "He's Mr. Control, but his advisers kept pushing him to be careful and appeal to the middle, to be a different person."
Mr. Stoiber's advisers hope to prepare him better before television debates with Mr. Schroder that will be a climax to the long campaign.
But Mr. Stoiber is in good form in a small group. In an interview with American journalists before a planned trip to Washington, he tried to show his familiarity with foreign policy, urged an even closer relationship with the United States and worked to undercut any idea that he is a provincial xenophobe, while defending restrictions on immigration.
He urges the European Union to find "a more uniform policy" and promises that Germany would try "to create a closer coherence in the trans-Atlantic alliance," with friendly criticism about American policies delivered privately, "in a spirit of close solidarity with the Americans."
He urged the European Union to find "a more uniform policy," though how a Stoiber-led government could produce such harmonization from countries as different as France and Greece he did not say. He did promise to try to improve Franco-German relations, "the very premise of European development," and without which "European integration is not possible."
In general, he said, the European Union should develop "new competencies in foreign and defense policy" and meddle less in other areas, like agriculture.
But Mr. Stoiber, like the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, says that Germans are not convinced that a war to overthrow Iraq's leader, Saddam Hussein, is necessary or sensible. "Germans don't feel threatened by Saddam Hussein" in the way the Bush administration does, Mr. Stoiber said. "The Americans should make it clear" what threats Iraq poses to Europe and the world in order to build "acceptance in principle" for any military action there.
Asked if he himself feels a significant threat from Iraq, Mr. Stoiber evaded the question, saying that "as an opposition politician" he was not privy to enough information to judge. He did promise to reverse the decline in Germany's military spending, now less than 1.5 percent of the gross national product, and "stop using the army as a kind of piggy bank for budget savings."
He bristles at the idea that he is the cold manager trying to oust the back-slapping Mr. Schroder. Stern magazine wrote that he had no warmth, but Mr. Stoiber said, "Did you expect Stern to write anything different?" He noted that since he had become the candidate of the Christian Democratic Union and his own Christian Social Union, the parties had opened up a consistent lead in the polls over Mr. Schroder's Social Democrats.
Anyway, Mr. Stoiber said, returning to the theme of competence that suits him best, he has run Bavaria since 1993 much better than Mr. Schroder ever ran Lower Saxony. "I have governed a much more successful state," he said, noting that Bavaria has one of the highest per capita incomes in Germany and one of the lowest unemployment rates. "And he governs Germany like he governed Lower Saxony, where everything has deteriorated. There is less growth than other countries, unemployment is on the rise, the social security system is dysfunctional."
Mr. Stoiber also spun figures in answer to questions about how much he would move to liberalize Germany's labor market, which he himself said was overregulated. He says there is a great area to move between Germany's current labor rigidity and the kind of "American hire-and-fire" policies he thinks Germany will never support.
He wants less regulation and taxes on small businesses and more incentives for self-employed people, and to duplicate Bavaria's privatization of state industry, with its profits turned toward investment in high-tech industry, not simply to expand the government budget.
He wants to get the government's share of the economy to less than 40 percent from its current 48 percent, reduce the top income-tax rate to less than 40 percent from last year's 48.5 percent, and reduce corporate payments for workers for nonwage items like pensions and health insurance to less than 40 percent. "So we say, 'Three times 40.' It's my motto," he said. "The mission of government is not to own but to shape."
Mr. Stoiber, born in a little Bavarian Alpine village called Oberaudorf to a fervently Roman Catholic mother, was educated by nuns, Mr. Kopf said. In contrast to Mr. Schroder, who has been married four times, Mr. Stoiber was married at 27 and lives a traditional family life, with a wife who stays in the background and three children.
He served in the military with a mountain division, went to law school in Munich and entered the bureaucracy immediately, getting his first job in 1971 in Bavaria's ministry for development and the environment.
He rose very quickly, becoming a personal adviser to the Bavarian boss, Franz Jozef Strauss, the next year and soon ran the ministry office. He was elected to the Bavarian Parliament in 1974, became general secretary of his party in 1978, and chief of staff to the prime minister in 1982. He also managed Mr. Strauss's catastrophic campaign for the chancellery -- the last leader of his party to try -- in 1980.
By 1988, Mr. Stoiber was the state's interior minister, becoming prime minister in 1993. He won re-election in 1998 with 52.9 percent of the vote and significant support among workers, solidifying his reputation. 
In January, the conservatives turned to him over the Christian Democrat leader, Angela Merkel, as their best chance of beating Mr. Schroder.
But to Mr. Kopf, Mr. Stoiber remains the didactic, conservative, efficient, bland, stiff and mistrustful manager who instills both respect and "a climate of anxiety" in those who work for him. He has always regarded immigration with anxiety and has appealed to concern about crime, and he has been an important, even cozy, partner for businessmen.
"He's going to have to learn to play on a different level," Mr. Kopf said. "But I think he has a good chance to win."
