HEADLINE: Some See Hope in New Jersey's Fiscal Plight, for Changing Taxation 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 5 

 BODY:
New Jersey's fiscal desperation gives some people a perverse hope: that the repercussions will be bad enough to generate interest in ripping up the state's tax system and starting over. 
 The budget that Gov. James E. McGreevey just stitched together promises to shift some expenses to local governments. And the source of almost all their revenue, the property tax, is already hated and already high. 
 New Jersey's per-capita property-tax bills are the highest in the nation, and about twice the national average. Moreover, property taxes account for an unusually high share of total state and local revenue: more than 45 percent, compared with a national average of about 32 percent. 
Virtually no one says this is a good idea. Gov. Jim Florio, in his last State of the State address eight years ago, said that "over-reliance on property taxes is the single most important problem our state faces." 
But when he spoke, Mr. Florio had just lost re-election, having taken the alternative route of raising income and sales taxes. No one has dared to do that since.
At the same time, New Jerseyans have clung to their inefficient and overlapping local governments, whatever the cost. 
But now, many legislators and fiscal experts say, the state might be forced to rewrite its tax system. "We need a crisis to get us mobilized," said Henry A. Coleman, an economist at Rutgers who was director of an exhaustive study on the state's tax system in the 1980's. 
One idea for breaking the deadlock, a constitutional convention on property tax reform, is growing along with resentment over widespread local tax increases. These increases are all but certain since Mr. McGreevey rejected increases in income and sales taxes and asked for a freeze on aid to local governments.
The state legislators who gathered in Trenton last month to endorse the constitutional convention proposal called the property tax grossly inequitable, antiquated, harshly regressive and punitive, among other things. 
That has also been the consensus of several decades' worth of blue-ribbon commissions, including Mr. Coleman's, along with a spectrum of research and advocacy groups.
Liberals hate the property tax because it is regressive; planners hate it because it encourages sprawl and residential segregation; urbanites hate it because it starves the cities; and good-government groups hate it for all those reasons.
Most of all, the critics say, New Jersey has to find a better way of financing its schools. The state pays about 42 percent of total school costs, while the national average is about 50 percent. Meanwhile, New Jersey's per-pupil costs, more than $10,000 a year, are the highest in the nation. 
The State Supreme Court, in the course of nearly 30 years of litigation over school finance, has said the state could not meet its constitutional obligation to children in poorer districts because it relies so heavily on "a local property base overtaxed to exhaustion."
While state aid to poor districts has increased substantially since that decision in 1990, residents of those districts still have disproportionately high property taxes.
A recent analysis by New Jersey Future, a statewide planning organization, shows a steady inverse relationship between a municipality's wealth and its tax rates: even accounting for widely varying assessment levels, the study found that the 32 municipalities with the highest per-capita incomes had an average property tax rate of less than 1.5 percent, while the 24 poorest had an average rate of 3.5 percent or more.
"It really, starkly illustrates the problem," said Tim Evans, the group's research director. "Anyone who can afford to leave does, leaving the poorest to pay the rest. It chases out businesses that used to pay. It's a self-reinforcing downward spiral."
The better-off suburbs, meanwhile, receive less state money for schools and their officials say the complex formula used to calculate aid does not compensate for the sharp enrollment increases that some suburbs are experiencing. And each new house that contains children is a net loss to the tax rolls.
"People are frightened to death of having children move into their community," said Ed O'Brien, the mayor of Metuchen, a middle-class town of 12,840 that pays more than 90 percent of its own education costs.
When a new condominium development was proposed recently, "it was an enormous fight," Mr. O'Brien said. "I had to convince people that people coming here are not going to have kids. That's not healthy."
In addition to the schools, which take about 70 percent of property tax revenue, New Jersey municipalities support expensive local governments, many of which refuse to share services. The state's 566 municipalities have nearly that many municipal buildings, hundreds of collections of snowplows and quite a few $90,000-a-year police chiefs. 
New Jersey is hardly the only state with these problems, but others distribute the pain more evenly and more progressively by relying less on property taxes. The typical mix of revenue is about 30 percent each from income, sales and property taxes, and 10 percent from other sources, Mr. Coleman said.
Most other states with high average property-tax payments have no sales tax or income tax. New Hampshire, which ranks second to New Jersey, has neither. New Jersey's per capita payment in 1998, the last year for which figures are available, was $1,744, and New Hampshire's was $1,545. 
New York and Connecticut also had high property taxes ($1,345 and $1,533 per capita, respectively), but both rely more on income taxes than New Jersey does.
Michigan, which used to rank near New Jersey, scrapped local school property taxes altogether by raising other taxes, devising a much lower statewide property tax and redistributing the proceeds. Since Michigan's restructuring in 1993, many other states have tried variations on the model. 
It is only because New Jersey's Legislature shows no sign of changing the tax structure that some influential legislators, acknowledging that they need the political cover, are calling for a constitutional convention, a proposal that promises nothing but deliberation and needs voter approval before it can even begin. 
Still, the idea is "the only thing that provides a sense of moving forward," said Judith Cambria, a fiscal analyst for the state's League of Women Voters. Ms. Cambria supported the proposal for a convention when it was introduced in the Legislature last year, but it died without much notice.
Ms. Cambria left the country over the winter, and when she returned recently, she said, "What really shocked me is I go away for two months, and I came back and all of a sudden this was really being talked about." 
The bill was probably doomed last year because the Republicans still controlled the Legislature, said Senator John H. Adler, a Democrat and a primary sponsor. "It's hard for the party in power to say that the system they've been running for the last decade is broken."
Still, the proposal is supported by some influential Republicans, including Senators Robert J. Martin and John J. Matheussen, both sponsors.
Then, too, hardly anyone was talking about a fiscal crisis last year.
"It's here now," Ms. Cambria said. "It's not going to get better. The things they did during the 90's were designed to push things off to the future, and the bills are here." 
Mayor O'Brien in Metuchen said voters were willing to talk. "I think people are more reasonable than politicians give them credit for," he said. "The income tax -- I don't think that's the death knell in this state, but people in Trenton are frightened.
"But these talking heads on cable screaming about taxes crowd out intelligent discourse. Year after year, because of an archaic formula that even people who are in the education community can't explain, you have a Gresham's law, the bad driving out the good."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
N.Y. Goliaths Too Rich For Tampa Bay Davids

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass

 BODY:
If Commissioner Bud Selig wants to sell his labor platform to anyone -- fans, recalcitrant owners or, most important, players -- he might want to instruct Major League Baseball Productions to make a videotape of the weekend series the Tampa Bay Devil Rays played at Yankee Stadium, then show it again and again and again. It could be Selig's Exhibit A.
 Here were the $34 million Devil Rays trying to scale the imposing mountain of the $131 million Yankees, and the matchup more closely resembled a dads-kids game, although fathers presumably would give their children more of a chance than the Devil Rays had against the Yankees. Hal McRae, the Devil Rays' manager, repeatedly used the word overmatched. 
 "We were just dominated by the Yankees," he said yesterday. "If they keep doing this, they're going to beat a lot of people. That's what they set out to do. They didn't spend $130 million to lose."
Major League Baseball has never before had the payroll of one team exceed the payroll of another by nearly $100 million. By the end of the season, the difference will probably be more than $100 million. Yet the overmatched Devil Rays have to play the Yankees 16 more times.
The Devil Rays have to play the games, despite their economic and physical deficiencies, because the Yankees need someone to play when they go out on the field each afternoon or night. An intrasquad game might create closer competition, but fans won't very likely spend $42 to see Roger Clemens pitch against Andy Pettitte.
This idea of having someone to play is a point Selig and the owners of the poorer teams haven't argued strongly enough in their efforts to get the players to allow the commissioner to take more of George Steinbrenner's money through revenue sharing and a luxury tax. They have taken surveys that purport to show fans' increasing dissatisfaction with competitive imbalance but have not spent enough time pointing out that as distasteful as it might be to Steinbrenner and the players who want him to save his money for them, the Yankees need an opponent 162 days a year. Do the Devil Rays qualify as an opponent? They showed up this weekend but didn't provide much opposition. In three games they scored a total of two runs.
Clemens was the Yankees' starter yesterday, and the dubious honor of matching pitches with him went to Tanyon Sturtze. Here was a 31-year-old journeyman pitcher opposing a six-time winner of the Cy Young award, a pitcher with a $295,000 salary against one who will earn $10.3 million or $15.45 million this year, depending on your method of calculation.
In the interest of full disclosure, it should be recalled that last September, in the first game at Yankee Stadium after the Sept. 11 attacks, Sturtze pitched seven shutout innings while Clemens gave up four runs in six and two-thirds innings in a 4-0 Tampa Bay victory, which ended Clemens's winning streak at 16 games.
No one could expect Sturtze to repeat that performance yesterday; yet he said he viewed such a matchup as a positive.
"I knew I was going against Clemens, and I knew I couldn't give up anything," he said. "I try to elevate my game to be like him and to try to stay with him. In the first inning I didn't give my team a chance to even compete in the game."
Sturtze said he got some pitches up, and the Yankees used his mistakes against him in scoring a quick three runs. "I think that's what they do better than anyone else, capitalize on mistakes where other teams miss them," he said.
Sturtze and other members of the Devil Rays rejected the notion that it was unfair to ask them to play the Yankees, a low-paid, inexperienced team against a high-paid collection of veteran players.
"We know what we're facing," McRae said, "but we don't know the outcome. We come in to try to change the outcome. We didn't this time. We have in the past."
Brent Abernathy, a young second baseman, said the players were not awed by the Yankees at all. "As a major league player, you have to play up to your capabilities," he said. "If you do that, you're going to be in ballgames and have a chance to win ballgames. We didn't play up to our capabilities."
Why didn't the Devil Rays play well in the weekend series?
"What do you want me to say?" Abernathy replied, his voice rising. "You want me to say the Yankees are the best team out there? I just told you we didn't play up to our capabilities. You want me to say they're gods? They're not."
Pettitte, Orlando Hernandez and Clemens might have had something to do with the Devil Rays' performance.
"We couldn't generate any offense," McRae said. "We were completely shut down. Sometimes you run into a hot pitching staff, and they were hot. The swings tell you the most. We didn't get good swings this series."
Now in their fifth year, the Devil Rays have lost to the Yankees 41 times and have beaten them 17 times. They haven't been quite the fodder that the Washington Generals have been for the Harlem Globetrotters, but they do resemble the Washington Senators, whom the Yankees of another era beat up regularly.
The predictable outcome of those series didn't prompt talk of the inability of low-revenue teams to compete with high-revenue teams. But Selig doesn't believe that slice of major league history is relevant to today's circumstances.
It isn't exactly clear why Yankees-Devil Rays circa 2002 is different from Yankees-Senators 1944-56 (195-89, .687) or Yankees-St. Louis Browns/Baltimore Orioles 1946-55 (163-57, .741). But if Selig wants to plunge his hand deeper into Steinbrenner's pocket, the tapes of the weekend games are available.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Ayer, one of Madison Avenue's oldest names, is fading away as it is absorbed by Kaplan Thaler.

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass 

 BODY:
AN old name in advertising is disappearing after 133 years. N. W. Ayer is being merged into a sibling agency in New York, the Kaplan Thaler Group, by their parent, the Bcom3 Group.
 Ayer, most recently known as N. W. Ayer & Partners, was founded as N. W. Ayer & Son in 1869 in Philadelphia. Ayer helped sell America on the Bell telephone system, Camel cigarettes and the Model A Ford. And over the years, Ayer copywriters created famous slogans like "When it rains it pours" for Morton salt, "Reach out and touch someone" for AT&T, "A diamond is forever" for De Beers and "Be all that you can be" for the Army. 
 Ayer and the J. Walter Thompson unit of the WPP Group had long fought in a friendly way over which agency ought to be known as America's oldest. Thompson maintains it should, tracing its roots to 1864. The battle is over now, as Ayer joins the Madison Avenue Valhalla reserved for once-familiar names like Ally & Gargano, Griffin Bacal, Warwick Baker Fiore and Wells Rich Greene.
Effective today, Ayer's 50 employees will begin working for Kaplan Thaler, which was founded in 1997; that doubles the size of the staff at Kaplan Thaler. Ayer's accounts, for clients like Charming Shoppes, Continental Airlines, the KitchenAid division of Maytag and Villeroy & Boch, will be transferred to Kaplan Thaler, increasing the billings at Kaplan Thaler to $325 million from about $225 million.
"The situation is very clear," said Roger Haupt, chairman and chief executive at Bcom3 in Chicago. Kaplan Thaler "has been extremely successful," he said, "and we wanted to build on that success."
The absorption of Ayer by Kaplan Thaler is unrelated, Mr. Haupt said, to the deal Bcom3 agreed to last month to be acquired for $3 billion by the Publicis Groupe in Paris. The Ayer move had been discussed for about six months, he added.
Kaplan Thaler, named for its chief executive and chief creative officer, Linda Kaplan Thaler, is known for producing advertising that consumers talk about for various reasons. The campaigns the agency creates for Aflac insurance are cute and funny, featuring a duck that quacks the company's name. The campaigns the agency creates for the Clairol Herbal Essences line of personal-care products, now owned by Procter & Gamble, are sexually provocative, centered on young women acting out scenes of intense ecstasy.
Other Kaplan Thaler clients include Blimpie International, the Coldwell Banker division of the Cendant Corporation and Pilot Pen. Ms. Kaplan Thaler, 51, will continue in her posts.
Heading the combined agency will be a challenge, Ms. Kaplan Thaler said, but it will also be "exciting" because the merger "made good business sense."
"It's difficult for agencies that are very small to flourish sometimes," she added, "and the economy makes everything a little bit more challenging."
The two agencies are a good match, Ms. Kaplan Thaler said, because they have similar cultures, many job functions "dovetailed" and there were no client conflicts.
Kaplan Thaler had been planning to relocate to Worldwide Plaza in Midtown Manhattan, where Ayer is based, she added. That move will now be in May.
Mary Beth Casey, 46, who had been president and chief executive at Ayer, is to "pursue several opportunities" at Bcom3 or Publicis, said Tricia Kenney, a spokeswoman for Ayer and Kaplan Thaler. The acquisition is to close by the end of June.
N. W. Ayer & Son was founded in Philadelphia on April 1, 1869. The founder was not, in fact, N. W. Ayer, but his son, Francis Wayland Ayer. The agency remained based in Philadelphia for more than 100 years, until it left for New York in 1973. In the early 1990's, Ayer faced difficult times, losing several large accounts like J. C. Penney and experiencing turmoil in the executive suite. The move to Worldwide Plaza burdened the agency with high costs, as did contracts for retired top executives.
As recently as 1996, Ayer had four offices and 585 employees, working on accounts with billings of $800 million for clients like AT&T, Avon Products, General Motors and Gillette. That year, the Ayer parent, Adcom Investors, agreed to sell the agency to the MacManus Group, which also owned agencies like D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles.
MacManus and the Leo Group in Chicago, which owned agencies like Leo Burnett Worldwide, merged to form Bcom3 in early 2000.
It was the right decision to consign the Ayer name to history, Mr. Haupt said, because "you don't want to end up in a situation where you ask, 'Is this Ayer? Is this Kaplan?' "
"It's Kaplan," he added, referring to the merged agency. "I don't believe in ambiguity."
Why not call the merged agency by the more famous Ayer name?
"The Kaplan Thaler Group doesn't carry the weight of a lot of history with it," Ms. Kaplan Thaler said. "So it has, in a way, a lighter load to carry."
In a final nod to history, Ayer will donate its archives and campaign materials to the National Museum of American History of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 9, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising Column in Business Day yesterday about the disappearance of the N. W. Ayer agency name misidentified the parent company of KitchenAid, an Ayer client. It is Whirlpool, not Maytag.
